name: K-8th grades (Math)
blurb: (No description)

name: Eureka Math/EngageNY support (Math)
blurb: (No description)

name: Remediation support for Eureka Math/EngageNY  (Math)
blurb: Remediation support in the form of "topic foundations\", which target the most important foundational concepts and skills from previous grades, aligned with topics in Eureka Math/EngageNY

name: On-grade support for EngageNY (Math)
blurb: Exercises and videos to support the mastery of on-grade-level concepts and skills, aligned to the Eureka Math/EngageNY curriculum

name: High school math (Math)
blurb: (No description)

name: Revision of shapes, estimation, simple operations, large numbers (Review of shapes, operations and large numbers)
blurb: In this chapter we will learn about place values, how to compare them, how to identify them, and we will do some exercises to increase our understanding of the topic.

name: Angles and unit of measurement for angles (Shapes and Angles)
blurb: In this topic we will learn about Recognizing angles as acute, obtuse, right etc. We will also learn how to measure angles using geometrical instruments like protractors, and ways to draw them!

name: Areas and patterns (Area and perimeter - Part 1)
blurb: In this topic, we will learn to compare areas, compare perimeters, find areas by rearrangement of parts, find square footage, perimeter, and we will practice a few problems to increase our understanding of these concepts.

name: Fraction comparisons and equivalent fractions (Parts and wholes)
blurb: In this topic we will learn about equivalent fractions, addition and subtraction of mixed numbers, visual representation of equivalent fractions, proportions, proportional relationships, ordering fractions, comparing fractions, and we will increase our understanding of this concept by practicing problems based on unknown proportions, cut and copy fractions, rate, etc.

name: Line of symmetry (Symmetry)
blurb: The Line of Symmetry is the imaginary line where you could fold the image and have both halves match exactly.

name: Rotational symmetry (Symmetry)
blurb: A shape has rotational symmetry if it still looks the same after a rotation.

name: Factors and multiples (Factors and multiples)
blurb: Lets learn more about factors and multiples!

name: Patterns (Patterns)
blurb: A form or design occurring in the world that repeats itself or take a predictable direction is a pattern! In this topic we will learn more about them, the relationships they form with each other, ways to visualize those relationships, graphing those relationships, math patterns, and we will also practice some exercises!

name: Representing 3-D objects on paper in the form of nets (Visualizing 3-D objects)
blurb: In this topic we will learn about polyhedra, calculating surface area using net, nets of 3D figures, and we will practice some exercises related to them!

name: Decimals (Decimals)
blurb: In this topic we will learn about decimal places, comparing decimals, adding and subtracting decimals using word based and numerical exercises!

name: Area and perimeter (Area and perimeter - Part 2)
blurb: In this topic we will learn about perimeter and area basics, finding dimensions of given perimeter, finding dimensions when area and perimeter are given, and comparing areas.

name: Strategies for multiplication and division (Ways to multiply and divide)
blurb: In this topic we will learn to multiply multiple digit numbers, the partial quotient method of division, and we will look at practical use of these concepts in unit conversion.

name: Volume (Volume and weight)
blurb: Volume is the amount of space that a substance or object occupies, or that is enclosed within a container. In this topic we will learn to convert between metric units of volume!

name: Weight (Volume and weight)
blurb: The weight of an object determines how heavy it is! In this topic we will learn about metric units of weight, and we will learn to convert between them.

name: Comparing 3-digit numbers (Knowing our numbers)
blurb: Learn how to compare three-digit numbers by thinking about place value (hundreds, tens, and ones).

name: Comparing multi-digit numbers (Knowing our numbers)
blurb: Learn how to compare multi-digit numbers by thinking about place value (thousands, hundreds, tens, and ones).

name: Lakhs, crores, millions and billions (Knowing our numbers)
blurb: Let's learn to play with large numbers involving lakhs, crores, millions, and billions.

name: Word problems involving lakhs and crores (Knowing our numbers)
blurb: (No description)

name: System of measurement (Knowing our numbers)
blurb: (No description)

name: Rounding (Knowing our numbers)
blurb: Rounding is useful when you are trying to roughly estimate numbers.

name: Rounding whole numbers (Knowing our numbers)
blurb: If you're looking to create an army of robot dogs, will it really make a difference if you have 10,300 dogs, 9,997 dogs or 10,005 dogs? Probably not. All you really care about is how many dogs you have to, say, the nearest thousand (10,000 dogs). In this tutorial, you'll learn about conventions for rounding whole numbers. Very useful when you might not need to (or cannot) be completely precise.  Common Core Standard: 4.NBT.A.3

name: Roman numerals (Knowing our numbers)
blurb: (No description)

name: Number line of whole numbers (Whole numbers)
blurb: (No description)

name: Arithmetic properties of whole numbers  (Whole numbers)
blurb: (No description)

name: Distributive property (Whole numbers)
blurb: (No description)

name: Factors and multiples (Playing with numbers)
blurb: In this tutorial, we'll begin to think about the numbers that "make up" the number. This will be useful throughout our study of math. Whether we are adding fractions, exploring mystical number patterns, or breaking computer codes, factoring numbers are key! Let's go, kids!  Common Core Standard: 4.OA.B.4

name: Prime and composite numbers (Playing with numbers)
blurb: Prime numbers have been studied by mathematicians and mystics for ages (seriously). They are both basic and mysterious. The more you explore them, the more you will realize that the universe is a fascinating place. This tutorial will introduce you to the magical world of prime numbers as well as their composite number brethren.  Common Core Standard: 4.OA.B.4

name: Divisibility tests (Playing with numbers)
blurb: (No description)

name: Prime factorisation (Playing with numbers)
blurb: (No description)

name: Common factors and multiples (Playing with numbers)
blurb: (No description)

name: Lowest common multiple (Playing with numbers)
blurb: (No description)

name: Highest common factor (Playing with numbers)
blurb: (No description)

name: Lines, line segments and rays (Basic geometrical ideas)
blurb: Let's draw points, lines, line segments, and rays.  We'll also think about perpendicular and parallel lines and identify these in two-dimensional figures.  Common Core Standard: 4.G.A.1

name: Angle introduction (Basic geometrical ideas)
blurb: What is an angle and how do we label, measure and construct them? Great question. Luckily we have all your answers! To begin our journey towards understanding angles, we'll learn terms like vertex, acute, obtuse, circle arc, circumference, and protractor. These basic angle concepts will get you on the road to angle domination!

name: Introduction to polygons  (Basic geometrical ideas)
blurb: Learn how different shapes have different numbers of corners, different side lengths, and so on. Use these properties to help you recognize shapes.

name: Curves and polygons (Basic geometrical ideas)
blurb: Let's identify parts of a circle

name: Copy of Angle types (Understanding elementary shapes)
blurb: Now that we know what angles are, let's dig a bit deeper and classify them and understand their properties better. Acute, obtuse, right, adjacent--all are angles that we will be become familiar with.

name: Measuring angles (Understanding elementary shapes)
blurb: Learn how to measure angles using a protractor.

name: Constructing angles (Understanding elementary shapes)
blurb: Learn how to draw angles using a protractor.

name: Parallel and perpendicular (Understanding elementary shapes)
blurb: Learn the definitions of "parallel" and "perpendicular".

name: Classifying triangles (Understanding elementary shapes)
blurb: Triangles can be classified in different ways. In this tutorial, we'll learn about scalene, isosceles, equilateral, acute, right, and obtuse triangles.

name: Copy of Shapes (Understanding elementary shapes)
blurb: Classify quadrilaterals, including rectangles, rhombuses, and squares.  See what attributes they have in common and which ones make them unique.

name: Geometric solids (Understanding elementary shapes)
blurb: Identify 3-dimensional figures and their parts (faces, edges, vertices).

name: Intro to negative numbers (Integers)
blurb: What are negative numbers? When do we use them? Where do we find them on the number line? Let's learn what happens in the world below zero!

name: Number opposites (Integers)
blurb: Opposite numbers are the same distance from 0 on opposite sides of the number line. A number opposite is sometimes called an additive inverse.

name: Absolute value (Integers)
blurb: You'll find absolute value absolutely straightforward--it is just the "distance from zero". If you have a positive number, it is its own absolute value. If you have a negative number, just make it positive to get the absolute value. As you see as you develop mathematically, this idea will eventually extended to more contexts and dimensions, so super important that you understand this core concept now.

name: Order negative numbers (Integers)
blurb: We all know that 6 is bigger than 4, but is -6 bigger than -4? This tutorial is designed to help you compare negative numbers.

name: Introduction to adding integers (Integers)
blurb: Learn how to add negative numbers. By the end of this tutorial, you'll be solving problems like 4 + (-7) with ease!

name: Introduction to subtracting integers (Integers)
blurb: Learn why subtracting a negative number is the same as adding its opposite!

name: Adding & subtracting integers (Integers)
blurb: Add and subtract negative numbers using a number line. It's the 7th grade mathematics shuffle: "Slide to the left for a negative value, and slide to the right for a positive value." Be careful, though. Which way do you move if you are subtracting a negative number? The answer awaits!

name: Adding & subtracting with negatives on the number line (Integers)
blurb: Learn how to use number lines to solve negative number addition and subtraction problems.

name: Fractions intro (Fractions)
blurb: Learn what a fraction is and identify unit fractions.

name: Fractions on the number line (Fractions)
blurb: Learn to identify fractions on a number line.

name: Fractions and whole numbers (Fractions)
blurb: Learn how to represent fractions as whole numbers and whole numbers as fractions.

name: Visualizing equivalent fractions (Fractions)
blurb: Learn how to find equivalent fractions by multiplying the numerator and denominator by the same number.

name: Equivalent fractions on the number line (Fractions)
blurb: Learn how to identify fractions on a number line.

name: Common denominators (Fractions)
blurb: Using our knowledge of equivalent fractions, let's rewrite fractions to have the same denominator.

name: Comparing fractions (Fractions)
blurb: In this tutorial, we'll practice understanding what quantities fractions actually represent and comparing those to each other.

name: Mixed numbers (Fractions)
blurb: Learn how to write improper fractions as mixed numbers (and mixed numbers as improper fractions).

name: Decomposing fractions (Fractions)
blurb: (No description)

name: Adding and subtracting fractions with like denominators (Fractions)
blurb: Learn how to add and subtract fractions. This is an introductory tutorial, so the fractions you add and subtract have the same denominators.

name: Visually adding and subtracting fractions with unlike denominators (Fractions)
blurb: An introduction to adding and subtracting fractions with unlike denominators that uses visual fraction models

name: Adding and subtracting fractions with unlike denominators (Fractions)
blurb: Learn how to add and subtract fractions that have different denominators.

name: Adding and subtracting mixed numbers (Fractions)
blurb: Learn how to add and subtract mixed numbers. This is an introductory tutorial, so the fractions you add and subtract have the same denominators.

name: Adding and subtracting mixed number with unlike denominators (Fractions)
blurb: Learn how to add and subtract mixed numbers whose fractional parts have different denominators.

name: Adding and subtracting fractions with unlike denominators word problems (Fractions)
blurb: Practice solving word problems by adding and subtracting fractions that have different denominators.

name: Introduction to decimals (Decimals)
blurb: What are decimal numbers? How are they like fractions?

name: Decimal place value introduction (Decimals)
blurb: Learn the basics of decimal place value.

name: Expanded form for decimals (Decimals)
blurb: Learn how to write a decimal like 3.14 in expanded form (3 + 0.1 + 0.04).

name: Decimals in written form (Decimals)
blurb: Learn how to write decimals like 3.14 in words as "three and fourteen hundredths".

name: Comparing decimal place values (Decimals)
blurb: For a number like 34.135, learn how to compare the 3 in the tens place to the 3 in the hundredths place.

name: Comparing decimals (Decimals)
blurb: Learn to tell which of two decimal numbers is bigger by thinking about place value.

name: Decimals on the number line (Decimals)
blurb: See how decimals can be placed on the number line, just like fractions and whole numbers can.

name: Converting decimals to fractions (Decimals)
blurb: Learn how to rewrite decimals as fractions.

name: Common fractions and decimals (Decimals)
blurb: Learn about common fractions and their decimal forms like 1 /2 = 0.5, 3/4 = 0.75, and 2/5 = 0.4.

name: Adding decimals (Decimals)
blurb: You get the general idea of decimals and what the digits in different places represent (place value). Now you're ready to do something with the decimals. Adding and subtracting is a good place to start. This will allow you to add your family's expenses to figure out if your little brother is laundering money (perhaps literally). Have fun!  Common Core Standard: 5.NBT.B.7

name: Copy of Adding decimals: standard algorithm  (Decimals)
blurb: Honestly, once you remember one very important rule, the rest of adding and subtracting decimals is a snap. That rule is to be sure and align your decimals first. In this tutorial, you'll get a chance to practice this with us and become fluent adding decimals. We'll tackle subtracting decimals in the next tutorial.

name: Subtracting decimals (Decimals)
blurb: Anything you can do with whole numbers, you can do with decimals.  Subtraction is no exception.  In this tutorial, you'll get some good practice subtracting decimals up the hundredths place.

name: Subtracting decimals: standard algorithm  (Decimals)
blurb: Just like with adding decimals, the key to subtracting decimals is aligning the decimal points. Let's practice!

name: Adding and subtracting decimals word problems (Decimals)
blurb: In this tutorial, we practice solving word problems by adding and subtracting decimal numbers.

name: Introduction to data handling (Data Handling)
blurb: Data handling involves collecting, organising and interpreting data. Let's learn more about these.

name: Pictographs (Picture graphs) (Data Handling)
blurb: Read and interpret picture graphs.  Also, make some graphs of your own!

name: Bar graphs (Data Handling)
blurb: Learn how to read and make bar graphs.

name: Count unit squares to find area (Mensuration)
blurb: Find area of shapes by counting unit squares.  Some shapes will require combining partial square units to find area.  Create rectangles with a given area by covering unit squares.

name: Multiply to find area (Mensuration)
blurb: Find area of rectangles by multiplying side lengths.  Find a missing side length of a rectangle when given the other side length and area.  Compare areas of rectangles presented in images or contexts.

name: Area and the distributive property (Mensuration)
blurb: Use the distributive property to find area of rectangles.

name: Decompose figures to find area (Mensuration)
blurb: Decompose figures into two to three rectangles to find area of entire figure.

name: Perimeter (Mensuration)
blurb: Have you ever wondered how much fencing you need to surround a plot of land? No? Well, you should still go through this tutorial just in case. You'll learn what perimeter is and how to calculate it.

name: Comparing area and perimeter (Mensuration)
blurb: Compare the areas and perimeters of rectangles when given a context or picture.

name: Area word problems (Mensuration)
blurb: Let's solve some real-world problems involving areas of rectangles.

name: Perimeter word problems (Mensuration)
blurb: Solve real world problems problems involving perimeter.

name: Overview and history of algebra (Algebra)
blurb: (No description)

name: Intro to variables (Algebra)
blurb: Wait, why are we using letters in math? How can an 'x' represent a number? What number is it? This tutorial is great if you're just beginning to delve into the world of variables and expressions.

name: Substitution & evaluating expressions (Algebra)
blurb: Learn how to substitute (or "plug in") values for variables and evaluate algebraic expressions.

name: Writing algebraic expressions introduction (Algebra)
blurb: Learn the basics of writing expressions with variables.

name: Writing basic algebraic expressions word problems (Algebra)
blurb: Learn how to write algebraic expressions (expressions with variables) to model real-world situations.

name: Uses of variables in common rules (Algebra)
blurb: (No description)

name: Algebraic equations basics (Algebra)
blurb: Explore what it means for equations with variables (algebraic equations) to be solved.

name: Introduction to ratios (Ratio and proportion review)
blurb: Ratios show up everywhere in life—sports, finance, medicine, cooking, you name it! In this tutorial, we learn what ratios are and how to use them.

name: Copy of Ratio word problems (Ratio and proportion review)
blurb: Practice solving ratio word problems like, "If 60 cherries go in 3 pies, how many cherries go in 9 pies?"

name: Copy of Introduction to rates (Ratio and proportion review)
blurb: Learn about a special type of ratio called a rate. A rate is the ratio of two measurements that have different units such as 10 kilometers per hour or 12 hot dogs per minute!

name: Identifying proportional relationships (Ratio and proportion review)
blurb: Learn how to tell whether two quantities are proportional by thinking about equivalent ratios and drawing graphs.

name: Writing & solving proportions (Ratio and proportion review)
blurb: Learn how to write proportions and how to solve proportions.

name: Line of symmetry (Symmetry)
blurb: A line of symmetry for a two-dimensional figure is a line across the figure such that the figure can be folded along the line into matching parts. In this tutorial, we'll identify line-symmetric figures and draw lines of symmetry.  Common Core Standard: 4.G.A.3

name: Copy of Constructing angles (Practical geometry)
blurb: A shape, formed by two lines or rays diverging from a common point (the vertex). In this topic we will learn how to construct basic angles using compass and straightedge using the bisector technique.

name: Constructing perpendiculars (Practical geometry)
blurb: Two lines are said to be perpendicular if they intersect such that the angles formed between them are right angles.

name: Integer addition and subtraction review (Integers)
blurb: Let's practice adding and subtracting negative numbers.

name: Integer arithmetic properties (Integers)
blurb: (No description)

name: Multiply & divide negative numbers (Integers)
blurb: You already know how to multiply and divide whole numbers, decimals, and fractions. See what happens when we throw negative numbers into the mix. It's really not so different!

name: Integer word problems (Integers)
blurb: Let's add, subtract, multiply, and divide negative numbers to solve a few problems we may see in the "real-world".

name: Adding and subtracting fractions review (optional) (Fractions and decimals)
blurb: Let's practice adding and subtracting fractions as a warm-up before we learn how to multiply and divide fractions.

name: Multiplying unit fractions and whole numbers (Fractions and decimals)
blurb: Learn how to multiply unit fractions and whole numbers.

name: Multiplying whole numbers and fractions (Fractions and decimals)
blurb: Learn the art of multiplying whole numbers by fractions. See how 3 times 2/3 is the same as 6 times 1/3, which is the same as 6/3.

name: Multiplication as scaling (Fractions and decimals)
blurb: Learn to see multiplication as a way to grow (scale up) and shrink (scale down) other numbers.

name: Multiplying fractions (Fractions and decimals)
blurb: Learn how to multiply a fraction by a fraction.

name: Multiplying mixed numbers (Fractions and decimals)
blurb: Learn how to multiply mixed numbers.

name: Multiplying fractions word problems (Fractions and decimals)
blurb: Get some practice solving word problems by multiplying fractions.

name: Fractions as division (Fractions and decimals)
blurb: **Spoiler Alert!** The fraction bar and the division symbol are really saying the same thing.

name: Dividing unit fractions by whole numbers (Fractions and decimals)
blurb: Learn how to divide unit fractions by whole numbers. Example: 1/5 ÷ 3 = 1/15.

name: Dividing whole numbers by unit fractions (Fractions and decimals)
blurb: Learn how to divide whole numbers by unit fractions. Example: 4 ÷ 1/3 = 12.

name: Dividing fractions by fractions (Fractions and decimals)
blurb: Learn how to divide fractions by other fractions.

name: Dividing fractions word problems (Fractions and decimals)
blurb: Practice solving word problems with fraction division.

name: Adding and subtraction decimals review (optional) (Fractions and decimals)
blurb: Let's practice adding and subtracting decimals as a warm-up before we learn how to multiply and divide decimals.

name: Multiplying decimals (Fractions and decimals)
blurb: The real world is seldom about whole numbers. If you precisely measure anything, you're likely to get a decimal. If you don't know how to multiply these decimals, then you won't be able to do all the powerful things that multiplication can do in the real world (figure out your commission as a robot possum salesperson, determining how much shag carpet you need for your secret lair, etc.).

name: Multiplying decimals: standard algorithm  (Fractions and decimals)
blurb: You've already multiplied decimals in the 5th grade. We'll show you some ways to handle slightly more complicated problems. Now you'll become super good at it with a bit more practice!  Common Core Standard: 6.NS.B.3

name: Dividing decimals (Fractions and decimals)
blurb: In this tutorial, we'll extend our division skills to include decimals! We get into some pretty fun stuff here including dividing decimals by whole numbers, and dividing whole numbers by decimals. Finally...dividing decimals by decimals.  Common Core Standard 5.NBT.B.7

name: Copy of Dividing decimals: standard algorithm  (Fractions and decimals)
blurb: Learn long division with decimals. Solve problems like 30.24 divided by 0.42.

name: Mean and median: The basics (Data Handling)
blurb: Mean and median are the most commonly used tools to measure the center of a distribution. They give us an idea of the typical value in a set of numerical data.

name: Interpreting data from bar graphs (Data Handling)
blurb: Categorical data comes from classifying information into categories. To understand categorical data, we often display it in bar graphs and pie graphs.

name: Copy of Basic theoretical probability (Data Handling)
blurb: Basic theoretical probability is mapping out how many outcomes are possible and seeing how many of those outcomes relate to the probability we're trying to find.

name: Algebraic equations basics (Simple equations)
blurb: Explore what it means for equations with variables (algebraic equations) to be solved.

name: Copy of Why we do the same thing to both sides of an equation (Simple equations)
blurb: A high-level, conceptual walk-through of what an equation represents and why we do the same thing to both sides of it

name: Copy of One-step addition & subtraction equations (Simple equations)
blurb: Solve equations by adding and subtracting numbers from both sides.

name: Copy of One-step multiplication and division equations (Simple equations)
blurb: Solve equations by multiplying and dividing numbers from both sides.

name: Copy of One-step equation word problems (Simple equations)
blurb: Let's use our algebra tools to solve a problem of earth-shattering importance: which Super Yoga plan is the best value! In this word problem, you'll put to practice your knowledge of variables, substitution, and one-step equations.

name: Two-steps equations intro (Simple equations)
blurb: Learn how to solve equations like 2x+7=13 and 3(x+4)=3, which can be solved in two steps.

name: Two-step equation word problems (Simple equations)
blurb: Learn how to set up and solve equations to find answers to real-world questions.

name: Vertical, complementary, and supplementary angles (Lines and angles)
blurb: Learn three types of angle pairs: vertical angles, complementary angles, and supplementary angles.

name: Angles between intersecting lines (Lines and angles)
blurb: This tutorial introduces us to angles.  It includes how we measure them, how angles relate to each other and properties of angles created from various types of intersecting lines.  Mr. Angle is actually far more fun than you might initially presume him to be.

name: Terms and labels in triangles (The triangle and its properties)
blurb: (No description)

name: Exterior angle property of a triangle (The triangle and its properties)
blurb: Let's learn what the exterior angle of a triangle is and how the exterior angle property connects it to the angles of a triangle.

name: Triangle angles (The triangle and its properties)
blurb:
Do the angles in a triangle always add up to the same thing?  Would I ask it if they didn't?  What do we know about the angles of a triangle if two of the sides are congruent (an isosceles triangle) or all three are congruent (an equilateral)?  This tutorial is the place to find out.

Common Core Standard: 8.G.A.5

name: Equilateral and isosceles triangles (The triangle and its properties)
blurb: (No description)

name: Triangle inequality theorem (The triangle and its properties)
blurb:
The triangle inequality theorem is, on some level, kind of simple.  But, as you'll see as you go into high level mathematics, it is often used in fancy proofs.

This tutorial introduces you to what it is and gives you some practice understanding the constraints on the dimensions of a triangle.

name: Copy of Pythagorean theorem (The triangle and its properties)
blurb:
Named after the Greek philosopher who lived nearly 2600 years ago, the Pythagorean theorem is as good as math theorems get (Pythagoras also started a religious movement).  It's simple.  It's beautiful.  It's powerful.

Common Core Standards: 8.G.B.7, 8.G.B.8

name: Triangle congruence (Congruence of triangles)
blurb: Learn how the definition of congruence using rigid transformations can be simplified to simple criteria when studying congruent triangles.

name: Ratio and proportion (Comparing quantities)
blurb: Before we jump into comparing quantities, let's practice some problems on ratio and proportion.

name: Intro to percents (Comparing quantities)
blurb: Percent literally means "per cent" or "per hundred". Learn how to rewrite fractions as percents and vice versa.

name: Percent-decimal conversions (Comparing quantities)
blurb: Decimals and percents are two ways of expressing the same number. For example, 0.5 and 50% mean the exact same thing. Learn how to convert decimals to percents and vice versa.

name: Percent problems (Comparing quantities)
blurb: Learn how to solve percent problems like these: What is 80% of 25? Three is what percent of four?

name: Copy of Percent word problems (Comparing quantities)
blurb: Learn how to solve a variety of word problems involving percentages.

name: Profit and loss (Comparing quantities)
blurb: Let's play with profit and loss problems to understand percentages even better.

name: Simple interest (Comparing quantities)
blurb: Let's play with a few simple interest problems and see how percentages are useful here too.

name: Intro to rational numbers (Rational numbers)
blurb: (No description)

name: Comparing rational numbers (Rational numbers)
blurb: (No description)

name: Adding & subtracting rational numbers (Rational numbers)
blurb: We're going to mix it up a little in this set of examples. Remember that a rational number is a real number that can be written as a simple fraction, or by extension a decimal or percentage. We have to be able to add and subtract numbers when they are in different formats, whether fraction, decimal or percentage. This gets to be fun as we learn to move between these expressions of rational numbers, and start to understand they're all pointing to same thing!  Common Core Standards: 7.NS.A.1d

name: Multiplication and division of rational numbers (Rational numbers)
blurb: (No description)

name: Copy of Rational number word problems (Rational numbers)
blurb: You already have many tools in your mathematical toolkit: addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division of decimals and fractions, as well as your understanding of units of measure. Now we'll put them all to work in solving some multi-step word problems.  Common Core Standards: 7.EE.B.3

name: Construction of triangles when the lengths of its three sides are known (SSS Criterion) (Practical geometry)
blurb: We can easily construct triangles when the lengths of all of its sides are known to us. In this chapter, we will get to understand how.

name: Area and perimeter (Perimeter and area)
blurb: Rectangles are common shapes that you will often find the need to compare. Who has a bigger poster size? Whose yard has more grass to mow? We'll learn about length, width, area, and perimeter--about all you need to know to begin comparing!

name: Area of parallelograms (Perimeter and area)
blurb: Understand the formula for the area of a parallelogram.

name: Area of triangles (Perimeter and area)
blurb: Understand the formula for the area of a triangle.

name: Area of shapes on grids (Perimeter and area)
blurb: Area problems involving triangles and quadrilaterals on grids

name: Area and circumference of circles (Perimeter and area)
blurb: A circle is at the foundation of geometry, and at the foundation of a circle is a special number called Pi. This number allows us to relate the radius, diameter, and circumference of a circle.

name: Area of composite figures (Perimeter and area)
blurb: Finding the area of more complex shapes like trapezoids and composite figures (shapes built from other shapes)

name: Area unit conversions (Perimeter and area)
blurb: Let's learn how to convert between square centimetres, square metres, square millimetres, and square kilometres.

name: The constituents of an expression (Algebraic Expressions)
blurb: Learn new words, such as "term" and "coefficient", which help us communicate about the different parts expressions.

name: Combining like terms- part 1/1 (Algebraic Expressions)
blurb: Combine the powers of Chuck Norris and polar bears to understand how to combine like terms.

name: Combining like terms- part 2/1 (Algebraic Expressions)
blurb: Learn how to combine like terms (with negative numbers and variables), including more complex problems involving the distributive property.

name: Adding & subtracting algebraic expressions (Algebraic Expressions)
blurb: Learn how to add and subtract polynomial expressions with one variable.

name: Adding and subtracting algebraic expressions : two variables (Algebraic Expressions)
blurb: Learn how to add and subtract polynomial that involve two variables. For example, x^3 + xy + 3y - (x^3 + 6xy + 2y^2).

name: Finding the value of an expression (Algebraic Expressions)
blurb: The value of an algebraic expression depends on the values of the variables forming the expression. There are a number of situations in which we need to find the value of an expression, such as when we wish to check whether a particular value of a variable satisfies a given equation or not. Let's understand in detail what we mean by this!

name: Number patterns (Algebraic Expressions)
blurb: Let's explore how numbers can grow in different ways and use what we learn to figure out where they can go.  We think you'll find this tutorial on number patterns more fun that you do :)

name: Exponents (Exponents and powers)
blurb:
Addition was nice.  Multiplication was cooler.  In the mood for a new operation that grows numbers even faster?  Ever felt like expressing repeated multiplication with less writing?  Ever wanted to describe how most things in the universe grow and shrink?  Well, exponents are your answer!

This tutorial covers everything from basic exponents to negative and fractional ones.  It assumes you remember your multiplication, negative numbers and fractions.

name: Exponent properties- part 1/1 (Exponents and powers)
blurb: (No description)

name: Exponent properties (Exponents and powers)
blurb:
Tired of hairy exponent expressions?  Feel compelled to clean them up?  Well, this tutorial might just give you the tools you need.

If you know a bit about exponents, you'll learn a ton more in this tutorial as you learn about the rules for simplifying exponents.

name: Scientific notation (Exponents and powers)
blurb:
Scientists and engineers often have to deal with super huge (like 6,000,000,000,000,000,000,000) and super small numbers (like 0.0000000000532) .  How can they do this without tiring their hands out?  How can they look at a number and understand how large or small it is without counting the digits?  The answer is to use scientific notation.

If you come to this tutorial with a basic understanding of positive and negative exponents, it should leave you with a new appreciation for representing really huge and really small numbers!

name: Orders of magnitude (Exponents and powers)
blurb: When people want to think about the general size of things but not worry about the exact number, they tend to think in terms of "orders of magnitude".  This allows us to analyze and make comparisons between numbers very quickly, which allows us to make decisions about them quickly as well.

name: Lines of symmetry for regular polygons (Symmetry)
blurb: The concept of line symmetry is closely related to mirror reflection. A shape has line symmetry when one half of it is the mirror image of the other half. A mirror line, thus, helps to visualise a line of symmetry.

name: Copy of Rotational Symmetry (Symmetry)
blurb: If any object rotates and there is no change in the shape and size, then it is said to have rotational symmetry. In this section we will learn more about rotational symmetry.

name: Nets for building 3D shapes (Visualising solid shapes)
blurb: A net is a sort of skeleton-outline in 2-D, which, when folded, results in a 3-D shape.

name: Viewing different sections of a solid (Visualising solid shapes)
blurb: When we slice (cut through) a 3D shape, we make a 2D shape called a cross section. In this tutorial, we think about the different cross sections we can make by slicing 3D shapes.

name: Properties of rational numbers (Rational numbers)
blurb: Let's discuss some properties of rational numbers. These properties are very similar to the properties we learnt earlier for integers even though there are some minor differences. The examples listed in this lesson all use only integers but everything remains the same for rational numbers too.

name: Distributive property (Rational numbers)
blurb: Let's learn about the distributive property of rational numbers. This property is very similar to the distributive property of integers even though there are some minor differences. The examples listed in this lesson all use only integers but everything remains the same for rational numbers too.

name: Copy of Fractions (Rational numbers)
blurb: Let's see how the properties of rational numbers apply to fractions. We'll try to add, subtract, multiply and divide some fractions.

name: Rational numbers between two rational numbers (Rational numbers)
blurb: How many rational numbers do you think there are between 2 and 3? Much more than we expect. Let's learn how to find some of them.

name: Two-steps equations intro (Linear equations in one variable)
blurb: Learn how to solve equations like 2x+7=13 and 3(x+4)=3, which can be solved in two steps.

name: Old school equations with Sal (Linear equations in one variable)
blurb: Some of Sal's oldest (and roughest) videos on algebra.  Great tutorial if you want to see what Khan Academy was like around 2006.  You might also like it if you feel like Sal has lost his magic now that he doesn't use the cheapest possible equipment to make the videos.

name: Linear equations with variables on both sides (Linear equations in one variable)
blurb: (No description)

name: Linear equations with parentheses (Linear equations in one variable)
blurb: Learn how to solve linear equations with parentheses using the distributive property. For example, solve -9 - (9x - 6) = 3(4x + 6).

name: Analyzing the number of solutions to linear equations (Linear equations in one variable)
blurb: Linear equations can either have a single solution, infinite solutions, or no solutions. Learn how to determine the number of solutions to a given equation, and how to create equations with a desired number of solutions.

name: Linear equations word problems (Linear equations in one variable)
blurb: Solve word problems by creating linear equations and solving them.

name: Two-step equation word problems (Linear equations in one variable)
blurb: Learn how to set up and solve equations to find answers to real-world questions.

name: Angles with polygons (Understanding Quadrilaterals)
blurb: Explore properties of angles in and arou polygons.

name: Quadrilateral types (Understanding Quadrilaterals)
blurb: (No description)

name: Quadrilateral proofs and angles (Understanding Quadrilaterals)
blurb: (No description)

name: Categorical data displays (Data Handling)
blurb: (No description)

name: Histograms (Data Handling)
blurb: Histograms display how many numerical data points there are in each "bucket" of values.

name: Pie Charts (Data Handling)
blurb: (No description)

name: Basic theoretical probability (Data Handling)
blurb: (No description)

name: Probability using sample spaces (Data Handling)
blurb: A sample space shows every possible equally likely outcome in some chance process like flipping a coin or rolling a pair of dice. Sample spaces can help us find the probability of certain events like rolling doubles or getting heads twice in three flips.

name: Square roots (Square and square roots)
blurb:
A strong contender for coolest symbol in mathematics is the radical.  What is it?  How does it relate to exponents?  How is the square root different than the cube root?  How can I simplify, multiply and add these things?  

This tutorial assumes you know the basics of exponents and exponent properties and takes you through the radical world for radicals (and gives you some good practice along the way)!

name: Square root using division method (Square and square roots)
blurb: Let's learn and practice finding the square root using division (digit by digit method). Let's also understand why this method works.

name: Approximating square roots (Square and square roots)
blurb: Let's learn how to approximate square roots.

name: Simplifying square roots (Square and square roots)
blurb: (No description)

name: Cube roots  (Cubes and cube roots)
blurb: If you're familiar with the idea of a square root, we're about to take things one step (dimension?) further with the cube root.  This generally refers to finding a number that, when cubed, is equal to the number that you're trying to find the cube root of!

name: Problems involving percentages (Comparing quantities)
blurb: Let's solve a few problems involving percentages.

name: Marked price and discount (Comparing quantities)
blurb: (No description)

name: Compound Interest (Comparing quantities)
blurb: Let's learn to solve compound interest problems.

name: Adding & subtracting polynomials (Part1/2) (Algebraic expressions and Identities)
blurb: Learn how to add and subtract polynomial expressions with one variable.

name: Adding and subtracting polynomials (Part2/2) (Algebraic expressions and Identities)
blurb: Learn how to add and subtract two polynomials to obtain another polynomial. For instance, express (3x^3+2x-1)+(2x^4-x^3+7x) as a polynomial in standard form.

name: Multiplying monomials (Algebraic expressions and Identities)
blurb: As an intro to more elaborate polynomial multiplication, learn how to multiply monomials (which are polynomials with a single term). For example, multiply 2x³ and 5x⁷.

name: Multiplying monomials by polynomials (Algebraic expressions and Identities)
blurb: Learn how to multiply a polynomial expression by a monomial expression. Monomials are just polynomials with a single term!

name: Multiplying binomials (Algebraic expressions and Identities)
blurb: Learn how to multiply two binomials together. For example, (3x - 7) * (10x + 2).

name: Special products of binomials (Algebraic expressions and Identities)
blurb: Learn about the special types of products of binomials: perfect squares and the difference of two squares. These will be very helpful once you tackle more advanced expressions in Algebra.

name: Multiplying binomials by polynomials (Algebraic expressions and Identities)
blurb: Learn how to multiply a polynomial expression by a binomial expression.

name: Polynomials word problems (Algebraic expressions and Identities)
blurb: See a few examples of how we can represent real-world situations with polynomials.

name: Geometric solids (3D shapes) (Visualising solid shapes)
blurb: Identify 3-dimensional figures and their parts (faces, edges, vertices).

name: 2D vs. 3D objects (Visualising solid shapes)
blurb: Visualize the relation between two-dimensional and three-dimensional objects.

name: Scale drawing (Visualising solid shapes)
blurb: (No description)

name: Copy of Area of trapezoids and composite figures (Mensuration)
blurb: Finding the area of more complex shapes like trapezoids and composite figures (shapes built from other shapes)

name: Surface area (Mensuration)
blurb: (No description)

name: Volume of rectangular prisms (Mensuration)
blurb: Welcome to the 3rd dimension! [cue spooky music] This tutorial explains how to find volume.

name: Volume and surface area of cylinder (Mensuration)
blurb: (No description)

name: Negative exponents (Exponents and powers)
blurb:
It's normally a bad idea to hang around with negative people or do negative things, but we think it's OK to associate with negative exponents.  And fractional exponents are even more fun.

This idea will open up entirely new vistas to your mathematical life.

name: Scientific notation (Exponents and powers)
blurb: (No description)

name: Orders of magnitude (Exponents and powers)
blurb: (No description)

name: Arithmetic with numbers in scientific notation (Exponents and powers)
blurb: Solve multiplication, division, addition, and subtraction problems involving numbers written in scientific notation.

name: Scientific notation word problems  (Exponents and powers)
blurb: Solve word problems involving scientific notation.

name: Direct and inverse proportion (Direct and inverse proportion)
blurb: Learn about direct and inverse variation, which are two types of relationships between two quantities. Direct variation is simply a proportional relationship, but inverse variation is more complicated and interesting. Gain some experience with it before we dive deeper into the world of rational functions.

name: Introduction to factorization (Factorization)
blurb: Learn what factorization is all about, and warm-up by factoring some monomials.

name: Factoring monomials (Factorization)
blurb: Learn how to write a monomial as a factor of two other monomials. For example, write 12x^3 as (4x)(3x^2).

name: Copy of Factoring polynomials by taking common factors (Factorization)
blurb: Learn how to take a common monomial factor out of a polynomial expression. For example, write 2x^3+6x^2+8x as (2x)(x^2+3x+4).

name: Evaluating expressions with unknown variables (Factorization)
blurb: Learn how to evaluate expressions with variables whose values are unknown, by using another information about those variables. For example, given that a+b=3, evaluate 4a+4b.

name: Factoring quadratics 1 (Factorization)
blurb: Learn how to factor quadratic expressions with a leading coefficient of 1. For example, factor x²+3x+2 as (x+1)(x+2).

name: Factoring quadratics by grouping (Factorization)
blurb: Learn how to factor quadratic expressions with a leading coefficient other than 1. For example, factor 2x²+7x+3 as (2x+1)(x+3).

name: Factoring polynomials with quadratic forms (Factorization)
blurb: Learn how to factor quadratic polynomials of the form ax^2+bx+c as the product of two linear binomials. For example, write x^2+3x-10 as (x+5)(x-2). Learn how to identify these forms in more elaborate polynomials that aren't necessarily quadratic. For example, write x^4-4x^2-12 as (x^2+2)(x^2-6).

name: Factoring quadratics: Difference of squares (Factorization)
blurb: Learn how to factor quadratics that have the "difference of squares" form. For example, write x²-16 as (x+4)(x-4). Learn how to identify this form in more elaborate expressions. For example, write 4x²-49 as (2x+7)(2x-7).

name: Factoring quadratics: Perfect squares (Factorization)
blurb: Learn how to factor quadratics that have the "perfect square" form. For example, write x²+6x+9 as (x+3)². Learn how to identify these forms in more elaborate expressions. For example, write 4x²+28x+49 as (2x+7)².

name: Strategy in factoring quadratics (Factorization)
blurb: There are a lot of methods to factor quadratics, which apply on different occasions and conditions. Now that we know all of them, let's think strategically about which of them is useful for a given quadratic expression we want to factor.

name: Copy of Factoring polynomials with special product forms (Factorization)
blurb: Factor polynomials of various degrees using factorization methods that are based on the special product forms "difference of squares" and "perfect squares." For example, factor 25x⁴-30x²+9 as (5x²-3)².

name: Practice dividing polynomials with remainders (Factorization)
blurb: After learning about the different methods in which we can find the quotient and the remainder of two polynomials, gain some practice with actually performing polynomial division yourself.

name: Intro to the coordinate plane (Introduction to graphs)
blurb: (No description)

name: Coordinate plane word problems (Introduction to graphs)
blurb: (No description)

name: Divisibility tests (Playing with numbers)
blurb: (No description)

name: Irrational numbers (Number systems)
blurb: Learn what irrational numbers are. Also learn how to classify numbers as whole, integer, rational, and irrational.

name: Rational numbers and repeating Decimals (Number systems)
blurb: Learn how to convert rational numbers from their repeating decimal form to their fractional form and vice versa.

name: Rational and irrational expressions (Number systems)
blurb: Determine whether various combinations of rational and irrational numbers are rational or irrational themselves.

name: Exponent properties review (Number systems)
blurb: Practice using the exponent properties to rewrite powers, where the exponent is an integer that can either be positive or negative.

name: Radicals (Number systems)
blurb: Radicals (also known as roots) are a generalization of square roots. They are the inverse operation of any power. For example, the 5th root of 32 is 2, because 2⁵=32.

name: Rational exponents intro (Number systems)
blurb: Learn the definition for raising a number by a fractional exponent, like 8^⅔.

name: Properties of exponents (rational exponents) (Number systems)
blurb: In this tutorial you will rewrite variable expressions with rational exponents using the properties of exponents.

name: Advanced: exponent & radical evaluation (Number systems)
blurb: Let's evaluate elaborate expressions that contain radicals and fractional exponents.

name: Simplifying square roots (Number systems)
blurb: We know how to evaluate square roots of perfect squares. For example, √16=4. What about the other square roots? It's harder to give an exact number, but we can simplify them so we have a better understanding of their value. For example, √32=4⋅√2. Learn more about it in this tutorial.

name: Simplifying radicals (higher-index roots) (Number systems)
blurb: Just like we can simplify square roots, we can simplify other radicals. This tutorial covers the simplification of higher-index roots. For example, ∜48=2⋅∜3.

name: Radicals (miscellaneous videos) (Number systems)
blurb: Various videos we have that cover advanced/special skills related to radical expressions.

name: Introduction to polynomials (Polynomials)
blurb: What exactly is a polynomial? What does the degree of a polynomial mean? Are there many types of polynomials? Let's learn more about polynomials and some terms related to them.

name: Zeroes of a polynomial (Polynomials)
blurb: What are zeroes of a polynomial? Why are they called the 'zeroes' when they are not the number zero? How do we find these zeroes?

name: Long division of polynomials (Polynomials)
blurb: We can divide one number by another and get a quotient and a reminder. We use the long division method to do this for numbers. Polynomials are just numbers in variable form. Let's see how we can use the same long division method to divide one polynomial by another.

name: Polynomial Remainder Theorem (Polynomials)
blurb: The polynomial remainder theorem allows us to easily determine whether a linear expression is a factor of a given polynomial. Learn exactly what the theorem means, practice using it, and learn about its proof.

name: Advanced polynomial factorization methods (Polynomials)
blurb: Learn more ways to factor polynomials with degree higher than 2.

name: Intro to the coordinate plane (Coordinate geometry)
blurb: (No description)

name: Coordinate plane: quadrant 1 (Coordinate geometry)
blurb: How can we communicate exactly where something is in two dimensions?  In this tutorial, we cover the basics of the coordinate plane and graphing points.

name: Quadrants on the coordinate plane (Coordinate geometry)
blurb: Learn the 4 quadrants of a coordinate plane.

name: Coordinate plane: 4 quadrants (Coordinate geometry)
blurb: We first explored the coordinate plane in the 5th grade, but that was only dealing with positive coordinates.  Now we know all about negative numbers so why not have negative coordinates as well? Let's get cozy with the x and y axis, plotting ordered pairs, quadrants, and reflection points. We got it covered. Sit back, relax, and get ready to groove with us.  Common Core Standards: 6.NS.C.6, 6.NS.C.6b, 6.NS.C.6c, 6.NS.C.8

name: Coordinate plane word problems (Coordinate geometry)
blurb: (No description)

name: Introduction to linear equation in 2 variables (Linear equations in two variables)
blurb: Understand what a solution to an equation really means. Practice plugging in values for variables to see whether or not an equation is true. And then, learn about the ways to solving a two-variable linear equation.

name: Graph of a Linear Equation in Two Variables (Linear equations in two variables)
blurb: Let's learn how to plot the graph of a linear equation in two variables and visualise why these equations are called 'linear'.

name: Linear models word problems (Linear equations in two variables)
blurb: Solve general word problems about real-world relationships that can be modeled by linear equations or functions.

name: Introduction (Introduction to Euclid's geometry)
blurb: So what did Euclid really do to be known as the 'father of geometry'.

name: Geometric definitions (Lines and angles)
blurb: Consider how precise definitions of geometry terms are like angle, circle, parallel lines, and a few others.

name: Angle types (Lines and angles)
blurb: Now that we know what angles are, let's dig a bit deeper and classify them and understand their properties better. Acute, obtuse, right, adjacent--all are angles that we will be become familiar with.

name: Vertical, complementary, and supplementary angles (Lines and angles)
blurb: Learn three types of angle pairs: vertical angles, complementary angles, and supplementary angles.

name: Angles between intersecting lines (Lines and angles)
blurb: This tutorial introduces us to angles.  It includes how we measure them, how angles relate to each other and properties of angles created from various types of intersecting lines.  Mr. Angle is actually far more fun than you might initially presume him to be.

name: Triangle angles (Lines and angles)
blurb:
Do the angles in a triangle always add up to the same thing?  Would I ask it if they didn't?  What do we know about the angles of a triangle if two of the sides are congruent (an isosceles triangle) or all three are congruent (an equilateral)?  This tutorial is the place to find out.

Common Core Standard: 8.G.A.5

name: Congruence of Triangles & its criteria (Triangles)
blurb: How do we know that two triangles are congruent if we cannot check by physically placing them on top of each other? We can use the various postulates of congruence- SSS, SAS, ASA and RHS to identify congruent triangles. We'll study these in detail and see a few examples of congruence here.

name: Proofs of theorems that use triangle congruence (Triangles)
blurb: Gain even more experience with using triangle congruence in proofs.

name: Theorems concerning triangle properties (Triangles)
blurb: Now that we know how to show that two triangles are congruent, let's put that to use by proving some theorems about triangles.

name: Inequalities in a Triangle (Triangles)
blurb: In this section, we will study Triangle Inequality Theorem which shows the relation between angles of a triangle and length of sides.

name: Quadrilaterals (Quadrilaterals)
blurb: Not all things with four sides and 90 degree angles are squares or rectangles! Sometimes the angles in these 4-sided shapes are less than (or greater than) 90 degrees, causing them to have a slightly odd shape. These are called quadrilaterals and come in a few different varieties. In this tutorial, you'll learn about them.  Common Core Standards: 5.G.B.3, 5.G.B.4

name: Quadrilateral proof and angles (Quadrilaterals)
blurb: Now that we know of some of the quadrilaterals and how they differ from one another, lets dig deeper into our first special quadrilateral - The parallelogram.

name: Area of parallelogram (Areas of parallelograms & triangles)
blurb: (No description)

name: Area of a triangle (Areas of parallelograms & triangles)
blurb: (No description)

name: Circles basics (Circles)
blurb: Make sure you're familiar with notation and key terms like radius, diameter, circumference, pi, tangent, secant, and major/minor arcs before you dive into the rest of the circles content.

name: Chord and Circles (Circles)
blurb: (No description)

name: Points and Circles (Circles)
blurb: (No description)

name: Inscribed angles (Circles)
blurb: We'll now dig a bit deeper in our understanding of circles by looking at inscribed angles and related properties.

name: Inscribed shapes problem solving (Circles)
blurb: Use properties of inscribed angles to prove properties of inscribed shapes, then apply these properties to some fun problem solving!

name: Basic Constructions (Constructions)
blurb: We will be learning the steps to draw the Bisectors of a given angle, and also how to bisect a line of any given length. In this section, we will also learn to construct angles of 60°, 90°, 45° with the help of scale and compass.

name: Area of a triangle-by Heron's formula (Heron's Formula)
blurb: Till now we have read 1/2*b*h as the only formulae to calculate the area of a triangle, now we will be able to calculate the area of any triangle using heron's Formula.

name: Surface area (Surface areas and volumes)
blurb: (No description)

name: Volume of cubes and cuboids (Surface areas and volumes)
blurb: Welcome to the 3rd dimension! [cue spooky music] This tutorial explains how to find volume.

name: Volume of cones, cylinders, and spheres (Surface areas and volumes)
blurb: Let's see how to find the volumes of cylinders, spheres and other three dimensional shapes.

name: Presentation of Data (Statistics)
blurb:
We will be exploring the methods to collect the data (primary & secondary) which is explained briefly through an activity. And when we've learnt how to collect the data, we will see how can data be arranged to make it more clear meaningful and to analyse it better. we will also see how to construct frequency distribution tables with given intervals to observe
 certain important features at a glance.

name: Ggraphical Representation of Data (Statistics)
blurb: Building on to more formal approach than previous classes on Bar graphs.

name: Graphical representation of data using histograms (Statistics)
blurb: We will learn how to draw histograms of uniform width, and of varying widths-for continuous class intervals depending upon the categories. We will also be learning to make Frequency polygons which is somehow just the extended version of histogram.

name: Measures of Central Tendency (Statistics)
blurb: Now we will learn to analyse the data and put it into practical use. We will learn the meaning and how to calculate Mean (frequency included), median and mode of a given data.

name: Probability basics (Probability)
blurb: Flip a quarter a hundred times. What's the probability that it will turn up heads? Tails? Even if we are unsure about whether something will happen, can we start to be mathematical about the "chances" of an event (essentially realizing that some things are more likely than others) occurring. This tutorial will introduce us to the tools that allow us to think about random events and the logic behind comparing, judging, and finding the probabilities of those events.

name: Euclid’s division algorithm (Real numbers)
blurb:
Euclid’s division Lemma states that given positive integers a and b, there exist unique integers q and r satisfying a = b*q + r, 0 ≤ r < b. Euclid's division algorithm gives us a recipe to use this lemma to find the HCF of two numbers. 
In this lesson, let's learn how to use Euclid's division algorithm to solve problems such as "find the HCF of 1312 and 125".

name: The Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic (Real numbers)
blurb: We will be learning how can we  express every composite number (factorised) as a product of primes, and no matter what this factorisation is always unique, apart from the order in which the prime factors occur. With the knowledge of  the fundamental theorem of arithmetic, we'll revisit the basic concepts like finding LCM and HCF of numbers in a much more efficient manner.

name: GCF and LCM (Real numbers)
blurb: You know how to find factors of a number.  But what about factors that are common to two numbers?  Even better, imagine the largest factors that are common to two numbers.   I know.  Too exciting!

name: Relationship between HCF and LCM (Real numbers)
blurb: We've practised finding LCM and HCF of two numbers using a number of ways. Let's look at some cool ways in which we can visualise all of this!

name: Revisiting Irrational Numbers (Real numbers)
blurb: In this section, we will prove that square root of a general prime number 'p' is irrational. We will also take an example to see how this works.

name: Revisiting Rational Numbers and Their Decimal Expansions (Real numbers)
blurb: In class 9 we've already studied about the decimal expansion of rational numbers. This time we'll be moving to learn and explore exactly when the decimal expansion of p/q is terminating and when it is non-terminating repeating (or recurring) by considering a rational number, say p/q where q is not equal to 0 􀀀

name: Intro to polynomials (Polynomials)
blurb: Learn about polynomial expressions: What are they? How are they constructed? What can we do with them?

name: Finding zeros of polynomials (Polynomials)
blurb: Use all the knowledge you have about polynomials to find their zeros (which are the input values that make the polynomial equal to zero).

name: Zeros of polynomials and their graphs (Polynomials)
blurb: Learn how to use the zeros of polynomials to draw a pretty good sketch of their graphs.

name: Long division of polynomials (Polynomials)
blurb:
Now we will be learning the division algorithm for the polynomials. We will first arrange the terms of the dividend and the divisor in the decreasing order
of their degrees. Now the division algorithm would be stated as p(x) and g(x) are any two polynomials with g(x) ≠ 0, then we can find polynomials q(x) and r(x) such that p(x) = g(x) × q(x) + r(x), where r(x) = 0 or degree of r(x) < degree of g(x).

name: Relationship between coefficients and zeroes of a polynomial (Polynomials)
blurb: **Rough** Find the polynomial given the two roots and vice versa. Use -b/a and c/a.

name: Modelling real-world scenarios with linear equations (Pair of linear equations in two variables)
blurb: Learn how to represent real-world relationships (that are described verbally) with linear graphs, equations, or functions.

name: Linear models word problems (Pair of linear equations in two variables)
blurb: Solve general word problems about real-world relationships that can be modeled by linear equations or functions.

name: Slope (Pair of linear equations in two variables)
blurb: Learn about slope (the steepness of a line) and how to find it.

name: Equivalent systems of equations and the elimination method (Pair of linear equations in two variables)
blurb: Learn about the elimination method, which is a way manipulate systems of equations in order to solve them algebraically. This is actually very similar to the way we manipulate single equations in order to solve them!

name: Solving systems of equations with substitution (Pair of linear equations in two variables)
blurb: Learn about the substitution method, which is another way to manipulate systems of equations in order to solve them.

name: Number of solutions to systems of equations (Pair of linear equations in two variables)
blurb: Learn about the possible number of solutions of systems of linear equations. Spoiler: There can be a single solution, zero solutions, or infinite solutions. These different cases define the distinctions between "consistent" and "inconsistent" systems, and between "dependent" and "independent" systems.

name: Systems of equations word problems (Pair of linear equations in two variables)
blurb: Now that we are able to solve any kind of system we are given, it's time to use that knowledge to solve some word problems.

name: Solving equations reducible to linear form (Pair of linear equations in two variables)
blurb: Let's learn how to solve equations that are reducible to linear form.

name: Quadratic factored form (Quadratic equations)
blurb: The factored form of a quadratic function is an expression that is, well, factored! Like f(x)=(2x+1)(x-3). Learn how to analyze functions given in this form to find their zeros, their vertex, and their graph.

name: Solving quadratics by taking square roots (Quadratic equations)
blurb: In this tutorial you will learn about the most basic way of solving quadratic equations.

name: Solving quadratics by factoring (Quadratic equations)
blurb: In this tutorial, you'll learn some pretty elaborate ways of solving quadratic equations, by harnessing the mighty strength of algebra.

name: Solving quadratics by completing the square (Quadratic equations)
blurb: Factorisation is just one way to find the root of the quadratic equation, in this section we will study about two more methods - completing the squares and Use of quadratic formula. So now, when you are given a quadratic equation you can see which methods to use to factorise it.

name: Solving quadratics using the quadratic formula (Quadratic equations)
blurb: Now that we know how to solve quadratics using factorisation and completing the perfect square, let's move on to discuss yet another way to find the factors. We call this the quadratic formula.

name: Word problems on quadratic equations (Quadratic equations)
blurb: **Rough** An intro video about modelling real-world scenarios.. a couple of exercises... A couple of solved examples.

name: Solving quadratic equations (Quadratic equations (advanced))
blurb: (No description)

name: Nature of roots (Quadratic equations (advanced))
blurb: (No description)

name: Intro to arithmetic progressions (Arithmetic progressions)
blurb: Learn about arithmetic sequences and their main features, the initial term and the common difference. Evaluate arithmetic sequences.

name: Constructing arithmetic sequences (Arithmetic progressions)
blurb: Learn how to find the explicit formula of an arithmetic sequence.

name: Sigma notation (Arithmetic progressions)
blurb: Learn how to use and interpret sigma notation. Hint: It means take the sum!

name: Sum to n terms of an arithmetic progression (Arithmetic progressions)
blurb: Learn how to evaluate and work with finite arithmetic series.

name: Applications of arithmetic progressions (Arithmetic progressions)
blurb: Let's look at the application of arithmetic sequences to problems involving divisibility.

name: Definitions of similarity (Triangles)
blurb: In this tutorial, you will learn how we determine whether two figures are similar.

name: Introduction to triangle similarity (Triangles)
blurb: In this tutorial, we will use what we learned about similarity of polygons in the specific case of triangles. We will come up with specific conditions for triangles to be similar, and use them to determine whether two triangles are similar.

name: Solving similar triangles (Triangles)
blurb: Learn how to find missing measures of triangles using the fact that they are similar to other triangles.

name: Solving problems with similar and congruent triangles (Triangles)
blurb: You already saw how we can use similarity and congruence to find missing measures in triangles. Let's do the same now to solve more kinds of polygons, and more challenging problems!

name: Solving modeling problems with similar and congruent triangles (Triangles)
blurb: Now that you are an expert with solving geometry problems using congruence and similarity, you are ready to solve some real-world problems!

name: Pythagoras Theorem (Triangles)
blurb: We all know what is Pythagorean Theorem. Let's try to prove it using similarity now.

name: Distance formula (Coordinate Geometry)
blurb: Let's learn how to find the distance between two points using Pythagoras theorem. This result is called the "distance formula".

name: Section Formula (Coordinate Geometry)
blurb: Let's learn to find to find the coordinates of a point that divides a line segment in a given ratio.  We do this using similarity of triangles. The result we get is famously called the "section formula'.

name: Ratio in which a point divides a line segment (Coordinate Geometry)
blurb: Let's learn how to find the ratio in which a point or a line divides a line segment. We will be using an intuitive approach involving similar triangles instead of relying on the section formula to solve such problems.

name: Distance and midpoints (Coordinate Geometry)
blurb: Find the distance between two points or the midpoint of two points.

name: Problem solving with distance on the coordinate plane (Coordinate Geometry)
blurb: Use what you know about distance to solve problems on the coordinate plan like finding the perimeter of a shape or determining if a point is on a circle.

name: Area of a triangle using coordinates (Coordinate Geometry)
blurb: Let's learn how to find the area of a triangle from the coordinates of the vertices. Let's derive the general formula and also look at an example.

name: Trigonometric Ratios (Introduction to trigonometry)
blurb: As it is the first time we are studying trigonometry, we will first understand the few introductory terms of sin,cos,tan,cosec,sec,cot,etc and will also learn few values of the trigonometric ratios. The values of an angle do not vary with the lengths of the sides of the triangle, if the angle remains the same. We will also be practicing few questions on the values of trigonometric ratios.

name: Solving for a side in a right triangle using the trigonometric ratios (Introduction to trigonometry)
blurb: Learn how to find a side length in a right triangle when given one side length and one acute angle.

name: The reciprocal trigonometric ratios (Introduction to trigonometry)
blurb: Learn about the remaining three side ratios in a right triangle: the secant, the cosecant, and the cotangent.

name: Trigonometric ratios and similarity (Introduction to trigonometry)
blurb: Learn how the trigonometric ratios are derived from triangle similarity considerations.

name: Sine and cosine of complementary angles (Introduction to trigonometry)
blurb: Learn about the relationship between the sine of an angle and the cosine of its complementary angle, which is the angle that completes to 90°.

name: Trigonometric ratios of special triangles (Introduction to trigonometry)
blurb: Learn to find the sine, cosine, and tangent of 45-45-90 triangles and also 30-60-90 triangles.

name: Trigonometric Identities (Introduction to trigonometry)
blurb: After learning the values of trigonometric ratios we will find the relationship between them to establish trigonometric identities.

name: Heights and distances (Some applications of trigonometry)
blurb: Solve real-world problems that can be modeled by right triangles, using trigonometry.

name: Tangent to a Circle (Circles)
blurb: Tangents are a very interesting and useful concept in Geometry. Their properties are used in solving several geometry problems and we will try to do some here.

name: Construction of Tangents to a Circle (Constructions 2)
blurb: We'll see how to construct tangents to a circle from a point on the circle as well as from a point outside it.

name: Circles basics (Area Related to Circles)
blurb: Make sure you're familiar with notation and key terms like radius, diameter, circumference, pi, tangent, secant, and major/minor arcs before you dive into the rest of the circles content.

name: Arc measures (Area Related to Circles)
blurb: Arc measure is equal to the arc's central angle. We'll explore this fact and solve some problems related to it.

name: Arc length (degrees) (Area Related to Circles)
blurb: Think about the relationship between central angle and arc length. This tutorial uses degrees not radians.

name: Introduction to radians (Area Related to Circles)
blurb: Most people know that you can measure angles with degrees, but only exceptionally worldly people know that radians can be an exciting alternative. As you'll see, degrees are somewhat arbitrary.

name: Arc length (radians) (Area Related to Circles)
blurb: Think about the relationships between arc measures, central angles, and arc length in radians.

name: Sectors (Area Related to Circles)
blurb: Learn how to find the area of a sector.

name: Area of a segment (Area Related to Circles)
blurb: **Rough** Start with a question - Make radius 42 and angle 60 degree (Ask Ashish for example)

name: Area of combination of figures (Area Related to Circles)
blurb: (No description)

name: Surface area of combination of solids (Surface Areas and Volumes)
blurb: Let's learn how to find the surface area of complex solids by breaking them into cylinders, cones, and hemispheres.

name: Volume of combination of solids (Surface Areas and Volumes)
blurb: Let's see how we can find the volume of a complicated looking solid by breaking it into simple solids like cylinders, cones, cuboids, and hemispheres.

name: Volume problems (Surface Areas and Volumes)
blurb: Learn to find volume of rings, triangular prisms, and rectangular prisms inside of other rectangular prisms.

name: Volume and surface area of a frustum of a cone (Surface Areas and Volumes)
blurb: Let's learn how to find the volume and surface area of a frustum of a cone (a bucket - shaped solid) by visualizing it as a small cone subtracted from a large cone.

name: Mean of grouped data (Statistics)
blurb: (No description)

name: Mode of grouped data (Statistics)
blurb: (No description)

name: Median of grouped data (Statistics)
blurb: (No description)

name: Plotting ogives (Statistics)
blurb: Let's learn how to plot ogives for a given data.

name: Probability basics (Probability)
blurb: Flip a quarter a hundred times. What's the probability that it will turn up heads? Tails? Even if we are unsure about whether something will happen, we can start to be mathematical about the "chances" of an event (essentially realizing that some things are more likely than others) occurring. This tutorial will introduce us to the tools that allow us to think about random events and the logic behind comparing, judging, and finding the probabilities of those events.

name: Multiplication rule for independent events (Probability)
blurb: What’s the probability that three people were all born on the same day of the week? How likely is a basketball player to make three shots in a row? In this tutorial, we’ll see that multiplying probabilities can be quite useful.

name: Multiplication rule for dependent events (Probability)
blurb: What’s the probability of drawing two aces in a row from a deck of cards? Getting an ace on the first card changes the probability for the second card. This tutorial covers how we can deal with that when multiplying probabilities.

name: Addition rule for probability (Probability)
blurb: What’s the probability of picking a card and getting a jack or a heart? What’s the probability that someone owns a laptop or a smartphone? This tutorial will show how we can add probabilities to solve these types of problems.

name: Intersection and union of sets (Sets)
blurb: Learn about the intersection and union of sets using venn diagrams

name: Types of sets (Sets)
blurb: (No description)

name: Operations on sets (Sets)
blurb: (No description)

name: Evaluating functions (Relations and functions)
blurb: Learn how to find the value of a function for a given input value.

name: Inputs and outputs of a function (Relations and functions)
blurb: Extend your understanding of the relationship between the inputs of a function and the outputs of that function.

name: Interpreting function notation (Relations and functions)
blurb: Solve some word problems by interpreting expressions of modeling functions.

name: Functions and equations (Relations and functions)
blurb: Understand the subtle differences and similarities between functions and equations. In this exercise, we will see how an equation can be turned into a function.

name: Introduction to the domain and range of a function (Relations and functions)
blurb: Learn what the domain and the range of a function are. Practice finding the domain and the range of a function given its graph.

name: Determining the domain of a function (Relations and functions)
blurb: Determine the domains of functions according to various considerations.

name: Recognizing functions (Relations and functions)
blurb: Learn how to distinguish between two-variable relationships that are functions and two-variable relationships that aren't functions.

name: Maximum and minimum points (Relations and functions)
blurb: Learn about maximum and minimum points of functions.

name: Intervals where a function is positive, negative, increasing, or decreasing (Relations and functions)
blurb: Learn about features of functions that have distinct graphical representations: intervals where the function is always positive or always negative, and intervals where the function is always increasing or always decreasing.

name: Interpreting features of graphs (Relations and functions)
blurb: Interpret the graphs of functions in terms of the contexts that are modeled by the functions.

name: Combining functions (Relations and functions)
blurb: (No description)

name: Piecewise functions (Relations and functions)
blurb: We are used to functions that have the same rule for all inputs. For example, f(x)=x² outputs the square of every input. Piecewise functions have different output rules, depending on the inputs. For example, we can define function g to output x² for all positive values of x and x³ for all negative values of x, so g(2)=4 and g(-2)=-8.

name: Determining the domain of advanced functions (Relations and functions)
blurb: Learn how to determine the domain of piecewise functions with different function rules.

name: Determining the range of advanced functions (Relations and functions)
blurb: Learn how to find the range of a function, which is the set of all of the function's possible outputs.

name: Introduction to logarithms (Exponential and Logarithmic functions)
blurb: Learn how we define logarithms and use this definition in order to evaluate various logarithms. For example, evaluate log_2(8) as 3 by realizing that 2^3=8.

name: The constant e and the natural logarithm (Exponential and Logarithmic functions)
blurb: Learn about a very special constant in math that has a pivotal role in the world of exponential and logarithmic function, the constant e.

name: Properties of logarithms (Exponential and Logarithmic functions)
blurb: Learn about special properties of logarithms that help us rewrite logarithmic expressions in different equivalent (much like we use properties of exponents to rewrite exponential expressions!).

name: Change of base formula for logarithms (Exponential and Logarithmic functions)
blurb: Learn how to rewrite any logarithmic expression in a different base. For example, rewrite log_2(3) as ln(3)/ln(2). This is very helpful for evaluating logarithms with a calculator, which only evaluates base-10 and base-e logarithms.

name: Exponential equations: logarithms (Exponential and Logarithmic functions)
blurb: Learn how to solve any exponential equation by using logarithms. For example, solve 2^x=3 by calculating log_2(3).

name: Solving exponential models (Exponential and Logarithmic functions)
blurb: Learn how to solve word problems that require exponential equations.

name: Logarithmic scale (optional) (Exponential and Logarithmic functions)
blurb: Enrich your knowledge with some videos about logarithmic scales and how useful they are.

name: Shifting functions (Playing with graphs)
blurb: Learn how to transform functions so their graph is shifted horizontally or vertically. Learn how to find the equation of a function that is a shift of another function.

name: Stretching functions (Playing with graphs)
