blurb: Learn how to transform functions so their graph is stretched horizontally or vertically. Learn how to find the equation of a function that is a stretch of another function.

name: Symmetry of functions (Playing with graphs)
blurb: You may already be familiar with types of symmetries of geometrical shapes. Learn how functions can be symmetrical too!

name: Symmetry of polynomial functions (Playing with graphs)
blurb: Learn how to determine the symmetry of a polynomial function.

name: Graphs of absolute value functions (Playing with graphs)
blurb: Learn how to graph absolute value functions like f(x)=|x+2|-8.

name: Graphs of radical functions (Playing with graphs)
blurb: Learn how the graphs of radical functions look, and how we can reason about them using function transformations (i.e. shifts, stretches, etc.).

name: Graphs of exponential functions (Playing with graphs)
blurb: Learn about the graphs of advanced exponential functions of the form y=a*b^(x+c)+d.

name: Graphs of logarithmic functions (Playing with graphs)
blurb: Learn about the graphs of logarithmic functions, and how they relate to graphs of exponential functions.

name: Graphs of polynomials using their zeroes (Playing with graphs)
blurb: Learn how to use the zeros of polynomials to draw a pretty good sketch of their graphs.

name: End behavior of polynomial functions (Playing with graphs)
blurb: Learn about the end behavior of polynomial functions. End behavior is the way the function behaves as the input values grow infinitely positive or infinitely negative.

name: Graphs of polynomials (Playing with graphs)
blurb: Combine your knowledge about the zeros and the end behavior of a polynomial in order to sketch its graph.

name: Intro to radians (Trigonometric functions)
blurb: Angle is a measure of the rotation about a point. We will explore different aspects of an angle and will understand what are degrees and radians.

name: Trigonometric values of special angles (Trigonometric functions)
blurb: Learn how to find the trigonometric values of some special angles without the use of a calculator.

name: Trigonometric functions (Trigonometric functions)
blurb: Learn about the ingenious way in which we define the trigonometric functions for any real number.

name: The graphs of sine, cosine, and tangent (Trigonometric functions)
blurb: Learn how the graphs of y=sin(θ), y=cos(θ), and y=tan(θ) look, using the unit circle definition of the functions.

name: Trigonometric identities (Trigonometric functions)
blurb: (No description)

name: Trigonometric equations (Trigonometric functions)
blurb: Learn how to solve equations of the form sin(x)=d or cos(x)=d where d is any number. For example, solve sin(x)=0.6.

name: Deductive and inductive reasoning (Principle of mathematical induction)
blurb: (No description)

name: Principle of mathematical induction (Principle of mathematical induction)
blurb: (No description)

name: What are the imaginary numbers? (Complex numbers)
blurb: Learn about the imaginary unit i (which is the square root of -1) and about imaginary numbers like 3i (which is the square root of -9).

name: What are the complex numbers? (Complex numbers)
blurb: Learn about complex numbers (spoiler: they are numbers that consist of both real and imaginary parts).

name: The complex plane (Complex numbers)
blurb: Learn how we can visualize complex numbers in a plane. This can be seen as an expansion of the 1-dimensional real number line into a 2-dimensional plane!

name: Adding & subtracting complex numbers (Complex numbers)
blurb: Learn how to add or subtract complex numbers. For example, write (2+3i)-(1+2i) as (1+i).

name: Multiplying complex numbers (Complex numbers)
blurb: Learn how to multiply complex numbers using the fact that i^2=-1 and the distributive property. For example, multiply (1+i) by (2+3i).

name: Complex conjugates & dividing complex numbers (Complex numbers)
blurb: Learn how to divide complex numbers using the conjugate of the divisor. For example, divide (2+3i) by (-1+4i) by multiplying both the dividend and the divisor by (-1-4i).

name: Absolute value & angle of complex numbers (Complex numbers)
blurb: Learn about very important graphical features of complex numbers: their absolute value and their angle.

name: Distance & midpoint of complex numbers (Complex numbers)
blurb: Learn how we define the distance of two complex numbers, and how we define their midpoint.

name: Polar form of complex numbers (Complex numbers)
blurb: Learn how to represent complex numbers in a different way. Unlike rectangular form, which emphasizes the real and imaginary parts, polar form emphasizes the absolute value ("modulus") and the angle ("argument").

name: Multiplying & dividing complex numbers in polar form (Complex numbers)
blurb: Learn how complex multiplication and division work when the numbers are given in polar form. Amazingly enough, this is much easier than multiplication and division in rectangular form.

name: Introduction to inequalities with variables (Linear inequalities)
blurb: Algebraic inequalities (inequalities with variables) are useful for describing real-world situations. Learn how to write inequalities and graph them on the number line.

name: One-step inequalities (Linear inequalities)
blurb: Learn how to solve (mathematical) inequalities. A key concept in this tutorial is flipping the inequality sign when multiplying or dividing both sides by a negative number.

name: Two-step inequalities (Linear inequalities)
blurb: Learn how to solve more complex (mathematical) inequalities. Also learn to construct inequalities to model real-world situations.

name: Multi-step inequalities (Linear inequalities)
blurb: Solve any possible linear inequality in one variable. For example, solve -3x-7<x+9.

name: Compound inequalities (Linear inequalities)
blurb: Learn how to solve compound inequalities. For example, solve 2x+1>3 AND -x-5<4.

name: Checking solutions of two-variable inequalities (Linear inequalities)
blurb: Learn how to check possible solutions of two-variable linear inequalities. For example, is (2, 0) a solution to y>x+1? In this tutorial, we also check solutions to systems of inequalities.

name: Constraining solutions of two-variable inequalities (Linear inequalities)
blurb: Given a specific value for one of the variables in a two-variable linear inequality (or system of inequalities), learn how to find the corresponding range of values for the other variable. For example, given that x=3, what are the possible values for y in 2x+y<1 ?

name: Graphing two-variable inequalities (Linear inequalities)
blurb: Learn how to graph two-variables linear inequalities and systems of two-variable linear inequalities.

name: Fundamental Principle of Counting (Permutations and combinations)
blurb: Let's learn the 'fundamental principle of counting' that forms the foundation for the rest of permutations and combinations.

name: Permutations (Permutations and combinations)
blurb: To 'permute' something is just a fancy way to 'rearrange' it. So, what we are really going to learn here is answers to questions involving numbers of ways in which things can be rearranged (or if you wish 'permuted').

name: Combinations (Permutations and combinations)
blurb: In cricket, selectors have to solve the hairy problem of deciding which 11 players to pick to play for India from a larger group of players. We learn to solve simpler problems than that like "How many ways can these selectors select 11 players from the squad of 20?" and when we don't care about the order in which the 11 players were selected, we call this kind of selection as a 'combination'.

name: Binomial Theorem for Positive Integral Indices (Binomial theorem)
blurb: Let's learn the binomial theorem and how to expand binomials. We will also look at the connection between the binomial theorem and combinatorics (permutations and combinations).

name: Sequences (Sequence and series)
blurb: Review sequences before you dive into arithmetic series.

name: Basic sigma notation (Sequence and series)
blurb: Learn how to use and interpret sigma notation. Hint: It means take the sum!

name: Finite arithmetic series (Sequence and series)
blurb: Learn how to evaluate and work with finite arithmetic series.

name: Finite geometric series (Sequence and series)
blurb: Whether you are computing mortgage payments or calculating how many users your website will have after a few years,  geometric  series show up in life far more than you imagine.  This tutorial will review all the important concepts and more!

name: Finite geometric series applications (Sequence and series)
blurb: Apply what you've learned about geometric series to model situations in some fun word problems.

name: Sum to n terms of special series (Sequence and series)
blurb: This topic explains concepts related to some special series, such as: Sum of first n natural numbers and sum of squares of the first n natural numbers.

name: x-intercepts and y-intercepts (Straight lines)
blurb: Learn about intercepts and practice finding them from graphs, tables, and equations.

name: Slope (Straight lines)
blurb: Learn about slope (the steepness of a line) and how to find it.

name: Horizontal & vertical lines (Straight lines)
blurb: You know what horizontal and vertical lines are, but how do their equations look? And what is their slope? Learn all about it in this tutorial.

name: Intro to slope-intercept form (Straight lines)
blurb: Make an introduction with the most common form of linear equations, slope-intercept form! For example, y=3x+5 is a linear equation in slope-intercept form.

name: Graphing slope-intercept equations (Straight lines)
blurb: Learn how to graph linear equations that are given in slope-intercept form. For example, graph y=2x+3.

name: Parallel and perpendicular lines on the coordinate plane (Straight lines)
blurb: You probably know what parallel and perpendicular lines are. In this tutorial, you will learn how these relationships are expressed on the coordinate plane (spoiler: parallel lines have the same slope, and the product of the slopes of perpendicular lines is always -1).

name: Equations of parallel and perpendicular lines (Straight lines)
blurb: Learn all about equations of parallel and perpendicular

name: Writing slope-intercept equations (Straight lines)
blurb: Learn how to write the equation of a line (in slope-intercept form) when given the graph of the equation or two points on the line. For example, write the equation of the line that passes through the points (0,1) and (5,4).

name: Point-slope form (Straight lines)
blurb: (y-b)=m(x-a)

name: Standard form (Straight lines)
blurb: ax+by=c

name: Summary: Forms of two-variable linear equations (Straight lines)
blurb: Take an overview of the three main forms of linear equations: slope-intercept, point-slope, and standard. Learn which form is most appropriate for different uses.

name: Distance between a point and a line (Straight lines)
blurb: An optional tutorial where you'll figure out the minimum distance from a point to a given line.

name: Introduction to conic sections (Conic sections)
blurb: Conic sections are formed when you intersect a plane with a cone. In this tutorial, you will learn more about what makes conic sections special.

name: Features of a circle (Conic sections)
blurb: Learn about the graphs of circles, and how their center and radius are represented algebraically.

name: Standard equation of a circle (Conic sections)
blurb: Learn about the standard form to represent a circle with an equation. For example, the equation (x-1)^2+(y+2)^2=9 is a circle whose center is (1,-2) and radius is 3.

name: Expanded equation of a circle (Conic sections)
blurb: Learn how to analyze an equation of a circle that is not given in the standard form. For example, find the center of the circle whose equation is x^2+y^2+4x-5=0.

name: Features of an ellipse (Conic sections)
blurb: Learn about the basic features of ellipses: their center and the two radii that pass through it, the major radius and the minor radius.

name: Equation of an ellipse (Conic sections)
blurb: (No description)

name: Foci of an ellipse (Conic sections)
blurb: Learn about the foci of an ellipse, which are two points for which the sum of the distances from any point on the ellipse is constant.

name: Features of a parabola (Conic sections)
blurb: A parabola is the set of all points equidistant from a point (called the focus) and a line (called the directrix). In this tutorial you will learn about the focus and the directrix, and how to find the equation of a parabola given its focus and directrix.

name: Features of a hyperbola (Conic sections)
blurb: A hyperbola is the set of all points whose distances from two specific points (called the foci) have the same difference. Learn more about it here.

name: Foci of a hyperbola (Conic sections)
blurb: Learn about the foci of the hyperbola: How to find them from the hyperbola's equation and how to find the equation when given the foci.

name: Identifying conic sections from their expanded equations (Conic sections)
blurb: Learn how to analyze expanded equations in order to determine which kind of conic section they represent.

name: Limits introduction (Limits)
blurb: A limit is the value that a function or sequence "approaches" as the input or index approaches some value. In this tutorial, we supply an intuitive understanding of limits.

name: Limits from tables (Limits)
blurb: Find limits by creating a table of values and analyzing the trend.

name: Copy of Limits from graphs (Limits)
blurb: Find limits by analyzing graphs.

name: One-sided limits (Limits)
blurb: Learn what one-sided limits are and analyze them via graphs.

name: One-sided vs. Two-sided limits (Limits)
blurb: Investigate the relationship between a two-sided limit at a point and the one-sided limits at that point (spoiler: the two-sided limits exists if and only if the one-sided limits exist and are equal).

name: Formal definition of limits (optional) (Limits)
blurb: The epsilon-delta definition of a limit is not assessed on the AP Calculus AB or BC Exam. However, teachers may include this topic in the course if time permits.

name: Review: Limits basics (Limits)
blurb: Review your understanding of the basics of limits with some challenge problems.

name: Limits from equations (direct substitution) (Limits)
blurb: Take your first steps in finding limits algebraically. For example, find the limit of x²+5x at x=2, or determine whether the limit of 2x/(x+1) at x=-1 exists.

name: Limits from equations (factoring & rationalizing) (Limits)
blurb: There are some limits that want us to work a little before we find them. Learn about two main methods of dealing with such limits: factorization and rationalization. For example, find the limit of (x²-1)/(x-1) at x=1.

name: Squeeze theorem (Limits)
blurb: The Squeeze theorem (or Sandwich theorem) states that for any three functions f, g, and h, if f(x)≤g(x)≤h(x) for all x-values on an interval except for a single value x=a, and the limits of f and h at x=a are equal to L, then the limit of g at x=a must be equal to L as well. This may seem simple but it's pure genius. Learn how it helps us find tricky limits like sin(x)/x at x=0.

name: Limits of trigonometric functions (Limits)
blurb: Find limits of trigonometric functions by manipulating the functions (using trigonometric identities) into expressions that are nicer to handle. For example, find the limit of sin(x)/sin(2x) at x=0.

name: Limits of piecewise functions (Limits)
blurb: Remember one-sided limits? Well, these are very useful when dealing with piecewise functions. For example, analyze the limit at x=2 of the function that gives (x-2)² for values lower than 2 and 2-x² for values lager than 2.

name: Review: Limits from equations (Limits)
blurb: Review your limit-evaluation skills with some challenge problems.

name: Introduction to differential calculus (Derivatives)
blurb: What's differential calculus all about? An answer to this question lies just right here.

name: Derivative as slope of tangent line (Derivatives)
blurb: One way of thinking about the derivative (of a function at a point) is as the slope of the tangent line (to the function's graph at that point). Get comfortable with this approach here.

name: Derivative as instantaneous rate of change (Derivatives)
blurb: One way of thinking about the derivative is as instantaneous rate of change. This is quite incredible because rate of change is usually found over a period of time, and not at an instant. Get comfortable with this approach here.

name: Secant lines (Derivatives)
blurb: Gain some experience working with secant lines. This will help us on our journey to find a formal definition for the derivative.

name: Derivative as a limit (Derivatives)
blurb: The derivative is actually a special kind of limit! This is yet another important stop on our continuing journey towards a formal definition of the derivative.

name: Formal definition of derivative (Derivatives)
blurb: There are two ways to define the derivative of function f at point x=a. The formal definition is the limit of [f(a+h)-f(x)]/h as h approaches 0, and the alternative definition is the limit of [f(x)-f(a)]/(x-a) as x approaches a. Make introduction with these two definitions.

name: Using the formal definition of derivative (Derivatives)
blurb: Learn how we can use their formal definition in order to find the derivatives of specific functions. For example, we find the derivative of f(x)=x² at x=3, or for any x-value.

name: Derivative as a function (Derivatives)
blurb: This may blow your mind, but the derivative of a function is a function in itself! Get comfortable in thinking about the derivative as a function that is separate from, but tightly related to, its original function.

name: Review: Derivative basics (Derivatives)
blurb: Review your conceptual understanding of derivatives with some challenge problems.

name: Basic differentiation rules (DIfferentiation)
blurb: If you ever tried to find derivatives using their formal definition, you probably know how tedious that may be. Fortunately, we have ways for finding derivatives much quicker, using differentiation rules! Make your first steps in this fascinating world by working with the more basic rules. For example, the derivative of [f(x)+g(x)] is f'(x)+g'(x), and the derivative of k⋅f(x) is k⋅f'(x).

name: Power rule (DIfferentiation)
blurb: The power rule says that the derivative of xⁿ is n⋅xⁿ⁻¹. It allows us to quickly find the derivative of any polynomial, and it doesn't even stop there! Make introduction with this simple but powerful rule.

name: Polynomial functions differentiation (DIfferentiation)
blurb: Put the power rule to use by differentiating various polynomials.

name: Rational functions differentiation (intro) (DIfferentiation)
blurb: Learn how the power rule can be used to differentiate some basic rational functions.

name: Radical functions differentiation (intro) (DIfferentiation)
blurb: Learn how the power rule can be used to differentiate some basic radical functions.

name: Sine & cosine, eˣ and ln(x) derivatives (DIfferentiation)
blurb: The derivative of sin(x) is cos(x) and the derivative of cos(x) is -sin(x). How convenient! Practice differentiating functions that include sine and cosine.

name: Review: Basic differentiation (DIfferentiation)
blurb: Review your understanding of basic differentiation rules and your knowledge of the derivatives of common functions with some challenge problems.

name: Product rule (DIfferentiation)
blurb: The product rule says that the derivative of the product f(x)g(x) is f'(x)g(x)+f(x)g'(x). This helps us find the derivative of a function which is a product of two other, more basic, functions.

name: Measures of dispersion (Statistics)
blurb:
In order to have a better interpretation of data one should have a good idea of how they are scattered or how much they are
bunched around a measure of central tendency (median, mean etc). Let's learn about measures of separation or spread in this tutorial.

name: Range (Statistics)
blurb: The Range is Maximum Value – Minimum Value. Let's explore the idea of range deeper in this tutorial.

name: Mean absolute deviation (grouped data) (Statistics)
blurb: Mean deviation for ungrouped data is explained in this subtopic along with it formulae to calculate it.

name: Variance and standard deviation (ungrouped data): (Statistics)
blurb: Standard deviation tells us how far away from the mean each data point typically is in a set of numbers. How we calculate standard deviation depends on whether the data represents an entire population or came from a sample. This tutorial focuses on the data that represents an entire population.

name: Comparing distributions (Statistics)
blurb:
This topic introduces the coefficient of variation: C.V. =(σ
/x)*100 where: x is not 0 for a certain data and comparison of two frequency distributions with same mean

name: Basic probability (Probability)
blurb: Flip a quarter a hundred times. What's the probability that it will turn up heads? Tails? Even if we are unsure about whether something will happen, we can start to be mathematical about the "chances" of an event (essentially realizing that some things are more likely than others) occurring. This tutorial will introduce us to the tools that allow us to think about random events and the logic behind comparing, judging, and finding the probabilities of those events.

name: Addition rule for probability (Probability)
blurb: What’s the probability of picking a card and getting a jack or a heart? What’s the probability that someone owns a laptop or a smartphone? This tutorial will show how we can add probabilities to solve these types of problems.

name: Compound probability of independent events using diagrams (Probability)
blurb:
What is the probability of making three free throws in a row (LeBron literally asks this in this tutorial).

In this tutorial, we'll explore compound events happening where the probability of one event is not dependent on the outcome of another (compound, independent, events).

name: Compound probability of independent events using the multiplication rule (Probability)
blurb: See how we can use the multiplication rule to find the compound probability of independent events.

name: Probability using combinatorics (Probability)
blurb: This tutorial will apply the permutation and combination tools you learned in the last tutorial to problems of probability.  You'll finally learn that there may be better "investments" than poring all your money into the Powerball Lottery.

name: Introduction to inverses of functions (Relations and functions)
blurb: Learn what inverses of functions are, and gain some experience with them by finding the outputs of the inverse of a function given that function.

name: Finding inverse functions (Relations and functions)
blurb: Learn how to find the inverses of polynomials functions, radical functions, and rational functions.

name: Verifying that functions are inverses (Relations and functions)
blurb: Learn how to check whether a pair of functions are the inverses of one another.

name: Determining whether a function is invertible (Relations and functions)
blurb: Learn about the conditions for a function to be invertible, and learn how to manipulate functions to make them invertible.

name: Formal definition of inverse functions (optional) (Relations and functions)
blurb: You can use a transformation/function to map from one set to another, but can you invert it?  In other words, is there a function/transformation that given the output of the original mapping, can output the original input (this is much clearer with diagrams). This tutorial addresses this question in a linear algebra context.

name: Copy of Two-variable functions (Relations and functions)
blurb: Learn about functions that take *two* inputs in order to output a single value.

name: Basic concepts (Inverse trigonometric functions)
blurb: In this subtopic we will explore the concept of inverse trigonometric functions, how to interchange the domain and range, graphs and principal branch of functions. We will also see the procedure of finding the principal value.

name: Domain and range of inverse trigonometric functions (Inverse trigonometric functions)
blurb: (No description)

name: Introduction to matrices (Matrices)
blurb: Learn what matrices are and about their parts (coordinates and dimensions).

name: Adding & subtracting matrices (Matrices)
blurb: Learn how to add and subtract two matrices to obtain a new matrix (just like numbers!).

name: Multiplying matrices by scalars (Matrices)
blurb: Learn how to multiply matrices by scalars (in the world of matrices, scalars are simply regular numbers). For example, multiply a 2X2 matrix by 3.

name: Properties of matrix addition & scalar multiplication (Matrices)
blurb: Learn about zero matrices and about how matrix addition, subtraction, and scalar multiplication are related to their corresponding operations with real numbers.

name: Multiplying matrices by matrices (Matrices)
blurb: Learn how to find the result of a multiplication of two matrices.

name: Properties of matrix multiplication (Matrices)
blurb: Learn about identity matrices and about how matrix multiplication relates to real number multiplication (spoiler: the distributive property applies but the commutative property does not!).

name: Transpose of a matrix (Matrices)
blurb: Let us now see what is a transpose of a matrix.

name: Elementary matrix row operations (Matrices)
blurb: Learn about the three basic operations we can perform on a matrix without changing the solution set of the linear system it represents.

name: Invertible matrices (Matrices)
blurb: In this subtopic we will define the inverse of a matrix, understand the proof of uniqueness of an inverse and calculate the Inverse of a matrix by using elementary operations on matrices.

name: Inverse of a matrix by elementary operations (Matrices)
blurb: (No description)

name: Determinants (Determinants)
blurb: Lets' learn to how to calculate the determinant of a 2x2 and 3x3 matrix by expansion.

name: Properties of determinants (Determinants)
blurb: Let's learn some of the properties of determinants and verify them by using expansion.

name: Adjoint and inverse of a matrix using minors and cofactors (Determinants)
blurb: We will explore the concept of minors and the order of a minor in a determinant.

name: Solving equations with inverse matrices (Determinants)
blurb: Learn how to solve systems of linear equations using inverse matrices, and how to solve matrix equations using inverse matrices.

name: Determinants in more depth (Optional) (Determinants)
blurb: Let us now get a deeper understanding of determinants and stretch ourselves with a few challenging concepts.

name: Continuity at a point (Continuity & differentiability)
blurb: A function is continuous at a point if its limit at that point exists and is equal to the actual function's value at that point.

name: Review: Limits of combined & composite functions (Continuity & differentiability)
blurb: Practice your basic understanding of limits and continuity with more complex cases.

name: Continuous functions (Continuity & differentiability)
blurb: Continuous functions are continuous at all of the points in their domains. In essence, these are functions whose graphs can be drawn with a single brush stroke.

name: Review: Intermediate value theorem (Continuity & differentiability)
blurb: The intermediate value theorem states that if a continuous function, f, with an interval, [a, b], as its domain, takes values f(a) and f(b) at each end of the interval, then it also takes any value between f(a) and f(b) at some point within the interval. This is a basic but important property of all continuous functions.

name: Differentiability (Continuity & differentiability)
blurb: The derivative of a function isn't necessarily defined at every point. Learn about the conditions for the derivative to exist, and specifically about how continuity fits with this story (spoiler: for a function to be differentiable at a point it must be continuous at that point, but the other way isn't necessary).

name: Review: Differentiation basics: (Continuity & differentiability)
blurb: (No description)

name: Product rule (Continuity & differentiability)
blurb: The product rule says that the derivative of the product f(x)g(x) is f'(x)g(x)+f(x)g'(x). This helps us find the derivative of a function which is a product of two other, more basic, functions.

name: Quotient rule (Continuity & differentiability)
blurb: The quotient rule says that the derivative of the quotient f(x)/g(x) is [f'(x)g(x)-f(x)g'(x)]/g²(x). This helps us find the derivative of a function which is a quotient of two other, more basic, functions.

name: Chain rule (Continuity & differentiability)
blurb: The chain rule says that the derivative of the composite function f(g(x)) is f'(g(x))⋅g'(x). This helps us find the derivative of a composite function. It may be slightly hard to grasp, but its importance cannot be overstated!

name: Review: Product, quotient, & chain rule (Continuity & differentiability)
blurb: Review your understanding of the product, quotient, and chain rules with some challenge problems.

name: Rational functions differentiation (Continuity & differentiability)
blurb: Solve problems involving the derivatives of rational functions. For example, find f'(1) of f(x)=(x+2)/(x-3).

name: Radical functions differentiation (Continuity & differentiability)
blurb: Solve problems involving the derivatives of radical functions. For example, find g'(5) of g(x)=∛(x²+5x-3).

name: Trigonometric functions differentiation (Continuity & differentiability)
blurb: Solve problems involving the derivatives of trigonometric functions. For example, find h'(π) of h(x)=sin(x²-4x+1).

name: Exponential functions differentiation (Continuity & differentiability)
blurb: Solve problems involving the derivatives of exponential functions. For example, find f'(1) of f(x)=2^(x²+x+5).

name: Logarithmic functions differentiation (Continuity & differentiability)
blurb: Solve problems involving the derivatives of logarithmic functions. For example, find g'(4) of g(x)=log(x²-1).

name: Derivatives capstone (Continuity & differentiability)
blurb: Review your function differentiation skills with some challenge problems.

name: Implicit differentiation introduction (Advanced differentiation)
blurb: Some two-variable relationships cannot be turned into a function, like the circle equation x²+y²=4. Implicit differentiation allows us to find the derivative of y with respect to x, even in such equations.

name: Implicit differentiation (advanced examples) (Advanced differentiation)
blurb: Tackle some more advanced problems of implicit differentiation. For example, find dy/dx for e^(xy²)=x-y.

name: Inverse trig functions differentiation (Advanced differentiation)
blurb: Implicit differentiation allows us to find the derivatives of arcsin(x), arccos(x), and arctan(x).

name: Derivatives of inverse functions (Advanced differentiation)
blurb: Implicit differentiation provides us with the relationship between the derivatives of inverse functions: if f and g are inverse functions, then f’(x)=1/(g’(f(x)). Get comfortable working with this relationship.

name: Disguised derivatives (Advanced differentiation)
blurb: Equipped with knowledge about the derivatives of all common functions, evaluate some limits that represent various derivatives.

name: Proofs for the derivatives of eˣ and ln(x) (Advanced differentiation)
blurb: The derivatives of eˣ and ln(x) may be simple, but proving them is a different story. Learn all about it here.

name: Logarithmic differentiation (Advanced differentiation)
blurb: In logarithmic differentiation, we find the derivative of the natural log of a function instead of the derivative of the function itself. It may surprise you, but this can sometimes actually be easier than regular differentiation, if not the only available option. For example, finding the derivative of xˣ.

name: Review: Advanced differentiation (Advanced differentiation)
blurb: Review your knowledge of the advanced differentiation topics with some challenge problems.

name: Higher-order derivatives (Advanced differentiation)
blurb: The derivative is a function, and as such it has its own derivative! The same goes for the derivative of the derivative, and so forth. These are all called higher-order derivatives.

name: Mean value theorem (Advanced differentiation)
blurb: The mean value theorem states that if a function f is continuous on the closed interval [a,b] and differentiable on the open interval (a,b), then there exists a point c in (a,b) such that f'(c) is equal to the function's average rate of change over [a,b].

name: Critical points (Playing with graphs (using differentiation))
blurb: Critical points are points where a function may obtain their minimum or maximum value. They play a critical role (pun intended) in analyzing the increasing and decreasing intervals of functions, and in finding their minimum and maximum points.

name: Increasing & decreasing intervals (Playing with graphs (using differentiation))
blurb: Analyze functions to find the intervals in which they are increasing or decreasing.

name: Relative minima & maxima (Playing with graphs (using differentiation))
blurb: Analyze functions to find their relative extrema (i.e. their relative minimum and maximum points).

name: Absolute minima & maxima (Playing with graphs (using differentiation))
blurb: Analyze functions to find their absolute extrema (i.e. their absolute minimum and maximum points).

name: Review: Increasing/decreasing intervals & extrema (Playing with graphs (using differentiation))
blurb: Review your understanding of increasing and decreasing intervals, and extremum points, with some challenge problems.

name: Concavity (Playing with graphs (using differentiation))
blurb: Concavity describes the shape of a graph as it increases or decreases: a graph that's concave up is shaped like a cup, U, and a graph that's concave down is shaped like a cap, ∩. Learn more about concavity and how it relates to a function's second derivative.

name: Points of inflection (Playing with graphs (using differentiation))
blurb: Points of inflection are points where the function changes concavity. Learn how to find and analyze them.

name: Sketching graphs using calculus (Playing with graphs (using differentiation))
blurb: Combine the tools provided by differential calculus with other algebraic tools in order to obtain detailed sketches of various functions.

name: Review: Concavity & points of inflection (Playing with graphs (using differentiation))
blurb: Review your understanding of concavity and points of inflections with some challenge problems.

name: Approximations (Applications of derivatives)
blurb: Let us now learn to use the concept of differentiation to approximate square root of a specific number without the direct calculation.

name: Rectilinear motion (optional) (Applications of derivatives)
blurb: Solve problems about motion along a line using the power of differential calculus. For example, given the position of a particle as a function of time s(t), find the particle's maximum velocity.

name: Related rates (Applications of derivatives)
blurb: Solve geometrical and real-world problems that concern multiple quantities that change at different, but related, rates. For example, given the rate of change of a circle's radius, find the rate of change of the circle's area.

name: Tangents & Normals (Applications of derivatives)
blurb: Let us relate the concept of tangents and normals of a graph to the derivative of a function. We will also explore how to calculate the equation of tangent at a specific point on the graph.

name: Optimization (Applications of derivatives)
blurb: Solve geometrical and real-world problems that involve finding the maximum (or minimum) possible value of a quantity. For example, find the maximum area of a rectangle whose perimeter is given.

name: Applied rates of change (Applications of derivatives)
blurb: Solve various rate of change problems where a real-world situation is modeled by an algebraic function.

name: L'Hôpital's rule (Applications of derivatives)
blurb: L'Hôpital's rule provides us with an easy, almost magical way of finding indeterminate limits of quotients of functions using the functions' derivatives. In short, the rule says that if the limits of functions f and g at x=a are 0 (or ထ) and the limit of f'(x)/g'(x) at x=a is equal to L, then the limit of f(x)/g(x) at x=a is also equal to L.

name: Review: Derivative applications (Applications of derivatives)
blurb: Review your understanding of the various applications of differential calculus with some challenge problems.

name: Antiderivatives (Indefinite Integrals)
blurb: If f' is the derivative of f, then f is the antiderivative of f'. To find the antiderivative of a function we need to perform some kind of reverse differentiation. Learn about it here.

name: Indefinite integrals intro (Indefinite Integrals)
blurb: Indefinite integrals are the way integral calculus deals with antiderivatives. Gain some practice in finding various indefinite integrals.

name: Indefinite integrals of common functions (Indefinite Integrals)
blurb: Indefinite integrals (or antiderivatives) are really just backward differentiation. Therefore, the indefinite integral of eˣ is eˣ+c, the indefinite integral of 1/x is ln(x)+c, the indefinite integral of sin(x) is -cos(x)+c, and the indefinite integral of cos(x) is sin(x)+c.

name: Review: Indefinite integrals & antiderivatives (Indefinite Integrals)
blurb: Review your understanding of indefinite integrals and antiderivatives with some challenge problems.

name: Integration by parts (Indefinite Integrals)
blurb: Learn how to use the product rule in order to find the integral of a product of functions (sadly this is more complicated than using the product rule the regular way).

name: u-substitution (Indefinite Integrals)
blurb: u-substitution is an extremely useful technique. Harnessing the power of the chain rule, it allows us to define a new variable (common denoted by the letter u) as a function of x, and obtain a new expression which is (hopefully) easier to integrate.

name: Reverse chain rule (Indefinite Integrals)
blurb: Reverse chain rule is another, faster way to think about u-substitution.

name: Partial fraction expansion (Indefinite Integrals)
blurb: Learn a useful algebraic tool to find the integrals of some rational functions.

name: Integration using trigonometric identities (Indefinite Integrals)
blurb: Some integrals that contain trig functions demand that we manipulate those functions using trig identities in order to find the integral.

name: Trigonometric substitution (Indefinite Integrals)
blurb: Another super useful technique for computing integrals involves replacing variables with trigonometric functions. This can make things seem a little more complicated at first, but with the help of trigonometric identities, this technique makes certain integrals solvable.

name: Functions defined by integrals (Definite Integrals)
blurb: Get comfortable with functions that for any input x, return the area under a curve between a given bound and x. This is an important stop on our journey to relating differential and integral calculus.

name: Fundamental theorem of calculus (Definite Integrals)
blurb: The fundamental theorem of calculus is definitely one of the most important theorems of all time! It relates differential calculus and the concept of the derivative with integral calculus and the concept of the integral. Learn all about it here!

name: Fundamental theorem of calculus: chain rule (Definite Integrals)
blurb: Get better acquainted with the fundamental theorem of calculus, and apply it for a class of seemingly hairy problems.

name: Definite integral as area (Definite Integrals)
blurb: Introducing the definite integral. It's basically a way to represent the area under a given curve with left-hand and right-hand bounds.

name: Definite integral properties (Definite Integrals)
blurb: Definite integrals behave is specific ways with shared properties. For example, the sum of the definite integrals of a function f from a to b and from b to c is equal to the definite integral of f from a to c. Learn about these properties and use them in order to evaluate integrals.

name: Review: Definite integral basics (Definite Integrals)
blurb: Review your understanding of the basics of definite integrals with some challenge problems.

name: Definite integral evaluation (Definite Integrals)
blurb: The fundamental theorem tells us how we can evaluate definite integrals. Now let us  put this to use and evaluate some!

name: Definite integrals of piecewise functions (Definite Integrals)
blurb: Evaluate definite integrals of piecewise functions. This is where the definite integral properties come into good use.

name: Challenging definite integrals (Definite Integrals)
blurb: (No description)

name: Improper integrals (Definite Integrals)
blurb: Improper integrals are like definite integrals, only unbounded from the left and/or right. And yes, some of them have finite values. An unbounded area with a finite size? That's calculus to you!

name: Riemann sums (Definite Integrals)
blurb: Riemann sums is the name of a family of methods we can use to approximate the area under a curve. Learn about the different ways and how they are constructed.

name: Riemann sums with sigma notation (Definite Integrals)
blurb: The larger the number of terms in a Riemann sum, the more accurate it is. But as the number of terms increases, we need better ways to write them down. This is where sigma notation comes in very handy.

name: Trapezoidal rule (Definite Integrals)
blurb: The trapezoidal rule is yet another way to approximate the area under a curve. Learn about they way it's constructed and how accurate it is comparing the rectangular Riemann sums.

name: Definite integral as the limit of a Riemann sum (Definite Integrals)
blurb: The definite integral of a function is the limit of a sequence of Riemann sums where the intervals become infinitely small. Learn more about this formal definition.

name: Review: Riemann sums (Definite Integrals)
blurb: Review your understanding of Riemann sums with some challenge problems.

name: Area under simple curves (Application of integrals)
blurb: After building a good understanding of integrals we will undertstand how to calculate the area under a curve by adding the area of numerous elementary strips and then we will extend it to calcuate the area of the region bounded by a curve and a line.

name: Area between two curves (Application of integrals)
blurb: Let us now extend our understanding of integrals to calculate areas by calculating the area between two curves.

name: Area defined by polar graphs (Application of integrals)
blurb: We're used to finding the area under curves in the Cartesian plane, but integration can be used to find area defined by polar curves too.

name: Arc length (optional) (Application of integrals)
blurb: Integral calculus isn't only useful for finding area. For example, it can also be used to find lengths of one-dimensional curves. Learn all about it here.

name: Intro to differential equations (Differential equations)
blurb: How is a differential equation different from a regular one?  Well, the solution is a function (or a class of functions), not a number.  How do you like me now (that is what the differential equation would say in response to your shock)!

name: Slope fields (optional) (Differential equations)
blurb: Slope fields are a tool we can use to analyze differential equations graphically. They don't demand any elaborate algebraic tool, which makes them easy to use.

name: Separable equations (Differential equations)
blurb: Arguably the 'easiest' class of differential equations.  Here we use our powers of algebra to "separate" the y's from the x's on two different sides of the equation and then we just integrate!

name: Homogeneous equations (Differential equations)
blurb:
In this equations, all of the fat is fully mixed in so it doesn't collect at the top.  No (that would be homogenized equations).

Actually, the term "homogeneous" is way overused in differential equations.  In this tutorial, we'll look at equations of the form y'=(F(y/x)).

name: Exact equations and integrating factors (Differential equations)
blurb: A very special class of often non-linear differential equations.  If you know a bit about partial derivatives, this tutorial will help you know how to 'exactly' solve these!

name: Vector basics (Vector algebra)
blurb: Learn the basics of vectors, like that a vector has both magnitude and direction.

name: Scalar multiplication (Vector algebra)
blurb: Multiply a vector by a scalar to get a new vector.

name: Magnitude of vectors (Vector algebra)
blurb: Find the magnitude of a vector given in component form.

name: Vector addition & subtraction (Vector algebra)
blurb: Combine two vectors by adding or subtracting them to get a new vector.

name: Combined vector operations (Vector algebra)
blurb: Use both scalar multiplication and vector addition or subtraction in the same problem!

name: Unit vectors (Vector algebra)
blurb: Learn about special vectors called unit vectors that have a magnitude of 1.

name: Magnitude & direction form of vectors (Vector algebra)
blurb: Think about how we can represent vectors using their magnitude and direction instead of their components.

name: Adding vectors in magnitude & direction form (Vector algebra)
blurb: Learn how to add two vectors together that are in magnitude and direction form. We can always use our old friend component form!

name: Component form of vectors (Vector algebra)
blurb: Convert vectors from magnitude and direction form to component form.

name: Applications of vectors (Vector algebra)
blurb: Apply what you've learned about vectors so far to solve some fun word problems.

name: Multiplication of a vector by a scalar (Vector algebra)
blurb: We will now learn how the multiplication of a vector by a scalar is defined.

name: Scalar product of two vectors (Vector algebra)
blurb: We know how to multiply number and we always get a number as a result. There are two ways to "multiply" vectors. In one of them, the result is a number and is called the scalar product or dot product of the two vectors. In the other, the result is a vector and is called the vector or cross product. Let us find out how to calculate and visualize the dot product of two vectors.

name: Vector product of two vectors (Vector algebra)
blurb: Now that we have a fair understanding of what a dot product is, let's learn what it means by a cross product of two vectors. Lets also intuitively compare the two.

name: Modeling with linear inequalities (Linear Programming)
blurb: Learn how to construct linear inequalities and systems of inequalities given a real-life context. Learn how to interpret such inequalities in terms of a real-life context, either algebraically or graphically.

name: Review: Multiplication rule for independent events (Probability of events)
blurb: What’s the probability that three people were all born on the same day of the week? How likely is a basketball player to make three shots in a row? In this tutorial, we’ll see that multiplying probabilities can be quite useful.

name: Review: Combinatorics and probability (Probability of events)
blurb: Once we understand the counting principle, permutations, and combinations, we can use those concepts to calculate some pretty advanced probabilities!

name: Multiplication rule for dependent events (Probability of events)
blurb: What’s the probability of drawing two aces in a row from a deck of cards? Getting an ace on the first card changes the probability for the second card. This tutorial covers how we can deal with that when multiplying probabilities.

name: Conditional probability and independence (Probability of events)
blurb: Conditional probability is the likelihood of some event occurring given some other event has occurred. You'll learn how to calculate conditional probability intuitively and with a formula called Bayes' theorem.

name: Conditional probability (Probability of events)
blurb: (No description)

name: Discrete and continuous random variables and probability models (Probability of events)
blurb: Discrete random variables occur in situations where we can list every possible outcome of a process, and assign each outcome a probability in a probability model. For example, how many heads will we get in three flips?

name: Expected value (Probability of events)
blurb: Expected value gives us the mean or long-term average number of success we can expect over time if we repeat a process over and over. For example, how much money can someone expect to win on average for each lottery ticket they buy?

name: Variance of random variables (Probability of events)
blurb: Transforming and combining random variables produces predictable changes in the expected value and variance of the outcomes.

name: Binomial random variables (Probability of events)
blurb: Binomial random variables are a special type of variable that comes up we repeat a process for a set number of independent trials, with each trial having the same probability of success, and we count how many successes we get at the end of the trials. For example, how many shots will a basketball player make in a series of 10 shots?

name: Poisson distribution (optional) (Probability of events)
blurb: The Poisson distribution is related to the binomial setting, but looks at the number of successes over time instead of over many repeated trials.

name: Comparing 3-digit numbers (Hindi) (Knowing our numbers (Hindi))
blurb: Learn how to compare three-digit numbers by thinking about place value (hundreds, tens, and ones).

name: Comparing multi-digit numbers (Hindi) (Knowing our numbers (Hindi))
blurb: Learn how to compare multi-digit numbers by thinking about place value (thousands, hundreds, tens, and ones).

name: Lakhs, crores, millions and billions (Hindi) (Knowing our numbers (Hindi))
blurb: Let's learn to play with large numbers involving lakhs, crores, millions, and billions.

name: Word problems involving lakhs and crores (Hindi) (Knowing our numbers (Hindi))
blurb: (No description)

name: System of measurement (Hindi) (Knowing our numbers (Hindi))
blurb: (No description)

name: Rounding (Hindi) (Knowing our numbers (Hindi))
blurb: Rounding is useful when you are trying to roughly estimate numbers.

name: Rounding whole numbers (Hindi) (Knowing our numbers (Hindi))
blurb: If you're looking to create an army of robot dogs, will it really make a difference if you have 10,300 dogs, 9,997 dogs or 10,005 dogs? Probably not. All you really care about is how many dogs you have to, say, the nearest thousand (10,000 dogs). In this tutorial, you'll learn about conventions for rounding whole numbers. Very useful when you might not need to (or cannot) be completely precise.  Common Core Standard: 4.NBT.A.3

name: Roman numerals (Hindi) (Knowing our numbers (Hindi))
blurb: (No description)

name: Number line of whole numbers (Hindi) (Whole Numbers (Hindi))
blurb: (No description)

name: Arithmetic properties of whole numbers (Hindi)  (Whole Numbers (Hindi))
blurb: (No description)

name: Distributive property (Hindi) (Whole Numbers (Hindi))
blurb: (No description)

name: Factors and multiples (Hindi) (Playing with numbers (Hindi))
blurb: In this tutorial, we'll begin to think about the numbers that "make up" the number. This will be useful throughout our study of math. Whether we are adding fractions, exploring mystical number patterns, or breaking computer codes, factoring numbers are key! Let's go, kids!  Common Core Standard: 4.OA.B.4

name: Prime and composite numbers (Hindi) (Playing with numbers (Hindi))
blurb: Prime numbers have been studied by mathematicians and mystics for ages (seriously). They are both basic and mysterious. The more you explore them, the more you will realize that the universe is a fascinating place. This tutorial will introduce you to the magical world of prime numbers as well as their composite number brethren.  Common Core Standard: 4.OA.B.4

name: Divisibility tests (Hindi) (Playing with numbers (Hindi))
blurb: (No description)

name: Prime factorisation (Hindi) (Playing with numbers (Hindi))
blurb: (No description)

name: Common factors and multiples (Hindi) (Playing with numbers (Hindi))
blurb: (No description)

name: Lowest common multiple (Hindi) (Playing with numbers (Hindi))
blurb: (No description)

name: Highest common factor (Hindi) (Playing with numbers (Hindi))
blurb: (No description)

name: Lines, line segments, and rays (Hindi) (Basic geometrical ideas (Hindi))
blurb: Let's draw points, lines, line segments, and rays.  We'll also think about perpendicular and parallel lines and identify these in two-dimensional figures.  Common Core Standard: 4.G.A.1

name: Angle introduction (Hindi) (Basic geometrical ideas (Hindi))
blurb: What is an angle and how do we label, measure and construct them? Great question. Luckily we have all your answers! To begin our journey towards understanding angles, we'll learn terms like vertex, acute, obtuse, circle arc, circumference, and protractor. These basic angle concepts will get you on the road to angle domination!

name: Introduction to polygons (Hindi) (Basic geometrical ideas (Hindi))
blurb: Learn how different shapes have different numbers of corners, different side lengths, and so on. Use these properties to help you recognize shapes.

name: Curves and polygons (Hindi) (Basic geometrical ideas (Hindi))
blurb: Let's identify parts of a circle

name: Angle types (Hindi) (Understanding elementary shapes (Hindi))
blurb: Now that we know what angles are, let's dig a bit deeper and classify them and understand their properties better. Acute, obtuse, right, adjacent--all are angles that we will be become familiar with.

name: Measuring angles (Hindi) (Understanding elementary shapes (Hindi))
blurb: Learn how to measure angles using a protractor.

name: Constructing angles (Hindi) (Understanding elementary shapes (Hindi))
blurb: Learn how to draw angles using a protractor.

name: Parallel and perpendicular (Hindi) (Understanding elementary shapes (Hindi))
blurb: Learn the definitions of "parallel" and "perpendicular".

name: Classifying triangles (Hindi) (Understanding elementary shapes (Hindi))
blurb: Triangles can be classified in different ways. In this tutorial, we'll learn about scalene, isosceles, equilateral, acute, right, and obtuse triangles.

name: Quadrilaterals (Hindi)  (Understanding elementary shapes (Hindi))
blurb: Classify quadrilaterals, including rectangles, rhombuses, and squares.  See what attributes they have in common and which ones make them unique.

name: Geometric solids (3D shapes) (Hindi) (Understanding elementary shapes (Hindi))
blurb: Identify 3-dimensional figures and their parts (faces, edges, vertices).

name: Intro to negative numbers (Hindi) (Integers (Hindi))
blurb: What are negative numbers? When do we use them? Where do we find them on the number line? Let's learn what happens in the world below zero!

name: Number opposites (Hindi) (Integers (Hindi))
blurb: Opposite numbers are the same distance from 0 on opposite sides of the number line. A number opposite is sometimes called an additive inverse.

name: Absolute value (Hindi) (Integers (Hindi))
blurb: You'll find absolute value absolutely straightforward--it is just the "distance from zero". If you have a positive number, it is its own absolute value. If you have a negative number, just make it positive to get the absolute value. As you see as you develop mathematically, this idea will eventually extended to more contexts and dimensions, so super important that you understand this core concept now.

name: Order integers (Hindi) (Integers (Hindi))
blurb: We all know that 6 is bigger than 4, but is -6 bigger than -4? This tutorial is designed to help you compare negative numbers.

name: Introduction to adding integers (Hindi) (Integers (Hindi))
blurb: Learn how to add negative numbers. By the end of this tutorial, you'll be solving problems like 4 + (-7) with ease!

name: Introduction to subtracting integers (Hindi) (Integers (Hindi))
blurb: Learn why subtracting a negative number is the same as adding its opposite!

name: Adding & subtracting integers (Hindi) (Integers (Hindi))
blurb: Add and subtract negative numbers using a number line. It's the 7th grade mathematics shuffle: "Slide to the left for a negative value, and slide to the right for a positive value." Be careful, though. Which way do you move if you are subtracting a negative number? The answer awaits!

name: Adding & subtracting with negatives on the number line (Hindi) (Integers (Hindi))
blurb: Learn how to use number lines to solve negative number addition and subtraction problems.

name: Fractions intro (Hindi) (Fractions (Hindi))
blurb: Learn what a fraction is and identify unit fractions.

name: Fractions on the number line (Hindi) (Fractions (Hindi))
blurb: Learn to identify fractions on a number line.

name: Fractions and whole numbers (Hindi) (Fractions (Hindi))
blurb: Learn how to represent fractions as whole numbers and whole numbers as fractions.

name: Equivalent fractions (Hindi)  (Fractions (Hindi))
blurb: Learn how to find equivalent fractions by multiplying the numerator and denominator by the same number.

name: Equivalent fractions on the number line (Hindi) (Fractions (Hindi))
blurb: Learn how to identify fractions on a number line.

name: Common denominators (Hindi) (Fractions (Hindi))
blurb: Using our knowledge of equivalent fractions, let's rewrite fractions to have the same denominator.

name: Comparing fractions (Hindi) (Fractions (Hindi))
blurb: In this tutorial, we'll practice understanding what quantities fractions actually represent and comparing those to each other.

name: Mixed numbers (Hindi) (Fractions (Hindi))
blurb: Learn how to write improper fractions as mixed numbers (and mixed numbers as improper fractions).

name: Decomposing fractions (Hindi) (Fractions (Hindi))
blurb: (No description)

name: Adding and subtracting fractions with like denominators (Hindi) (Fractions (Hindi))
blurb: Learn how to add and subtract fractions. This is an introductory tutorial, so the fractions you add and subtract have the same denominators.

name: Visually adding and subtracting fractions with unlike denominators (Hindi) (Fractions (Hindi))
blurb: An introduction to adding and subtracting fractions with unlike denominators that uses visual fraction models

name: Adding and subtracting fractions with unlike denominators (Hindi) (Fractions (Hindi))
blurb: Learn how to add and subtract fractions that have different denominators.

name: Adding and subtracting mixed numbers (Hindi) (Fractions (Hindi))
blurb: Learn how to add and subtract mixed numbers. This is an introductory tutorial, so the fractions you add and subtract have the same denominators.

name: Adding and subtracting mixed number with unlike denominators (Hindi) (Fractions (Hindi))
blurb: Learn how to add and subtract mixed numbers whose fractional parts have different denominators.

name: Adding and subtracting fractions with unlike denominators word problems (Hindi) (Fractions (Hindi))
blurb: Practice solving word problems by adding and subtracting fractions that have different denominators.

name: Intro to decimals (Hindi) (Decimals (Hindi))
blurb: What are decimal numbers? How are they like fractions?

name: Decimal place value intro (Hindi) (Decimals (Hindi))
blurb: Learn the basics of decimal place value.

name: Decimals in expanded form (Hindi) (Decimals (Hindi))
blurb: Learn how to write a decimal like 3.14 in expanded form (3 + 0.1 + 0.04).

name: Decimals in written form (Hindi) (Decimals (Hindi))
blurb: Learn how to write decimals like 3.14 in words as "three and fourteen hundredths".

name: Comparing decimal place values (Hindi) (Decimals (Hindi))
blurb: For a number like 34.135, learn how to compare the 3 in the tens place to the 3 in the hundredths place.

name: Comparing decimals (Hindi) (Decimals (Hindi))
blurb: Learn to tell which of two decimal numbers is bigger by thinking about place value.

name: Decimals on the number line (Hindi) (Decimals (Hindi))
blurb: See how decimals can be placed on the number line, just like fractions and whole numbers can.

name: Rewriting decimals as fractions (Hindi) (Decimals (Hindi))
blurb: Learn how to rewrite decimals as fractions.

name: Common fractions and decimals (Hindi) (Decimals (Hindi))
blurb: Learn about common fractions and their decimal forms like 1 /2 = 0.5, 3/4 = 0.75, and 2/5 = 0.4.

name: Adding decimals (Hindi) (Decimals (Hindi))
blurb: You get the general idea of decimals and what the digits in different places represent (place value). Now you're ready to do something with the decimals. Adding and subtracting is a good place to start. This will allow you to add your family's expenses to figure out if your little brother is laundering money (perhaps literally). Have fun!  Common Core Standard: 5.NBT.B.7

name: Adding decimals: standard algorithm (Hindi)  (Decimals (Hindi))
blurb: Honestly, once you remember one very important rule, the rest of adding and subtracting decimals is a snap. That rule is to be sure and align your decimals first. In this tutorial, you'll get a chance to practice this with us and become fluent adding decimals. We'll tackle subtracting decimals in the next tutorial.

name: Subtracting decimals (Hindi) (Decimals (Hindi))
blurb: Anything you can do with whole numbers, you can do with decimals.  Subtraction is no exception.  In this tutorial, you'll get some good practice subtracting decimals up the hundredths place.

name: Subtracting decimals: standard algorithm (Hindi)  (Decimals (Hindi))
blurb: Just like with adding decimals, the key to subtracting decimals is aligning the decimal points. Let's practice!

name: Adding and subtracting decimals word problems (Hindi) (Decimals (Hindi))
blurb: In this tutorial, we practice solving word problems by adding and subtracting decimal numbers.

name: Introduction to data handling (Hindi) (Data Handling (Hindi))
blurb: Data handling involves collecting, organising and interpreting data. Let's learn more about these.

name: Pictographs (Picture graphs) (Hindi) (Data Handling (Hindi))
blurb: Read and interpret picture graphs.  Also, make some graphs of your own!

name: Bar graphs (Hindi) (Data Handling (Hindi))
blurb: Learn how to read and make bar graphs.

name: Count unit squares to find area (Hindi) (Mensuration (Hindi))
blurb: Find area of shapes by counting unit squares.  Some shapes will require combining partial square units to find area.  Create rectangles with a given area by covering unit squares.

name: Multiply to find area (Hindi) (Mensuration (Hindi))
blurb: Find area of rectangles by multiplying side lengths.  Find a missing side length of a rectangle when given the other side length and area.  Compare areas of rectangles presented in images or contexts.

name: Area and the distributive property (Hindi) (Mensuration (Hindi))
blurb: Use the distributive property to find area of rectangles.

name: Decompose figures to find area (Hindi) (Mensuration (Hindi))
blurb: Decompose figures into two to three rectangles to find area of entire figure.

name: Perimeter (Hindi) (Mensuration (Hindi))
blurb: Have you ever wondered how much fencing you need to surround a plot of land? No? Well, you should still go through this tutorial just in case. You'll learn what perimeter is and how to calculate it.

name: Comparing area and perimeter (Hindi) (Mensuration (Hindi))
blurb: Compare the areas and perimeters of rectangles when given a context or picture.

name: Area word problems (Hindi) (Mensuration (Hindi))
blurb: Let's solve some real-world problems involving areas of rectangles.

name: Perimeter word problems (Hindi) (Mensuration (Hindi))
blurb: Solve real world problems problems involving perimeter.

name: Overview and history of algebra (Hindi) (Algebra (Hindi))
blurb: (No description)

name: Intro to variables (Hindi) (Algebra (Hindi))
blurb: Wait, why are we using letters in math? How can an 'x' represent a number? What number is it? This tutorial is great if you're just beginning to delve into the world of variables and expressions.

name: Substitution & evaluating expressions (Hindi) (Algebra (Hindi))
blurb: Learn how to substitute (or "plug in") values for variables and evaluate algebraic expressions.

name: Writing algebraic expressions introduction (Hindi) (Algebra (Hindi))
blurb: Learn the basics of writing expressions with variables.

name: Writing basic algebraic expressions word problems (Hindi) (Algebra (Hindi))
blurb: Learn how to write algebraic expressions (expressions with variables) to model real-world situations.

name: Uses of variables in common rules (Hindi) (Algebra (Hindi))
blurb: (No description)

name: Algebraic equations basics (Hindi) (Algebra (Hindi))
blurb: Explore what it means for equations with variables (algebraic equations) to be solved.

name: Copy of Introduction to ratios (Ratio and proportion (Hindi))
blurb: Ratios show up everywhere in life—sports, finance, medicine, cooking, you name it! In this tutorial, we learn what ratios are and how to use them.

name: Copy of Copy of Ratio word problems (Ratio and proportion (Hindi))
blurb: Practice solving ratio word problems like, "If 60 cherries go in 3 pies, how many cherries go in 9 pies?"

name: Copy of Copy of Introduction to rates (Ratio and proportion (Hindi))
blurb: Learn about a special type of ratio called a rate. A rate is the ratio of two measurements that have different units such as 10 kilometers per hour or 12 hot dogs per minute!

name: Copy of Identifying proportional relationships (Ratio and proportion (Hindi))
blurb: Learn how to tell whether two quantities are proportional by thinking about equivalent ratios and drawing graphs.

name: Copy of Writing & solving proportions (Ratio and proportion (Hindi))
blurb: Learn how to write proportions and how to solve proportions.

name: Line of symmetry (Symmetry (Hindi))
blurb: A line of symmetry for a two-dimensional figure is a line across the figure such that the figure can be folded along the line into matching parts. In this tutorial, we'll identify line-symmetric figures and draw lines of symmetry.  Common Core Standard: 4.G.A.3

name: Copy of Constructing angles (Practical geometry (Hindi))
blurb: A shape, formed by two lines or rays diverging from a common point (the vertex). In this topic we will learn how to construct basic angles using compass and straightedge using the bisector technique.

name: Integer addition and subtraction review (Hindi) (Integers (Hindi))
blurb: Let's practice adding and subtracting negative numbers.

name: Integers arithmetic properties (Hindi) (Integers (Hindi))
blurb: (No description)

name: Multiply & divide negative numbers (Hindi) (Integers (Hindi))
blurb: You already know how to multiply and divide whole numbers, decimals, and fractions. See what happens when we throw negative numbers into the mix. It's really not so different!

name: Integer word problems (Hindi) (Integers (Hindi))
blurb: Let's add, subtract, multiply, and divide negative numbers to solve a few problems we may see in the "real-world".

name: Adding and subtracting fractions review (optional) (Hindi) (Fractions and Decimals (Hindi))
blurb: Let's practice adding and subtracting fractions as a warm-up before we learn how to multiply and divide fractions.

name: Multiplying unit fractions and whole numbers (Hindi) (Fractions and Decimals (Hindi))
blurb: Learn how to multiply unit fractions and whole numbers.

name: Multiplying whole numbers and fractions (Hindi) (Fractions and Decimals (Hindi))
blurb: Learn the art of multiplying whole numbers by fractions. See how 3 times 2/3 is the same as 6 times 1/3, which is the same as 6/3.

name: Multiplication as scaling (Hindi) (Fractions and Decimals (Hindi))
blurb: Learn to see multiplication as a way to grow (scale up) and shrink (scale down) other numbers.

name: Multiplying fractions (Hindi) (Fractions and Decimals (Hindi))
blurb: Learn how to multiply a fraction by a fraction.

name: Multiplying mixed numbers (Hindi) (Fractions and Decimals (Hindi))
blurb: Learn how to multiply mixed numbers.

name: Multiplying fractions word problems (Hindi) (Fractions and Decimals (Hindi))
blurb: Get some practice solving word problems by multiplying fractions.

name: Fractions as division (Hindi) (Fractions and Decimals (Hindi))
blurb: **Spoiler Alert!** The fraction bar and the division symbol are really saying the same thing.

name: Dividing unit fractions by whole numbers (Hindi) (Fractions and Decimals (Hindi))
blurb: Learn how to divide unit fractions by whole numbers. Example: 1/5 ÷ 3 = 1/15.

name: Dividing whole numbers by unit fractions (Hindi) (Fractions and Decimals (Hindi))
blurb: Learn how to divide whole numbers by unit fractions. Example: 4 ÷ 1/3 = 12.

name: Dividing fractions by fractions (Hindi) (Fractions and Decimals (Hindi))
blurb: Learn how to divide fractions by other fractions.

name: Dividing fractions word problems (Hindi) (Fractions and Decimals (Hindi))
blurb: Practice solving word problems with fraction division.

name: Adding and subtraction decimals review (optional) (Hindi) (Fractions and Decimals (Hindi))
blurb: Let's practice adding and subtracting decimals as a warm-up before we learn how to multiply and divide decimals.

name: Multiplying decimals (Hindi) (Fractions and Decimals (Hindi))
blurb: The real world is seldom about whole numbers. If you precisely measure anything, you're likely to get a decimal. If you don't know how to multiply these decimals, then you won't be able to do all the powerful things that multiplication can do in the real world (figure out your commission as a robot possum salesperson, determining how much shag carpet you need for your secret lair, etc.).

name: Multiplying decimals: standard algorithm (Hindi) (Fractions and Decimals (Hindi))
blurb: You've already multiplied decimals in the 5th grade. We'll show you some ways to handle slightly more complicated problems. Now you'll become super good at it with a bit more practice!  Common Core Standard: 6.NS.B.3

name: Dividing decimals (Hindi) (Fractions and Decimals (Hindi))
blurb: In this tutorial, we'll extend our division skills to include decimals! We get into some pretty fun stuff here including dividing decimals by whole numbers, and dividing whole numbers by decimals. Finally...dividing decimals by decimals.  Common Core Standard 5.NBT.B.7

name: Dividing decimals: standard algorithm (Hindi) (Fractions and Decimals (Hindi))
blurb: Learn long division with decimals. Solve problems like 30.24 divided by 0.42.

name: Algebraic equations basics (Hindi) (Simple equations (Hindi))
blurb: Explore what it means for equations with variables (algebraic equations) to be solved.

name: One-step equations intuition (Hindi) (Simple equations (Hindi))
blurb: A high-level, conceptual walk-through of what an equation represents and why we do the same thing to both sides of it

name: One-step addition & subtraction equations (Hindi) (Simple equations (Hindi))
blurb: Solve equations by adding and subtracting numbers from both sides.

name: One-step multiplication and division equations (Hindi) (Simple equations (Hindi))
blurb: Solve equations by multiplying and dividing numbers from both sides.

name: One-step equation word problems (Hindi) (Simple equations (Hindi))
blurb: Let's use our algebra tools to solve a problem of earth-shattering importance: which Super Yoga plan is the best value! In this word problem, you'll put to practice your knowledge of variables, substitution, and one-step equations.

name: Two-steps equations intro (Hindi) (Simple equations (Hindi))
blurb: Learn how to solve equations like 2x+7=13 and 3(x+4)=3, which can be solved in two steps.

name: Two-step equation word problems (Hindi) (Simple equations (Hindi))
blurb: Learn how to set up and solve equations to find answers to real-world questions.

name: Vertical, complementary, and supplementary angles (Hindi) (Lines and angles (Hindi))
blurb: Learn three types of angle pairs: vertical angles, complementary angles, and supplementary angles.

name: Angles between intersecting lines (Hindi) (Lines and angles (Hindi))
blurb: This tutorial introduces us to angles.  It includes how we measure them, how angles relate to each other and properties of angles created from various types of intersecting lines.  Mr. Angle is actually far more fun than you might initially presume him to be.

name: Exterior angle property of a triangle (Hindi) (The triangle and its properties (Hindi))
blurb: Let's learn what the exterior angle of a triangle is and how the exterior angle property connects it to the angles of a triangle.

name: Triangle angles (Hindi) (The triangle and its properties (Hindi))
blurb:
Do the angles in a triangle always add up to the same thing?  Would I ask it if they didn't?  What do we know about the angles of a triangle if two of the sides are congruent (an isosceles triangle) or all three are congruent (an equilateral)?  This tutorial is the place to find out.

Common Core Standard: 8.G.A.5

name: Equilateral and isosceles triangles (Hindi) (The triangle and its properties (Hindi))
blurb: (No description)

name: Triangle inequality theorem (Hindi) (The triangle and its properties (Hindi))
blurb:
The triangle inequality theorem is, on some level, kind of simple.  But, as you'll see as you go into high level mathematics, it is often used in fancy proofs.

This tutorial introduces you to what it is and gives you some practice understanding the constraints on the dimensions of a triangle.

name: Pythagoras theorem (Hindi) (The triangle and its properties (Hindi))
blurb:
Named after the Greek philosopher who lived nearly 2600 years ago, the Pythagorean theorem is as good as math theorems get (Pythagoras also started a religious movement).  It's simple.  It's beautiful.  It's powerful.

Common Core Standards: 8.G.B.7, 8.G.B.8

name: Triangle congruence (Hindi) (Congruence of triangles (Hindi))
blurb: Learn how the definition of congruence using rigid transformations can be simplified to simple criteria when studying congruent triangles.

name: Area and perimeter (Hindi) (Perimeter and area - hindi)
blurb: Rectangles are common shapes that you will often find the need to compare. Who has a bigger poster size? Whose yard has more grass to mow? We'll learn about length, width, area, and perimeter--about all you need to know to begin comparing!

name: Area of parallelograms (Hindi) (Perimeter and area - hindi)
blurb: Understand the formula for the area of a parallelogram.

name: Area of triangles (Hindi) (Perimeter and area - hindi)
blurb: Understand the formula for the area of a triangle.

name: Area of shapes on grids (Perimeter and area - hindi)
blurb: Area problems involving triangles and quadrilaterals on grids

name: Area and circumference of circles (Hindi) (Perimeter and area - hindi)
blurb: A circle is at the foundation of geometry, and at the foundation of a circle is a special number called Pi. This number allows us to relate the radius, diameter, and circumference of a circle.

name: Area of composite figures (Hindi) (Perimeter and area - hindi)
blurb: Finding the area of more complex shapes like trapezoids and composite figures (shapes built from other shapes)

name: Area unit conversions (Hindi) (Perimeter and area - hindi)
blurb: Let's learn how to convert between square centimetres, square metres, square millimetres, and square kilometres.

name: The constituents of an expression (Hindi) (Algebraic expressions - Hindi)
blurb: Learn new words, such as "term" and "coefficient", which help us communicate about the different parts expressions.

name: Combining like terms- part 1/2 (Hindi) (Algebraic expressions - Hindi)
blurb: Combine the powers of Chuck Norris and polar bears to understand how to combine like terms.

name: Combining like terms- part 2/1 (Algebraic expressions - Hindi)
blurb: Learn how to combine like terms (with negative numbers and variables), including more complex problems involving the distributive property.

name: Adding & subtracting algebraic expressions (Hindi) (Algebraic expressions - Hindi)
blurb: Learn how to add and subtract polynomial expressions with one variable.

name: Adding and subtracting algebraic expressions : two variables (Hindi) (Algebraic expressions - Hindi)
blurb: Learn how to add and subtract polynomial that involve two variables. For example, x^3 + xy + 3y - (x^3 + 6xy + 2y^2).

name: Finding the value of an expression (Hindi) (Algebraic expressions - Hindi)
blurb: The value of an algebraic expression depends on the values of the variables forming the expression. There are a number of situations in which we need to find the value of an expression, such as when we wish to check whether a particular value of a variable satisfies a given equation or not. Let's understand in detail what we mean by this!

name: Number patterns (Hindi) (Algebraic expressions - Hindi)
blurb: Let's explore how numbers can grow in different ways and use what we learn to figure out where they can go.  We think you'll find this tutorial on number patterns more fun that you do :)

name: Exponents (Hindi) (Exponents and powers - hindi)
blurb:
Addition was nice.  Multiplication was cooler.  In the mood for a new operation that grows numbers even faster?  Ever felt like expressing repeated multiplication with less writing?  Ever wanted to describe how most things in the universe grow and shrink?  Well, exponents are your answer!

This tutorial covers everything from basic exponents to negative and fractional ones.  It assumes you remember your multiplication, negative numbers and fractions.

name: Exponent properties- part 1/1 (Hindi) (Exponents and powers - hindi)
blurb: (No description)

name: Exponent properties (Hindi) (Exponents and powers - hindi)
blurb:
Tired of hairy exponent expressions?  Feel compelled to clean them up?  Well, this tutorial might just give you the tools you need.

If you know a bit about exponents, you'll learn a ton more in this tutorial as you learn about the rules for simplifying exponents.

name: Two-steps equations intro (Hindi) (Linear equations in one variable (Hindi))
blurb: Learn how to solve equations like 2x+7=13 and 3(x+4)=3, which can be solved in two steps.

name: Old school equations with Sal (Hindi) (Linear equations in one variable (Hindi))
blurb: Some of Sal's oldest (and roughest) videos on algebra.  Great tutorial if you want to see what Khan Academy was like around 2006.  You might also like it if you feel like Sal has lost his magic now that he doesn't use the cheapest possible equipment to make the videos.

name: Linear equations with variables on both sides (Hindi) (Linear equations in one variable (Hindi))
blurb: (No description)

name: Linear equations with parentheses (Hindi) (Linear equations in one variable (Hindi))
blurb: Learn how to solve linear equations with parentheses using the distributive property. For example, solve -9 - (9x - 6) = 3(4x + 6).

name: Analyzing the number of solutions to linear equations (Hindi) (Linear equations in one variable (Hindi))
