name: Unit word problems (Measurement and data)
blurb: Now that you have some experience converting between units, let's apply that skill in some real-world problems (okay, some of them are a bit concocted, but it's all about the learning)! We'll tackle word problems that deal with distance, weight, volume, time, and more!   Common Core Standard: 5.MD.A.1

name: Data (Measurement and data)
blurb: Unit conversion and data points on a line plot.

name: Coordinate plane (Geometry)
blurb: How can we communicate exactly where something is in two dimensions?  In this tutorial, we cover the basics of the coordinate plane and graphing points.

name: Coordinate plane word problems (Geometry)
blurb: Represent real world problems by graphing points in the first quadrant of the coordinate plane, and interpret coordinate values of points in the context of the situation.

name: Quadrilaterals (Geometry)
blurb: Not all things with four sides and 90 degree angles are squares or rectangles! Sometimes the angles in these 4-sided shapes are less than (or greater than) 90 degrees, causing them to have a slightly odd shape. These are called quadrilaterals and come in a few different varieties. In this tutorial, you'll learn about them.  Common Core Standards: 5.G.B.3, 5.G.B.4

name: Writing expressions (Algebraic thinking)
blurb: In this tutorial, we will learn to describe situations using mathematical expressions, and consider the effect of using parentheses in the outcome of those expressions.

name: Number patterns (Algebraic thinking)
blurb: One of the fundamentals of algebra is learning to recognize patterns among numbers and being able to visualize those patterns and relationships. So...let's use some mathematical tools to visualize, interpret, and graph patterns involving the coordinate plane. Trust us, this sounds a lot more complicated than it really is. Just follow along and pause the videos as necessary. We're not going anywhere!

name: Intro to ratios (Ratios, rates, and percentages)
blurb: Ratios show up everywhere in life—sports, finance, medicine, cooking, you name it! In this tutorial, we learn what ratios are and how to use them.

name: Equivalent ratios (Ratios, rates, and percentages)
blurb: (No description)

name: Visualize ratios (Ratios, rates, and percentages)
blurb: Use double number lines, ratio tables, and tape diagrams to visualize ratios.

name: Ratio word problems (Ratios, rates, and percentages)
blurb: Expand on ratios by exploring part:part:whole ratios and ratios on the coordinate plane.

name: Introduction to rates (Ratios, rates, and percentages)
blurb: Learn about a special type of ratio called a rate. A rate is the ratio of two measurements that have different units such as 10 kilometers per hour or 12 hot dogs per minute!

name: Introduction to percentages (Ratios, rates, and percentages)
blurb: Percent literally means "per cent" or "per hundred". Visually identify percents from fraction models and identify equivalent fractions and percents.

name: Percent, decimal, fraction conversions (Ratios, rates, and percentages)
blurb: Decimals, fractions, and percents are three ways of expressing the same number. For example, 1/2, 0.5, and 50% mean the exact same thing. Learn how to convert decimals and fractions to percents and vice versa.

name: Percent problems (Ratios, rates, and percentages)
blurb: Learn how to solve percent problems like these: What is 80% of 25? Three is what percent of four?

name: Percent word problems (Ratios, rates, and percentages)
blurb: Learn how to solve a variety of word problems involving percentages.

name: Adding decimals (Arithmetic operations)
blurb: Honestly, once you remember one very important rule, the rest of adding and subtracting decimals is a snap. That rule is to be sure and align your decimals first. In this tutorial, you'll get a chance to practice this with us and become fluent adding decimals. We'll tackle subtracting decimals in the next tutorial.

name: Subtracting decimals (Arithmetic operations)
blurb: Just like with adding decimals, the key to subtracting decimals is aligning the decimal points. Let's practice!

name: Adding and subtracting decimals word problems (Arithmetic operations)
blurb: In this tutorial, we practice solving word problems by adding and subtracting decimal numbers.

name: Multiplying decimals (Arithmetic operations)
blurb: You've already multiplied decimals in the 5th grade. We'll show you some ways to handle slightly more complicated problems. Now you'll become super good at it with a bit more practice!  Common Core Standard: 6.NS.B.3

name: Division (Arithmetic operations)
blurb: Learn long division on whole numbers. Solve problems like 9815 divided by 65.

name: Dividing decimals (Arithmetic operations)
blurb: Learn long division with decimals. Solve problems like 30.24 divided by 0.42.

name: Dividing fractions by fractions (Arithmetic operations)
blurb: Learn how to divide fractions by other fractions.

name: Exponents (Arithmetic operations)
blurb: In 3rd grade, you learned that there is an easier way to write "5+5+5".  You saw that 5+5+5=3x5.  But is there an easier way to write repeated multiplication (like "5x5x5")?  Absolutely!  That's exactly what exponents are for!  Common Core Standard: 6.EE.A.1

name: Order of operations (Arithmetic operations)
blurb: In this tutorial, we learn the "order of operations" to evaluate more complex expressions involving exponents, parentheses, multiplication and division, and addition and subtraction.

name: Intro to negative numbers (Negative numbers)
blurb: What are negative numbers? When do we use them? Where do we find them on the number line? Let's learn what happens in the world below zero!

name: Negative decimals and fractions on the number line (Negative numbers)
blurb: Practice finding positive and negative decimals and fractions on the number line.

name: Number opposites (Negative numbers)
blurb: Opposite numbers are the same distance from 0 on opposite sides of the number line. A number opposite is sometimes called an additive inverse.

name: Comparing negative numbers (Negative numbers)
blurb: We all know that 6 is bigger than 4, but is -6 bigger than -4? This tutorial is designed to help you compare negative numbers.

name: Negative symbol as opposite (Negative numbers)
blurb: (No description)

name: Absolute value (Negative numbers)
blurb: You'll find absolute value absolutely straightforward--it is just the "distance from zero". If you have a positive number, it is its own absolute value. If you have a negative number, just make it positive to get the absolute value. As you see as you develop mathematically, this idea will eventually extended to more contexts and dimensions, so super important that you understand this core concept now.  Common Core Standards: 6.NS.C.7, 6.NS.C.7c, 6.NS.C.7d

name: Coordinate plane (Negative numbers)
blurb: We first explored the coordinate plane in the 5th grade, but that was only dealing with positive coordinates.  Now we know all about negative numbers so why not have negative coordinates as well? Let's get cozy with the x and y axis, plotting ordered pairs, quadrants, and reflection points. We got it covered. Sit back, relax, and get ready to groove with us.  Common Core Standards: 6.NS.C.6, 6.NS.C.6b, 6.NS.C.6c, 6.NS.C.8

name: Properties of numbers (Properties of numbers)
blurb: Learn the basic properties of addition and multiplication.

name: Whole numbers & integers (Properties of numbers)
blurb: Learn about the difference between the set of whole numbers and integers.

name: Least common multiple (Properties of numbers)
blurb: Life is good, but it can always get better. Just imagine being able to find the smallest number that is a multiple of two other numbers! It's called the LCM or Least Common Multiple. Other than making your life more fulfilling, lcm will allow you to do incredible things like adding fractions.  Common Core Standard: 6.NS.B.4

name: Greatest common factor (Properties of numbers)
blurb: You know how to find factors of a number, but what about factors that are common to two numbers? Even better, imagine the largest factors that are common to two numbers. These are called the greatest common factors (GCF) or sometimes greatest common divisors (GCD). Yay, acronyms! Too exciting!  Common Core Standard: 6.NS.B.4

name: Parts of algebraic expressions (Variables & expressions introduction)
blurb: Wait, why are we using letters in math? How can an 'x' represent a number? What number is it? We will also learn new words, such as "term" and "coefficient", which help us communicate about the different parts of expressions.  This tutorial is great if you're just beginning to delve into the world of variables and expressions.

name: Substitution & evaluating expressions (Variables & expressions introduction)
blurb: Learn how to substitute (or "plug in") values for variables and evaluate algebraic expressions.

name: Expression value intuition (Variables & expressions introduction)
blurb: Explore how the value of an algebraic expression changes as the value of its variable changes.

name: Evaluating expressions word problems (Variables & expressions introduction)
blurb: Learn how to plug in values to evaluate real-world expressions.

name: Writing algebraic expressions introduction (Variables & expressions introduction)
blurb: Learn the basics of writing expressions with variables.

name: Writing basic algebraic expressions word problems (Variables & expressions introduction)
blurb: Learn how to write algebraic expressions (expressions with variables) to model real-world situations.

name: Distributive property (Variables & expressions introduction)
blurb: Learn how to apply the distributive property to numerical expressions (without variables) and algebraic expressions (with variables). The distributive property is also sometimes called the distributive law.

name: Combining like terms (Variables & expressions introduction)
blurb: Combine the powers of Chuck Norris and polar bears to understand how to combine like terms.

name: Introduction to equivalent algebraic expressions (Variables & expressions introduction)
blurb: Learn to tell whether or not two algebraic expressions are equivalent by combining like terms and using the distributive property.

name: Algebraic equations basics (Equations & inequalities introduction)
blurb: Explore what it means for equations with variables (algebraic equations) to be solved.

name: Why we do the same thing to both sides of an equation (Equations & inequalities introduction)
blurb: A high-level, conceptual walk-through of what an equation represents and why we do the same thing to both sides of it

name: One-step addition & subtraction equations (Equations & inequalities introduction)
blurb: Solve equations by adding and subtracting numbers from both sides.

name: One-step multiplication and division equations (Equations & inequalities introduction)
blurb: Solve equations by multiplying and dividing numbers from both sides.

name: Finding mistakes in one-step equations (Equations & inequalities introduction)
blurb: Practice spotting the mistake in someone else's work as they attempt to solve one-step equations.

name: Super Yoga Plans (Equations & inequalities introduction)
blurb: Let's use our algebra tools to solve a problem of earth-shattering importance: which Super Yoga plan is the best value! In this word problem, you'll put to practice your knowledge of variables, substitution, and one-step equations.

name: Intro to inequalities with variables (Equations & inequalities introduction)
blurb: Algebraic inequalities (inequalities with variables) are useful for describing real-world situations. Learn how to write inequalities and graph them on the number line.

name: Dependent and independent variables (Equations & inequalities introduction)
blurb: Sometimes one variable depends on another. For example, the amount of money you make might depend on how many hours you work.

name: Areas of parallelograms (Geometry)
blurb: Understand the formula for the area of a parallelogram.

name: Areas of triangles (Geometry)
blurb: Understand the formula for the area of a triangle.

name: Area of trapezoids and composite figures (Geometry)
blurb: Finding the area of more complex shapes like trapezoids and composite figures (shapes built from other shapes)

name: Geometric solids (Geometry)
blurb: Identify 3-dimensional figures and their parts (faces, edges, vertices).

name: Volume with fractions (Geometry)
blurb: Finding the volume of rectangular prisms that have fractional side lengths

name: Surface area (Geometry)
blurb: Learn how to find the total area of the surfaces of 3D shapes. To do this, we wrap 3D shapes in 2D nets.

name: Polygons on the coordinate plane (Geometry)
blurb: Math problems that test your understanding of polygons and points on the coordinate plane

name: Dot plots & frequency tables (Data and statistics)
blurb: A dot plot is like a bar chart, but it displays data using dots (not bars). And a frequency table is like a dot plot, but it displays data in a simple table (not a fancy diagram).

name: Intro to statistics (Data and statistics)
blurb: Statistics help us answer many questions, but not all questions are statistical. In this tutorial, we'll learn to tell the difference between a statistical question and a non-statistical question.

name: Histograms (Data and statistics)
blurb: Histograms are similar to dot plots and bar graphs, but they work a little bit differently. In this tutorial, we'll learn how histograms work and when to use them.

name: Mean and median (Data and statistics)
blurb: Mean and median are measures of "central tendency." That is, they help us find the center (or middle) of the data. In this tutorial, we'll learn how to compute mean and median.

name: Mean and median challenge problems (Data and statistics)
blurb: Practice solving more challenging problems using your knowledge of mean and median.

name: Interquartile range (IQR) (Data and statistics)
blurb: Interquartile range (IQR) is a tool for reasoning about the spread of data. Higher values of IQR tell you the data is more spread out. Lower values of IQR tell you the data is closer together.

name: Box and whisker plots (Data and statistics)
blurb: Whether you're looking at scientific data or stock price charts, box-and-whisker plots can illuminate patterns in your life. This tutorial covers what they are, how to read them, and how to construct them.

name: Mean absolute deviation (MAD) (Data and statistics)
blurb: Mean absolute deviation (MAD) is a tool for reasoning about the spread of data, just like interquartile range (IQR). Higher values of MAD tell you the data is more spread out. Lower values of MAD tell you the data is closer together.

name: Comparing data displays (Data and statistics)
blurb: Learn how to interpret and compare dot plots, histograms, and box plots.

name: Shape of data distributions (Data and statistics)
blurb: Like people, no two data distributions look exactly the same. Well, maybe that's not always true... Anyway, the point is that each data distribution has it's own shape. In this tutorial, you'll learn new vocabulary that will have you discussing the shape of data distributions like a pro in no time!

name: Intro to adding negative numbers (Negative numbers: addition and subtraction)
blurb: Learn how to add negative numbers. By the end of this tutorial, you'll be solving problems like 4 + (-7) with ease!

name: Intro to subtracting negative numbers (Negative numbers: addition and subtraction)
blurb: Learn why subtracting a negative number is the same as adding its opposite!

name: Adding & subtracting with negatives on the number line (Negative numbers: addition and subtraction)
blurb: Learn how to use number lines to solve negative number addition and subtraction problems.

name: Adding & subtracting integers (Negative numbers: addition and subtraction)
blurb: Add and subtract negative numbers using a number line. It's the 7th grade mathematics shuffle: "Slide to the left for a negative value, and slide to the right for a positive value." Be careful, though. Which way do you move if you are subtracting a negative number? The answer awaits!

name: Adding & subtracting negative fractions (Negative numbers: addition and subtraction)
blurb: Learn how to add and subtract fractions, even when they're negative.

name: Addition & subtraction word problems with negatives (Negative numbers: addition and subtraction)
blurb: See how adding and subtracting negative numbers can be used in different situations.

name: Absolute value (Negative numbers: addition and subtraction)
blurb: Find the distance between any two numbers using absolute value.

name: Properties of addition & subtraction (Negative numbers: addition and subtraction)
blurb: Apply the properties of addition and subtraction to negative numbers.

name: Adding & subtracting negative numbers with variables (Negative numbers: addition and subtraction)
blurb: Feeling positive about all of this negative number stuff? Challenge yourself to solve some more advanced problems, including expressions with variables.

name: Multiply & divide negative numbers (Negative numbers: multiplication and division)
blurb: You already know how to multiply and divide whole numbers, decimals, and fractions. See what happens when we throw negative numbers into the mix. It's really not so different!

name: Multiplication & division word problems with negatives (Negative numbers: multiplication and division)
blurb: Explore the meaning of negative numbers in different situations.

name: Understanding multiplying and dividing fractions (Negative numbers: multiplication and division)
blurb: Solve more complex multiplication and division problems involving negative fractions.

name: Multiply & divide negative fractions (Negative numbers: multiplication and division)
blurb: We've already multiplied and divided fractions, and we've also multiplied and divided negative numbers. Now we combine those skills.

name: Order of operations (Negative numbers: multiplication and division)
blurb: In this tutorial, we'll start by learning why we need order of operations and build all the way up to evaluating challenging order of operations expressions involving negative numbers.

name: Properties of multiplication and division (Negative numbers: multiplication and division)
blurb: See how the properties of multiplication & division apply to negative numbers.

name: Converting fractions to decimals (Fractions, decimals, & percentages)
blurb: This tutorial guides you through two very important skills: converting fractions to decimals and converting decimals to fractions.

name: Adding & subtracting rational numbers (Fractions, decimals, & percentages)
blurb: We're going to mix it up a little in this set of examples. Remember that a rational number is a real number that can be written as a simple fraction, or by extension a decimal or percentage. We have to be able to add and subtract numbers when they are in different formats, whether fraction, decimal or percentage. This gets to be fun as we learn to move between these expressions of rational numbers, and start to understand they're all pointing to same thing!  Common Core Standards: 7.NS.A.1d

name: Percent word problems (Fractions, decimals, & percentages)
blurb: At least 50% of the math that you end up doing in your real life will involve percentages.  We're not really sure about that figure, but it sounds authoritative.  Anyway, unless you've watched this tutorial, you're really in no position to argue otherwise.   Common Core Standards: 7.EE.B.3

name: Rational number word problems (Fractions, decimals, & percentages)
blurb: You already have many tools in your mathematical toolkit: addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division of decimals and fractions, as well as your understanding of units of measure. Now we'll put them all to work in solving some multi-step word problems.  Common Core Standards: 7.EE.B.3

name: Rate problems with fractions (Rates & proportional relationships)
blurb: Learn how to compute rates associated with ratios of fractions or decimals. For example, if you run 6.5 meters in 1.5 seconds, what is your speed in meters per second?

name: Constant of proportionality (Rates & proportional relationships)
blurb: Identify the constant of proportionality (unit rate) in tables, graphs, equations, diagrams, and verbal descriptions of proportional relationships.

name: Constant of proportionality (Rates & proportional relationships)
blurb: Interpret the meaning of constants of proportionality and compare constants of proportionality in different formats.

name: Identifying proportional relationships (Rates & proportional relationships)
blurb: Learn how to tell whether two quantities are proportional by thinking about equivalent ratios and drawing graphs.

name: Graphs of proportional relationships (Rates & proportional relationships)
blurb: Interpret graphs of proportional relationships.

name: Writing & solving proportions (Rates & proportional relationships)
blurb: Learn how to write proportions and how to solve proportions.

name: Equations of proportional relationships (Rates & proportional relationships)
blurb: Learn how to write equations of proportional relationships in the form y=kx.

name: Combining like terms (Algebraic expressions, equations, & inequalities)
blurb: Learn how to combine like terms (with negative numbers and variables), including more complex problems involving the distributive property.

name: The distributive property & equivalent expressions (Algebraic expressions, equations, & inequalities)
blurb: Learn how to factor and expand algebraic expressions (expressions with variables) by applying the distributive property.

name: Interpreting linear expressions (Algebraic expressions, equations, & inequalities)
blurb: Any expression (mathematical or otherwise) has meaning. Help us match the linear expression to the meaning options given. In some cases, more than one meaning may apply.

name: Two-step equations intro (Algebraic expressions, equations, & inequalities)
blurb: Learn how to solve equations like 2x+7=13 and 3(x+4)=3, which can be solved in two steps.

name: Two-step equations with decimals and fractions (Algebraic expressions, equations, & inequalities)
blurb: Get some practice solving two-step equations that involve decimals and fractions

name: Two-step equation word problems (Algebraic expressions, equations, & inequalities)
blurb: Learn how to set up and solve equations to find answers to real-world questions.

name: One-step inequalities (Algebraic expressions, equations, & inequalities)
blurb: Learn how to solve (mathematical) inequalities. A key concept in this tutorial is flipping the inequality sign when multiplying or dividing both sides by a negative number.

name: Two-step inequalities (Algebraic expressions, equations, & inequalities)
blurb: Learn how to solve more complex (mathematical) inequalities. Also learn to construct inequalities to model real-world situations.

name: Area and circumference of circles (Geometry)
blurb: A circle is at the foundation of geometry, and at the foundation of a circle is a special number called Pi. This number allows us to relate the radius, diameter, and circumference of a circle.

name: Area and circumference challenge problems (Geometry)
blurb: Problems that stretch your understanding of area and circumference of circles

name: Angles (Geometry)
blurb: Learn three types of angle pairs: vertical angles, complementary angles, and supplementary angles.

name: Unknown angle algebra problems (Geometry)
blurb: Practice finding missing angles in figures using your knowledge of vertical, supplementary, and complementary angles.

name: Constructing triangles (Geometry)
blurb: Let's practice making triangles and start thinking about when it's possible or impossible to make a triangle.

name: Slicing geometric shapes (Geometry)
blurb: When we slice (cut through) a 3D shape, we make a 2D shape called a cross section. In this tutorial, we think about the different cross sections we can make by slicing 3D shapes.

name: Scale copies (Geometry)
blurb: (No description)

name: Scale drawings (Geometry)
blurb: A map depicts objects much smaller than they are in real life. A map is a great example of a scale drawing. In this tutorial, we'll take a mathematical look at the nature of scale drawings.

name: Volume problems (Geometry)
blurb: Learn to find volume of rings, triangular prisms, and rectangular prisms inside of other rectangular prisms.

name: Basic probability (Statistics and probability)
blurb: Flip a quarter a hundred times. What's the probability that it will turn up heads? Tails?    Even if we are unsure about whether something will happen, can we start to be mathematical about the "chances" of an event (essentially realizing that some things are more likely than others) occurring.  This tutorial will introduce us to the tools that allow us to think about random events and the logic behind comparing, judging, and finding the probabilities of those events.

name: Theoretical and experimental probability (Statistics and probability)
blurb: In many situations, we don't know exact probabilities, so we estimate probability based on history of events.

name: Compound events and sample spaces (Statistics and probability)
blurb: Learn about sample spaces and probability for compound events.  Learn the counting principle.

name: Comparing and sampling populations (Statistics and probability)
blurb: When we are trying to make a judgement about a population, it is often impractical (or impossible) to observe every member of the population.  Imagine trying to survey all 300+ million Americans to understand the likely outcome of the next presidential election!  Because of this, much of statistics is collecting data from a representative and random sample.  From the data collected from this random sample we can infer things about the greater population.

name: Repeating decimals (Numbers and operations)
blurb: Learn how to convert between repeating decimals and fractions.

name: Square roots & cube roots (Numbers and operations)
blurb: A strong contender for coolest symbol in mathematics is the radical. What is it? How does it relate to exponents? How is the square root different than the cube root? Learn all about square roots and cube roots in this tutorial.

name: Irrational numbers (Numbers and operations)
blurb: Learn what irrational numbers are. Also learn how to classify numbers as whole, integer, rational, and irrational.

name: Approximating irrational numbers (Numbers and operations)
blurb: The values of irrational numbers can't be written perfectly as decimals or fractions. However, we can approximate them, which is usually good enough. In this tutorial, we learn how to approximate and compare irrational numbers.

name: Exponents with negative bases (Numbers and operations)
blurb: Evaluate exponential expressions with negative bases, use odd and even rules to determine the sign of an exponential expression, and learn about powers of 1 and 0.

name: Exponent properties intro (Numbers and operations)
blurb: Learn the rules for simplifying exponent expressions.

name: Negative exponents (Numbers and operations)
blurb: It's normally a bad idea to hang around with negative people or do negative things, but we think it's OK to associate with negative exponents. As a matter of fact, we'll learn that positive and negative exponents have quite the opposite effect on their bases.

name: Exponent properties (integer exponents) (Numbers and operations)
blurb: Practice using the exponent properties to rewrite powers, where the exponent can either be positive or negative.

name: Working with powers of 10 (Numbers and operations)
blurb: This tutorial leads in to scientific notation. It features multiplication and division problems involving powers of 10.

name: Scientific notation intro (Numbers and operations)
blurb: Scientists and engineers often deal with super huge numbers like 6,000,000,000,000,000,000,000 and super small numbers like 0.0000000000532. How can they do this without tiring their hands out?  How can they look at a number and understand how large or small it is without counting the digits? The answer to both questions: scientific notation.

name: Computing with numbers in scientific notation (Numbers and operations)
blurb: Solve multiplication, division, addition, and subtraction problems involving numbers written in scientific notation.

name: Scientific notation word problems (Numbers and operations)
blurb: Solve word problems involving scientific notation.

name: Linear equations with variables on both sides (Solving equations)
blurb: Learn how to solve linear equations that have the variable on both sides of the equation. For example, solve 2x+5=6x-3.

name: Equations with parentheses (Solving equations)
blurb: Learn how to solve linear equations with parentheses using the distributive property. For example, solve -9 - (9x - 6) = 3(4x + 6).

name: Number of solutions to equations (Solving equations)
blurb: Linear equations can either have a single solution, infinite solutions, or no solutions. Learn how to determine the number of solutions to a given equation, and how to create equations with a desired number of solutions.

name: Equations word problems (Solving equations)
blurb: Solve word problems by creating linear equations and solving them.

name: Graphing proportional relationships (Linear equations and functions)
blurb: When you walk at a constant rate, the relationship between the distance you've walked and the time you've spent walking is proportional. In this tutorial, we learn about proportional relationships (constant rates) and their graphs.

name: Solutions to linear equations (Linear equations and functions)
blurb: Learn how to figure out if an ordered pair is a solution to a linear equation.

name: Intercepts (Linear equations and functions)
blurb: Learn about intercepts of a line.  Identify intercepts using a table, graph, and equation.

name: Slope (Linear equations and functions)
blurb: Learn about slope of a line and the slope formula.  Identify slope from a graph, two points, and an equation.

name: Intro to slope-intercept form (Linear equations and functions)
blurb: Make an introduction with the most common form of linear equations, slope-intercept form! For example, y=3x+5 is a linear equation in slope-intercept form.

name: slope-intercept form (Linear equations and functions)
blurb: Learn about the slope-intercept form of two-variable linear equations, and how to interpret it to find the slope and y-intercept of their line.  Find the slope-intercept equation of a line from its graph, a table, or two points.

name: Writing slope-intercept equations (Linear equations and functions)
blurb: Learn how to write the equation of a line (in slope-intercept form) when given the graph of the equation or two points on the line. For example, write the equation of the line that passes through the points (0,1) and (5,4).

name: Functions & function notation (Linear equations and functions)
blurb: Learn how to evaluate functions from a formula or graph.  Compare linear functions.

name: Linear models (Linear equations and functions)
blurb: Learn to use linear models to show relationships between two variables and represent them using a table, equation, or a graph.

name: Comparing linear functions (Linear equations and functions)
blurb: Compare features of linear functions, such as slope and intercepts, where the functions are given in different forms—tables, graphs, or formulas.

name: Constructing linear models for real-world relationships (Linear equations and functions)
blurb: Learn how to represent real-world relationships (that are described verbally) with linear graphs, equations, or functions.

name: Recognizing functions (Linear equations and functions)
blurb:
Relationships can be any association between sets of numbers while functions have only one output for a given input.  This tutorial works through a bunch of examples of testing whether something is a valid function.  As always, we really encourage you to pause the videos and try the problems before Sal does!

Common Core Standard: 8.F.A.1

name: Linear and nonlinear functions (Linear equations and functions)
blurb: Not every relationship in the universe can be represented by a line (in fact, most can't be).  We call these "nonlinear".  In this tutorial, you'll learn to tell the difference between a linear and nonlinear function! Have fun!

name: Intro to systems of equations (Systems of equations)
blurb: Whether in the real world or a cliche fantasy one, systems of equations are key to solving super-important issues like "the make-up of change in a troll's pocket". This tutorial shows you how to solve systems of equations graphically.

name: Systems of equations with graphing (Systems of equations)
blurb:
We already know that we can represent the set of all x-y pairs that satisfy a linear equation as a line.  If there is a point where two of these lines intersect, then the x-y pair corresponding to that point must satisfy both equations. 

Common Core Standards: 8.EE.C.8, 8.EE.C.8a

name: Solving systems with substitution (Systems of equations)
blurb:
This tutorial is focused on solving systems through substitution.  It has more examples than you can shake a dog at.  As always, pause the video and try to solve before Sal does.  Once you get a hang for things, feel free to skip the rest of the videos and try the exercises.  The best way to learn, after all, is to do rather than just listen!

Common Core Standards: 8.EE.C.8, 8.EE.C.8b

name: Number of solutions to systems of equations (Systems of equations)
blurb: Learn about the possible number of solutions of systems of linear equations. Spoiler: There can be a single solution, zero solutions, or infinite solutions. These different cases define the distinctions between "consistent" and "inconsistent" systems, and between "dependent" and "independent" systems.

name: Systems of equations word problems (Systems of equations)
blurb: Now that we are able to solve any kind of system we are given, it's time to use that knowledge to solve some word problems.

name: Angles between intersecting lines (Geometry)
blurb:
Welcome.  I'd like to introduce you to Mr. Angle.  Nice to meet you.  So nice to meet you.  

This tutorial introduces us to angles.  It includes how we measure them, how angles relate to each other and properties of angles created from various types of intersecting lines.  Mr. Angle is actually far more fun than you might initially presume him to be.

name: Triangle angles (Geometry)
blurb:
Do the angles in a triangle always add up to the same thing?  Would I ask it if they didn't?  What do we know about the angles of a triangle if two of the sides are congruent (an isosceles triangle) or all three are congruent (an equilateral)?  This tutorial is the place to find out.

Common Core Standard: 8.G.A.5

name: The Pythagorean theorem (Geometry)
blurb:
Named after the Greek philosopher who lived nearly 2600 years ago, the Pythagorean theorem is as good as math theorems get (Pythagoras also started a religious movement).  It's simple.  It's beautiful.  It's powerful.

Common Core Standards: 8.G.B.7, 8.G.B.8

name: Pythagorean theorem application (Geometry)
blurb: Apply the Pythagorean theorem to area and perimeter, 3D figures, and real world problems.

name: Pythagorean theorem and distance between points (Geometry)
blurb: Use the Pythagorean theorem to find the distance between points on a coordinate plane and the length of diagonal lines on a coordinate plane.

name: Pythagorean Theorem Proofs (Geometry)
blurb:
The Pythagorean theorem is one of the most famous ideas in all of mathematics.  This tutorial proves it.  Then proves it again... and again... and again.  More than just satisfying any skepticism of whether the Pythagorean theorem is really true (only one proof would be sufficient for that), it will hopefully open your mind to new and beautiful ways to prove something very powerful.

Common Core Standard: 8.G.B.6

name: Volume (Geometry)
blurb:
Let's see how to find the volumes of cylinders, spheres and other three dimensional shapes.

Common Core Standard: 8.G.C.9

name: Transformations (Geometric transformations)
blurb: Identify transformations, including translations, rotations, reflections, and dilations.

name: Translations (Geometric transformations)
blurb: Learn about transformations and how to perform them.

name: Rotations (Geometric transformations)
blurb: Learn about rotations and how to perform them.

name: Reflections (Geometric transformations)
blurb: Learn about reflections and how to perform them.

name: Properties & definitions of transformations (Geometric transformations)
blurb: Let's continue our deep voyage through the world of transformations! Use your knowledge about the precise descriptions of the rigid transformations and their properties in various situations.

name: Dilations (Geometric transformations)
blurb:
In addition to the three rigid transformation, there are the dilations, which expand or shrink figures while keeping the same proportions. These are extremely important in the subject of Similarity!

Gain experience by performing dilation, learn how to find the dilation that maps a given figure to another, and learn how to manually draw the image of a dilation.

name: Congruence and similarity (Geometric transformations)
blurb: Learn about congruence and similarity, specifically as they relate to transformations.  Learn to dilate shapes.

name: Introduction to scatter plots (Data and modeling)
blurb: Learn how to display data in two variables using scatter plots.

name: Interpreting scatter plots (Data and modeling)
blurb: Learn the basics of interpreting trends in scatter plots.

name: Estimating lines of best fit (Data and modeling)
blurb: When we display data on scatter plots, we often see trends. Sometimes these trends are linear, meaning that the data roughly follows the path of a line.

name: Two-way tables (Data and modeling)
blurb: Learn how to read, interpret, and use two-way frequency tables.

name: Basic addition and subtraction (Addition and subtraction)
blurb: Adding and subtracting is the basis of all mathematics.  This tutorial introduces you to one-digit addition and subtraction.

name: Addition and subtraction within 20 (Addition and subtraction)
blurb: Add and subtract numbers 20 or less.  Find the missing number in addition and subtraction equations.

name: Strategies for adding within 100 (Addition and subtraction)
blurb: Learn strategies for adding and subtracting 2-digit numbers.

name: Addition within 100 (Addition and subtraction)
blurb: Learn to add two-digit numbers like 37 and 49.

name: Subtraction within 100 (Addition and subtraction)
blurb: Learn to subtract two-digit numbers like 47 and 39.

name: Word problems within 100 (Addition and subtraction)
blurb: Learn how to solve addition and subtraction word problems. Numbers used 100 or less.

name: Adding with regrouping within 1000 (Addition and subtraction)
blurb: Learn how to add numbers like 259 + 363. These addition problems are a harder than the ones we've done before because they require regrouping (also called carrying).

name: Subtraction with regrouping within 1000  (Addition and subtraction)
blurb: Learn how to subtract numbers like 363 - 259. These subtraction problems are a harder than the ones we've done before because they require regrouping (also called borrowing).

name: Multiplication intro (Multiplication and division)
blurb: Welcome to the concept of multiplication.

name: Multiplication by tens, hundreds, and thousands (Multiplication and division)
blurb: Learn to multiply whole numbers by multiples of ten. Example: 7 x 500 = 3500

name: Multiplication: place value and area models (Multiplication and division)
blurb: Most people learn to multiply, but only a select-few actually understand what the multiplication represents. This tutorial, with the help of grids and area models, will allow you to be part of this elite group.

name: Multi-digit multiplication (Multiplication and division)
blurb: Learn to multiply multi-digit whole numbers with and without regrouping.

name: Division intro (Multiplication and division)
blurb: Welcome to the concept of division.

name: Division: place value and area (Multiplication and division)
blurb: Dividing big numbers can be difficult to wrap your mind around. In this tutorial, we'll learn some visual ways to think through large division problems.

name: Multi-digit division (Multiplication and division)
blurb: Learn to divide multi-digit numbers by 1-digit numbers.  Answers will not have remainders.

name: Remainders (Multiplication and division)
blurb: Some division problems don't work out perfectly. For example, we know that 6 divided by 3 is 2, and 9 divided by 3 is 3. But, what is 7 divided by 3? Or 8 divided by 3? In division problems like these, we're left with remainders.

name: Multi-digit division (Multiplication and division)
blurb: Learn to divide any whole number by a multiple-digit whole number.

name: Multi-step word problems (Multiplication and division)
blurb: In this tutorial, we'll start to challenge you with more sophisticated multiplication and division word problems. If you understand mult-digit multiplication and long division, you have all the tools you need to tackle these. May the force be with you!

name: Intro to negative numbers (Negative numbers)
blurb: What are negative numbers? When do we use them? Where do we find them on the number line? Let's learn what happens in the world below zero!

name: Order negative numbers (Negative numbers)
blurb: We all know that 6 is bigger than 4, but is -6 bigger than -4? This tutorial is designed to help you compare negative numbers.

name: Number opposites (Negative numbers)
blurb: Opposite numbers are the same distance from 0 on opposite sides of the number line. A number opposite is sometimes called an additive inverse.

name: Absolute value (Negative numbers)
blurb: You'll find absolute value absolutely straightforward--it is just the "distance from zero". If you have a positive number, it is its own absolute value. If you have a negative number, just make it positive to get the absolute value. As you see as you develop mathematically, this idea will eventually extended to more contexts and dimensions, so super important that you understand this core concept now.  Common Core Standards: 6.NS.C.7, 6.NS.C.7c, 6.NS.C.7d

name: Intro to adding negative numbers (Negative numbers)
blurb: Learn how to add negative numbers. By the end of this tutorial, you'll be solving problems like 4 + (-7) with ease!

name: Intro to subtracting negative numbers (Negative numbers)
blurb: Learn why subtracting a negative number is the same as adding its opposite!

name: Adding & subtracting integers (Negative numbers)
blurb: Add and subtract negative numbers using a number line. It's the 7th grade mathematics shuffle: "Slide to the left for a negative value, and slide to the right for a positive value." Be careful, though. Which way do you move if you are subtracting a negative number? The answer awaits!

name: Multiply & divide negative numbers (Negative numbers)
blurb: You already know how to multiply and divide whole numbers, decimals, and fractions. See what happens when we throw negative numbers into the mix. It's really not so different!

name: Fractions intro (Fractions)
blurb: Learn what a fraction is and identify unit fractions.

name: Fractions on the number line (Fractions)
blurb: Learn to identify fractions on a number line.

name: Equivalent fractions (Fractions)
blurb: Learn how to find equivalent fractions visually and by multiplying the numerator and denominator by the same number.

name: Comparing fractions (Fractions)
blurb: In this tutorial, we'll practice understanding what quantities fractions actually represent and comparing those to each other.

name: Common denominators (Fractions)
blurb: Using our knowledge of equivalent fractions, let's rewrite fractions to have the same denominator.

name: Decomposing fractions (Fractions)
blurb: See that a fraction can be broken up (or decomposed) into a bunch of other fractions.

name: Adding and subtracting fractions with like denominators (Fractions)
blurb: Learn how to add and subtract fractions. This is an introductory tutorial, so the fractions you add and subtract have the same denominators.

name: Mixed numbers (Fractions)
blurb: Learn how to write improper fractions as mixed numbers (and mixed numbers as improper fractions).

name: Adding and subtracting fractions with unlike denominators (Fractions)
blurb: Learn how to add and subtract fractions that have different denominators.

name: Adding and subtracting mixed number with unlike denominators (Fractions)
blurb: Learn how to add and subtract mixed numbers whose fractional parts have different denominators.

name: Adding and subtracting fractions word problems (Fractions)
blurb: Practice solving word problems by adding and subtracting fractions.

name: Multiplying whole numbers and fractions (Fractions)
blurb: Learn the art of multiplying whole numbers by fractions. See how 3 times 2/3 is the same as 6 times 1/3, which is the same as 6/3.

name: Multiplication as scaling (Fractions)
blurb: Learn to see multiplication as a way to grow (scale up) and shrink (scale down) other numbers.

name: Multiplying fractions (Fractions)
blurb: Learn how to multiply a fraction by a fraction.

name: Multiplying mixed numbers (Fractions)
blurb: Learn how to multiply mixed numbers.

name: Multiplying fractions word problems (Fractions)
blurb: Get some practice solving word problems by multiplying fractions.

name: Fractions as division (Fractions)
blurb: **Spoiler Alert!** The fraction bar and the division symbol are really saying the same thing.

name: Dividing unit fractions and whole numbers (Fractions)
blurb: Learn how to divide unit fractions by whole numbers. Example: 1/5 ÷ 3 = 1/15.

name: Dividing fractions by fractions (Fractions)
blurb: Learn how to divide fractions by other fractions.

name: Dividing fractions word problems (Fractions)
blurb: Practice solving word problems with fraction division.

name: Introduction to decimals (Decimals)
blurb: What are decimal numbers? How are they like fractions?

name: Decimals on the number line (Decimals)
blurb: See how decimals can be placed on the number line, just like fractions and whole numbers can.

name: Rounding decimals (Decimals)
blurb: Learn how to round decimal numbers to specific place values. For example, round 3.14159 to the nearest hundredth as 3.14.

name: Comparing decimals (Decimals)
blurb: Let's test our understanding of decimals by comparing them to one another!

name: Rewriting decimals to fractions (Decimals)
blurb: Learn how to rewrite decimals as fractions.

name: Adding decimals (Decimals)
blurb: Honestly, once you remember one very important rule, the rest of adding and subtracting decimals is a snap. That rule is to be sure and align your decimals first. In this tutorial, you'll get a chance to practice this with us and become fluent adding decimals. We'll tackle subtracting decimals in the next tutorial.

name: Subtracting decimals (Decimals)
blurb: Just like with adding decimals, the key to subtracting decimals is aligning the decimal points. Let's practice!

name: Adding and subtracting decimals word problems (Decimals)
blurb: In this tutorial, we practice solving word problems by adding and subtracting decimal numbers.

name: Multiplying decimals (Decimals)
blurb: You've already multiplied decimals in the 5th grade. We'll show you some ways to handle slightly more complicated problems. Now you'll become super good at it with a bit more practice!  Common Core Standard: 6.NS.B.3

name: Dividing decimals (Decimals)
blurb: Learn long division with decimals. Solve problems like 30.24 divided by 0.42.

name: Lines, line segments and rays (Lines)
blurb: Let's draw points, lines, line segments, and rays.  We'll also think about perpendicular and parallel lines and identify these in two-dimensional figures.  Common Core Standard: 4.G.A.1

name: Parallel and perpendicular (Lines)
blurb: Learn the definitions of "parallel" and "perpendicular".

name: Angle introduction (Angles)
blurb: What is an angle and how do we label, measure and construct them? Great question. Luckily we have all your answers! To begin our journey towards understanding angles, we'll learn terms like vertex, acute, obtuse, circle arc, circumference, and protractor. These basic angle concepts will get you on the road to angle domination!

name: Measuring and drawing angles (Angles)
blurb: Learn how to measure angles using a protractor.

name: Angles in circles (Angles)
blurb: Learn how to measure angles using a circle protractor and solve word problems about angles as part of a circle.

name: Angle types (Angles)
blurb: Now that we know what angles are, let's dig a bit deeper and classify them and understand their properties better. Acute, obtuse, right, adjacent--all are angles that we will be become familiar with.

name: Vertical, complementary, and supplementary angles (Angles)
blurb: Learn three types of angle pairs: vertical angles, complementary angles, and supplementary angles.

name: Angles between intersecting lines (Angles)
blurb: This tutorial introduces us to angles.  It includes how we measure them, how angles relate to each other and properties of angles created from various types of intersecting lines.  Mr. Angle is actually far more fun than you might initially presume him to be.

name: Properties of shapes (Shapes)
blurb: Learn how different shapes have different numbers of corners, different side lengths, and so on. Use these properties to help you recognize shapes.

name: Quadrilaterals (Shapes)
blurb: Not all things with four sides and 90 degree angles are squares or rectangles! Sometimes the angles in these 4-sided shapes are less than (or greater than) 90 degrees, causing them to have a slightly odd shape. These are called quadrilaterals and come in a few different varieties. In this tutorial, you'll learn about them.

name: Triangles (Shapes)
blurb: Triangles can be classified in different ways. In this tutorial, we'll learn about scalene, isosceles, equilateral, acute, right, and obtuse triangles.

name: Classifying shapes (Shapes)
blurb: Practice classifying geometric shapes.

name: Triangle angles (Shapes)
blurb:
Do the angles in a triangle always add up to the same thing?  Would I ask it if they didn't?  What do we know about the angles of a triangle if two of the sides are congruent (an isosceles triangle) or all three are congruent (an equilateral)?  This tutorial is the place to find out.

Common Core Standard: 8.G.A.5

name: Copy of Geometric solids (Shapes)
blurb: Identify 3-dimensional figures and their parts (faces, edges, vertices).

name: Coordinate plane: quadrant 1 (Coordinate plane)
blurb: How can we communicate exactly where something is in two dimensions?  In this tutorial, we cover the basics of the coordinate plane and graphing points.

name: Coordinate plane (Coordinate plane)
blurb: We first explored the coordinate plane in the 5th grade, but that was only dealing with positive coordinates.  Now we know all about negative numbers so why not have negative coordinates as well? Let's get cozy with the x and y axis, plotting ordered pairs, quadrants, and reflection points. We got it covered. Sit back, relax, and get ready to groove with us.  Common Core Standards: 6.NS.C.6, 6.NS.C.6b, 6.NS.C.6c, 6.NS.C.8

name: Quadrants (Coordinate plane)
blurb: Learn the 4 quadrants of a coordinate plane.

name: Reflecting points on coordinate plane (Coordinate plane)
blurb: Learn to reflect points on a coordinate plane across both axes and the origin.

name: Quadrilaterals on the coordinate plane (Coordinate plane)
blurb: Math problems that test your understanding of Quadrilateral and points on the coordinate plane

name: Drawing polygons in the coordinate plane (Coordinate plane)
blurb: Practice drawing shapes on the coordinate plane.

name: Count unit squares to find area (Area and perimeter)
blurb: Find area of shapes by counting unit squares.  Some shapes will require combining partial square units to find area.  Create rectangles with a given area by covering unit squares.

name: Area of rectangles (Area and perimeter)
blurb: Transition from counting unit squares to multiplying side length to find area.  Measure side lengths with a ruler to find area.  Find area of rectangles by multiplying side lengths.  Find a missing side length of a rectangle when given the other side length and area.

name: Perimeter (Area and perimeter)
blurb: Have you ever wondered how much fencing you need to surround a plot of land? No? Well, you should still go through this tutorial just in case. You'll learn what perimeter is and how to calculate it.

name: Area of parallelograms (Area and perimeter)
blurb: Understand the formula for the area of a parallelogram.

name: Area of triangles (Area and perimeter)
blurb: Understand the formula for the area of a triangle.

name: Area of trapezoids and composite figures (Area and perimeter)
blurb: Finding the area of more complex shapes like trapezoids and composite figures (shapes built from other shapes)

name: Area and circumference of circles (Area and perimeter)
blurb: A circle is at the foundation of geometry, and at the foundation of a circle is a special number called Pi. This number allows us to relate the radius, diameter, and circumference of a circle.

name: Volume of rectangular prisms (Volume and surface area)
blurb: Welcome to the 3rd dimension! [cue spooky music] This tutorial explains how to find volume.

name: Volume with fractions (Volume and surface area)
blurb: Finding the volume of rectangular prisms that have fractional side lengths

name: Surface area (Volume and surface area)
blurb: Learn how to find the total area of the surfaces of 3D shapes. To do this, we wrap 3D shapes in 2D nets.

name: Volume of cones, cylinders, and spheres (Volume and surface area)
blurb: Let's see how to find the volumes of cylinders, spheres and other three dimensional shapes.

name: Pythagorean theorem (Pythagorean theorem)
blurb:
Named after the Greek philosopher who lived nearly 2600 years ago, the Pythagorean theorem is as good as math theorems get (Pythagoras also started a religious movement).  It's simple.  It's beautiful.  It's powerful.

Common Core Standards: 8.G.B.7, 8.G.B.8

name: Pythagorean theorem application (Pythagorean theorem)
blurb: Apply the Pythagorean theorem to area and perimeter, 3D figures, and real world problems.

name: Pythagorean theorem and distance between points (Pythagorean theorem)
blurb: Use the Pythagorean theorem to find the distance between points on a coordinate plane and the length of diagonal lines on a coordinate plane.

name: Pythagorean Theorem Proofs (Pythagorean theorem)
blurb:
The Pythagorean theorem is one of the most famous ideas in all of mathematics.  This tutorial proves it.  Then proves it again... and again... and again.  More than just satisfying any skepticism of whether the Pythagorean theorem is really true (only one proof would be sufficient for that), it will hopefully open your mind to new and beautiful ways to prove something very powerful.

Common Core Standard: 8.G.B.6

name: Line of symmetry (Transformations, congruence, and similarity)
blurb: A line of symmetry for a two-dimensional figure is a line across the figure such that the figure can be folded along the line into matching parts. In this tutorial, we'll identify line-symmetric figures and draw lines of symmetry.

name: Transformations intro (Transformations, congruence, and similarity)
blurb: Identify transformations, including translations, rotations, reflections, and dilations.

name: Translations (Transformations, congruence, and similarity)
blurb: Learn about transformations and how to perform them.

name: Rotations (Transformations, congruence, and similarity)
blurb: Learn about rotations and how to perform them.

name: Reflections (Transformations, congruence, and similarity)
blurb: Learn about reflections and how to perform them.

name: Properties & definitions of transformations (Transformations, congruence, and similarity)
blurb: Let's continue our deep voyage through the world of transformations! Use your knowledge about the precise descriptions of the rigid transformations and their properties in various situations.

name: Dilations (Transformations, congruence, and similarity)
blurb:
In addition to the three rigid transformation, there are the dilations, which expand or shrink figures while keeping the same proportions. These are extremely important in the subject of Similarity!

Gain experience by performing dilation, learn how to find the dilation that maps a given figure to another, and learn how to manually draw the image of a dilation.

name: Congruence and similarity (Transformations, congruence, and similarity)
blurb: Learn about congruence and similarity, specifically as they relate to transformations.  Learn to dilate shapes.

name: Place value (Arithmetic properties)
blurb: In this tutorial we'll learn about place value.  This is key to better understanding what we're really doing when we count, carry, regroup, multiply, and divide with multi-digit numbers.

name: Rounding whole numbers (Arithmetic properties)
blurb:
If you're looking to create an army of robot dogs, will it really make a difference if you have 10,300 dogs, 9,997 dogs or 10,005 dogs?  Probably not.  All you really care about is how many dogs you have to, say, the nearest thousand (10,000 dogs).

In this tutorial, we'll learn about conventions for rounding whole numbers.  Very useful when we might not need to (or cannot) be completely precise.

name: Regrouping whole numbers (Arithmetic properties)
blurb: Regrouping involves taking value from one place and giving it to another.  It is a great way to make sure you understand place value.  It is also super useful when subtracting multi-digit numbers (the process is often called "borrowing" even though you never really "pay back" the value taken from one place and given to another).

name: Order of operations (Arithmetic properties)
blurb: If you have the expression "3 + 4 x 5", do you add the 3 to the 4 first or multiply the 4 and 5 first?  To clear up confusion here, the math world has defined which operation should get priority over others.  This is super important.  You won't really be able to do any involved math if you don't get this clear.  But don't worry, this tutorial has your back.

name: Arithmetic properties (Arithmetic properties)
blurb:
2 + 3 = 3 + 2, 6 x 4 = 4 x 6.  Adding zero to a number does not change the number.  Likewise, multiplying a number by 1 does not change it.

You may already know these things from working through other tutorials, but some people (not us) like to give these properties names that sound far more complicated than the property themselves.  This tutorial (which we're not a fan of), is here just in case you're asked to identify the "Commutative Law of Multiplication".   We believe the important thing isn't the fancy label, but the underlying idea (which isn't that fancy).

name: Distributive property (Arithmetic properties)
blurb: The distributive property is an idea that shows up over and over again in mathematics.  It is the idea that 5 x (3 + 4) = (5 x 3) + (5 x 4).  If that last statement made complete sense, no need to watch this tutorial.  If it didn't or you don't know why it's true, then this tutorial might be a good way to pass the time :)

name: Rational and irrational numbers (Arithmetic properties)
blurb: More numbers than you probably imagine can be represented as the ratio of two integers.  We call these rational numbers. But there are also really amazing numbers that can't.  As you can guess, we call them irrational numbers.

name: Divisibility tests (Factors and multiples)
blurb: Whether you are trying to impress your dog's friends (who are obsessed with figuring out number divisibility) or quickly factor a number, it can be very useful to tell whether a number is divisible by another.  This tutorial walks through some of the more standard divisibility methods and describes why they work.

name: Factors and multiples (Factors and multiples)
blurb: In this tutorial, we'll begin to think about the numbers that "make up" the number.  This will be useful throughout our study of math.  Whether we are adding fractions, exploring mystical number patterns, or breaking computer codes, factoring numbers are key!  Eye of the tiger!

name: Prime numbers (Factors and multiples)
blurb: Prime numbers have been studied by mathematicians and mystics for ages (seriously).  They are both basic and mysterious.  The more you explore them, the more you will realize that the universe is a fascinating place.  This tutorial will introduce you to the magical world of prime numbers.

name: Prime factorization (Factors and multiples)
blurb: You know what prime numbers are and how to identify them.  In this tutorial, we'll see that *all* positive whole numbers can be broken down into products of prime numbers (In some way, prime numbers are the "atoms" of the number world that can be multiplied to create any other number).  Besides being a fascinating idea, it is also extremely useful.  Prime factorization can be used to decrypt encrypted information!

name: Least common multiple (Factors and multiples)
blurb: Life is good, but it can always get better.  Just imagine being able to find the smallest number that is a multiple of two other numbers!  Other than making your life more fulfilling, it will allow you to do incredible things like adding fractions.

name: Greatest common divisor (Factors and multiples)
blurb: You know how to find factors of a number.  But what about factors that are common to two numbers?  Even better, imagine the largest factors that are common to two numbers.   I know.  Too exciting!

name: Representing data (Applying mathematical reasoning)
blurb: Learn about different ways to represent and display data.

name: Stem and leaf plots (Applying mathematical reasoning)
blurb: Learn how to read and interpret stem-and-leaf plots.

name: Picture graphs, bar graphs, and histograms (Applying mathematical reasoning)
blurb: Read and interpret picture graphs, bar graphs and histograms.  Also, make some graphs of your own!

name: Frequency tables and dot plots (Applying mathematical reasoning)
blurb: A dot plot is like a bar chart, but it displays data using dots (not bars). And a frequency table is like a dot plot, but it displays data in a simple table (not a fancy diagram).

name: Number patterns (Applying mathematical reasoning)
blurb: Let's explore how numbers can grow in different ways and use what we learn to figure out where they can go.  We think you'll find this tutorial on number patterns more fun that you do :)

name: Area of rectangles (Measurement)
blurb: Area is how we thinking about how much space something takes in two dimensions such as comparing how much land one property takes up versus another.  In this tutorial, we'll take a conceptual look at how area is actually measured (especially for rectangles).

name: Perimeter (Measurement)
blurb: Have you ever wondered how much fencing you need to surround a plot of land?  No?  Well, you should still go through this tutorial just in case.  You'll learn all about how to think about and calculate perimeter--essentially the length of the boundary of a figure.

name: Volume of a rectangular prism (Measurement)
blurb: Volume measures how much 3-dimensional "space" an object takes up.  We'll see in this tutorial that it is an extension of length (1-D) or area (2-D) to three dimensions!

name: Fractions intro (Fractions)
blurb: Learn what a fraction is and identify unit fractions.

name: Fractions on the number line (Fractions)
blurb: Learn to identify fractions on a number line.

name: Equivalent fractions (Fractions)
blurb: Learn how to find equivalent fractions visually and by multiplying the numerator and denominator by the same number.

name: Comparing fractions (Fractions)
blurb: In this tutorial, we'll practice understanding what quantities fractions actually represent and comparing those to each other.

name: Common denominators (Fractions)
blurb: Using our knowledge of equivalent fractions, let's rewrite fractions to have the same denominator.

name: Decomposing fractions (Fractions)
blurb: See that a fraction can be broken up (or decomposed) into a bunch of other fractions.

name: Adding and subtracting fractions with like denominators (Fractions)
blurb: Learn how to add and subtract fractions. This is an introductory tutorial, so the fractions you add and subtract have the same denominators.

name: Mixed numbers (Fractions)
blurb: Learn how to write improper fractions as mixed numbers (and mixed numbers as improper fractions).

name: Adding and subtracting fractions with unlike denominators (Fractions)
blurb: Learn how to add and subtract fractions that have different denominators.

name: Adding and subtracting mixed number with unlike denominators (Fractions)
blurb: Learn how to add and subtract mixed numbers whose fractional parts have different denominators.

name: Adding and subtracting fractions word problems (Fractions)
blurb: Practice solving word problems by adding and subtracting fractions.

name: Multiplying whole numbers and fractions (Fractions)
blurb: Learn the art of multiplying whole numbers by fractions. See how 3 times 2/3 is the same as 6 times 1/3, which is the same as 6/3.

name: Multiplication as scaling (Fractions)
blurb: Learn to see multiplication as a way to grow (scale up) and shrink (scale down) other numbers.

name: Multiplying fractions (Fractions)
blurb: Learn how to multiply a fraction by a fraction.

name: Multiplying mixed numbers (Fractions)
blurb: Learn how to multiply mixed numbers.

name: Multiplying fractions word problems (Fractions)
blurb: Get some practice solving word problems by multiplying fractions.

name: Fractions as division (Fractions)
blurb: **Spoiler Alert!** The fraction bar and the division symbol are really saying the same thing.

name: Dividing unit fractions and whole numbers (Fractions)
blurb: Learn how to divide unit fractions by whole numbers. Example: 1/5 ÷ 3 = 1/15.

name: Dividing fractions by fractions (Fractions)
blurb: Learn how to divide fractions by other fractions.

name: Dividing fractions word problems (Fractions)
blurb: Practice solving word problems with fraction division.

name: Introduction to decimals (Decimals)
blurb: What are decimal numbers? How are they like fractions?

name: Decimals on the number line (Decimals)
blurb: See how decimals can be placed on the number line, just like fractions and whole numbers can.

name: Rounding decimals (Decimals)
blurb: Learn how to round decimal numbers to specific place values. For example, round 3.14159 to the nearest hundredth as 3.14.

name: Comparing decimals (Decimals)
blurb: Let's test our understanding of decimals by comparing them to one another!

name: Rewriting decimals to fractions (Decimals)
blurb: Learn how to rewrite decimals as fractions.

name: Adding decimals (Decimals)
blurb: Honestly, once you remember one very important rule, the rest of adding and subtracting decimals is a snap. That rule is to be sure and align your decimals first. In this tutorial, you'll get a chance to practice this with us and become fluent adding decimals. We'll tackle subtracting decimals in the next tutorial.

name: Subtracting decimals (Decimals)
blurb: Just like with adding decimals, the key to subtracting decimals is aligning the decimal points. Let's practice!

name: Adding and subtracting decimals word problems (Decimals)
blurb: In this tutorial, we practice solving word problems by adding and subtracting decimal numbers.

name: Multiplying decimals (Decimals)
blurb: You've already multiplied decimals in the 5th grade. We'll show you some ways to handle slightly more complicated problems. Now you'll become super good at it with a bit more practice!  Common Core Standard: 6.NS.B.3

name: Dividing decimals (Decimals)
blurb: Learn long division with decimals. Solve problems like 30.24 divided by 0.42.

name: Intro to negative numbers (Negative numbers)
blurb: What are negative numbers? When do we use them? Where do we find them on the number line? Let's learn what happens in the world below zero!

name: Order negative numbers (Negative numbers)
blurb: We all know that 6 is bigger than 4, but is -6 bigger than -4? This tutorial is designed to help you compare negative numbers.

name: Number opposites (Negative numbers)
blurb: Opposite numbers are the same distance from 0 on opposite sides of the number line. A number opposite is sometimes called an additive inverse.

name: Absolute value (Negative numbers)
blurb: You'll find absolute value absolutely straightforward--it is just the "distance from zero". If you have a positive number, it is its own absolute value. If you have a negative number, just make it positive to get the absolute value. As you see as you develop mathematically, this idea will eventually extended to more contexts and dimensions, so super important that you understand this core concept now.  Common Core Standards: 6.NS.C.7, 6.NS.C.7c, 6.NS.C.7d

name: Intro to adding negative numbers (Negative numbers)
blurb: Learn how to add negative numbers. By the end of this tutorial, you'll be solving problems like 4 + (-7) with ease!

name: Intro to subtracting negative numbers (Negative numbers)
blurb: Learn why subtracting a negative number is the same as adding its opposite!

name: Adding & subtracting integers (Negative numbers)
blurb: Add and subtract negative numbers using a number line. It's the 7th grade mathematics shuffle: "Slide to the left for a negative value, and slide to the right for a positive value." Be careful, though. Which way do you move if you are subtracting a negative number? The answer awaits!

name: Multiply & divide negative numbers (Negative numbers)
blurb: You already know how to multiply and divide whole numbers, decimals, and fractions. See what happens when we throw negative numbers into the mix. It's really not so different!

name: Coordinate plane (Negative numbers)
blurb: We first explored the coordinate plane in the 5th grade, but that was only dealing with positive coordinates.  Now we know all about negative numbers so why not have negative coordinates as well? Let's get cozy with the x and y axis, plotting ordered pairs, quadrants, and reflection points. We got it covered. Sit back, relax, and get ready to groove with us.  Common Core Standards: 6.NS.C.6, 6.NS.C.6b, 6.NS.C.6c, 6.NS.C.8

name: Introduction to ratios (Ratios, rates, proportions)
blurb: Ratios show up everywhere in life—sports, finance, medicine, cooking, you name it! In this tutorial, we learn what ratios are and how to use them.

name: Visualize ratios (Ratios, rates, proportions)
blurb: Use double number lines, ratio tables, and tape diagrams to visualize ratios.

name: Ratio word problems (Ratios, rates, proportions)
blurb: Expand on ratios by exploring part:part:whole ratios and ratios on the coordinate plane.

name: Introduction to rates (Ratios, rates, proportions)
blurb: Learn about a special type of ratio called a rate. A rate is the ratio of two measurements that have different units such as 10 kilometers per hour or 12 hot dogs per minute!

name: Intro to percents (Ratios, rates, proportions)
blurb: Percent literally means "per cent" or "per hundred". Learn how to rewrite fractions as percents and vice versa.

name: Percent-decimal conversions (Ratios, rates, proportions)
blurb: Decimals and percents are two ways of expressing the same number. For example, 0.5 and 50% mean the exact same thing. Learn how to convert decimals to percents and vice versa.

name: Percent problems (Ratios, rates, proportions)
blurb: Learn how to solve percent problems like these: What is 80% of 25? Three is what percent of four?

name: Percent word problems (Ratios, rates, proportions)
blurb: Learn how to solve a variety of word problems involving percentages.

name: Constant of proportionality (Ratios, rates, proportions)
blurb: Identify the constant of proportionality (unit rate) in tables, graphs, equations, diagrams, and verbal descriptions of proportional relationships.

name: Identifying proportional relationships (Ratios, rates, proportions)
blurb: Learn how to tell whether two quantities are proportional by thinking about equivalent ratios and drawing graphs.

name: Writing & solving proportions (Ratios, rates, proportions)
blurb: Learn how to write proportions and how to solve proportions.

name: Intro to variables (Equations, expressions, and inequalities )
blurb: Wait, why are we using letters in math? How can an 'x' represent a number? What number is it? This tutorial is great if you're just beginning to delve into the world of variables and expressions.

name: Substitution & evaluating expressions (Equations, expressions, and inequalities )
blurb: Learn how to substitute (or "plug in") values for variables and evaluate algebraic expressions.

name: Expression value intuition (Equations, expressions, and inequalities )
blurb: Explore how the value of an algebraic expression changes as the value of its variable changes.

name: Constructing numeric expressions (Equations, expressions, and inequalities )
blurb: Let's construct and interpret expressions from word problems.  We can also think about what the effects of parentheses are.

name: Evaluating expressions word problems (Equations, expressions, and inequalities )
blurb: Learn how to plug in values to evaluate real-world expressions.

name: Writing algebraic expressions introduction (Equations, expressions, and inequalities )
blurb: Learn the basics of writing expressions with variables.

name: Writing basic algebraic expressions word problems (Equations, expressions, and inequalities )
blurb: Learn how to write algebraic expressions (expressions with variables) to model real-world situations.

name: Algebraic equations basics (Equations, expressions, and inequalities )
blurb: Explore what it means for equations with variables (algebraic equations) to be solved.

name: Why we do the same thing to both sides of an equation (Equations, expressions, and inequalities )
blurb: A high-level, conceptual walk-through of what an equation represents and why we do the same thing to both sides of it

name: One-step addition & subtraction equations (Equations, expressions, and inequalities )
blurb: Solve equations by adding and subtracting numbers from both sides.

name: One-step multiplication and division equations (Equations, expressions, and inequalities )
blurb: Solve equations by multiplying and dividing numbers from both sides.

name: One-step equation word problems (Equations, expressions, and inequalities )
blurb: Let's use our algebra tools to solve a problem of earth-shattering importance: which Super Yoga plan is the best value! In this word problem, you'll put to practice your knowledge of variables, substitution, and one-step equations.

name: Inequalities: Greater than and less than basics (Equations, expressions, and inequalities )
blurb:
Equality is usually a good thing, but the world is not a perfect place.  No matter how hard we try, we can't help but compare one thing to another and realize how unequal they may be.

This tutorial gives you the tools to do these comparisons in the mathematical world (which we call inequalities).  You'll become familiar with the "greater than" and "less than symbols" and learn to use them.

name: Two-step equations intro (Equations, expressions, and inequalities )
blurb: Learn how to solve equations like 2x+7=13 and 3(x+4)=3, which can be solved in two steps.

name: Dependent and independent variables (Equations, expressions, and inequalities )
blurb: Sometimes one variable depends on another. For example, the amount of money you make might depend on how many hours you work.

name: Exponents (Exponents, radicals, and scientific notation)
blurb:
Addition was nice.  Multiplication was cooler.  In the mood for a new operation that grows numbers even faster?  Ever felt like expressing repeated multiplication with less writing?  Ever wanted to describe how most things in the universe grow and shrink?  Well, exponents are your answer!

This tutorial covers everything from basic exponents to negative and fractional ones.  It assumes you remember your multiplication, negative numbers and fractions.

name: Square roots (Exponents, radicals, and scientific notation)
blurb:
A strong contender for coolest symbol in mathematics is the radical.  What is it?  How does it relate to exponents?  How is the square root different than the cube root?  How can I simplify, multiply and add these things?  

This tutorial assumes you know the basics of exponents and exponent properties and takes you through the radical world for radicals (and gives you some good practice along the way)!

name: Cube roots  (Exponents, radicals, and scientific notation)
blurb: If you're familiar with the idea of a square root, we're about to take things one step (dimension?) further with the cube root.  This generally refers to finding a number that, when cubed, is equal to the number that you're trying to find the cube root of!

name: Exponent properties (Exponents, radicals, and scientific notation)
blurb:
Tired of hairy exponent expressions?  Feel compelled to clean them up?  Well, this tutorial might just give you the tools you need.

If you know a bit about exponents, you'll learn a ton more in this tutorial as you learn about the rules for simplifying exponents.

name: Negative exponents (Exponents, radicals, and scientific notation)
blurb:
It's normally a bad idea to hang around with negative people or do negative things, but we think it's OK to associate with negative exponents.  And fractional exponents are even more fun.

This idea will open up entirely new vistas to your mathematical life.

name: Scientific notation (Exponents, radicals, and scientific notation)
blurb:
Scientists and engineers often have to deal with super huge (like 6,000,000,000,000,000,000,000) and super small numbers (like 0.0000000000532) .  How can they do this without tiring their hands out?  How can they look at a number and understand how large or small it is without counting the digits?  The answer is to use scientific notation.

If you come to this tutorial with a basic understanding of positive and negative exponents, it should leave you with a new appreciation for representing really huge and really small numbers!

name: Orders of magnitude (Exponents, radicals, and scientific notation)
blurb: When people want to think about the general size of things but not worry about the exact number, they tend to think in terms of "orders of magnitude".  This allows us to analyze and make comparisons between numbers very quickly, which allows us to make decisions about them quickly as well.

name: Computing with scientific notation (Exponents, radicals, and scientific notation)
blurb: You already understand what scientific notation is.  Now you'll actually use it to compute values and solve real-world problems.

name: Negative numbers (Foundations)
