blurb: Understanding and operating with negative numbers is key in algebra.  This tutorial will make sure that you have the basics down!

name: Absolute value (Foundations)
blurb: Absolute value is a simple but important property of numbers. Get comfortable with finding the absolute value of numbers and interpreting their meaning.

name: Exponents (Foundations)
blurb:
Addition was nice.  Multiplication was cooler.  In the mood for a new operation that grows numbers even faster?  Ever felt like expressing repeated multiplication with less writing?  Ever wanted to describe how most things in the universe grow and shrink?  Well, exponents are your answer!

This tutorial covers everything from basic exponents to negative and fractional ones.  It assumes you remember your multiplication, negative numbers and fractions.

name: Square roots (Foundations)
blurb: A strong contender for coolest symbol in mathematics is the radical. What is it? How does it relate to exponents? Learn all about square roots in this tutorial.

name: Order of operations (Foundations)
blurb: In this tutorial, we learn the "order of operations" to evaluate more complex expressions involving exponents, parentheses, multiplication and division, and addition and subtraction.

name: Fractions (Foundations)
blurb: This tutorial will help to review arithmetic with fractions

name: Decimals, fractions and percentages (Foundations)
blurb: Let's review how to convert between fractions, decimals and percentages

name: Operations with decimals (Foundations)
blurb: Add, subtract, multiply, and divide decimals.

name: Area of triangles (Foundations)
blurb: Understand the formula for the area of a triangle.

name: Circumference and area of circles (Foundations)
blurb: Circles are everywhere.  How can we measure how big they are?  Well, we could think about the distance around the circle (circumference).  Another option would be to think about how much space it takes up on our paper (area).  Have fun!

name: Introduction to variables (Algebraic expressions)
blurb: Wait, why are we using letters in math? How can an 'x' represent a number? What number is it? This tutorial is great if you're just beginning to delve into the world of variables and expressions.

name: Substitution & evaluating expressions (Algebraic expressions)
blurb: Learn how to substitute (or "plug in") values for variables and evaluate algebraic expressions.

name: Writing algebraic expressions (Algebraic expressions)
blurb: Learn the basics of writing expressions with variables.

name: Combining like terms (Algebraic expressions)
blurb: Learn how to combine like terms (with negative numbers and variables), including more complex problems involving the distributive property.

name: Distributive property (Algebraic expressions)
blurb: Learn how to apply the distributive property to numerical expressions (without variables) and algebraic expressions (with variables). The distributive property is also sometimes called the distributive law.

name: Equivalent algebraic expressions (Algebraic expressions)
blurb: Learn to tell whether or not two algebraic expressions are equivalent by combining like terms and using the distributive property.

name: Nested fractions (Algebraic expressions)
blurb: Learn how to simplify rational expressions that contain further rational expressions within their numerators or denominators.

name: One-step addition & subtraction equations (Linear equations and inequalities)
blurb: Solve equations by adding/subtracting numbers from both sides, or by multiplying/dividing both sides by the same number.

name: Two-steps equations intro (Linear equations and inequalities)
blurb: Learn how to solve equations like 2x+7=13 and 3(x+4)=3, which can be solved in two steps.

name: Linear equations with variables on both sides (Linear equations and inequalities)
blurb: Learn how to solve linear equations that have the variable on both sides of the equation. For example, solve 2x+5=6x-3. Also learn how to solve linear equations with expressions in parentheses. For example, 3(x-1)=9.

name: One-step inequalities (Linear equations and inequalities)
blurb: Learn how to solve (mathematical) inequalities. A key concept in this tutorial is flipping the inequality sign when multiplying or dividing both sides by a negative number.

name: Two-step inequalities (Linear equations and inequalities)
blurb: Learn how to solve more complex (mathematical) inequalities. Also learn to construct inequalities to model real-world situations.

name: Multi-step inequalities (Linear equations and inequalities)
blurb: Solve any possible linear inequality in one variable. For example, solve -3x-7<x+9.

name: Writing & solving proportions (Linear equations and inequalities)
blurb: Learn how to write proportions and how to solve proportions.

name: Coordinate plane (Graphing lines and slope)
blurb: Let's get cozy with the x and y axis, plotting ordered pairs, quadrants, and reflection points.

name: Solutions to two-variable linear equations (Graphing lines and slope)
blurb: Understand what a solution to an equation really means. Practice plugging in values for variables to see whether or not an equation is true.

name: x-intercepts and y-intercepts (Graphing lines and slope)
blurb: Learn about intercepts and practice finding them from graphs, tables, and equations.

name: Slope (Graphing lines and slope)
blurb: Learn about slope (the steepness of a line) and how to find it.

name: Horizontal & vertical lines (Graphing lines and slope)
blurb: You know what horizontal and vertical lines are, but how do their equations look? And what is their slope? Learn all about it in this tutorial.

name: Slope-intercept form intro (Graphing lines and slope)
blurb: Make an introduction with the most common form of linear equations, slope-intercept form! For example, y=3x+5 is a linear equation in slope-intercept form.

name: Writing slope-intercept equations (Graphing lines and slope)
blurb: Learn how to write the equation of a line (in slope-intercept form) when given the graph of the equation or two points on the line. For example, write the equation of the line that passes through the points (0,1) and (5,4).

name: Graphing two-variable inequalities (Graphing lines and slope)
blurb: Learn how to graph two-variables linear inequalities.

name: Systems of equations overview (Systems of equations)
blurb: This video series covers everything you need to know about systems of equations, through stories about trolls, kings, and cupcakes!

name: Systems of equations intro (Systems of equations)
blurb: Learn what "systems of equations" are, what counts as a solution to such a system, and how we can use graphs to solve them.

name: Elimination method for systems of equations (Systems of equations)
blurb: Learn about the elimination method, which is a way to manipulate systems of equations in order to solve them algebraically. This is actually very similar to the way we manipulate single equations in order to solve them!

name: Substitution method for systems of equations (Systems of equations)
blurb: Learn about the substitution method, which is another way to manipulate systems of equations in order to solve them.

name: Number of solutions to systems of equations (Systems of equations)
blurb: Learn about the possible number of solutions of systems of linear equations. Spoiler: There can be a single solution, zero solutions, or infinite solutions. These different cases define the distinctions between "consistent" and "inconsistent" systems, and between "dependent" and "independent" systems.

name: Solving any system of linear equations (Systems of equations)
blurb: Use everything you learned so far in order to solve any kind of system of equations!

name: Exponent properties intro (Expressions with exponents)
blurb: Learn the rules for simplifying exponent expressions.

name: Negative exponents (Expressions with exponents)
blurb: It's normally a bad idea to hang around with negative people or do negative things, but we think it's OK to associate with negative exponents. As a matter of fact, we'll learn that positive and negative exponents have quite the opposite effect on their bases.

name: Exponent properties (integer exponents) (Expressions with exponents)
blurb: Practice using the exponent properties to rewrite powers, where the exponent can either be positive or negative.

name: Scientific notation intro (Expressions with exponents)
blurb: Scientists and engineers often deal with super huge numbers like 6,000,000,000,000,000,000,000 and super small numbers like 0.0000000000532. How can they do this without tiring their hands out?  How can they look at a number and understand how large or small it is without counting the digits? The answer to both questions: scientific notation.

name: Scientific notation word problems (Expressions with exponents)
blurb: Solve word problems involving scientific notation.

name: Adding & subtracting polynomials (Quadratics and polynomials)
blurb: Learn how to add and subtract polynomial expressions with one variable.

name: Multiplying binomials (Quadratics and polynomials)
blurb: Learn how to multiply monomials and binomials.

name: Special products of binomials (Quadratics and polynomials)
blurb: Learn about the special types of products of binomials: perfect squares and the difference of two squares. These will be very helpful once you tackle more advanced expressions in Algebra.

name: Factoring polynomials by taking common factors (Quadratics and polynomials)
blurb: Learn how to take a common monomial factor out of a polynomial expression. For example, write 2x³+6x²+8x as (2x)(x²+3x+4).

name: Factoring quadratics 1 (Quadratics and polynomials)
blurb: Learn how to factor quadratic expressions with a leading coefficient of 1. For example, factor x²+3x+2 as (x+1)(x+2).

name: Factoring quadratics 2 (Quadratics and polynomials)
blurb: Learn how to factor quadratic expressions with a leading coefficient other than 1. For example, factor 2x²+7x+3 as (2x+1)(x+3).

name: Factoring quadratics: Difference of squares (Quadratics and polynomials)
blurb: Learn how to factor quadratics that have the "difference of squares" form. For example, write x²-16 as (x+4)(x-4). Learn how to identify this form in more elaborate expressions. For example, write 4x²-49 as (2x+7)(2x-7).

name: Factoring quadratics: Perfect squares (Quadratics and polynomials)
blurb: Learn how to factor quadratics that have the "perfect square" form. For example, write x²+6x+9 as (x+3)². Learn how to identify these forms in more elaborate expressions. For example, write 4x²+28x+49 as (2x+7)².

name: Solving quadratic equations by factoring (Quadratics and polynomials)
blurb: In this tutorial, you'll learn some pretty elaborate ways of solving quadratic equations, by harnessing the mighty strength of algebra.

name: Equations & geometry (Equations and geometry)
blurb: Solve problems in geometry by creating and solving appropriate linear equations.

name: Triangle angles (Equations and geometry)
blurb: Do the angles in a triangle always add up to the same thing?  Would I ask it if they didn't?  What do we know about the angles of a triangle if two of the sides are congruent (an isosceles triangle) or all three are congruent (an equilateral)?  This tutorial is the place to find out.

name: Pythagorean theorem (Equations and geometry)
blurb: Named after the Greek philosopher who lived nearly 2600 years ago, the Pythagorean theorem is as good as math theorems get (Pythagoras also started a religious movement).  It's simple.  It's beautiful.  It's powerful.

name: Triangle similarity intro (Equations and geometry)
blurb: In this tutorial, we will use what we learned about similarity of polygons in the specific case of triangles. We will come up with specific conditions for triangles to be similar, and use them to determine whether two triangles are similar.

name: Solving similar triangles (Equations and geometry)
blurb: Learn how to find missing measures of triangles using the fact that they are similar to other triangles.

name: Overview and history of algebra (Algebra foundations)
blurb:
Did you realize that the word "algebra" comes from Arabic (just like "algorithm" and "al jazeera" and "Aladdin")?  And what is so great about algebra anyway?  

This tutorial doesn't explore algebra so much as it introduces the history and ideas that underpin it.

name: Introduction to variables (Algebra foundations)
blurb: Wait, why are we using letters in math? How can an 'x' represent a number? What number is it? This tutorial is great if you're just beginning to delve into the world of variables and expressions.

name: Substitution and evaluating expressions (Algebra foundations)
blurb: Learn how to substitute (or "plug in") values for variables and evaluate algebraic expressions.

name: Evaluating expressions word problems (Algebra foundations)
blurb: Learn how to plug in values to evaluate real-world expressions.

name: Writing algebraic expressions introduction (Algebra foundations)
blurb: Learn the basics of writing expressions with variables.

name: Dependent & independent variables (Algebra foundations)
blurb: Sometimes one variable depends on another. For example, the amount of money you make might depend on how many hours you work.

name: Combining like terms (Algebra foundations)
blurb: Learn how to combine like terms (with negative numbers and variables), including more complex problems involving the distributive property.

name: Introduction to equivalent algebraic expressions (Algebra foundations)
blurb: Learn to tell whether or not two algebraic expressions are equivalent by combining like terms and using the distributive property.

name: Interpreting linear expressions (Algebra foundations)
blurb: Any expression (mathematical or otherwise) has meaning. Help us match the linear expression to the meaning options given. In some cases, more than one meaning may apply.

name: Division by zero (Algebra foundations)
blurb: Sal uses algebraic reasoning to tackle the problems of dividing by zero.

name: Algebraic equations basics (One-variable linear equations)
blurb: Explore what it means for equations with variables (algebraic equations) to be solved.

name: Why we do the same thing to both sides of an equation (One-variable linear equations)
blurb: A high-level, conceptual walk-through of what an equation represents and why we do the same thing to both sides of it

name: One-step addition & subtraction equations (One-variable linear equations)
blurb: Solve equations by adding and subtracting numbers from both sides.

name: One-step multiplication & division equations (One-variable linear equations)
blurb: Solve equations by multiplying and dividing numbers from both sides.

name: Two-steps equations intro (One-variable linear equations)
blurb: Learn how to solve equations like 2x+7=13 and 3(x+4)=3, which can be solved in two steps.

name: Two-step equation word problems (One-variable linear equations)
blurb: Learn how to set up and solve equations to find answers to real-world questions.

name: Linear equations with variables on both sides (One-variable linear equations)
blurb: Learn how to solve linear equations that have the variable on both sides of the equation. For example, solve 2x+5=6x-3.

name: Linear equations with parentheses (One-variable linear equations)
blurb: Learn how to solve linear equations with parentheses using the distributive property. For example, solve -9 - (9x - 6) = 3(4x + 6).

name: Analyzing the number of solutions to linear equations (One-variable linear equations)
blurb: Linear equations can either have a single solution, infinite solutions, or no solutions. Learn how to determine the number of solutions to a given equation, and how to create equations with a desired number of solutions.

name: Linear equations word problems (One-variable linear equations)
blurb: Solve word problems by creating linear equations and solving them.

name: Solving for a variable (One-variable linear equations)
blurb: An equation like ax+3x=bx+5 can still be solved for x even though some of the coefficients are variables.

name: Introduction to inequalities with variables (Solving inequalities)
blurb: Algebraic inequalities (inequalities with variables) are useful for describing real-world situations. Learn how to write inequalities and graph them on the number line.

name: One-step inequalities (Solving inequalities)
blurb: Learn how to solve (mathematical) inequalities. A key concept in this tutorial is flipping the inequality sign when multiplying or dividing both sides by a negative number.

name: Two-step inequalities (Solving inequalities)
blurb: Learn how to solve more complex (mathematical) inequalities. Also learn to construct inequalities to model real-world situations.

name: Multi-step inequalities (Solving inequalities)
blurb: Solve any possible linear inequality in one variable. For example, solve -3x-7<x+9.

name: Compound inequalities (Solving inequalities)
blurb: Learn how to solve compound inequalities. For example, solve 2x+1>3 AND -x-5<4.

name: Rate conversion (Working with units | Algebra 1 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Practice solving word problems that involve the conversion between different units for the same quantity. For example, a rate problem where some rates are in km/h and some are in m/s.

name: Appropriate units (Working with units | Algebra 1 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how to work with units that are arithmetic combinations of more simple units. For example, velocity units are quotients of distance units over time units, which corresponds to the formula v=d/t.

name: Word problems with multiple units (Working with units | Algebra 1 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Practice solving word problems that involve a variety of units.

name: Two-variable linear equations intro (Two-variable linear equations)
blurb: Understand what a solution to an equation really means. Practice plugging in values for variables to see whether or not an equation is true.

name: x-intercepts and y-intercepts (Two-variable linear equations)
blurb: Learn about intercepts and practice finding them from graphs, tables, and equations.

name: Slope (Two-variable linear equations)
blurb: Learn about slope (the steepness of a line) and how to find it.

name: Horizontal & vertical lines (Two-variable linear equations)
blurb: You know what horizontal and vertical lines are, but how do their equations look? And what is their slope? Learn all about it in this tutorial.

name: Intro to slope-intercept form (Two-variable linear equations)
blurb: Make an introduction with the most common form of linear equations, slope-intercept form! For example, y=3x+5 is a linear equation in slope-intercept form.

name: Graphing slope-intercept equations (Two-variable linear equations)
blurb: Learn how to graph linear equations that are given in slope-intercept form. For example, graph y=2x+3.

name: Writing slope-intercept equations (Two-variable linear equations)
blurb: Learn how to write the equation of a line (in slope-intercept form) when given the graph of the equation or two points on the line. For example, write the equation of the line that passes through the points (0,1) and (5,4).

name: Point-slope form (Two-variable linear equations)
blurb: (y-b)=m(x-a)

name: Standard form (Two-variable linear equations)
blurb: ax+by=c

name: Summary: Forms of two-variable linear equations (Two-variable linear equations)
blurb: Take an overview of the three main forms of linear equations: slope-intercept, point-slope, and standard. Learn which form is most appropriate for different uses.

name: Evaluating functions (Functions | Algebra 1 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how to find the value of a function for a given input value.

name: Inputs and outputs of a function (Functions | Algebra 1 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Extend your understanding of the relationship between the inputs of a function and the outputs of that function.

name: Functions and equations (Functions | Algebra 1 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Understand the subtle differences and similarities between functions and equations. In this exercise, we will see how an equation can be turned into a function.

name: Interpreting function notation (Functions | Algebra 1 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Solve some word problems by interpreting expressions of modeling functions.

name: Introduction to the domain and range of a function (Functions | Algebra 1 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn what the domain and the range of a function are. Practice finding the domain and the range of a function given its graph.

name: Determining the domain of a function (Functions | Algebra 1 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Determine the domains of functions according to various considerations.

name: Recognizing functions (Functions | Algebra 1 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how to distinguish between two-variable relationships that are functions and two-variable relationships that aren't functions.

name: Maximum and minimum points (Functions | Algebra 1 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn about maximum and minimum points of functions.

name: Intervals where a function is positive, negative, increasing, or decreasing (Functions | Algebra 1 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn about features of functions that have distinct graphical representations: intervals where the function is always positive or always negative, and intervals where the function is always increasing or always decreasing.

name: Interpreting features of graphs (Functions | Algebra 1 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Interpret the graphs of functions in terms of the contexts that are modeled by the functions.

name: Average rate of change (Functions | Algebra 1 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn what's the average rate of change of a function and how to find it over given intervals.

name: Average rate of change word problems (Functions | Algebra 1 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Solve word problems that concern the average rate of change of a functional relationship.

name: Interpreting linear functions and equations (Linear word problems)
blurb: Solve word problems where you need to answer a question about a real-world relationship based on its mathematical model.

name: Comparing linear functions (Linear word problems)
blurb: Compare features of linear functions, such as slope and intercepts, where the functions are given in different forms—tables, graphs, or formulas.

name: Constructing linear models for real-world relationships (Linear word problems)
blurb: Learn how to represent real-world relationships (that are described verbally) with linear graphs, equations, or functions.

name: Linear models word problems (Linear word problems)
blurb: Solve general word problems about real-world relationships that can be modeled by linear equations or functions.

name: Introduction to arithmetic sequences (Sequences)
blurb: Learn about arithmetic sequences and their main features, the initial term and the common difference. Evaluate arithmetic sequences.

name: Arithmetic sequences (Sequences)
blurb: Learn how to find the explicit or recursive formula of an arithmetic sequence.

name: Introduction to geometric sequences (Sequences)
blurb: Learn about geometric sequences and their main features, the initial term and the common ratio. Evaluate geometric sequences.

name: Geometric sequences (Sequences)
blurb: Learn how to find the explicit or recursive formula of a geometric sequence.

name: Modeling with sequences (Sequences)
blurb: Now that we've mastered arithmetic and geometric sequences, let's see how they can help us solve real-world word problems. In this tutorial you will find the formula for a sequence that models a real-world relationship.

name: General sequences (Sequences)
blurb: Arithmetic and geometric sequences are very useful, but they are definitely not the only kinds of sequences out there. Let's zoom out and consider some other kinds of sequences.

name: Introduction to systems of equations (Systems of equations | Algebra 1 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn what "systems of equations" are, what counts as a solution to such a system, and how we can use graphs to solve them.

name: Equivalent systems of equations and the elimination method (Systems of equations | Algebra 1 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn about the elimination method, which is a way manipulate systems of equations in order to solve them algebraically. This is actually very similar to the way we manipulate single equations in order to solve them!

name: Solving systems of equations with substitution (Systems of equations | Algebra 1 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn about the substitution method, which is another way to manipulate systems of equations in order to solve them.

name: Manipulating expressions with unknown variables (Systems of equations | Algebra 1 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how to rewrite expressions with variables whose values are unknown, by using another information about those variables. For example, given that a+b=0, express a*b in terms of b alone.

name: Number of solutions to systems of equations (Systems of equations | Algebra 1 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn about the possible number of solutions of systems of linear equations. Spoiler: There can be a single solution, zero solutions, or infinite solutions. These different cases define the distinctions between "consistent" and "inconsistent" systems, and between "dependent" and "independent" systems.

name: Solving any system of linear equations (Systems of equations | Algebra 1 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Use everything you learned so far in order to solve any kind of system of equations!

name: Systems of equations word problems (Systems of equations | Algebra 1 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Now that we are able to solve any kind of system we are given, it's time to use that knowledge to solve some word problems.

name: Checking solutions of inequalities (Inequalities (systems & graphs))
blurb: Learn how to check possible solutions of two-variable linear inequalities. For example, is (2, 0) a solution to y>x+1? In this tutorial, we also check solutions to systems of inequalities.

name: Graphing two-variable inequalities (Inequalities (systems & graphs))
blurb: Learn how to graph two-variables linear inequalities and systems of two-variable linear inequalities.

name: Modeling with linear inequalities (Inequalities (systems & graphs))
blurb: Learn how to construct linear inequalities and systems of inequalities given a real-life context. Learn how to interpret such inequalities in terms of a real-life context, either algebraically or graphically.

name: Graphs of absolute value functions (Absolute value & piecewise functions)
blurb: Learn how to graph absolute value functions like f(x)=|x+2|-8.

name: Piecewise functions (Absolute value & piecewise functions)
blurb: We are used to functions that have the same rule for all inputs. For example, f(x)=x² outputs the square of every input. Piecewise functions have different output rules, depending on the inputs. For example, we can define function g to output x² for all positive values of x and x³ for all negative values of x, so g(2)=4 and g(-2)=-8.

name: Exponent properties review (Rational exponents & radicals)
blurb: Practice using the exponent properties to rewrite powers, where the exponent is an integer that can either be positive or negative.

name: Radicals (Rational exponents & radicals)
blurb: Radicals (also known as roots) are a generalization of square roots. They are the inverse operation of any power. For example, the 5th root of 32 is 2, because 2⁵=32.

name: Rational exponents intro (Rational exponents & radicals)
blurb: Learn the definition for raising a number by a fractional exponent, like 8^⅔.

name: Properties of exponents (rational exponents) (Rational exponents & radicals)
blurb: In this tutorial you will rewrite variable expressions with rational exponents using the properties of exponents.

name: Advanced exponent & radical evaluation (Rational exponents & radicals)
blurb: Evaluate elaborate expressions that contain radicals and fractional exponents.

name: Simplifying square roots (Rational exponents & radicals)
blurb: We know how to evaluate square roots of perfect squares. For example, √16=4. What about the other square roots? It's harder to give an exact number, but we can simplify them so we have a better understanding of their value. For example, √32=4⋅√2. Learn more about it in this tutorial.

name: Simplifying radicals (higher-index roots) (Rational exponents & radicals)
blurb: Just like we can simplify square roots, we can simplify other radicals. This tutorial covers the simplification of higher-index roots. For example, ∜48=2⋅∜3.

name: Exponential vs. linear growth (Exponential growth & decay | Algebra 1 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn about exponential growth and decay, and specifically how it always grows (or diminishes) by equal factors.

name: Exponential expressions (Exponential growth & decay | Algebra 1 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how to construct exponential functions to model real-world situations.

name: Graphs of exponential growth (Exponential growth & decay | Algebra 1 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how an exponential function behaves as the value of its input increases to positive infinity or decreases to negative infinity. Learn how to graph basic exponential functions.

name: Exponential vs. linear growth over time (Exponential growth & decay | Algebra 1 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how to distinguish between linear and exponential growth, and learn the differences between the end behavior of polynomial and exponential functions.

name: Exponential decay (Exponential growth & decay | Algebra 1 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how to construct exponential functions and then analyze them to model and solve real-world problems.

name: Exponential functions from tables & graphs (Exponential growth & decay | Algebra 1 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how to analyze the formulas of basic exponential functions in order to find their common ratio, initial value, and other parameters.

name: Intro to polynomials (Polynomials | Algebra 1 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn about polynomial expressions: What are they? How are they constructed? What can we do with them?

name: Introduction to polynomial operations (Polynomials | Algebra 1 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how to add and subtract polynomial expressions with one variable.

name: Adding and subtracting polynomials: two variables (Polynomials | Algebra 1 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how to add and subtract polynomial that involve two variables. For example, x^3 + xy + 3y - (x^3 + 6xy + 2y^2).

name: Multiplying monomials (Polynomials | Algebra 1 | Khan Academy)
blurb: As an intro to more elaborate polynomial multiplication, learn how to multiply monomials (which are polynomials with a single term). For example, multiply 2x³ and 5x⁷.

name: Multiplying a monomial by a polynomial (Polynomials | Algebra 1 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how to multiply a polynomial expression by a monomial expression. Monomials are just polynomials with a single term!

name: Multiplying binomials (Polynomials | Algebra 1 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how to multiply two binomials together. For example, (3x - 7) * (10x + 2).

name: Multiplying binomials by polynomials (Polynomials | Algebra 1 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how to multiply a polynomial expression by a binomial expression.

name: Special products of binomials (Polynomials | Algebra 1 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn about the special types of products of binomials: perfect squares and the difference of two squares. These will be very helpful once you tackle more advanced expressions in Algebra.

name: Polynomials word problems (Polynomials | Algebra 1 | Khan Academy)
blurb: See a few examples of how we can represent real-world situations with polynomials.

name: Introduction to factorization (Factorization)
blurb: Learn what factorization is all about, and warm-up by factoring some monomials.

name: Factoring monomials (Factorization)
blurb: Learn how to write a monomial as a factor of two other monomials. For example, write 12x^3 as (4x)(3x^2).

name: Factoring polynomials by taking common factors (Factorization)
blurb: Learn how to take a common monomial factor out of a polynomial expression. For example, write 2x^3+6x^2+8x as (2x)(x^2+3x+4).

name: Evaluating expressions with unknown variables (Factorization)
blurb: Learn how to evaluate expressions with variables whose values are unknown, by using another information about those variables. For example, given that a+b=3, evaluate 4a+4b.

name: Factoring quadratics intro (Factorization)
blurb: Learn how to factor quadratic expressions with a leading coefficient of 1. For example, factor x²+3x+2 as (x+1)(x+2).

name: Factoring quadratics by grouping (Factorization)
blurb: Learn how to factor quadratic expressions with a leading coefficient other than 1. For example, factor 2x²+7x+3 as (2x+1)(x+3).

name: Factoring polynomials with quadratic forms (Factorization)
blurb: Learn how to factor quadratic polynomials of the form ax^2+bx+c as the product of two linear binomials. For example, write x^2+3x-10 as (x+5)(x-2). Learn how to identify these forms in more elaborate polynomials that aren't necessarily quadratic. For example, write x^4-4x^2-12 as (x^2+2)(x^2-6).

name: Factoring quadratics: Difference of squares (Factorization)
blurb: Learn how to factor quadratics that have the "difference of squares" form. For example, write x²-16 as (x+4)(x-4). Learn how to identify this form in more elaborate expressions. For example, write 4x²-49 as (2x+7)(2x-7).

name: Factoring quadratics: Perfect squares (Factorization)
blurb: Learn how to factor quadratics that have the "perfect square" form. For example, write x²+6x+9 as (x+3)². Learn how to identify these forms in more elaborate expressions. For example, write 4x²+28x+49 as (2x+7)².

name: Strategy in factoring quadratics (Factorization)
blurb: There are a lot of methods to factor quadratics, which apply on different occasions and conditions. Now that we know all of them, let's think strategically about which of them is useful for a given quadratic expression we want to factor.

name: Factoring polynomials with special product forms (Factorization)
blurb: Factor polynomials of various degrees using factorization methods that are based on the special product forms "difference of squares" and "perfect squares." For example, factor 25x⁴-30x²+9 as (5x²-3)².

name: Parabolas intro (Quadratics)
blurb: Learn what parabolas are and about their main features: their general shape, vertex, and axis of symmetry.

name: Quadratic factored form (Quadratics)
blurb: The factored form of a quadratic function is an expression that is, well, factored! Like f(x)=(2x+1)(x-3). Learn how to analyze functions given in this form to find their zeros, their vertex, and their graph.

name: Solving quadratics by taking square roots (Quadratics)
blurb: In this tutorial you will learn about the most basic way of solving quadratic equations.

name: Quadratic vertex form (Quadratics)
blurb: The vertex form of a quadratic function shows the coordinates of the parabola's vertex. For example, the vertex of g(x)=(x-1)²+2 is at (1,2). Learn how to analyze functions given in this form to find their zeros, their vertex, and their graph.

name: Solving quadratics by factoring (Quadratics)
blurb: In this tutorial, you'll learn some pretty elaborate ways of solving quadratic equations, by harnessing the mighty strength of algebra.

name: Completing the square (Quadratics)
blurb: You're already familiar with factoring quadratics, but have begun to realize that it only is useful in certain cases.  Well, this tutorial will introduce you to something far more powerful and general.  Even better, it is the bridge to understanding and proving the famous quadratic formula.

name: The quadratic formula (Quadratics)
blurb: Learn how to solve any quadratic equation with the most general tool of all, the quadratic formula!

name: Quadratic standard form (Quadratics)
blurb: In this tutorial, we will learn how to graph quadratic functions given in different forms.

name: Features & forms of quadratic functions (Quadratics)
blurb: Learn about the features of quadratic functions, and how to find them given the formula of the function. Also learn about the different forms of quadratic functions: standard, vertex, and factored.

name: Transforming parabolas (Quadratics)
blurb: Learn how function transformations affect the graphs of quadratic functions.

name: Rational and irrational numbers (Irrational numbers)
blurb: Learn what irrational numbers are. Also learn how to classify numbers as whole, integer, rational, and irrational.

name: Rational and irrational expressions (Irrational numbers)
blurb: Determine whether various combinations of rational and irrational numbers are rational or irrational themselves.

name: Proofs concerning irrational numbers (Irrational numbers)
blurb: Learn some proofs about the existence of irrational numbers.

name: Intro to Euclidean geometry (Geometry foundations)
blurb:
Roughly 2400 years ago, Euclid of Alexandria wrote Elements which served as the world's geometry textbook until recently.  Studied by Abraham Lincoln in order to sharpen his mind and truly appreciate mathematical deduction, it is still the basis of what we consider a first year course in geometry.

This tutorial gives a bit of this background and then lays the conceptual foundation of points, lines, circles and planes that we will use as we journey through the world of Euclid.

name: Angles (Geometry foundations)
blurb: Review your knowledge about angles.

name: Polygons (Geometry foundations)
blurb: Review your knowledge about triangles, quadrilaterals, and polygons in general.

name: Area (Geometry foundations)
blurb: Review your knowledge about area.

name: Introduction to rigid transformations (Transformations)
blurb: The three rigid transformations are translations, rotations, and reflections. Get to know them and gain some experience in performing them on different figures.

name: Translations (Transformations)
blurb: Learn how to find the translation that maps a given figure to another, and how to manually draw the image of a translation.

name: Rotations (Transformations)
blurb: Learn how to find the rotation that maps a given figure to another, and how to manually draw the image of a rotation.

name: Reflections (Transformations)
blurb: Learn how to find the reflection that maps a given figure to another, and how to manually draw the image of a reflection.

name: Rigid transformations overview (Transformations)
blurb: After studying each rigid transformation in separate, it's time to take a broader look at those transformations: which properties are preserved under which kind of transformation, and how do we map shapes using sequences of rigid transformations?

name: Dilations (Transformations)
blurb:
In addition to the three rigid transformation, there are the dilations, which expand or shrink figures while keeping the same proportions. These are extremely important in the subject of Similarity!

Gain experience by performing dilation, learn how to find the dilation that maps a given figure to another, and learn how to manually draw the image of a dilation.

name: Properties & definitions of transformations (Transformations)
blurb: Let's continue our deep voyage through the world of transformations! Use your knowledge about the precise descriptions of the rigid transformations and their properties in various situations.

name: Symmetry (Transformations)
blurb: Learn about different kinds of symmetries of two-dimensional shapes, and analyze various shapes according to their symmetries.

name: Transformations & congruence (Congruence)
blurb: Two figures are congruent if you can go from one to another through some combination of translations, reflections and rotations.  In this tutorial, we'll really internalize this by working through the actual transformations.

name: Triangle congruence (Congruence)
blurb: Learn how the definition of congruence using rigid transformations can be simplified to simple criteria when studying congruent triangles.

name: Theorems concerning triangle properties (Congruence)
blurb: Now that we know how to show that two triangles are congruent, let's put that to use by proving some theorems about triangles.

name: Working with triangles (Congruence)
blurb: Learn how to solve different geometric problems using triangle congruence.

name: Theorems concerning parallelogram properties (Congruence)
blurb: Triangle congruence is not only useful when working with triangles, it's also useful with any other kind of polygon! Prove a few theorems about the properties of parallelograms using triangle congruence.

name: Proofs of theorems that use triangle congruence (Congruence)
blurb: Gain even more experience with using triangle congruence in proofs.

name: Constructing bisectors of lines & angles (Congruence)
blurb: With just a compass and a straightedge  (or virtual versions of them), you'll be amazed by how many geometric shapes you can construct perfectly.  This tutorial gets you started with the building block of how to bisect angle and lines (and how to construct perpendicular bisectors of lines).

name: Definitions of similarity (Similarity)
blurb: In this tutorial, you will learn how we determine whether two figures are similar.

name: Introduction to triangle similarity (Similarity)
blurb: In this tutorial, we will use what we learned about similarity of polygons in the specific case of triangles. We will come up with specific conditions for triangles to be similar, and use them to determine whether two triangles are similar.

name: Solving similar triangles (Similarity)
blurb: Learn how to find missing measures of triangles using the fact that they are similar to other triangles.

name: Angle bisector theorem (Similarity)
blurb: Learn about the angle bisector theorem, which makes a clever use of triangle similarity in order to find a special proportion that holds for angle bisectors of triangles.

name: Solving problems with similar & congruent triangles (Similarity)
blurb: You already saw how we can use similarity and congruence to find missing measures in triangles. Let's do the same now to solve more kinds of polygons, and more challenging problems!

name: Solving modeling problems with similar & congruent triangles (Similarity)
blurb: Now that you are an expert with solving geometry problems using congruence and similarity, you are ready to solve some real-world problems!

name: Pythagorean theorem (Right triangles & trigonometry)
blurb:
Named after the Greek philosopher who lived nearly 2600 years ago, the Pythagorean theorem is as good as math theorems get (Pythagoras also started a religious movement).  It's simple.  It's beautiful.  It's powerful.

In this tutorial, we will cover what it is and how it can be used.  We have another tutorial that gives you as many proofs of it as you might need.

name: Pythagorean theorem proofs (Right triangles & trigonometry)
blurb: The Pythagorean theorem is one of the most famous ideas in all of mathematics.  This tutorial proves it.  Then proves it again... and again... and again.  More than just satisfying any skepticism of whether the Pythagorean theorem is really true (only one proof would be sufficient for that), it will hopefully open your mind to new and beautiful ways to prove something very powerful.

name: Special right triangles (Right triangles & trigonometry)
blurb: We hate to pick favorites, but there really are certain right triangles that are more special than others.  In this tutorial, we pick them out, show why they're special, and prove it!  These include 30-60-90 and 45-45-90 triangles (the numbers refer to the measure of the angles in the triangle).

name: Introduction to the trigonometric ratios (Right triangles & trigonometry)
blurb: Learn what sine, cosine, and tangent are.

name: Solving for a side in a right triangle using the trigonometric ratios (Right triangles & trigonometry)
blurb: Learn how to find a side length in a right triangle when given one side length and one acute angle.

name: Solving for an angle in a right triangle using the trigonometric ratios (Right triangles & trigonometry)
blurb: Learn how to find an acute angle in a right triangle when given two side lengths.

name: Modeling with right triangles (Right triangles & trigonometry)
blurb: Solve real-world problems that can be modeled by right triangles, using trigonometry.

name: Trigonometric ratios & similarity (Right triangles & trigonometry)
blurb: Learn how the trigonometric ratios are derived from triangle similarity considerations.

name: Sine & cosine of complementary angles (Right triangles & trigonometry)
blurb: Learn about the relationship between the sine of an angle and the cosine of its complementary angle, which is the angle that completes to 90°.

name: Law of sines (Right triangles & trigonometry)
blurb: Learn about the Law of sines and how to use it in order to find missing side lengths and angles in general triangles.

name: Law of cosines (Right triangles & trigonometry)
blurb: Learn about the Law of cosines and how to use it in order to find missing side lengths and angles in general triangles.

name: Solving general triangles (Right triangles & trigonometry)
blurb: Use the power of trigonometry in order to solve various problems that involve triangles.

name: Solid geometry intro (Solid geometry)
blurb: Tired of perimeter and area and now want to measure 3-D space-take-upness.  Well you've found the right tutorial.  Enjoy!

name: Density (Solid geometry)
blurb: Use your knowledge of surface area and volume to solve problems involving density.

name: 2D vs. 3D objects (Solid geometry)
blurb: Visualize the relation between two-dimensional and three-dimensional objects.

name: Distance and midpoints (Analytic geometry)
blurb: Find the distance between two points or the midpoint of two points.

name: Dividing line segments (Analytic geometry)
blurb: Think about ratios of lengths of segments between points.

name: Problem solving with distance on the coordinate plane (Analytic geometry)
blurb: Use what you know about distance to solve problems on the coordinate plan like finding the perimeter of a shape or determining if a point is on a circle.

name: Parallel & perpendicular lines on the coordinate plane (Analytic geometry)
blurb: You probably know what parallel and perpendicular lines are. In this tutorial, you will learn how these relationships are expressed on the coordinate plane (spoiler: parallel lines have the same slope, and the product of the slopes of perpendicular lines is always -1).

name: Equations of parallel & perpendicular lines (Analytic geometry)
blurb: Learn all about equations of parallel and perpendicular

name: Circles basics (Circles)
blurb: Make sure you're familiar with notation and key terms like radius, diameter, circumference, pi, tangent, secant, and major/minor arcs before you dive into the rest of the circles content.

name: Arc measures (Circles)
blurb: Arc measure is equal to the arc's central angle. We'll explore this fact and solve some problems related to it.

name: Arc length (degrees) (Circles)
blurb: Think about the relationship between central angle and arc length. This tutorial uses degrees not radians.

name: Introduction to radians (Circles)
blurb: Most people know that you can measure angles with degrees, but only exceptionally worldly people know that radians can be an exciting alternative. As you'll see, degrees are somewhat arbitrary.

name: Arc length (radians) (Circles)
blurb: Think about the relationships between arc measures, central angles, and arc length in radians.

name: Sectors (Circles)
blurb: Learn how to find the area of a sector.

name: Inscribed angles (Circles)
blurb: We'll now dig a bit deeper in our understanding of circles by looking at inscribed angles and related properties.

name: Inscribed shapes problem solving (Circles)
blurb: Use properties of inscribed angles to prove properties of inscribed shapes, then apply these properties some fun problem solving!

name: Properties of tangents (Circles)
blurb: Explore, prove, and apply properties of circles that involve tangents.

name: Standard equation of a circle (Circles)
blurb: Learn about the standard form to represent a circle with an equation. For example, the equation (x-1)^2+(y+2)^2=9 is a circle whose center is (1,-2) and radius is 3.

name: Expanded equation of a circle (Circles)
blurb: Learn how to analyze an equation of a circle that is not given in the standard form. For example, find the center of the circle whose equation is x^2+y^2+4x-5=0.

name: Constructing regular polygons inscribed in circles (Circles)
blurb: Have you ever wondered how people would draw a square, equilateral triangle or even hexagon before there were computers?  Well, now you're going to do just that (ironically, with a computer).  Using our virtual compass and straightedge, you'll construct several regular shapes (by inscribing them inside circles).

name: Constructing circumcircles & incircles (Circles)
blurb: In our study of triangles, we spent a decent amount of time think about incenters (the intersections of the angle bisectors) and circumcenters (the intersections of the perpendicular bisectors).  We'll now leverage this knowledge to actually construct circle inscribed and circumscribed about a triangle using only a compass and straightedge (actually virtual versions of them).

name: Constructing a line tangent to a circle (Circles)
blurb: Learn how to construct tangents to circles with certain conditions using compass and straightedge. For example, draw the tangent to a given circle that passes through a given point.

name: Combining functions (Functions | Algebra 2 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how to take two basic functions and combine them into a new function which is their sum, difference, product, or quotient.

name: Composing functions (Functions | Algebra 2 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn what function composition is, how to to work with composite functions, and how to find the formulas of the composition of two functions.

name: Modeling situations by combining and composing functions (Functions | Algebra 2 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Make use of knowledge in combining and composing functions, by modeling complex real-world situations.

name: Shifting functions (Functions | Algebra 2 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how to transform functions so their graph is shifted horizontally or vertically. Learn how to find the equation of a function that is a shift of another function.

name: Stretching functions (Functions | Algebra 2 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how to transform functions so their graph is stretched horizontally or vertically. Learn how to find the equation of a function that is a stretch of another function.

name: Introduction to inverses of functions (Functions | Algebra 2 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn what inverses of functions are, and gain some experience with them by finding the outputs of the inverse of a function given that function.

name: Finding inverse functions (Functions | Algebra 2 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how to find the inverses of polynomials functions, radical functions, and rational functions.

name: Verifying that functions are inverses (Functions | Algebra 2 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how to check whether a pair of functions are the inverses of one another.

name: Determining whether a function is invertible (Functions | Algebra 2 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn about the conditions for a function to be invertible, and learn how to manipulate functions to make them invertible.

name: What are the imaginary numbers? (Complex numbers | Algebra 2 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn about the imaginary unit i (which is the square root of -1) and about imaginary numbers like 3i (which is the square root of -9).

name: What are the complex numbers? (Complex numbers | Algebra 2 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn about complex numbers (spoiler: they are numbers that consist of both real and imaginary parts).

name: The complex plane (Complex numbers | Algebra 2 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how we can visualize complex numbers in a plane. This can be seen as an expansion of the 1-dimensional real number line into a 2-dimensional plane!

name: Adding and subtracting complex numbers (Complex numbers | Algebra 2 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how to add or subtract complex numbers. For example, write (2+3i)-(1+2i) as (1+i).

name: Multiplying complex numbers (Complex numbers | Algebra 2 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how to multiply complex numbers using the fact that i^2=-1 and the distributive property. For example, multiply (1+i) by (2+3i).

name: Adding and subtracting polynomials (Arithmetic with polynomials)
blurb: Learn how to add and subtract two polynomials to obtain another polynomial. For instance, express (3x^3+2x-1)+(2x^4-x^3+7x) as a polynomial in standard form.

name: Multiplying polynomials (Arithmetic with polynomials)
blurb: Learn how to multiply two polynomials to obtain another polynomial. For instance, express (2x^2+5)*(x^3-2x+6) as a polynomial in standard form.

name: Long division of polynomials (Arithmetic with polynomials)
blurb: Learn how to divide two polynomials using long division.

name: Synthetic division of polynomials (Arithmetic with polynomials)
blurb: Learn how to divide polynomials using synthetic division.

name: Practice dividing polynomials with remainders (Arithmetic with polynomials)
blurb: After learning about the different methods in which we can find the quotient and the remainder of two polynomials, gain some practice with actually performing polynomial division yourself.

name: Polynomial remainder theorem (Arithmetic with polynomials)
blurb: The polynomial remainder theorem allows us to easily determine whether a linear expression is a factor of a given polynomial. Learn exactly what the theorem means, practice using it, and learn about its proof.

name: The binomial theorem (Polynomials | Algebra 2 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how to expand powers of binomial expressions (which are polynomial expressions with exactly two terms). This is done using the binomial theorem!

name: Understanding the binomial theorem (Polynomials | Algebra 2 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Now that you know how to use the binomial theorem in order to expand powers of binomial expressions, let's gain further insight into why this actually works!

name: Factoring polynomials - Quadratic forms (Polynomials | Algebra 2 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how to factor quadratic polynomials of the form ax^2+bx+c as the product of two linear binomials. Learn how to identify these forms in more elaborate polynomials that aren't necessarily quadratic.

name: Factoring polynomials - Special product forms (Polynomials | Algebra 2 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how to factor quadratics that have the "perfect square" form and the "difference of squares" form. Learn how to identify these forms in more elaborate polynomials that aren't necessarily quadratic.

name: Advanced polynomial factorization methods (Polynomials | Algebra 2 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn more ways to factor polynomials with degree higher than 2.

name: Proving polynomial identities (Polynomials | Algebra 2 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Practice proving polynomial identities, using all the factorization and expansion methods you know.

name: Polynomial identities with complex numbers (Polynomials | Algebra 2 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Prove more polynomial identities, this time including complex numbers!

name: Quadratic equations with complex numbers (Polynomials | Algebra 2 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Remember all these quadratic equations with "no real solution"? Well, it turns out those equations do have a solution, it's just a complex number! Solve a bunch of those here.

name: The Fundamental Theorem of Algebra (Polynomials | Algebra 2 | Khan Academy)
blurb: You may already have noticed that quadratic equations always have a solution when including complex number solutions. It turns out this is true for any polynomial equation, of any degree! Learn about this and more, right here.

name: Finding zeros of polynomials (Polynomials | Algebra 2 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Use all the knowledge you have about polynomials to find their zeros (which are the input values that make the polynomial equal to zero).

name: Zeros of polynomials and their graphs (Polynomials | Algebra 2 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how to use the zeros of polynomials to draw a pretty good sketch of their graphs.

name: End behavior of polynomial functions (Polynomials | Algebra 2 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn about the end behavior of polynomial functions. End behavior is the way the function behaves as the input values grow infinitely positive or infinitely negative.

name: Graphs of polynomials (Polynomials | Algebra 2 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Combine your knowledge about the zeros and the end behavior of a polynomial in order to sketch its graph.

name: Introduction to symmetry of functions (Polynomials | Algebra 2 | Khan Academy)
blurb: You may already be familiar with types of symmetries of geometrical shapes. Learn how functions can be symmetrical too!

name: Symmetry of polynomial functions (Polynomials | Algebra 2 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how to determine the symmetry of a polynomial function.

name: Solving square-root equations (Radical relationships)
blurb: Learn how to solve equations with square-root expressions in them. For example, solve √(2x-5)=√(7-3x).

name: Analyzing extraneous solutions of square-root equations (Radical relationships)
blurb: Learn about the conditions for obtaining extraneous solutions while solving radical equations.

name: Solving cube-root equations (Radical relationships)
blurb: Learn how to solve equations with cube-root expressions in them. For example, solve ∛(2-6x)=x+3.

name: Domain of radical functions (Radical relationships)
blurb: Learn how the domain of radical functions is determined.

name: Graphs of radical functions (Radical relationships)
blurb: Learn how the graphs of radical functions look, and how we can reason about them using function transformations (i.e. shifts, stretches, etc.).

name: Simplifying rational expressions (Rational relationships)
blurb: Learn how to simplify rational expressions by canceling factors that are shared by the numerator and the denominator. Sometimes this calls for factoring the numerator and the denominator in various ways.

name: Multiplying and dividing rational expressions (Rational relationships)
blurb: Learn how to multiply and divide rational expressions. You will be surprised to see how similar it is to multiplying and dividing fractions!

name: Adding and subtracting rational expressions (Rational relationships)
blurb: Learn how to add and subtract rational expressions. Like multiplication and division, this skill has a remarkable affinity to adding and subtracting fractions!

name: Nested fractions (Rational relationships)
blurb: Learn how to simplify rational expressions that contain further rational expressions within their numerators or denominators.

name: Solving rational equations (Rational relationships)
blurb: Learn how to solve equations that have a rational expression, or a few of those.

name: Direct and inverse variation (Rational relationships)
blurb: Learn about direct and inverse variation, which are two types of relationships between two quantities. Direct variation is simply a proportional relationship, but inverse variation is more complicated and interesting. Gain some experience with it before we dive deeper into the world of rational functions.

name: End behavior of rational functions (Rational relationships)
blurb: Learn about the ways in which rational functions behave as x approaches positive or negative infinity. This gets interesting Learn how to determine this behavior for any kind of rational function.

name: Discontinuities of rational functions (Rational relationships)
blurb: Learn about the ways in which rational functions behave when their denominator is equal to zero. This gets interesting when vertical asymptotes are involved! Learn how to determine this behavior for any kind of rational function.

name: Graphs of rational functions (Rational relationships)
blurb: Combine your knowledge of intercepts, horizontal asymptotes, vertical asymptotes, and removable discontinuities, in order to analyze entire graphs of rational functions!

name: Modeling with rational functions (Rational relationships)
blurb: See some examples of how rational functions and equations can come in handy when solving real-world word problems.

name: Equivalent forms of exponential expressions (Exponential growth & decay | Algebra 2 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how to manipulate exponential expressions in different ways. For example, rewrite 8^x as 2^(3x).

name: Solving exponential equations using properties of exponents (Exponential growth & decay | Algebra 2 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how to solve advanced exponential equations by manipulating the expressions in the equations using the properties of exponents. For example, solve 2^(x+1)=8^x by rewriting 8^x as 2^(3x) and then equating x+1=3x.

name: Interpreting the rate of change of exponential models (Exponential growth & decay | Algebra 2 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how to analyze exponential modeling functions in order to find their rate of change.

name: Constructing exponential models according to rate of change (Exponential growth & decay | Algebra 2 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how to find the modeling function of an exponential real world context, according to the description of its rate of change.

name: Advanced interpretation of exponential models (Exponential growth & decay | Algebra 2 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how to interpret an exponential modeling function by first manipulating it according to your needs. For example, rewrite 5^(2x+1) as 5*25^x to find that the unit growth factor is 25.

name: Distinguishing between linear and exponential growth (Exponential growth & decay | Algebra 2 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how to analyze real-world quantitative relationships given as tables of values to determine whether they represent linear growth or exponential growth.

name: Introduction to logarithms (Exponentials & logarithms)
blurb: Learn how we define logarithms and use this definition in order to evaluate various logarithms. For example, evaluate log_2(8) as 3 by realizing that 2^3=8.

name: The constant e and the natural logarithm (Exponentials & logarithms)
blurb: Learn about a very special constant in math that has a pivotal role in the world of exponential and logarithmic function, the constant e.

name: Properties of logarithms (Exponentials & logarithms)
blurb: Learn about special properties of logarithms that help us rewrite logarithmic expressions in different equivalent (much like we use properties of exponents to rewrite exponential expressions!).

name: The change of base formula for logarithms (Exponentials & logarithms)
blurb: Learn how to rewrite any logarithmic expression in a different base. For example, rewrite log_2(3) as ln(3)/ln(2). This is very helpful for evaluating logarithms with a calculator, which only evaluates base-10 and base-e logarithms.

name: Solving exponential equations with logarithms (Exponentials & logarithms)
blurb: Learn how to solve any exponential equation by using logarithms. For example, solve 2^x=3 by calculating log_2(3).

name: Solving exponential models (Exponentials & logarithms)
blurb: Learn how to solve word problems that require exponential equations.

name: Graphs of exponential functions (Exponentials & logarithms)
blurb: Learn about the graphs of advanced exponential functions of the form y=a*b^(x+c)+d.

name: Graphs of logarithmic functions (Exponentials & logarithms)
blurb: Learn about the graphs of logarithmic functions, and how they relate to graphs of exponential functions.

name: Logarithmic scale (optional) (Exponentials & logarithms)
blurb: Enrich your knowledge with some videos about logarithmic scales and how useful they are.

name: Introduction to radians (Trigonometry | Algebra 2 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn about radians, which are the official unit of measurement for angles in algebra (in contrast to degrees, which are used in geometry).

name: The unit circle definition of sine, cosine, and tangent (Trigonometry | Algebra 2 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how the trigonometric ratios are extended to all real numbers using algebra. Start solving simple problems that involve this new definition of the trigonometric functions.

name: The graphs of sine, cosine, and tangent (Trigonometry | Algebra 2 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how the graphs of y=sin(θ), y=cos(θ), and y=tan(θ) look, using the unit circle definition of the functions.

name: Basic trigonometric identities (Trigonometry | Algebra 2 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn about very useful trigonometric identities that arise by considering different properties of the unit circle definition.

name: Trigonometric values of special angles (Trigonometry | Algebra 2 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how to find the trigonometric values of some special angles without the use of a calculator.

name: The Pythagorean identity (Trigonometry | Algebra 2 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Prove the Pythagorean trigonometric identity for all real numbers and use it in order to solve problems.

name: Introduction to amplitude, midline, and extrema of sinusoidal functions (Trigonometry | Algebra 2 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn about very important features of sinusoidal functions: the amplitude and the midline. Learn how they relate to the extremum points of the function.

name: Finding amplitude and midline of sinusoidal functions from their formulas (Trigonometry | Algebra 2 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how to find the amplitude and the midline of the graph of a sinusoidal function from its formula. For example, find the amplitude and the midline of f(x)=3*sin(2x-1)+5.

name: Period of sinusoidal functions (Trigonometry | Algebra 2 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn about the period of sinusoidal functions: how it relates to extremum points and the midline, and how to find it from the formula of the function. For example, find the period of f(x)=3*sin(2x-1)+5.

name: Graphing sinusoidal functions (Trigonometry | Algebra 2 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how to draw the graph of sinusoidal functions. For example, draw the graph of f(x)=-2*cos(πx)-7.

name: Constructing sinusoidal functions (Trigonometry | Algebra 2 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how to find the formula of a sinusoidal function from its graph or a few selected features. Model real-world situations with sinusoidal functions.

name: Solving equations by graphing (Advanced equations & functions)
blurb: Learn how to approximate the solution to any equation by using the power of graphs.

name: Systems of quadratic equations (Advanced equations & functions)
blurb: Learn how to solve systems of two equations in two variables, where at least one of the equations is quadratic.

name: Interpreting the symmetry of algebraic models (Advanced equations & functions)
blurb: Learn how to interpret graphs of modeling functions in terms of their context by considering their symmetry.

name: Interpreting the end behavior of algebraic models (Advanced equations & functions)
blurb: Learn how to interpret graphs of modeling functions in terms of their context by considering their end behavior.

name: Interpreting the periodicity of algebraic models (Advanced equations & functions)
blurb: Learn how to interpret graphs of modeling functions in terms of their context by considering their periodicity.

name: Comparing features of functions (Advanced equations & functions)
blurb: Learn how to compare various features between two functions, each represented in a different way.

name: Arithmetic sequences (Sequences and Series)
blurb: Review arithmetic sequences before you dive into arithmetic series.

name: Sigma notation (Sequences and Series)
blurb: Learn how to use and interpret sigma notation. Hint: It means take the sum!

name: Copy of Sequences and series (Sequences and Series)
blurb: Learn how to evaluate and work with finite arithmetic series.

name: Geometric sequences (Sequences and Series)
blurb: Review geometric sequences before you dive into geometric series.

name: Finite geometric series (Sequences and Series)
blurb: Whether you are computing mortgage payments or calculating how many users your website will have after a few years,  geometric  series show up in life far more than you imagine.  This tutorial will review all the important concepts and more!

name: Finite geometric series word problems (Sequences and Series)
blurb: Apply what you've learned about geometric series to model situations in some fun word problems.

name: Modeling with one-variable equations and inequalities (Modeling | Algebra 2 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how to determine the appropriate *type* of modeling equation (or inequality) according to the description of a real-world context.

name: Manipulating formulas (Modeling | Algebra 2 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how to solve problems that involve multi-variable formulas.

name: Introduction to conic sections (Conic sections | Algebra 2 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Conic sections are formed when you intersect a plane with a cone. In this tutorial, you will learn more about what makes conic sections special.

name: The features of a circle (Conic sections | Algebra 2 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn about the graphs of circles, and how their center and radius are represented algebraically.

name: Standard equation of a circle (Conic sections | Algebra 2 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn about the standard form to represent a circle with an equation. For example, the equation (x-1)^2+(y+2)^2=9 is a circle whose center is (1,-2) and radius is 3.

name: Expanded equation of a circle (Conic sections | Algebra 2 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how to analyze an equation of a circle that is not given in the standard form. For example, find the center of the circle whose equation is x^2+y^2+4x-5=0.

name: Focus and directrix of a parabola (Conic sections | Algebra 2 | Khan Academy)
blurb: A parabola is the set of all points equidistant from a point (called the focus) and a line (called the directrix). In this tutorial you will learn about the focus and the directrix, and how to find the equation of a parabola given its focus and directrix.

name: Introduction to the trigonometric ratios (Basic trigonometry)
blurb: Meet your new best friends: sine, cosine, and tangent.

name: Solving for a side in a right triangle using the trigonometric ratios (Basic trigonometry)
blurb: Learn how to find a side length in a right triangle when given one side length and one acute angle.

name: Solving for an angle in a right triangle using the trigonometric ratios (Basic trigonometry)
blurb: Learn how to find an acute angle in a right triangle when given two side lengths.

name: Modeling with right triangles (Basic trigonometry)
blurb: Solve real-world problems that can be modeled by right triangles, using trigonometry.

name: Trigonometric ratios and similarity (Basic trigonometry)
blurb: Learn how the trigonometric ratios are derived from triangle similarity considerations.

name: Sine and cosine of complementary angles (Basic trigonometry)
blurb: Learn about the relationship between the sine of an angle and the cosine of its complementary angle, which is the angle that completes to 90°.

name: Trigonometric ratios of special triangles (Basic trigonometry)
blurb: Learn to find the sine, cosine, and tangent of 45-45-90 triangles and also 30-60-90 triangles.

name: Introduction to the Pythagorean trigonometric identity (Basic trigonometry)
blurb: Learn about a very special trigonometric identity that follows from the Pythagorean theorem.

name: The reciprocal trigonometric ratios (Basic trigonometry)
blurb: Learn about the remaining three side ratios in a right triangle: the secant, the cosecant, and the cotangent.

name: The law of sines (Trigonometry with general triangles)
blurb: Learn about the Law of sines and how to use it in order to find missing side lengths and angles in general triangles.

name: The law of cosines (Trigonometry with general triangles)
blurb: Learn about the Law of cosines and how to use it in order to find missing side lengths and angles in general triangles.

name: Solving general triangles (Trigonometry with general triangles)
blurb: Use the power of trigonometry in order to solve various problems that involve triangles.

name: Introduction to radians (The unit circle definition of sine, cosine, and tangent)
blurb: Learn about radians, which are the official unit of measurement for angles in algebra (in contrast to degrees, which are used in geometry).

name: The unit circle definition of the trigonometric functions (The unit circle definition of sine, cosine, and tangent)
blurb: Learn about the ingenious way in which we define the trigonometric functions for any real number.

name: The graphs of sine, cosine, and tangent (The unit circle definition of sine, cosine, and tangent)
blurb: Learn how the graphs of y=sin(θ), y=cos(θ), and y=tan(θ) look, using the unit circle definition of the functions.

name: Basic trigonometric identities (The unit circle definition of sine, cosine, and tangent)
blurb: Learn about very useful trigonometric identities that arise by considering different properties of the unit circle definition.

name: Trigonometric values of special angles (The unit circle definition of sine, cosine, and tangent)
blurb: Learn how to find the trigonometric values of some special angles without the use of a calculator.

name: The Pythagorean identity (The unit circle definition of sine, cosine, and tangent)
blurb: Prove the Pythagorean trigonometric identity for all real numbers and use it in order to solve problems.

name: Long live Tau (The unit circle definition of sine, cosine, and tangent)
blurb: Watch videos by Sal and Vi that discuss the ongoing battle between the more popular Pi (π=3.14..) and its more qualified rival Tau (τ=6.28...).

name: The graphs of sine, cosine, and tangent (Graphs of trigonometric functions)
blurb: Learn how the graphs of y=sin(θ), y=cos(θ), and y=tan(θ) look, using the unit circle definition of the functions.

name: Introduction to amplitude, midline, and extrema of sinusoidal functions (Graphs of trigonometric functions)
blurb: Learn about very important features of sinusoidal functions: the amplitude and the midline. Learn how they relate to the extremum points of the function.

name: Finding amplitude and midline of sinusoidal functions from their formulas (Graphs of trigonometric functions)
blurb: Learn how to find the amplitude and the midline of the graph of a sinusoidal function from its formula. For example, find the amplitude and the midline of f(x)=3*sin(2x-1)+5.

name: Period of sinusoidal functions (Graphs of trigonometric functions)
blurb: Learn about the period of sinusoidal functions: how it relates to extremum points and the midline, and how to find it from the formula of the function. For example, find the period of f(x)=3*sin(2x-1)+5.

name: Graphing sinusoidal functions (Graphs of trigonometric functions)
blurb: Learn how to draw the graph of sinusoidal functions. For example, draw the graph of f(x)=-2*cos(πx)-7.

name: Constructing sinusoidal functions (Graphs of trigonometric functions)
blurb: Learn how to find the formula of a sinusoidal function from its graph or a few selected features. Model real-world situations with sinusoidal functions.

name: The inverse trigonometric functions (Trigonometric equations and identities)
blurb: Learn about the inverse functions of sine, cosine, and tangent, and how they are defined even though the functions are not really invertible. These functions will be very helpful when you will solve trigonometric equations.

name: Solving basic sinusoidal equations (Trigonometric equations and identities)
blurb: Learn how to solve equations of the form sin(x)=d or cos(x)=d where d is any number. For example, solve sin(x)=0.6.

name: Solving advanced sinusoidal equations (Trigonometric equations and identities)
blurb: Learn how to solve equations of the form a*sin(bx+c)=d or a*cos(bx+c)=d where a, b, c, and d are any number. For example, solve 5*sin(2x-1)=3.

name: Solving sinusoidal models (Trigonometric equations and identities)
blurb: Solve word problems that involve sinusoidal modeling functions.

name: Introduction to the trigonometric angle addition identities (Trigonometric equations and identities)
blurb: Learn about the trigonometric angle addition identities, which help us discuss the trig values of sums of angles in terms of the trig values of the individual angles. For example, we can express sin(x+y) in terms of sin(x), sin(y), cos(x), and cos(y).

name: Using trigonometric identities to solve problems (Trigonometric equations and identities)
blurb: Learn about different ways in which trigonometric identities, such as the Pythagorean identity and the angle addition identities, can be used to solve problems.

name: Challenging trigonometry problems (Trigonometric equations and identities)
blurb: See Sal solve a bunch of very challenging geometry and algebra problems that involve trigonometry.

name: Analyzing one categorical variable (Analyzing categorical data)
blurb: Let's learn how to create and read bar graphs to describe categorical data.

name: Two-way tables (Analyzing categorical data)
blurb: We use two-way tables to see the relationship between two categorical variables. Let's learn the basics of how to create and read two-way tables.

name: Distributions in two-way tables (Analyzing categorical data)
blurb: To see see if there is a relationship between the variables in a two-way table, we look at special distributions within the two-way table. Identifying and reading marginal and conditional distributions help us to see the relationships in two-way tables.

name: Displaying quantitative data with graphs (Displaying and comparing quantitative data)
blurb: It's not easy to see patterns or relationships when all you have are large lists of numbers. We use dot plots, histograms, and stem and leaf plots to display quantitative data so it is easier to understand what the data is saying.

name: Describing and comparing distributions (Displaying and comparing quantitative data)
blurb: To describe a distribution of quantitative data, we talk about its shape, center, and spread. We also use these features to compare distributions of data.

name: More on data displays (Displaying and comparing quantitative data)
blurb: In this lesson we'll look at a other types of data displays like line graphs.

name: Measuring center in quantitative data (Summarizing quantitative data)
blurb: We use measures of center like mean and median to summarize an entire set of data with just one number. Let's look at how to calculate mean and median given raw data or a data display.

name: More on mean and median (Summarizing quantitative data)
blurb: Once you know the basics of how to calculate the mean and median, you can start to think deeper about more advanced concepts. This tutorial covers how to find the mean and median from a data display, how new data points impact the mean and median, and how to find missing values given a mean.

name: Interquartile range (IQR) (Summarizing quantitative data)
blurb: Let's learn how to measure spread in a set of data using interquartile range, which is also referred to as IQR for short.
