name: Variance and standard deviation of a population (Summarizing quantitative data)
blurb: Variance and standard deviation give us a powerful way to measure spread. Standard deviation gives us an idea of the typical distance between each data point and the mean. Let's learn how to calculate the variance and standard deviation of a population.

name: Variance and standard deviation of a sample (Summarizing quantitative data)
blurb: If our data came from a sample, and we want to use it to represent its larger population, we need to slightly modify our formulas for variance and standard deviation. Let's look at how to calculate variance and standard deviation based on sample data.

name: More on standard deviation (Summarizing quantitative data)
blurb: This collection of videos and simulations is useful if you want to develop a very deep understanding of population vs. sample standard deviation. We'll explore why we divide by n-1 when working with sample data, and look at what it means to be a biased vs. an unbiased estimator.

name: Box and whisker plots (Summarizing quantitative data)
blurb: Box and whisker plots show us the shape, center, spread, and even more features about a set of data. We'll learn how to construct box and whisker plots (often called box plots), and we'll also look at how to read and interpret box plots.

name: Other measures of spread (Summarizing quantitative data)
blurb: Let's look at how to use range and mean absolute deviation (MAD) to measure the spread or variation in a data set.

name: Percentiles (Modeling data distributions)
blurb: Let's learn about percentiles, which measure what percent of data is at or below a given point in a distribution.

name: Z-scores (Modeling data distributions)
blurb: We use standardized scores (also called z-scores) to measure position in a distribution by looking at exactly how many standard deviations away from the mean a given data point is.

name: Effects of linear transformations (Modeling data distributions)
blurb: We can predict how transforming a set of data will impact measures of center and spread.

name: Density curves (Modeling data distributions)
blurb: A density curve models the distribution of a quantitative variable with a smooth curve. The area under a density curve over some interval represents what proportion of observations fall in that interval. Let's learn how to create density curves and understand their properties.

name: Normal distributions and the empirical rule (Modeling data distributions)
blurb: Here we introduce perhaps the most important type of distribution in statistics — the normal distribution. We'll look at what exactly makes a density curve "normal," and we'll learn about the empirical rule (also called the 68-95-99.7 rule).

name: Normal distribution calculations (Modeling data distributions)
blurb: We use z-scores to solve problems involving area under a normal distribution.

name: More on normal distributions (Modeling data distributions)
blurb: What exactly do we mean when we say a variable is normally distributed? Let's look at some mathematical properties of normal distributions.

name: Introduction to scatterplots (Exploring bivariate numerical data)
blurb: Let's go over the basics of how to construct a scatter plot and describe the relationship we see with its form, direction, and strength.

name: Correlation coefficients (Exploring bivariate numerical data)
blurb: We'll learn to calculate and use the correlation coefficient r to describe the strength and direction of a linear relationship.

name: Introduction to trend lines (Exploring bivariate numerical data)
blurb: When we see a pattern in a scatterplot, it's often useful to model that pattern with a trend line. This lesson covers how to informally fit a line to data, make predictions, and think about the slope and y-intercept of the trend line.

name: Least-squares regression equations (Exploring bivariate numerical data)
blurb: Once we see a linear pattern in a scatterplot, we fit a line to model the relationship and make predictions. But how do we know what line fits the data "best?" To solve this problem, we'll learn about residuals and least-squares regression .

name: Assessing the fit in least-squares regression (Exploring bivariate numerical data)
blurb: Let's learn how to measure how well a linear model actually fits the relationship in a scatterplot using residual plots and r-squared. We'll also look at how outliers can be influential points in least-squares regression.

name: More on regression (Exploring bivariate numerical data)
blurb: This is a more advanced collection of videos that goes into some more advanced topics and proofs in least-squares regression.

name: Statistical questions (Study design)
blurb: Statistics gives us the tools to effectively answer questions using data. So the first step in actually doing statistics is to form a question! This tutorial looks at what type of questions we deal with in statistics.

name: Sampling and observational studies (Study design)
blurb: Taking a sample and giving a survey is one of the most common ways to get information about a large population. Doing every step well is important though, otherwise your claims may be not accurate. This tutorial covers some of the basics of samples and surveys.

name: Sampling methods (Study design)
blurb: The goal of sampling is to get a group that is representative of its population. This lesson explores different strategies we can use — like stratified and cluster sampling — to get a good sample. We'll also look at possible sources of bias in voluntary response and convenience sampling.

name: Types of studies (experimental vs. observational) (Study design)
blurb: This lesson covers how to distinguish between a few primary types of studies used to collect data. Learning to identify a study as either observational or experimental helps us in making appropriate conclusions.

name: Experiments (Study design)
blurb: An experiment assigns some subjects to receive a treatment while others don't get the treatment. Experiments allow us to see how a treatment affects changes in a response variable. This lesson covers basic principles of experiment design.

name: Basic theoretical probability (Probability)
blurb: Basic theoretical probability is mapping out how many outcomes are possible and seeing how many of those outcomes relate to the probability we're trying to find.

name: Probability using sample spaces (Probability)
blurb: A sample space shows every possible equally likely outcome in some chance process like flipping a coin or rolling a pair of dice. Sample spaces can help us find the probability of certain events like rolling doubles or getting heads twice in three flips.

name: Basic set operations (Probability)
blurb: Basic set operations and set notation are the language of more advanced probability and logic. Learn how to express intersections, unions, complements, and subsets symbolically.

name: Experimental probability (Probability)
blurb: Experimental probability estimates the theoretical probability of an event by repeating trials over and over and keeping track of what percent of the trials the event actually happens. For example, spin a coin over and over and see if it lands on "heads" 50% of the time (you may be surprised).

name: Randomness, probability, and simulation (Probability)
blurb: The probability of an event gives us an idea of how often that event will occur in a long series of trials. We'll learn how to set up and carry out simulations to estimate theoretical probability using experimental probability.

name: Addition rule (Probability)
blurb: The addition rule says that we can find the probably of one event or another event happening by adding their probabilities, but we have to be careful and subtract the overlapping probability of both events happening at the same time.

name: Multiplication rule for independent events (Probability)
blurb: The multiplication rule says that we can multiply the probability of independent events to find the probably of all of the events happening. You'll learn how to find the probability of getting three heads in a row when tossing a coin, or a basketball player making five shots in a row.

name: Multiplication rule for dependent events (Probability)
blurb: The multiplication rule works for dependent events, we just have to adjust each probability based on the previous event occurring. You'll learn how to find the probability of events like drawing two red cards in a row from a deck of cards.

name: Conditional probability and independence (Probability)
blurb: Conditional probability is the likelihood of some event occurring given some other event has occurred. You'll learn how to calculate conditional probability intuitively and with a formula called Bayes' theorem.

name: Counting principle and factorial (Counting, permutations, and combinations)
blurb: The counting principal tells us that we can multiply the number of choices together to get a count of the total possible outcomes. If you own two pairs of pants and three shirts, then you have six possible outfits.

name: Permutations (Counting, permutations, and combinations)
blurb: Permutations count how many ways you can select and arrange items or people from a larger group. For example, how many different ways can we award a gold, silver, and bronze medal to three runners out of a group of 10?

name: Combinations (Counting, permutations, and combinations)
blurb: Combinations are similar to permutations. Combinations count how many ways we can pick a group of people or things from a larger group where order doesn't matter. For example, how many different groups of 3 people can a company with 10 employees send on a business trip?

name: Combinatorics and probability (Counting, permutations, and combinations)
blurb: Once we understand the counting principle, permutations, and combinations, we can use those concepts to calculate some pretty advanced probabilities!

name: Discrete random variables (Random variables)
blurb: Discrete random variables occur in situations where we can list every possible outcome of a process, and assign each outcome a probability in a probability model. For example, how many heads will we get in three flips? We'll learn how to make a probability distribution, find some probabilities, and calculate the mean (or expected value), variance, and standard deviation of a random variable.

name: Continuous random variables (Random variables)
blurb: Continuous random variables arise from situations where we measure some attribute on a scale — like height, weight, volume, temperature, or time. We'll learn how to identify a continuous random variable and calculate probabilities using area under density curves.

name: Transforming random variables (Random variables)
blurb: Transforming random variables produces predictable changes in the expected value and variance of the outcomes. Let's look at how changing units impacts the distribution of a discrete random variable.

name: Combining random variables (Random variables)
blurb: Combining random variables leads to some predictable and some less predictable distributions. Let's look at how adding and subtracting random variables can produce new distributions that help us solve some pretty interesting probability problems.

name: Binomial random variables (Random variables)
blurb: Binomial random variables are a special type of variable that comes up we repeat a process for a set number of independent trials, with each trial having the same probability of success, and we count how many successes we get at the end of the trials. For example, how many free-throws will a basketball player make in a series of 10 shots?

name: Binomial mean and standard deviation formulas (Random variables)
blurb: Let's use what we've learned about combining random variables to create the mean and standard deviation formulas for a binomial random variable.

name: Geometric random variables (Random variables)
blurb: Geometric variables are similar but different from binomial variables. The key difference is that with a geometric variable, we count the number of trials it takes to get our first success. For example, how many attempts will it take me to make my first free-throw? Learn to calculate probabilities and the mean (expected value) for these variables.

name: More on expected value (Random variables)
blurb: Expected value gives us the mean or long-term average number of success we can expect over time if we repeat a process over and over. For example, how much money can someone expect to win on average for each lottery ticket they buy?

name: Poisson distribution (Random variables)
blurb: The Poisson distribution is related to the binomial setting, but looks at the number of successes over time instead of over many repeated trials.

name: What is a sampling distribution? (Sampling distributions)
blurb: (No description)

name: Sampling distribution of a sample proportion (Sampling distributions)
blurb: Learn how to find the mean and variance of the sampling distribution of a sample proportion.

name: Sampling distribution of a sample mean (Sampling distributions)
blurb: Learn how to find the mean and standard deviation of the sampling distribution of a sample mean. Also, learn about the central limit theorem and why it is one of the most important theorems in statistics.

name: Introduction to confidence intervals (One-sample confidence intervals)
blurb: (No description)

name: Estimating a population proportion (One-sample confidence intervals)
blurb: A confidence interval for a proportion estimates what percent of a population fits some category based on a results from a sample. For example, if 70 adults own a cell phone in a random sample of 100 adults, we can be fairly confident that the true percentage in the population is somewhere between 61% and 79%. Go through this tutorial to learn how to calculate confidence intervals like this.

name: Estimating a population mean (One-sample confidence intervals)
blurb: A confidence interval for a mean estimates a population mean based on the results from a sample. Go through this tutorial to learn how to calculate confidence intervals using sample mean and sample standard deviation.

name: Old confidence interval videos (One-sample confidence intervals)
blurb: Here are even more videos on confidence intervals.

name: The idea of significance tests (Significance tests (hypothesis testing))
blurb: This tutorial gives some intuition for how we go through a significance test, what a p-value is, how we make conclusions, and what types of error we may make in our conclusions.

name: Error probabilities and power (Significance tests (hypothesis testing))
blurb: (No description)

name: Tests about a population proportion (Significance tests (hypothesis testing))
blurb: These significance tests tell us if a sample offers convincing evidence that a population proportion is different from some hypothesized value.

name: Tests about a population mean (Significance tests (hypothesis testing))
blurb: These significance tests tell us if a sample offers convincing evidence that a population mean is different from some hypothesized value.

name: More significance testing videos (Significance tests (hypothesis testing))
blurb: (No description)

name: Comparing two proportions (Significance tests and confidence intervals (two samples))
blurb: Build confidence intervals and do significance tests to see if there is a significant difference between the proportions of some variable in two populations.

name: Comparing two means (Significance tests and confidence intervals (two samples))
blurb: Build confidence intervals and do significance tests to see if there is a significant difference between the means of some variable in two populations.

name: Chi-square goodness-of-fit tests (Inference for categorical data (chi-square tests))
blurb: A chi-square goodness-of-fit test examines how well a sample of categorical data fits a hypothesized distribution. For example, take a sample of people and ask them what day of the week they were born. You probably won't get the same number of people born on each day, but does that offer strong evidence that the distribution isn't even for everyone?

name: Chi-square tests for homogeneity and association/independence (Inference for categorical data (chi-square tests))
blurb: These chi-square tests evaluate the independence (or homogeneity) of categorical variables in a two-way table.

name: Inference about slope (Advanced regression (inference and transforming))
blurb: We'll make confidence intervals to estimate slope based on sample data. We'll also do significance tests about slope to see if a sample slope is significantly different than 0.

name: Nonlinear regression (Advanced regression (inference and transforming))
blurb: Nonlinear regression is fitting various curves to data and evaluating which curve fits the data best.

name: Analysis of variance (ANOVA) (Analysis of variance (ANOVA))
blurb: Learn how analysis of variance (ANOVA) tests work and how to use F statistics to test hypotheses.

name: Creating and interpreting scatterplots (Scatterplots - Algebra I)
blurb: Do people who eat more vegetables tend to be happier? Is crime getting better or worse over time? In this tutorial we'll make scatterplots to see if there is a correlation between two variables.

name: Estimating with trend lines (Scatterplots - Algebra I)
blurb: If we know how big a person’s feet are, can we predict their height? In this tutorial, we'll fit a line to the pattern we see and use it to make predictions.

name: Displays of distributions (Data distributions)
blurb: A picture says a thousand words. A well-made data display can show data in a way that everyone understands. In this tutorial we'll learn how to construct and describe some common displays of data.

name: Summarizing distributions (Data distributions)
blurb: How long does a typical person spend on a phone each week? Is it different for younger people? In this tutorial we'll use measures of center like mean and median to summarize and compare sets of data.

name: Summarizing spread of distributions (Data distributions)
blurb: Individual results will vary. Measuring spread in distributions helps us to describe how much variability there is in a set of data. In this tutorial we'll use range, interquartile range, and standard deviation to talk about the spread in a data set.

name: Box and whisker plots (Data distributions)
blurb: Whether we're looking at scientific data or stock price charts, box-and-whisker plots can show up in life. This tutorial covers what they are, how to read them and how to construct them.

name: Comparing distributions (Data distributions)
blurb: Do people live longer in different parts of the world? In this tutorial we’ll compare the center and spread of distributions to see what conclusions we can make.

name: Two-way frequency tables (Two-way tables and categorical data)
blurb: Frequency tables show us how many times something happened. This tutorial covers how to read and interpret two-way frequency tables.

name: Two-way relative frequency tables (Two-way tables and categorical data)
blurb: Relative frequency tables show us what percent of the time something happened. This tutorial covers how to construct, read, and and interpret two-way relative frequency tables.

name: Samples and surveys (Study Design)
blurb: If we want to know something about a large group of people, we can take a sample and give them a survey. This tutorial introduces how that process works.

name: Observational studies and experiments (Study Design)
blurb: “A new study shows that people who eat lobster regularly tend to live longer.” That may be true, but it doesn’t necessarily mean that eating lobster causes people to live longer. We could set up an experiment to find out if lobster is truly the cause. This tutorial covers the difference between observational studies and experiments.

name: Probability basics (Probability)
blurb: Flip a quarter a hundred times. What's the probability that it will turn up heads? Tails? Even if we are unsure about whether something will happen, we can start to be mathematical about the "chances" of an event (essentially realizing that some things are more likely than others) occurring. This tutorial will introduce us to the tools that allow us to think about random events and the logic behind comparing, judging, and finding the probabilities of those events.

name: Counting with permutations (Probability)
blurb: You want to display your Chuck Norris dolls on your desk at school and there is only room for five of them. Unfortunately, you own 50. How many ways can you pick the dolls and arrange them on your desk?

name: Counting with combinations (Probability)
blurb: You are already familiar with calculating permutation ("How many ways could 7 different people sit in 4 different seats?"). But what if you didn't care about which seat they sat in? What if you just cared about which 4 people were in the car? Or put another way, you want to know how many combinations of 4 people can you stick in the car from a pool of 7 candidates. Or how many ways are there to choose 4 things from a pool of 7? Look no further than this tutorial to answer your questions.

name: Probability with counting, permutations, combinations (Probability)
blurb: This tutorial will apply the permutation and combination tools you learned in the last tutorial to problems of probability. You'll finally learn that there may be better "investments" than spending all your money on the Powerball Lottery.

name: Multiplication rule for independent events (Probability)
blurb: What’s the probability that three people were all born on the same day of the week? How likely is a basketball player to make three shots in a row? In this tutorial, we’ll see that multiplying probabilities can be quite useful.

name: Multiplication rule for dependent events (Probability)
blurb: What’s the probability of drawing two aces in a row from a deck of cards? Getting an ace on the first card changes the probability for the second card. This tutorial covers how we can deal with that when multiplying probabilities.

name: Addition rule for probability (Probability)
blurb: What’s the probability of picking a card and getting a jack or a heart? What’s the probability that someone owns a laptop or a smartphone? This tutorial will show how we can add probabilities to solve these types of problems.

name: Conditional probability (Probability)
blurb: Given someone likes cheese, what’s the probability they also like pizza? Knowing something can change what we know about the probability of something else. This tutorial on conditional probability covers how to find probability based on some known condition.

name: Simulation and randomness (Probability)
blurb: Drawing names from a hat is fun, and so is calculating probability with formulas, but there are other options. This tutorial covers how we can use simulations and random digits to get samples and find probabilities.

name: Expected value (Probability)
blurb: Will a basketball player score more points over time from a two point shot or a three point shot? How much money can we expect to win back if we play the lottery? This tutorial on expected value will help us answer these types of questions.

name: Binomial probability (Binomial probability)
blurb: If a basketball player has a 60% chance of making a free-throw, and he’s going to shoot 10 free-throws, what’s the probability that they make 5 or fewer free-throws? This tutorial on binomial probability will cover how to deal with problems just like this one.

name: Normal distributions (Normal distributions)
blurb: What percent of people are taller than 2 meters? What percent of people taking the SAT will score more than three standard deviations about the mean? This tutorial will cover how to use Normal distributions to solve problems like these.

name: Introduction to data (Analyzing categorical data)
blurb: Welcome! Statistics is the science of collecting, summarizing, analyzing, interpreting, and drawing conclusions from data. We're excited to offer lessons specifically designed for AP Statistics.

name: Analyzing one categorical variable (Analyzing categorical data)
blurb: Let's learn how to create and read bar graphs to describe categorical data.

name: Two-way tables (Analyzing categorical data)
blurb: We use two-way tables to see the relationship between two categorical variables. Let's learn the basics of how to create and read two-way tables.

name: Distributions in two-way tables (Analyzing categorical data)
blurb: To see see if there is a relationship between the variables in a two-way table, we look at special distributions within the two-way table. Identifying and reading marginal and conditional distributions help us to see the relationships in two-way tables.

name: Frequency tables and dot plots (Displaying and comparing quantitative data)
blurb: Represent the distribution of a quantitative variable with a frequency table or a dot plot.

name: Displaying quantitative data with graphs (Displaying and comparing quantitative data)
blurb: It's not easy to see patterns or relationships when all you have are large lists of numbers. We use dot plots, histograms, and stem and leaf plots to display quantitative data so it is easier to understand what the data is saying.

name: Describing and comparing distributions (Displaying and comparing quantitative data)
blurb: To describe a distribution of quantitative data, we talk about its shape, center, and spread. We also use these features to compare distributions of data.

name: Measuring center in quantitative data (Summarizing quantitative data)
blurb: We use measures of center like mean and median to summarize an entire set of data with just one number. Let's look at how to calculate mean and median given raw data or a data display.

name: More on mean and median (Summarizing quantitative data)
blurb: We look at shape and outliers to determine which measure of center is preferred for a given set of data. Let's look at why sometimes it makes sense to use mean, while other times it makes sense to use median.

name: Measuring spread in quantitative data (Summarizing quantitative data)
blurb: We use measures of spread to get an idea of how much variability there is in a set of data. Let's look at how to calculate and understand a few different measures of spread like interquartile range (also called IQR), variance, and standard deviation.

name: More on standard deviation (Summarizing quantitative data)
blurb: This collection of videos and simulations is useful if you want to develop a very deep understanding of population vs. sample standard deviation. We'll explore why we divide by n-1 when working with sample data, and look at what it means to be a biased vs. an unbiased estimator.

name: Box and whisker plots (Summarizing quantitative data)
blurb: Box and whisker plots show us the shape, center, spread, and even more features about a set of data. We'll learn how to construct box and whisker plots (often called box plots), and we'll also look at how to read and interpret box plots.

name: Percentiles (cumulative relative frequency) (Modeling data distributions)
blurb: Let's learn about percentiles, which measure what percent of data is at or below a given point in a distribution.

name: Z-scores (Modeling data distributions)
blurb: We use standardized scores (also called z-scores) to measure position in a distribution by looking at exactly how many standard deviations away from the mean a given data point is.

name: Effects of linear transformations (Modeling data distributions)
blurb: We can predict how transforming a set of data will impact measures of center and spread.

name: Density curves (Modeling data distributions)
blurb: A density curve models the distribution of a quantitative variable with a smooth curve. The area under a density curve over some interval represents what proportion of observations fall in that interval. Let's learn how to create density curves and understand their properties.

name: Normal distributions and the empirical rule (Modeling data distributions)
blurb: Here we introduce perhaps the most important type of distribution in statistics — the normal distribution. We'll look at what exactly makes a density curve "normal," and we'll learn about the empirical rule (also called the 68-95-99.7 rule).

name: Normal distribution calculations (Modeling data distributions)
blurb: We use z-scores to solve problems involving area under a normal distribution.

name: Making and describing scatterplots (Exploring bivariate numerical data)
blurb: Let's go over the basics of how to construct a scatter plot and describe the relationship we see with its form, direction, and strength.

name: Correlation coefficients (Exploring bivariate numerical data)
blurb: We'll learn to calculate and use the correlation coefficient r to describe the strength and direction of a linear relationship.

name: Least-squares regression equations (Exploring bivariate numerical data)
blurb: Once we see a linear pattern in a scatterplot, we fit a line to model the relationship and make predictions. But how do we know what line fits the data "best?" To solve this problem, we'll learn about residuals and least-squares regression .

name: Assessing the fit in least-squares regression (Exploring bivariate numerical data)
blurb: Let's learn how to measure how well a linear model actually fits the relationship in a scatterplot using residual plots and r-squared. We'll also look at how outliers can be influential points in least-squares regression.

name: Sampling and observational studies (Study design)
blurb: When we want to gather data from a large population, we survey or observe a sample from that population. This lesson covers sampling and survey methods and the types of conclusions that can be drawn.

name: Sampling methods (Study design)
blurb: The goal of sampling is to get a group that is representative of its population. This lesson explores different strategies we can use — like stratified and cluster sampling — to get a good sample. We'll also look at possible sources of bias in voluntary response and convenience sampling.

name: Types of studies (experimental vs. observational) (Study design)
blurb: This lesson covers how to distinguish between a few primary types of studies used to collect data. Learning to identify a study as either observational or experimental helps us in making appropriate conclusions.

name: Experiments (Study design)
blurb: An experiment assigns some subjects to receive a treatment while others don't get the treatment. Experiments allow us to see how a treatment affects changes in a response variable. This lesson covers basic principles of experiment design.

name: Randomness, probability, and simulation (Probability)
blurb: The probability of an event gives us an idea of how often that event will occur in a long series of trials. We'll learn how to set up and carry out simulations to estimate theoretical probability using experimental probability.

name: Addition rule (Probability)
blurb: The addition rule says that we can find the probably of one event or another event happening by adding their probabilities, but we have to be careful and subtract the overlapping probability of both events happening at the same time.

name: Multiplication rule (Probability)
blurb: The multiplication rule says that we can multiply the probabilities of independent events to find the probably of all of the events happening. When events aren't independent, we just have to change the probability of subsequent events. We'll learn how to find the probability of getting three heads in a row when tossing a coin, or drawing three red cards in a row from a deck of cards.

name: Conditional probability (Probability)
blurb: Conditional probability is the likelihood of some event occurring given some other event has occurred. We'll learn how to calculate conditional probability intuitively and with a formula called Bayes' theorem, and then we'll use probability to determine if two events are independent.

name: Discrete random variables (Random variables)
blurb: Discrete random variables occur in situations where we can list every possible outcome of a process, and assign each outcome a probability in a probability model. For example, how many heads will we get in three flips? We'll learn how to make a probability distribution, find some probabilities, and calculate the mean (or expected value), variance, and standard deviation of a random variable.

name: Continuous random variables (Random variables)
blurb: Continuous random variables arise from situations where we measure some attribute on a scale — like height, weight, volume, temperature, or time. We'll learn how to identify a continuous random variable and calculate probabilities using area under density curves.

name: Transforming random variables (Random variables)
blurb: Transforming random variables produces predictable changes in the expected value and variance of the outcomes. Let's look at how changing units impacts the distribution of a discrete random variable.

name: Combining random variables (Random variables)
blurb: Combining random variables leads to some predictable and some less predictable distributions. Let's look at how adding and subtracting random variables can produce new distributions that help us solve some pretty interesting probability problems.

name: Binomial random variables (Random variables)
blurb: Binomial random variables are a special type of variable that comes up we repeat a process for a set number of independent trials, with each trial having the same probability of success, and we count how many successes we get at the end of the trials. For example, how many free-throws will a basketball player make in a series of 10 shots? Learn to identify these variables, use them to find probability, and calculate their mean and standard deviation.

name: Binomial mean and standard deviation formulas (Random variables)
blurb: Let's use what we've learned about combining random variables to create the mean and standard deviation formulas for a binomial random variable.

name: Geometric random variables (Random variables)
blurb: Geometric variables are similar but different from binomial variables. The key difference is that with a geometric variable, we count the number of trials it takes to get our first success. For example, how many attempts will it take me to make my first free-throw? Learn to calculate probabilities and the mean (expected value) for these variables.

name: What is a sampling distribution? (Sampling distributions)
blurb: (No description)

name: Sampling distribution of a sample proportion (Sampling distributions)
blurb: (No description)

name: Sampling distribution of a sample mean (Sampling distributions)
blurb: (No description)

name: Introduction to confidence intervals (One-sample confidence intervals)
blurb: Let's explore why and how we build confidence intervals.

name: Confidence intervals for proportions (One-sample confidence intervals)
blurb: We build a confidence interval for a proportion when we want to estimate what percent of a population fits some category. For example, what percent of voters support a certain candidate? Instead of polling everyone, we can take a sample and make an estimate using a confidence interval.

name: Confidence intervals for means (One-sample confidence intervals)
blurb: We build a confidence interval for a mean when we want to estimate some average in a population. For instance, what's the mean income in a country?We can't get data from everyone, so we take a sample and make an estimate using a confidence interval.

name: The idea of significance tests (Significance tests (hypothesis testing))
blurb: (No description)

name: Error probabilities and power (Significance tests (hypothesis testing))
blurb: (No description)

name: Testing hypotheses about a proportion (Significance tests (hypothesis testing))
blurb: (No description)

name: Testing hypotheses about a mean (Significance tests (hypothesis testing))
blurb: (No description)

name: Confidence intervals for the difference between two proportions (Inference comparing two groups or populations)
blurb: We can build a confidence interval to estimate the difference between two population proportions. For example, a politician might poll samples of people from two different locations to estimate the difference in the percent of voters that support their campaign.

name: Testing the difference between two proportions (Inference comparing two groups or populations)
blurb: We can do a significance test to judge if the difference between two proportions is significant (unlikely to occur by chance alone). For example, a company might want to test to see if there is a difference in what percent of their employees are satisfied between two of their locations.

name: Confidence intervals for the difference between two means (Inference comparing two groups or populations)
blurb: We can build a confidence interval to estimate the difference between two population means. For example, a food scientist might want to estimate the difference in the average sizes of two varieties of the same fruit.

name: Testing the difference between two means (Inference comparing two groups or populations)
blurb: We can do a significance test to judge if the difference between two means is significant (unlikely to occur by chance alone). For example, a chain of restaurants might want to test to see if there is a difference in the average portion size between two of their locations.

name: Chi-square goodness-of-fit tests (Chi-square tests for categorical data)
blurb: (No description)

name: Chi-square tests for two-way tables (Chi-square tests for categorical data)
blurb: (No description)

name: Inference about slope (More on regression)
blurb: We'll make confidence intervals to estimate slope based on sample data. We'll also do significance tests about slope to see if a sample slope is significantly different than 0.

name: Transformations to achieve linearity (More on regression)
blurb: When we have a nonlinear relationship, we can often use logarithms, powers, and roots to transform the data so the relationship becomes linear. This allows us to use least-squares regression and do other inference procedures that we're already familiar with.

name: Prepare for the exam (Prepare for the 2018 AP Statistics Exam)
blurb: (No description)

name: The inverse trigonometric functions (Trigonometry | Precalculus | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn about the inverse functions of sine, cosine, and tangent, and how they are defined even though the functions are not really invertible. These functions will be very helpful when you will solve trigonometric equations.

name: Copy of Solving basic sinusoidal equations (Trigonometry | Precalculus | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how to solve equations of the form sin(x)=d or cos(x)=d where d is any number. For example, solve sin(x)=0.6.

name: Solving advanced sinusoidal equations (Trigonometry | Precalculus | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how to solve equations of the form a*sin(bx+c)=d or a*cos(bx+c)=d where a, b, c, and d are any number. For example, solve 5*sin(2x-1)=3.

name: Solving sinusoidal models (Trigonometry | Precalculus | Khan Academy)
blurb: Solve word problems that involve sinusoidal modeling functions.

name: Introduction to the trigonometric angle addition identities (Trigonometry | Precalculus | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn about the trigonometric angle addition identities, which help us discuss the trig values of sums of angles in terms of the trig values of the individual angles. For example, we can express sin(x+y) in terms of sin(x), sin(y), cos(x), and cos(y).

name: Using trigonometric identities to solve problems (Trigonometry | Precalculus | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn about different ways in which trigonometric identities, such as the Pythagorean identity and the angle addition identities, can be used to solve problems.

name: Introduction to conic sections (Conic sections | Precalculus | Khan Academy)
blurb: Conic sections are formed when you intersect a plane with a cone. In this tutorial, you will learn more about what makes conic sections special.

name: The features of a circle (Conic sections | Precalculus | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn about the graphs of circles, and how their center and radius are represented algebraically.

name: Standard equation of a circle (Conic sections | Precalculus | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn about the standard form to represent a circle with an equation. For example, the equation (x-1)^2+(y+2)^2=9 is a circle whose center is (1,-2) and radius is 3.

name: Expanded equation of a circle (Conic sections | Precalculus | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how to analyze an equation of a circle that is not given in the standard form. For example, find the center of the circle whose equation is x^2+y^2+4x-5=0.

name: Center and radii of an ellipse (Conic sections | Precalculus | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn about the basic features of ellipses: their center and the two radii that pass through it, the major radius and the minor radius.

name: Foci of an ellipse (Conic sections | Precalculus | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn about the foci of an ellipse, which are two points for which the sum of the distances from any point on the ellipse is constant.

name: Focus and directrix of a parabola (Conic sections | Precalculus | Khan Academy)
blurb: A parabola is the set of all points equidistant from a point (called the focus) and a line (called the directrix). In this tutorial you will learn about the focus and the directrix, and how to find the equation of a parabola given its focus and directrix.

name: Introduction to hyperbolas (Conic sections | Precalculus | Khan Academy)
blurb: A hyperbola is the set of all points whose distances from two specific points (called the foci) have the same difference. Learn more about it here.

name: Foci of a hyperbola (Conic sections | Precalculus | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn about the foci of the hyperbola: How to find them from the hyperbola's equation and how to find the equation when given the foci.

name: Hyperbolas not centered at the origin (Conic sections | Precalculus | Khan Academy)
blurb: Generalize what you learned about hyperbolas to study hyperbolas whose center can be any point.

name: Identifying conic sections from their expanded equations (Conic sections | Precalculus | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how to analyze expanded equations in order to determine which kind of conic section they represent.

name: Challenging conic section problems (IIT JEE) (Conic sections | Precalculus | Khan Academy)
blurb: See Sal solve two (very) advanced problems from the IIT JEE exam, a highly challenging exam administered in India.

name: Vector basics (Vectors)
blurb: Learn the basics of vectors, like that a vector has both magnitude and direction.

name: Magnitude of vectors (Vectors)
blurb: Find the magnitude of a vector given in component form.

name: Scalar multiplication (Vectors)
blurb: Multiply a vector by a scalar to get a new vector.

name: Vector addition and subtraction (Vectors)
blurb: Combine two vectors by adding or subtracting them to get a new vector.

name: Combined vector operations (Vectors)
blurb: Use both scalar multiplication and vector addition or subtraction in the same problem!

name: Unit vectors (Vectors)
blurb: Learn about special vectors called unit vectors that have a magnitude of 1.

name: Vectors in magnitude and direction form (Vectors)
blurb: Think about how we can represent vectors using their magnitude and direction instead of their components.

name: Component form of vectors (Vectors)
blurb: Convert vectors from magnitude and direction form to component form.

name: Adding vectors in magnitude and direction form (Vectors)
blurb: Learn how to add two vectors together that are in magnitude and direction form. We can always use our old friend component form!

name: Applications of vectors (Vectors)
blurb: Apply what you've learned about vectors so far to solve some fun word problems.

name: Introduction to matrices (Matrices)
blurb: Learn what matrices are and about their parts (coordinates and dimensions).

name: Representing linear systems of equations with augmented matrices (Matrices)
blurb: Learn how systems of linear equations with multiple variables are represented with matrices.

name: Elementary matrix row operations (Matrices)
blurb: Learn about the three basic operations we can perform on a matrix without changing the solution set of the linear system it represents.

name: Row-echelon form and Gaussian elimination (Matrices)
blurb: Learn how to use the matrix row operations in order to easily solve large systems of linear equations.

name: Adding and subtracting matrices (Matrices)
blurb: Learn how to add and subtract two matrices to obtain a new matrix (just like numbers!).

name: Multiplying matrices by scalars (Matrices)
blurb: Learn how to multiply matrices by scalars (in the world of matrices, scalars are simply regular numbers). For example, multiply a 2X2 matrix by 3.

name: Properties of matrix addition & scalar multiplication (Matrices)
blurb: Learn about zero matrices and about how matrix addition, subtraction, and scalar multiplication are related to their corresponding operations with real numbers.

name: Multiplying matrices by matrices (Matrices)
blurb: Learn how to find the result of a multiplication of two matrices.

name: Properties of matrix multiplication (Matrices)
blurb: Learn about identity matrices and about how matrix multiplication relates to real number multiplication (spoiler: the distributive property applies but the commutative property does not!).

name: Matrices as transformations (Matrices)
blurb: Learn how matrices can be used as transformations of vectors or transformations of the plane.

name: The determinant of a 2x2 matrix (Matrices)
blurb: Learn what the determinant of a matrix is and how to find it for 2x2 matrices.

name: Introduction to matrix inverses (Matrices)
blurb: Learn what the inverse of a matrix is, and how to determine whether two matrices are inverses or whether a matrix is invertible.

name: Finding the inverse of a matrix using its determinant (Matrices)
blurb: Learn about a way to find the inverse of a matrix using its determinant and adjugates.

name: Practice finding the inverses of 2x2 matrices (Matrices)
blurb: After you've learned how to find the inverse of a 2x2 matrix, gain some practice with it.

name: Solving equations with inverse matrices (Matrices)
blurb: Learn how to solve systems of linear equations using inverse matrices, and how to solve matrix equations using inverse matrices.

name: Model real-world situations with matrices (Matrices)
blurb: Learn how matrices can be used to describe real-world situations.

name: What are the imaginary numbers? (Complex numbers | Precalculus | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn about the imaginary unit i (which is the square root of -1) and about imaginary numbers like 3i (which is the square root of -9).

name: What are the complex numbers? (Complex numbers | Precalculus | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn about complex numbers (spoiler: they are numbers that consist of both real and imaginary parts).

name: The complex plane (Complex numbers | Precalculus | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how we can visualize complex numbers in a plane. This can be seen as an expansion of the 1-dimensional real number line into a 2-dimensional plane!

name: Adding and subtracting complex numbers (Complex numbers | Precalculus | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how to add or subtract complex numbers. For example, write (2+3i)-(1+2i) as (1+i).

name: Distance and midpoint of complex numbers (Complex numbers | Precalculus | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how we define the distance of two complex numbers, and how we define their midpoint.

name: Multiplying complex numbers (Complex numbers | Precalculus | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how to multiply complex numbers using the fact that i^2=-1 and the distributive property. For example, multiply (1+i) by (2+3i).

name: Complex conjugates and dividing complex numbers (Complex numbers | Precalculus | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how to divide complex numbers using the conjugate of the divisor. For example, divide (2+3i) by (-1+4i) by multiplying both the dividend and the divisor by (-1-4i).

name: Absolute value and angle of complex numbers (Complex numbers | Precalculus | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn about very important graphical features of complex numbers: their absolute value and their angle.

name: Polar form of complex numbers (Complex numbers | Precalculus | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how to represent complex numbers in a different way. Unlike rectangular form, which emphasizes the real and imaginary parts, polar form emphasizes the absolute value ("modulus") and the angle ("argument").

name: Multiplying and dividing complex numbers in polar form (Complex numbers | Precalculus | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how complex multiplication and division work when the numbers are given in polar form. Amazingly enough, this is much easier than multiplication and division in rectangular form.

name: Challenging complex number problem (Complex numbers | Precalculus | Khan Academy)
blurb: This tutorial goes through a fancy problem from the IIT JEE exam in India (competitive exam for getting into their top engineering schools).  Whether or not you live in India, this is a good example to test whether you are a complex number rock star.

name: Basic probability (Probability and combinatorics)
blurb: Flip a quarter a hundred times. What's the probability that it will turn up heads? Tails? Even if we are unsure about whether something will happen, we can start to be mathematical about the "chances" of an event (essentially realizing that some things are more likely than others) occurring. This tutorial will introduce us to the tools that allow us to think about random events and the logic behind comparing, judging, and finding the probabilities of those events.

name: Venn diagrams and the addition rule (Probability and combinatorics)
blurb: What is the probability of getting a diamond or an ace from a deck of cards?  Well I could get a diamond that is not an ace, an ace that is not a diamond, or the ace of diamonds.  This tutorial helps us think these types of situations through a bit better (especially with the help of our good friend, the Venn diagram).

name: Compound probability of independent events using diagrams (Probability and combinatorics)
blurb:
What is the probability of making three free throws in a row (LeBron literally asks this in this tutorial).

In this tutorial, we'll explore compound events happening where the probability of one event is not dependent on the outcome of another (compound, independent, events).

name: Compound probability of independent events using the multiplication rule (Probability and combinatorics)
blurb: See how we can use the multiplication rule to find the compound probability of independent events.

name: Dependent events (Probability and combinatorics)
blurb: What's the probability of picking two "e" from the bag in scrabble (assuming that I don't replace the tiles).  Well, the probability of picking an 'e' on your second try depends on what happened in the first (if you picked an 'e' the first time around, then there is one less 'e' in the bag).  This is just one of many, many type of scenarios involving dependent probability.

name: Permutations (Probability and combinatorics)
blurb: You want to display your Chuck Norris dolls on your desk at school and there is only room for five of them.  Unfortunately, you own 50.  How many ways can you pick the dolls and arrange them on your desk?

name: Combinations (Probability and combinatorics)
blurb: You are already familiar with calculating permutation ("How many ways could 7 different people sit in 4 different seats?").  But what if you didn't care about which seat they sat in?  What if you just cared about which 4 people were in the car?  Or put another way, you want to know how many combinations of 4 people can you stick in the car from a pool of 7 candidates.  Or how many ways are there to choose 4 things from a pool of 7?  Look no further than this tutorial to answer your questions.

name: Probability using combinatorics (Probability and combinatorics)
blurb: This tutorial will apply the permutation and combination tools you learned in the last tutorial to problems of probability.  You'll finally learn that there may be better "investments" than poring all your money into the Powerball Lottery.

name: Arithmetic sequences (Series | Precalculus | Khan Academy)
blurb: Review arithmetic sequences before you dive into arithmetic series.

name: Sigma notation (Series | Precalculus | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how to use and interpret sigma notation. Hint: It means take the sum!

name: Sequences and series (Series | Precalculus | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how to evaluate and work with finite arithmetic series.

name: Geometric sequences (Series | Precalculus | Khan Academy)
blurb: Review geometric sequences before you dive into geometric series.

name: Finite geometric series (Series | Precalculus | Khan Academy)
blurb: Whether you are computing mortgage payments or calculating how many users your website will have after a few years,  geometric  series show up in life far more than you imagine.  This tutorial will review all the important concepts and more!

name: Finite geometric series word problems (Series | Precalculus | Khan Academy)
blurb: Apply what you've learned about geometric series to model situations in some fun word problems.

name: Logarithmic differentiation (Derivatives: chain rule and other advanced topics)
blurb: In logarithmic differentiation, we find the derivative of the natural log of a function instead of the derivative of the function itself. It may surprise you, but this can sometimes actually be easier than regular differentiation, if not the only available option. For example, finding the derivative of xˣ.

name: L’Hôpital’s rule: composite exponential functions (Applications of derivatives)
blurb: L'Hôpital's rule provides us with an easy, almost magical way of finding indeterminate limits of quotients of functions using the functions' derivatives. In short, the rule says that if the limits of functions f and g at x=a are 0 (or ထ) and the limit of f'(x)/g'(x) at x=a is equal to L, then the limit of f(x)/g(x) at x=a is also equal to L.
