name: Strategy in factoring quadratics (Factorization)
blurb: There are a lot of methods to factor quadratics, which apply on different occasions and conditions. Now that we know all of them, let's think strategically about which of them is useful for a given quadratic expression we want to factor.

name: Factoring polynomials with special product forms (Factorization)
blurb: Factor polynomials of various degrees using factorization methods that are based on the special product forms "difference of squares" and "perfect squares." For example, factor 25x⁴-30x²+9 as (5x²-3)².

name: Polynomial remainder theorem (Factorization)
blurb: The polynomial remainder theorem allows us to easily determine whether a linear expression is a factor of a given polynomial. Learn exactly what the theorem means, practice using it, and learn about its proof.

name: Parabolas intro (Quadratics)
blurb: Learn what parabolas are and about their main features: their general shape, vertex, and axis of symmetry.

name: Quadratic factored form (Quadratics)
blurb: The factored form of a quadratic function is an expression that is, well, factored! Like f(x)=(2x+1)(x-3). Learn how to analyze functions given in this form to find their zeros, their vertex, and their graph.

name: Solving quadratics by taking square roots (Quadratics)
blurb: In this tutorial you will learn about the most basic way of solving quadratic equations.

name: Quadratic vertex form (Quadratics)
blurb: The vertex form of a quadratic function shows the coordinates of the parabola's vertex. For example, the vertex of g(x)=(x-1)²+2 is at (1,2). Learn how to analyze functions given in this form to find their zeros, their vertex, and their graph.

name: Solving quadratics by factoring (Quadratics)
blurb: In this tutorial, you'll learn some pretty elaborate ways of solving quadratic equations, by harnessing the mighty strength of algebra.

name: Completing the square (Quadratics)
blurb: You're already familiar with factoring quadratics, but have begun to realize that it only is useful in certain cases.  Well, this tutorial will introduce you to something far more powerful and general.  Even better, it is the bridge to understanding and proving the famous quadratic formula.

name: The quadratic formula (Quadratics)
blurb: Learn how to solve any quadratic equation with the most general tool of all, the quadratic formula!

name: Quadratic standard form (Quadratics)
blurb: In this tutorial, we will learn how to graph quadratic functions given in different forms.

name: Features & forms of quadratic functions (Quadratics)
blurb: Learn about the features of quadratic functions, and how to find them given the formula of the function. Also learn about the different forms of quadratic functions: standard, vertex, and factored.

name: Transforming parabolas (Quadratics)
blurb: Learn how function transformations affect the graphs of quadratic functions.

name: Irrational numbers (Irrational numbers)
blurb: Learn what irrational numbers are. Also learn how to classify numbers as whole, integer, rational, and irrational.

name: Sums & products of rational/irrational numbers (Irrational numbers)
blurb: Determine whether various combinations of rational and irrational numbers are rational or irrational themselves.

name: Proofs concerning irrational numbers (Irrational numbers)
blurb: Learn some proofs about the existence of irrational numbers.

name: What are the imaginary numbers? (Complex numbers | Mathematics 2 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn about the imaginary unit i (which is the square root of -1) and about imaginary numbers like 3i (which is the square root of -9).

name: What are the complex numbers? (Complex numbers | Mathematics 2 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn about complex numbers (spoiler: they are numbers that consist of both real and imaginary parts).

name: The complex plane (Complex numbers | Mathematics 2 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how we can visualize complex numbers in a plane. This can be seen as an expansion of the 1-dimensional real number line into a 2-dimensional plane!

name: Adding & subtracting complex numbers (Complex numbers | Mathematics 2 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how to add or subtract complex numbers. For example, write (2+3i)-(1+2i) as (1+i).

name: Multiplying complex numbers (Complex numbers | Mathematics 2 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how to multiply complex numbers using the fact that i^2=-1 and the distributive property. For example, multiply (1+i) by (2+3i).

name: Equivalent forms of exponential expressions (Exponential growth & decay | Mathematics 2 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how to manipulate exponential expressions in different ways. For example, rewrite 8^x as 2^(3x).

name: Exponential equations: properties of exponents (Exponential growth & decay | Mathematics 2 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how to solve advanced exponential equations by manipulating the expressions in the equations using the properties of exponents. For example, solve 2^(x+1)=8^x by rewriting 8^x as 2^(3x) and then equating x+1=3x.

name: Interpreting the rate of change of exponential models (Exponential growth & decay | Mathematics 2 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how to analyze exponential modeling functions in order to find their rate of change.

name: Constructing exponential models according to rate of change (Exponential growth & decay | Mathematics 2 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how to find the modeling function of an exponential real world context, according to the description of its rate of change.

name: Advanced interpretation of exponential models (Exponential growth & decay | Mathematics 2 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how to interpret an exponential modeling function by first manipulating it according to your needs. For example, rewrite 5^(2x+1) as 5*25^x to find that the unit growth factor is 25.

name: Distinguishing between linear and exponential growth (Exponential growth & decay | Mathematics 2 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how to analyze real-world quantitative relationships given as tables of values to determine whether they represent linear growth or exponential growth.

name: Modeling with one-variable equations & inequalities (Modeling with algebra)
blurb: Learn how to determine the appropriate *type* of modeling equation (or inequality) according to the description of a real-world context.

name: Manipulating formulas (Modeling with algebra)
blurb: Learn how to solve problems that involve multi-variable formulas.

name: Definitions of similarity (Similarity)
blurb: In this tutorial, you will learn how we determine whether two figures are similar.

name: Introduction to triangle similarity (Similarity)
blurb: In this tutorial, we will use what we learned about similarity of polygons in the specific case of triangles. We will come up with specific conditions for triangles to be similar, and use them to determine whether two triangles are similar.

name: Solving similar triangles (Similarity)
blurb: Learn how to find missing measures of triangles using the fact that they are similar to other triangles.

name: Angle bisector theorem (Similarity)
blurb: Learn about the angle bisector theorem, which makes a clever use of triangle similarity in order to find a special proportion that holds for angle bisectors of triangles.

name: Solving problems with similar & congruent triangles (Similarity)
blurb: You already saw how we can use similarity and congruence to find missing measures in triangles. Let's do the same now to solve more kinds of polygons, and more challenging problems!

name: Solving modeling problems with similar & congruent triangles (Similarity)
blurb: Now that you are an expert with solving geometry problems using congruence and similarity, you are ready to solve some real-world problems!

name: Pythagorean theorem (Right triangles & trigonometry)
blurb:
Named after the Greek philosopher who lived nearly 2600 years ago, the Pythagorean theorem is as good as math theorems get (Pythagoras also started a religious movement).  It's simple.  It's beautiful.  It's powerful.

In this tutorial, we will cover what it is and how it can be used.  We have another tutorial that gives you as many proofs of it as you might need.

name: Pythagorean theorem proofs (Right triangles & trigonometry)
blurb: The Pythagorean theorem is one of the most famous ideas in all of mathematics.  This tutorial proves it.  Then proves it again... and again... and again.  More than just satisfying any skepticism of whether the Pythagorean theorem is really true (only one proof would be sufficient for that), it will hopefully open your mind to new and beautiful ways to prove something very powerful.

name: Special right triangles (Right triangles & trigonometry)
blurb: We hate to pick favorites, but there really are certain right triangles that are more special than others.  In this tutorial, we pick them out, show why they're special, and prove it!  These include 30-60-90 and 45-45-90 triangles (the numbers refer to the measure of the angles in the triangle).

name: Introduction to the trigonometric ratios (Right triangles & trigonometry)
blurb: Learn what sine, cosine, and tangent are.

name: Solving for a side in a right triangle using the trigonometric ratios (Right triangles & trigonometry)
blurb: Learn how to find a side length in a right triangle when given one side length and one acute angle.

name: Solving for an angle in a right triangle using the trigonometric ratios (Right triangles & trigonometry)
blurb: Learn how to find an acute angle in a right triangle when given two side lengths.

name: Modeling with right triangles (Right triangles & trigonometry)
blurb: Solve real-world problems that can be modeled by right triangles, using trigonometry.

name: Trigonometric ratios & similarity (Right triangles & trigonometry)
blurb: Learn how the trigonometric ratios are derived from triangle similarity considerations.

name: Sine & cosine of complementary angles (Right triangles & trigonometry)
blurb: Learn about the relationship between the sine of an angle and the cosine of its complementary angle, which is the angle that completes to 90°.

name: Solid geometry intro (Solid geometry)
blurb: Tired of perimeter and area and now want to measure 3-D space-take-upness.  Well you've found the right tutorial.  Enjoy!

name: Density (Solid geometry)
blurb: Use your knowledge of surface area and volume to solve problems involving density.

name: 2D vs. 3D objects (Solid geometry)
blurb: Visualize the relation between two-dimensional and three-dimensional objects.

name: Circles basics (Circles)
blurb: Make sure you're familiar with notation and key terms like radius, diameter, circumference, pi, tangent, secant, and major/minor arcs before you dive into the rest of the circles content.

name: Arc measures (Circles)
blurb: Arc measure is equal to the arc's central angle. We'll explore this fact and solve some problems related to it.

name: Arc length (degrees) (Circles)
blurb: Think about the relationship between central angle and arc length. This tutorial uses degrees not radians.

name: Introduction to radians (Circles)
blurb: Most people know that you can measure angles with degrees, but only exceptionally worldly people know that radians can be an exciting alternative. As you'll see, degrees are somewhat arbitrary.

name: Arc length (radians) (Circles)
blurb: Think about the relationships between arc measures, central angles, and arc length in radians.

name: Sectors (Circles)
blurb: Learn how to find the area of a sector.

name: Inscribed angles (Circles)
blurb: We'll now dig a bit deeper in our understanding of circles by looking at inscribed angles and related properties.

name: Inscribed shapes problem solving (Circles)
blurb: Use properties of inscribed angles to prove properties of inscribed shapes, then apply these properties some fun problem solving!

name: Properties of tangents (Circles)
blurb: Explore, prove, and apply properties of circles that involve tangents.

name: Area of inscribed triangle (Circles)
blurb: This more advanced (and very optional) tutorial is fun to look at for enrichment.  It builds to figuring out the formula for the area of a triangle inscribed in a circle!

name: Constructing regular polygons inscribed in circles (Circles)
blurb: Have you ever wondered how people would draw a square, equilateral triangle or even hexagon before there were computers?  Well, now you're going to do just that (ironically, with a computer).  Using our virtual compass and straightedge, you'll construct several regular shapes (by inscribing them inside circles).

name: Constructing circumcircles & incircles (Circles)
blurb: In our study of triangles, we spent a decent amount of time think about incenters (the intersections of the angle bisectors) and circumcenters (the intersections of the perpendicular bisectors).  We'll now leverage this knowledge to actually construct circle inscribed and circumscribed about a triangle using only a compass and straightedge (actually virtual versions of them).

name: Constructing a line tangent to a circle (Circles)
blurb: Learn how to construct tangents to circles with certain conditions using compass and straightedge. For example, draw the tangent to a given circle that passes through a given point.

name: Introduction to conic sections (Conic sections | Mathematics 2 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Conic sections are formed when you intersect a plane with a cone. In this tutorial, you will learn more about what makes conic sections special.

name: Features of a circle (Conic sections | Mathematics 2 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn about the graphs of circles, and how their center and radius are represented algebraically.

name: Standard equation of a circle (Conic sections | Mathematics 2 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn about the standard form to represent a circle with an equation. For example, the equation (x-1)^2+(y+2)^2=9 is a circle whose center is (1,-2) and radius is 3.

name: Expanded equation of a circle (Conic sections | Mathematics 2 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how to analyze an equation of a circle that is not given in the standard form. For example, find the center of the circle whose equation is x^2+y^2+4x-5=0.

name: Focus & directrix of a parabola (Conic sections | Mathematics 2 | Khan Academy)
blurb: A parabola is the set of all points equidistant from a point (called the focus) and a line (called the directrix). In this tutorial you will learn about the focus and the directrix, and how to find the equation of a parabola given its focus and directrix.

name: Probability basics (Probability)
blurb: Flip a quarter a hundred times. What's the probability that it will turn up heads? Tails? Even if we are unsure about whether something will happen, can we start to be mathematical about the "chances" of an event (essentially realizing that some things are more likely than others) occurring. This tutorial will introduce us to the tools that allow us to think about random events and the logic behind comparing, judging, and finding the probabilities of those events.

name: Counting with combinations (Probability)
blurb: You are already familiar with calculating permutation ("How many ways could 7 different people sit in 4 different seats?"). But what if you didn't care about which seat they sat in? What if you just cared about which 4 people were in the car? Or put another way, you want to know how many combinations of 4 people can you stick in the car from a pool of 7 candidates. Or how many ways are there to choose 4 things from a pool of 7? Look no further than this tutorial to answer your questions.

name: Probability with counting, permutations, combinations (Probability)
blurb: This tutorial will apply the permutation and combination tools you learned in the last tutorial to problems of probability. You'll finally learn that there may be better "investments" than spending all your money on the Powerball Lottery.

name: Multiplication rule for independent events (Probability)
blurb: What’s the probability that three people were all born on the same day of the week? How likely is a basketball player to make three shots in a row? In this tutorial, we’ll see that multiplying probabilities can be quite useful.

name: Multiplication rule for dependent events (Probability)
blurb: What’s the probability of drawing two aces in a row from a deck of cards? Getting an ace on the first card changes the probability for the second card. This tutorial covers how we can deal with that when multiplying probabilities.

name: Addition rule for probability (Probability)
blurb: What’s the probability of picking a card and getting a jack or a heart? What’s the probability that someone owns a laptop or a smartphone? This tutorial will show how we can add probabilities to solve these types of problems.

name: Conditional probability (Probability)
blurb: Given someone likes cheese, what’s the probability they also like pizza? Knowing something can change what we know about the probability of something else. This tutorial on conditional probability covers how to find probability based on some known condition.

name: Simulation and randomness (Probability)
blurb: Drawing names from a hat is fun, and so is calculating probability with formulas, but there are other options. This tutorial covers how we can use simulations and random digits to get samples and find probabilities.

name: Expected value (Probability)
blurb: Will a basketball player score more points over time from a two point shot or a three point shot? How much money can we expect to win back if we play the lottery? This tutorial on expected value will help us answer these types of questions.

name: Combining functions (Functions | Mathematics 3 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how to take two basic functions and combine them into a new function which is their sum, difference, product, or quotient.

name: Composing functions (Functions | Mathematics 3 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn what function composition is, how to to work with composite functions, and how to find the formulas of the composition of two functions.

name: Modeling situations by combining & composing functions (Functions | Mathematics 3 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Make use of knowledge in combining and composing functions, by modeling complex real-world situations.

name: Shifting functions (Functions | Mathematics 3 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how to transform functions so their graph is shifted horizontally or vertically. Learn how to find the equation of a function that is a shift of another function.

name: Stretching functions (Functions | Mathematics 3 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how to transform functions so their graph is stretched horizontally or vertically. Learn how to find the equation of a function that is a stretch of another function.

name: Introduction to inverses of functions (Functions | Mathematics 3 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn what inverses of functions are, and gain some experience with them by finding the outputs of the inverse of a function given that function.

name: Finding inverse functions (Functions | Mathematics 3 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how to find the inverses of polynomials functions, radical functions, and rational functions.

name: Verifying that functions are inverses (Functions | Mathematics 3 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how to check whether a pair of functions are the inverses of one another.

name: Determining whether a function is invertible (Functions | Mathematics 3 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn about the conditions for a function to be invertible, and learn how to manipulate functions to make them invertible.

name: Binomial theorem (Polynomials | Mathematics 3 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how to expand powers of binomial expressions (which are polynomial expressions with exactly two terms). This is done using the binomial theorem!

name: Understanding the binomial theorem (Polynomials | Mathematics 3 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Now that you know how to use the binomial theorem in order to expand powers of binomial expressions, let's gain further insight into why this actually works!

name: Advanced polynomial factorization methods (Polynomials | Mathematics 3 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn more ways to factor polynomials with degree higher than 2.

name: Proving polynomial identities (Polynomials | Mathematics 3 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Practice proving polynomial identities, using all the factorization and expansion methods you know.

name: Polynomial identities with complex numbers (Polynomials | Mathematics 3 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Prove more polynomial identities, this time including complex numbers!

name: Quadratic equations with complex numbers (Polynomials | Mathematics 3 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Remember all these quadratic equations with "no real solution"? Well, it turns out those equations do have a solution, it's just a complex number! Solve a bunch of those here.

name: Fundamental theorem of Algebra (Polynomials | Mathematics 3 | Khan Academy)
blurb: You may already have noticed that quadratic equations always have a solution when including complex number solutions. It turns out this is true for any polynomial equation, of any degree! Learn about this and more, right here.

name: Finding zeros of polynomials (Polynomials | Mathematics 3 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Use all the knowledge you have about polynomials to find their zeros (which are the input values that make the polynomial equal to zero).

name: Zeros of polynomials and their graphs (Polynomials | Mathematics 3 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how to use the zeros of polynomials to draw a pretty good sketch of their graphs.

name: End behavior of polynomial functions (Polynomials | Mathematics 3 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn about the end behavior of polynomial functions. End behavior is the way the function behaves as the input values grow infinitely positive or infinitely negative.

name: Graphs of polynomials (Polynomials | Mathematics 3 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Combine your knowledge about the zeros and the end behavior of a polynomial in order to sketch its graph.

name: Introduction to symmetry of functions (Polynomials | Mathematics 3 | Khan Academy)
blurb: You may already be familiar with types of symmetries of geometrical shapes. Learn how functions can be symmetrical too!

name: Symmetry of polynomial functions (Polynomials | Mathematics 3 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how to determine the symmetry of a polynomial function.

name: Square-root equations (Radical relationships)
blurb: Learn how to solve equations with square-root expressions in them. For example, solve √(2x-5)=√(7-3x).

name: Extraneous solutions of radical equations (Radical relationships)
blurb: Learn about the conditions for obtaining extraneous solutions while solving radical equations.

name: Cube-root equations (Radical relationships)
blurb: Learn how to solve equations with cube-root expressions in them. For example, solve ∛(2-6x)=x+3.

name: Domain of radical functions (Radical relationships)
blurb: Learn how the domain of radical functions is determined.

name: Graphs of radical functions (Radical relationships)
blurb: Learn how the graphs of radical functions look, and how we can reason about them using function transformations (i.e. shifts, stretches, etc.).

name: Simplifying rational expressions (Rational relationships)
blurb: Learn how to simplify rational expressions by canceling factors that are shared by the numerator and the denominator. Sometimes this calls for factoring the numerator and the denominator in various ways.

name: Multiplying & dividing rational expressions (Rational relationships)
blurb: Learn how to multiply and divide rational expressions. You will be surprised to see how similar it is to multiplying and dividing fractions!

name: Adding & subtracting rational expressions (Rational relationships)
blurb: Learn how to add and subtract rational expressions. Like multiplication and division, this skill has a remarkable affinity to adding and subtracting fractions!

name: Nested fractions (Rational relationships)
blurb: Learn how to simplify rational expressions that contain further rational expressions within their numerators or denominators.

name: Rational equations (Rational relationships)
blurb: Learn how to solve equations that have a rational expression, or a few of those.

name: Direct and inverse variation (Rational relationships)
blurb: Learn about direct and inverse variation, which are two types of relationships between two quantities. Direct variation is simply a proportional relationship, but inverse variation is more complicated and interesting. Gain some experience with it before we dive deeper into the world of rational functions.

name: End behavior of rational functions (Rational relationships)
blurb: Learn about the ways in which rational functions behave as x approaches positive or negative infinity. This gets interesting Learn how to determine this behavior for any kind of rational function.

name: Discontinuities of rational functions (Rational relationships)
blurb: Learn about the ways in which rational functions behave when their denominator is equal to zero. This gets interesting when vertical asymptotes are involved! Learn how to determine this behavior for any kind of rational function.

name: Graphs of rational functions (Rational relationships)
blurb: Combine your knowledge of intercepts, horizontal asymptotes, vertical asymptotes, and removable discontinuities, in order to analyze entire graphs of rational functions!

name: Copy of Modeling with rational functions (Rational relationships)
blurb: See some examples of how rational functions and equations can come in handy when solving real-world word problems.

name: Introduction to logarithms (Exponentials & logarithms)
blurb: Learn how we define logarithms and use this definition in order to evaluate various logarithms. For example, evaluate log_2(8) as 3 by realizing that 2^3=8.

name: The constant e and the natural logarithm (Exponentials & logarithms)
blurb: Learn about a very special constant in math that has a pivotal role in the world of exponential and logarithmic function, the constant e.

name: Properties of logarithms (Exponentials & logarithms)
blurb: Learn about special properties of logarithms that help us rewrite logarithmic expressions in different equivalent (much like we use properties of exponents to rewrite exponential expressions!).

name: Change of base formula for logarithms (Exponentials & logarithms)
blurb: Learn how to rewrite any logarithmic expression in a different base. For example, rewrite log_2(3) as ln(3)/ln(2). This is very helpful for evaluating logarithms with a calculator, which only evaluates base-10 and base-e logarithms.

name: Exponential equations: logarithms (Exponentials & logarithms)
blurb: Learn how to solve any exponential equation by using logarithms. For example, solve 2^x=3 by calculating log_2(3).

name: Solving exponential models (Exponentials & logarithms)
blurb: Learn how to solve word problems that require exponential equations.

name: Graphs of exponential functions (Exponentials & logarithms)
blurb: Learn about the graphs of advanced exponential functions of the form y=a*b^(x+c)+d.

name: Graphs of logarithmic functions (Exponentials & logarithms)
blurb: Learn about the graphs of logarithmic functions, and how they relate to graphs of exponential functions.

name: Logarithmic scale (optional) (Exponentials & logarithms)
blurb: Enrich your knowledge with some videos about logarithmic scales and how useful they are.

name: Law of sines (Trigonometry | Mathematics 3 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn about the Law of sines and how to use it in order to find missing side lengths and angles in general triangles.

name: Law of cosines (Trigonometry | Mathematics 3 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn about the Law of cosines and how to use it in order to find missing side lengths and angles in general triangles.

name: Solving general triangles (Trigonometry | Mathematics 3 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Use the power of trigonometry in order to solve various problems that involve triangles.

name: Introduction to radians (Trigonometry | Mathematics 3 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn about radians, which are the official unit of measurement for angles in algebra (in contrast to degrees, which are used in geometry).

name: Unit circle definition of sine, cosine, & tangent (Trigonometry | Mathematics 3 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how the trigonometric ratios are extended to all real numbers using algebra. Start solving simple problems that involve this new definition of the trigonometric functions.

name: Graphs of sine, cosine, & tangent (Trigonometry | Mathematics 3 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how the graphs of y=sin(θ), y=cos(θ), and y=tan(θ) look, using the unit circle definition of the functions.

name: Basic trigonometric identities (Trigonometry | Mathematics 3 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn about very useful trigonometric identities that arise by considering different properties of the unit circle definition.

name: Trigonometric values of special angles (Trigonometry | Mathematics 3 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how to find the trigonometric values of some special angles without the use of a calculator.

name: Pythagorean identity (Trigonometry | Mathematics 3 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Prove the Pythagorean trigonometric identity for all real numbers and use it in order to solve problems.

name: Introduction to amplitude, midline, & extrema of sinusoidal functions (Trigonometry | Mathematics 3 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn about very important features of sinusoidal functions: the amplitude and the midline. Learn how they relate to the extremum points of the function.

name: Finding amplitude & midline from formula (Trigonometry | Mathematics 3 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how to find the amplitude and the midline of the graph of a sinusoidal function from its formula. For example, find the amplitude and the midline of f(x)=3*sin(2x-1)+5.

name: Period of sinusoidal functions (Trigonometry | Mathematics 3 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn about the period of sinusoidal functions: how it relates to extremum points and the midline, and how to find it from the formula of the function. For example, find the period of f(x)=3*sin(2x-1)+5.

name: Graphing sinusoidal functions (Trigonometry | Mathematics 3 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how to draw the graph of sinusoidal functions. For example, draw the graph of f(x)=-2*cos(πx)-7.

name: Constructing sinusoidal functions (Trigonometry | Mathematics 3 | Khan Academy)
blurb: Learn how to find the formula of a sinusoidal function from its graph or a few selected features. Model real-world situations with sinusoidal functions.

name: Solving equations by graphing (Advanced equations & functions)
blurb: Learn how to approximate the solution to any equation by using the power of graphs.

name: Systems of quadratic equations (Advanced equations & functions)
blurb: Learn how to solve systems of two equations in two variables, where at least one of the equations is quadratic.

name: Interpreting the symmetry of algebraic models (Advanced equations & functions)
blurb: Learn how to interpret graphs of modeling functions in terms of their context by considering their symmetry.

name: Interpreting the end behavior of algebraic models (Advanced equations & functions)
blurb: Learn how to interpret graphs of modeling functions in terms of their context by considering their end behavior.

name: Interpreting the periodicity of algebraic models (Advanced equations & functions)
blurb: Learn how to interpret graphs of modeling functions in terms of their context by considering their periodicity.

name: Comparing features of functions (Advanced equations & functions)
blurb: Learn how to compare various features between two functions, each represented in a different way.

name: Basic sigma notation (Series)
blurb: Learn how to use and interpret sigma notation. Hint: It means take the sum!

name: Finite arithmetic series (Series)
blurb: Learn how to evaluate and work with finite arithmetic series.

name: Finite geometric series (Series)
blurb: Whether you are computing mortgage payments or calculating how many users your website will have after a few years,  geometric  series show up in life far more than you imagine.  This tutorial will review all the important concepts and more!

name: Finite geometric series applications (Series)
blurb: Apply what you've learned about geometric series to model situations in some fun word problems.

name: Samples and surveys (Study Design)
blurb: If we want to know something about a large group of people, we can take a sample and give them a survey. This tutorial introduces how that process works.

name: Observational studies and experiments (Study Design)
blurb: “A new study shows that people who eat lobster regularly tend to live longer.” That may be true, but it doesn’t necessarily mean that eating lobster causes people to live longer. We could set up an experiment to find out if lobster is truly the cause. This tutorial covers the difference between observational studies and experiments.

name: Binomial probability (Binomial probability)
blurb: If a basketball player has a 60% chance of making a free-throw, and he’s going to shoot 10 free-throws, what’s the probability that they make 5 or fewer free-throws? This tutorial on binomial probability will cover how to deal with problems just like this one.

name: Normal distributions (Normal distributions)
blurb: What percent of people are taller than 2 meters? What percent of people taking the SAT will score more than three standard deviations about the mean? This tutorial will cover how to use Normal distributions to solve problems like these.

name: Numbers 0 to 120 (Place value | Arithmetic (all content))
blurb: Learn the numbers from 0 to 120.

name: Ones and tens (Place value | Arithmetic (all content))
blurb: (No description)

name: Comparing two-digit numbers (Place value | Arithmetic (all content))
blurb: Learn how to compare two-digit numbers by thinking about place value (tens and ones).

name: Hundreds (Place value | Arithmetic (all content))
blurb: Learn to see three-digit numbers as hundreds, tens, and ones

name: Comparing 3-digit numbers (Place value | Arithmetic (all content))
blurb: Learn how to compare three-digit numbers by thinking about place value (hundreds, tens, and ones).

name: Rounding (Place value | Arithmetic (all content))
blurb: Rounding is useful when you are trying to roughly estimate numbers.

name: Intro to place value (Place value | Arithmetic (all content))
blurb: Learn about whole number place values, create numbers with given place values, and use place value blocks to identify a number.

name: How 10 relates to place value (Place value | Arithmetic (all content))
blurb: Learn to multiply and divide whole numbers by 10.  Learn how multiplying and dividing by 10 affects place value.

name: Ways to write numbers (standard, written, and expanded forms) (Place value | Arithmetic (all content))
blurb: Learn to write whole numbers in expanded form, written form, and standard form.

name: Regrouping whole numbers (Place value | Arithmetic (all content))
blurb: Regroup whole numbers based on their place values.

name: Comparing multi-digit numbers (Place value | Arithmetic (all content))
blurb: Compare whole numbers with at least 3 digits.

name: Rounding whole numbers (Place value | Arithmetic (all content))
blurb: If you're looking to create an army of robot dogs, will it really make a difference if you have 10,300 dogs, 9,997 dogs or 10,005 dogs? Probably not. All you really care about is how many dogs you have to, say, the nearest thousand (10,000 dogs). In this tutorial, you'll learn about conventions for rounding whole numbers. Very useful when you might not need to (or cannot) be completely precise.  Common Core Standard: 4.NBT.A.3

name: Roman numerals (Place value | Arithmetic (all content))
blurb: (No description)

name: Basic addition and subtraction (Addition and subtraction)
blurb: Adding and subtracting is the basis of all mathematics.  This tutorial introduces you to one-digit addition and subtraction.

name: Making 10 (Addition and subtraction)
blurb: Learn how to make the number 10 from two smaller numbers.

name: Addition and subtraction word problems (Addition and subtraction)
blurb: Learn how to solve addition and subtraction word problems with small numbers. Numbers used are 10 or less.

name: Addition and subtraction within 20 (Addition and subtraction)
blurb: Add and subtract numbers 20 or less.  Find the missing number in addition and subtraction equations.

name: Word problems within 20 (Addition and subtraction)
blurb: Learn how to solve addition and subtraction word problems. Numbers used are 20 or less.

name: Word problems with "more" and "fewer" (Addition and subtraction)
blurb: Learn how to solve word problems that use the words "more" and "fewer". Numbers used are 20 or less.

name: Intro to addition with two-digit numbers (Addition and subtraction)
blurb: Learn how to add two-digit numbers. By the end of this tutorial, you'll be able to solve problems like 48+6 and 48+21. More advanced problems like 48+28 will be covered in a future tutorial.

name: Intro to subtraction with two-digit numbers (Addition and subtraction)
blurb: Learn how to subtract two-digit numbers. By the end of this tutorial, you'll be able to solve problems like 48-9 and 48-31. More advanced problems like 48-29 will be covered in a future tutorial.

name: Strategies for adding within 100 (Addition and subtraction)
blurb: Learn strategies for adding and subtracting 2-digit numbers.

name: Addition within 100 (Addition and subtraction)
blurb: Learn to add two-digit numbers like 37 and 49.

name: Subtraction within 100 (Addition and subtraction)
blurb: Learn to subtract two-digit numbers like 47 and 39.

name: Word problems within 100 (Addition and subtraction)
blurb: Learn how to solve addition and subtraction word problems. Numbers used 100 or less.

name: Adding and ones, tens, and hundreds (Addition and subtraction)
blurb: Learn how to solve addition problems by adding ones, tens, and hundreds.

name: Subtracting and ones, tens, and hundreds (Addition and subtraction)
blurb: Learn how to solve addition problems by adding ones, tens, and hundreds.

name: Strategies for adding two and three-digit numbers (Addition and subtraction)
blurb: Learn strategies for solving addition problems within 1000.

name: Adding with regrouping within 1000 (Addition and subtraction)
blurb: Learn how to add numbers like 259 + 363. These addition problems are a harder than the ones we've done before because they require regrouping (also called carrying).

name: Subtraction with regrouping within 1000  (Addition and subtraction)
blurb: Learn how to subtract numbers like 363 - 259. These subtraction problems are a harder than the ones we've done before because they require regrouping (also called borrowing).

name: Addition and subtraction missing value problems (Addition and subtraction)
blurb: Learn how to solve problems like "___ - 237 = 448" where you don't know one of the values in an addition or subtraction equation.

name: Addition and subtraction greater than 1000 (Addition and subtraction)
blurb: Learn strategies for adding and subtracting numbers greater than 1000.

name: Multiplication intro (Multiplication and division)
blurb: Welcome to the concept of multiplication.

name: Multiplication facts (Multiplication and division)
blurb: Learn multiplication facts (sometimes called times tables).

name: Properties of multiplication (Multiplication and division)
blurb: Learn about the commutative, associative, and distributive properties of multiplication.  Solve multiplication problems by changing the order of factors (commutativity), the grouping of factors (associativity), and by decomposing the factors (distributive property).

name: Multiplying by 10 (Multiplication and division)
blurb:
As we'll see in this tutorial, multiplying a multiple of 10--like 10, 20, 30, 40, etc.--by a single digit number is not too much more complicated.

Common Core Standard: 3.NBT.A.3

name: Multiplication by tens, hundreds, and thousands (Multiplication and division)
blurb: Learn to multiply whole numbers by multiples of ten. Example: 7 x 500 = 3500

name: Multiplication: place value and area models (Multiplication and division)
blurb: Most people learn to multiply, but only a select-few actually understand what the multiplication represents. This tutorial, with the help of grids and area models, will allow you to be part of this elite group.

name: Multi-digit multiplication (Multiplication and division)
blurb: Learn to multiply multi-digit whole numbers with and without regrouping.

name: Relating multiplication and division (Multiplication and division)
blurb: Let's see how multiplication and division are related.

name: Division intro (Multiplication and division)
blurb: Welcome to the concept of division.

name: Division facts (Multiplication and division)
blurb: Learn your division facts

name: Division problems that work out nicely (Multiplication and division)
blurb: Learn to solve division problems like 3500 ÷ 50 that work out nicely.

name: Division: place value and area (Multiplication and division)
blurb: Dividing big numbers can be difficult to wrap your mind around. In this tutorial, we'll learn some visual ways to think through large division problems.

name: Multi-digit division (Multiplication and division)
blurb: Learn to divide multi-digit numbers by 1-digit numbers.  Answers will not have remainders.

name: Remainders (Multiplication and division)
blurb: Some division problems don't work out perfectly. For example, we know that 6 divided by 3 is 2, and 9 divided by 3 is 3. But, what is 7 divided by 3? Or 8 divided by 3? In division problems like these, we're left with remainders.

name: Multi-digit division (Multiplication and division)
blurb: Learn to divide any whole number by a multiple-digit whole number.

name: Multi-step word problems (Multiplication and division)
blurb: In this tutorial, we'll start to challenge you with more sophisticated multiplication and division word problems. If you understand mult-digit multiplication and long division, you have all the tools you need to tackle these. May the force be with you!

name: Intro to negative numbers (Negative numbers)
blurb: What are negative numbers? When do we use them? Where do we find them on the number line? Let's learn what happens in the world below zero!

name: Number opposites (Negative numbers)
blurb: Opposite numbers are the same distance from 0 on opposite sides of the number line. A number opposite is sometimes called an additive inverse.

name: Absolute value (Negative numbers)
blurb: You'll find absolute value absolutely straightforward--it is just the "distance from zero". If you have a positive number, it is its own absolute value. If you have a negative number, just make it positive to get the absolute value. As you see as you develop mathematically, this idea will eventually extended to more contexts and dimensions, so super important that you understand this core concept now.  Common Core Standards: 6.NS.C.7, 6.NS.C.7c, 6.NS.C.7d

name: Intro to adding negative numbers (Negative numbers)
blurb: Learn how to add negative numbers. By the end of this tutorial, you'll be solving problems like 4 + (-7) with ease!

name: Intro to subtracting negative numbers (Negative numbers)
blurb: Learn why subtracting a negative number is the same as adding its opposite!

name: Adding & subtracting integers (Negative numbers)
blurb: Add and subtract negative numbers using a number line. It's the 7th grade mathematics shuffle: "Slide to the left for a negative value, and slide to the right for a positive value." Be careful, though. Which way do you move if you are subtracting a negative number? The answer awaits!

name: Adding & subtracting with negatives on the number line (Negative numbers)
blurb: Learn how to use number lines to solve negative number addition and subtraction problems.

name: Multiply & divide negative numbers (Negative numbers)
blurb: You already know how to multiply and divide whole numbers, decimals, and fractions. See what happens when we throw negative numbers into the mix. It's really not so different!

name: Fractions intro (Fractions)
blurb: Learn what a fraction is and identify unit fractions.

name: What fractions mean (Fractions)
blurb: Learn to recognize fractions and their parts.

name: Fractions on the number line (Fractions)
blurb: Learn to identify fractions on a number line.

name: Fractions and whole numbers (Fractions)
blurb: Learn how to represent fractions as whole numbers and whole numbers as fractions.

name: Comparing fractions (Fractions)
blurb: In this tutorial, we'll practice understanding what quantities fractions actually represent and comparing those to each other.

name: Equivalent fractions (Fractions)
blurb: Learn how to create equivalent fractions using visuals.

name: Equivalent fractions on the number line (Fractions)
blurb: Learn how to identify fractions on a number line.

name: Visualizing equivalent fractions (Fractions)
blurb: Learn how to find equivalent fractions by multiplying the numerator and denominator by the same number.

name: Common denominators (Fractions)
blurb: Using our knowledge of equivalent fractions, let's rewrite fractions to have the same denominator.

name: Decomposing fractions (Fractions)
blurb: See that a fraction can be broken up (or decomposed) into a bunch of other fractions.

name: Adding and subtracting fractions with like denominators (Fractions)
blurb: Learn how to add and subtract fractions. This is an introductory tutorial, so the fractions you add and subtract have the same denominators.

name: Mixed numbers (Fractions)
blurb: Learn how to write improper fractions as mixed numbers (and mixed numbers as improper fractions).

name: Adding and subtracting mixed numbers (Fractions)
blurb: Learn how to add and subtract mixed numbers. This is an introductory tutorial, so the fractions you add and subtract have the same denominators.

name: Visually adding and subtracting fractions with unlike denominators (Fractions)
blurb: An introduction to adding and subtracting fractions with unlike denominators that uses visual fraction models

name: Adding and subtracting fractions with unlike denominators (Fractions)
blurb: Learn how to add and subtract fractions that have different denominators.

name: Adding and subtracting mixed number with unlike denominators (Fractions)
blurb: Learn how to add and subtract mixed numbers whose fractional parts have different denominators.

name: Adding and subtracting fractions with unlike denominators word problems (Fractions)
blurb: Practice solving word problems by adding and subtracting fractions that have different denominators.

name: Multiplying unit fractions and whole numbers (Fractions)
blurb: Learn how to multiply unit fractions and whole numbers.

name: Multiplying whole numbers and fractions (Fractions)
blurb: Learn the art of multiplying whole numbers by fractions. See how 3 times 2/3 is the same as 6 times 1/3, which is the same as 6/3.

name: Multiplication as scaling (Fractions)
blurb: Learn to see multiplication as a way to grow (scale up) and shrink (scale down) other numbers.

name: Multiplying fractions (Fractions)
blurb: Learn how to multiply a fraction by a fraction.

name: Multiplying mixed numbers (Fractions)
blurb: Learn how to multiply mixed numbers.

name: Multiplying fractions word problems (Fractions)
blurb: Get some practice solving word problems by multiplying fractions.

name: Fractions as division (Fractions)
blurb: **Spoiler Alert!** The fraction bar and the division symbol are really saying the same thing.

name: Dividing unit fractions by whole numbers (Fractions)
blurb: Learn how to divide unit fractions by whole numbers. Example: 1/5 ÷ 3 = 1/15.

name: Dividing whole numbers by unit fractions (Fractions)
blurb: Learn how to divide whole numbers by unit fractions. Example: 4 ÷ 1/3 = 12.

name: Dividing fractions by fractions (Fractions)
blurb: Learn how to divide fractions by other fractions.

name: Dividing fractions word problems (Fractions)
blurb: Practice solving word problems with fraction division.

name: Introduction to decimals (Decimals)
blurb: What are decimal numbers? How are they like fractions?

name: Decimal place value introduction (Decimals)
blurb: Learn the basics of decimal place value.

name: Decimals on the number line (Decimals)
blurb: See how decimals can be placed on the number line, just like fractions and whole numbers can.

name: Converting decimals to fractions (Decimals)
blurb: Learn how to rewrite decimals as fractions.

name: Adding decimals (Decimals)
blurb: You get the general idea of decimals and what the digits in different places represent (place value). Now you're ready to do something with the decimals. Adding and subtracting is a good place to start. This will allow you to add your family's expenses to figure out if your little brother is laundering money (perhaps literally). Have fun!  Common Core Standard: 5.NBT.B.7

name: Adding decimals: standard algorithm  (Decimals)
blurb: Honestly, once you remember one very important rule, the rest of adding and subtracting decimals is a snap. That rule is to be sure and align your decimals first. In this tutorial, you'll get a chance to practice this with us and become fluent adding decimals. We'll tackle subtracting decimals in the next tutorial.

name: Subtracting decimals (Decimals)
blurb: Anything you can do with whole numbers, you can do with decimals.  Subtraction is no exception.  In this tutorial, you'll get some good practice subtracting decimals up the hundredths place.

name: Subtracting decimals: standard algorithm  (Decimals)
blurb: Just like with adding decimals, the key to subtracting decimals is aligning the decimal points. Let's practice!

name: Adding and subtracting decimals word problems (Decimals)
blurb: In this tutorial, we practice solving word problems by adding and subtracting decimal numbers.

name: Multiplying decimals (Decimals)
blurb: The real world is seldom about whole numbers. If you precisely measure anything, you're likely to get a decimal. If you don't know how to multiply these decimals, then you won't be able to do all the powerful things that multiplication can do in the real world (figure out your commission as a robot possum salesperson, determining how much shag carpet you need for your secret lair, etc.).

name: Multiplying decimals: standard algorithm  (Decimals)
blurb: You've already multiplied decimals in the 5th grade. We'll show you some ways to handle slightly more complicated problems. Now you'll become super good at it with a bit more practice!  Common Core Standard: 6.NS.B.3

name: Dividing decimals (Decimals)
blurb: In this tutorial, we'll extend our division skills to include decimals! We get into some pretty fun stuff here including dividing decimals by whole numbers, and dividing whole numbers by decimals. Finally...dividing decimals by decimals.  Common Core Standard 5.NBT.B.7

name: Dividing decimals: standard algorithm  (Decimals)
blurb: Learn long division with decimals. Solve problems like 30.24 divided by 0.42.

name: Significant figures (Decimals)
blurb:
There is a strong temptation in life to appear precise, even when you are aren't accurate.   If you  precisely measure one dimension of a carpet to be 3.256 meters and eyeball the other dimensional to be "roughly 2 meters", can you really claim that the area is  6.512 square meters (3.256 x 2)?  Isn't that a little misleading?  

This tutorial gets us thinking about this conundrum and gives us the best practices that scientists and engineers use to not mislead each other.

name: Overview and history of algebra (Introduction to algebra)
blurb:
Did you realize that the word "algebra" comes from Arabic (just like "algorithm" and "al jazeera" and "Aladdin")?  And what is so great about algebra anyway?  

This tutorial doesn't explore algebra so much as it introduces the history and ideas that underpin it.

name: Introduction to variables (Introduction to algebra)
blurb: Wait, why are we using letters in math? How can an 'x' represent a number? What number is it? This tutorial is great if you're just beginning to delve into the world of variables and expressions.

name: Substitution and evaluating expressions (Introduction to algebra)
blurb: Learn how to substitute (or "plug in") values for variables and evaluate algebraic expressions.

name: Evaluating expressions word problems (Introduction to algebra)
blurb: Learn how to plug in values to evaluate real-world expressions.

name: Writing algebraic expressions introduction (Introduction to algebra)
blurb: Learn the basics of writing expressions with variables.

name: Introduction to equivalent algebraic expressions (Introduction to algebra)
blurb: Learn to tell whether or not two algebraic expressions are equivalent by combining like terms and using the distributive property.

name: Dependent & independent variables (Introduction to algebra)
blurb: Sometimes one variable depends on another. For example, the amount of money you make might depend on how many hours you work.

name: Combining like terms (Introduction to algebra)
blurb: Learn how to combine like terms (with negative numbers and variables), including more complex problems involving the distributive property.

name: Interpreting linear expressions (Introduction to algebra)
blurb: Any expression (mathematical or otherwise) has meaning. Help us match the linear expression to the meaning options given. In some cases, more than one meaning may apply.

name: Irrational numbers (Introduction to algebra)
blurb: Learn what irrational numbers are. Also learn how to classify numbers as whole, integer, rational, and irrational.

name: Sums and products of rational and irrational numbers (Introduction to algebra)
blurb: Determine whether various combinations of rational and irrational numbers are rational or irrational themselves.

name: Proofs concerning irrational numbers (Introduction to algebra)
blurb: Learn some proofs about the existence of irrational numbers.

name: Division by zero (Introduction to algebra)
blurb: Sal uses algebraic reasoning to tackle the problems of dividing by zero.

name: Alternate number bases (Introduction to algebra)
blurb: Most of us are used to using the digits 0-9 to represent numbers in the base-10 (decimal)number system.  In this tutorial, we'll see that is just one of many (really infinite) number systems.  In particular, we will focus on the binary (base-2) and hexadecimal (base-16) systems.

name: Algebraic equations basics (Solving basic equations & inequalities (one variable, linear))
blurb: Explore what it means for equations with variables (algebraic equations) to be solved.

name: Why we do the same thing to both sides of an equation (Solving basic equations & inequalities (one variable, linear))
blurb: A high-level, conceptual walk-through of what an equation represents and why we do the same thing to both sides of it

name: One-step addition & subtraction equations (Solving basic equations & inequalities (one variable, linear))
blurb: Solve equations by adding and subtracting numbers from both sides.

name: One-step multiplication & division equations (Solving basic equations & inequalities (one variable, linear))
blurb: Solve equations by multiplying and dividing numbers from both sides.

name: Two-steps equations intro (Solving basic equations & inequalities (one variable, linear))
blurb: Learn how to solve equations like 2x+7=13 and 3(x+4)=3, which can be solved in two steps.

name: Two-step equation word problems (Solving basic equations & inequalities (one variable, linear))
blurb: Learn how to set up and solve equations to find answers to real-world questions.

name: Linear equations with variables on both sides (Solving basic equations & inequalities (one variable, linear))
blurb: Learn how to solve linear equations that have the variable on both sides of the equation. For example, solve 2x+5=6x-3.

name: Linear equations with parentheses (Solving basic equations & inequalities (one variable, linear))
blurb: Learn how to solve linear equations with parentheses using the distributive property. For example, solve -9 - (9x - 6) = 3(4x + 6).

name: Analyzing the number of solutions to linear equations (Solving basic equations & inequalities (one variable, linear))
blurb: Linear equations can either have a single solution, infinite solutions, or no solutions. Learn how to determine the number of solutions to a given equation, and how to create equations with a desired number of solutions.

name: Linear equations word problems (Solving basic equations & inequalities (one variable, linear))
blurb: Solve word problems by creating linear equations and solving them.

name: Linear equations with unknown coefficients (Solving basic equations & inequalities (one variable, linear))
blurb: An equation like ax+3x=bx+5 can still be solved for x even though some of the coefficients are variables.

name: Old school equations with Sal (Solving basic equations & inequalities (one variable, linear))
blurb: Some of Sal's oldest (and roughest) videos on algebra.  Great tutorial if you want to see what Khan Academy was like around 2006.  You might also like it if you feel like Sal has lost his magic now that he doesn't use the cheapest possible equipment to make the videos.

name: Introduction to inequalities with variables (Solving basic equations & inequalities (one variable, linear))
blurb: Algebraic inequalities (inequalities with variables) are useful for describing real-world situations. Learn how to write inequalities and graph them on the number line.

name: One-step inequalities (Solving basic equations & inequalities (one variable, linear))
blurb: Learn how to solve (mathematical) inequalities. A key concept in this tutorial is flipping the inequality sign when multiplying or dividing both sides by a negative number.

name: Two-step inequalities (Solving basic equations & inequalities (one variable, linear))
blurb: Learn how to solve more complex (mathematical) inequalities. Also learn to construct inequalities to model real-world situations.

name: Multi-step inequalities (Solving basic equations & inequalities (one variable, linear))
blurb: Solve any possible linear inequality in one variable. For example, solve -3x-7<x+9.

name: Compound inequalities (Solving basic equations & inequalities (one variable, linear))
blurb: Learn how to solve compound inequalities. For example, solve 2x+1>3 AND -x-5<4.

name: Two-variable linear equations intro (Linear equations, functions, & graphs)
blurb: Understand what a solution to an equation really means. Practice plugging in values for variables to see whether or not an equation is true.

name: x-intercepts and y-intercepts (Linear equations, functions, & graphs)
blurb: Learn about intercepts and practice finding them from graphs, tables, and equations.

name: Slope (Linear equations, functions, & graphs)
blurb: Learn about slope (the steepness of a line) and how to find it.

name: Copy of Horizontal & vertical lines (Linear equations, functions, & graphs)
blurb: You know what horizontal and vertical lines are, but how do their equations look? And what is their slope? Learn all about it in this tutorial.

name: Intro to slope-intercept form (Linear equations, functions, & graphs)
blurb: Make an introduction with the most common form of linear equations, slope-intercept form! For example, y=3x+5 is a linear equation in slope-intercept form.

name: Graphing slope-intercept equations (Linear equations, functions, & graphs)
blurb: Learn how to graph linear equations that are given in slope-intercept form. For example, graph y=2x+3.

name: Writing slope-intercept equations (Linear equations, functions, & graphs)
blurb: Learn how to write the equation of a line (in slope-intercept form) when given the graph of the equation or two points on the line. For example, write the equation of the line that passes through the points (0,1) and (5,4).

name: Point-slope form (Linear equations, functions, & graphs)
blurb: (y-b)=m(x-a)

name: Standard form (Linear equations, functions, & graphs)
blurb: ax+by=c

name: Summary: Forms of two-variable linear equations (Linear equations, functions, & graphs)
blurb: Take an overview of the three main forms of linear equations: slope-intercept, point-slope, and standard. Learn which form is most appropriate for different uses.

name: Interpreting linear functions and equations (Linear equations, functions, & graphs)
blurb: Solve word problems where you need to answer a question about a real-world relationship based on its mathematical model.

name: Comparing linear functions (Linear equations, functions, & graphs)
blurb: Compare features of linear functions, such as slope and intercepts, where the functions are given in different forms—tables, graphs, or formulas.

name: Constructing linear models for real-world relationships (Linear equations, functions, & graphs)
blurb: Learn how to represent real-world relationships (that are described verbally) with linear graphs, equations, or functions.

name: Linear models word problems (Linear equations, functions, & graphs)
blurb: Solve general word problems about real-world relationships that can be modeled by linear equations or functions.

name: Introduction to arithmetic sequences (Sequences)
blurb: Learn about arithmetic sequences and their main features, the initial term and the common difference. Evaluate arithmetic sequences.

name: Constructing arithmetic sequences (Sequences)
blurb: Learn how to find the explicit or recursive formula of an arithmetic sequence.

name: Introduction to geometric sequences (Sequences)
blurb: Learn about geometric sequences and their main features, the initial term and the common ratio. Evaluate geometric sequences.

name: Constructing geometric sequences (Sequences)
blurb: Learn how to find the explicit or recursive formula of a geometric sequence.

name: Modeling with sequences (Sequences)
blurb: Now that we've mastered arithmetic and geometric sequences, let's see how they can help us solve real-world word problems. In this tutorial you will find the formula for a sequence that models a real-world relationship.

name: General sequences (Sequences)
blurb: Arithmetic and geometric sequences are very useful, but they are definitely not the only kinds of sequences out there. Let's zoom out and consider some other kinds of sequences.

name: Systems of equations overview (System of equations)
blurb: This video series covers everything you need to know about systems of equations, through stories about trolls, kings, and cupcakes!

name: Introduction to systems of equations (System of equations)
blurb: Learn what "systems of equations" are, what counts as a solution to such a system, and how we can use graphs to solve them.

name: Equivalent systems of equations and the elimination method (System of equations)
blurb: Learn about the elimination method, which is a way manipulate systems of equations in order to solve them algebraically. This is actually very similar to the way we manipulate single equations in order to solve them!

name: Solving systems of equations with substitution (System of equations)
blurb: Learn about the substitution method, which is another way to manipulate systems of equations in order to solve them.

name: Manipulating expressions with unknown variables (System of equations)
blurb: Learn how to rewrite expressions with variables whose values are unknown, by using another information about those variables. For example, given that a+b=0, express a*b in terms of b alone.

name: Number of solutions to systems of equations (System of equations)
blurb: Learn about the possible number of solutions of systems of linear equations. Spoiler: There can be a single solution, zero solutions, or infinite solutions. These different cases define the distinctions between "consistent" and "inconsistent" systems, and between "dependent" and "independent" systems.

name: Solving any system of linear equations (System of equations)
blurb: Use everything you learned so far in order to solve any kind of system of equations!

name: Systems of equations word problems (System of equations)
blurb: Now that we are able to solve any kind of system we are given, it's time to use that knowledge to solve some word problems.

name: Solving equations by graphing (System of equations)
blurb: Learn how to approximate the solution to any equation by using the power of graphs.

name: Systems with three variables (System of equations)
blurb: Learn how to make the most out of the familiar algebraic techniques in order to solve systems of three equations with three variables.

name: Checking solutions of two-variable inequalities (Two-variable inequalities)
blurb: Learn how to check possible solutions of two-variable linear inequalities. For example, is (2, 0) a solution to y>x+1? In this tutorial, we also check solutions to systems of inequalities.

name: Constraining solutions of two-variable inequalities (Two-variable inequalities)
blurb: Given a specific value for one of the variables in a two-variable linear inequality (or system of inequalities), learn how to find the corresponding range of values for the other variable. For example, given that x=3, what are the possible values for y in 2x+y<1 ?

name: Graphing two-variable inequalities (Two-variable inequalities)
blurb: Learn how to graph two-variables linear inequalities and systems of two-variable linear inequalities.

name: Modeling with linear inequalities (Two-variable inequalities)
blurb: Learn how to construct linear inequalities and systems of inequalities given a real-life context. Learn how to interpret such inequalities in terms of a real-life context, either algebraically or graphically.

name: Evaluating functions (Functions)
blurb: Learn how to find the value of a function for a given input value.

name: Inputs and outputs of a function (Functions)
blurb: Extend your understanding of the relationship between the inputs of a function and the outputs of that function.

name: Functions and equations (Functions)
blurb: Understand the subtle differences and similarities between functions and equations. In this exercise, we will see how an equation can be turned into a function.

name: Interpreting function notation (Functions)
blurb: Solve some word problems by interpreting expressions of modeling functions.

name: Introduction to the domain and range of a function (Functions)
blurb: Learn what the domain and the range of a function are. Practice finding the domain and the range of a function given its graph.

name: Determining the domain of a function (Functions)
blurb: Determine the domains of functions according to various considerations.

name: Recognizing functions (Functions)
blurb: Learn how to distinguish between two-variable relationships that are functions and two-variable relationships that aren't functions.

name: Piecewise functions (Functions)
blurb: Piecewise functions are functions that have different assignment rules for different numbers. For example, a function can return x² for any negative x-value and return x³ for any non-negative x-value.

name: Maximum and minimum points (Functions)
blurb: Learn about maximum and minimum points of functions.

name: Intervals where a function is positive, negative, increasing, or decreasing (Functions)
blurb: Learn about features of functions that have distinct graphical representations: intervals where the function is always positive or always negative, and intervals where the function is always increasing or always decreasing.

name: Interpreting features of graphs (Functions)
blurb: Interpret the graphs of functions in terms of the contexts that are modeled by the functions.

name: Average rate of change (Functions)
blurb: Learn what's the average rate of change of a function and how to find it over given intervals.

name: Average rate of change word problems (Functions)
blurb: Solve word problems that concern the average rate of change of a functional relationship.

name: Combining functions (Functions)
blurb: Learn how to take two basic functions and combine them into a new function which is their sum, difference, product, or quotient.

name: Composing functions (Functions)
blurb: Learn what function composition is, how to to work with composite functions, and how to find the formulas of the composition of two functions.

name: Shifting functions (Functions)
blurb: Learn how to transform functions so their graph is shifted horizontally or vertically. Learn how to find the equation of a function that is a shift of another function.

name: Stretching functions (Functions)
blurb: Learn how to transform functions so their graph is stretched horizontally or vertically. Learn how to find the equation of a function that is a stretch of another function.

name: Modeling situations by combining and composing functions (Functions)
blurb: Make use of knowledge in combining and composing functions, by modeling complex real-world situations.

name: Introduction to inverses of functions (Functions)
blurb: Learn what inverses of functions are, and gain some experience with them by finding the outputs of the inverse of a function given that function.

name: Finding inverse functions (Functions)
blurb: Learn how to find the inverses of polynomials functions, radical functions, and rational functions.

name: Verifying that functions are inverses (Functions)
blurb: Learn how to check whether a pair of functions are the inverses of one another.

name: Determining whether a function is invertible (Functions)
blurb: Learn about the conditions for a function to be invertible, and learn how to manipulate functions to make them invertible.

name: Determining the domain of advanced functions (Functions)
blurb: Learn how to determine the domain of piecewise functions with different function rules.

name: Determining the range of a function (Functions)
blurb: Learn how to find the range of a function, which is the set of all of the function's possible outputs.

name: Graphing nonlinear piecewise functions (Functions)
blurb: Learn how to graph piecewise functions whose assignment rules are not linear.

name: Interpreting the symmetry of algebraic models (Functions)
blurb: Learn how to interpret graphs of modeling functions in terms of their context by considering their symmetry.

name: Interpreting the end behavior of algebraic models (Functions)
blurb: Learn how to interpret graphs of modeling functions in terms of their context by considering their end behavior.

name: Interpreting the periodicity of algebraic models (Functions)
blurb: Learn how to interpret graphs of modeling functions in terms of their context by considering their periodicity.

name: Comparing features of functions (Functions)
blurb: Learn how to compare various features between two functions, each represented in a different way.

name: Two-variable functions (Functions)
blurb: Learn about functions that take *two* inputs in order to output a single value.

name: Graphs of absolute value functions (Absolute value equations, functions, & inequalities)
blurb: Learn how to graph absolute value functions like f(x)=|x+2|-8.

name: Solving absolute value equations (Absolute value equations, functions, & inequalities)
blurb: Learn how to solve absolute-value equations. For example, solve 2|x-1|=5.

name: Solving absolute value inequalities (Absolute value equations, functions, & inequalities)
blurb: Learn how to solve absolute value inequalities. For example, solve |x-12|+4<14.

name: Parabolas intro (Quadratic equations & functions)
blurb: Learn what parabolas are and about their main features: their general shape, vertex, and axis of symmetry.

name: Quadratic factored form (Quadratic equations & functions)
blurb: The factored form of a quadratic function is an expression that is, well, factored! Like f(x)=(2x+1)(x-3). Learn how to analyze functions given in this form to find their zeros, their vertex, and their graph.

name: Solving quadratics by taking square roots (Quadratic equations & functions)
blurb: In this tutorial you will learn about the most basic way of solving quadratic equations.

name: Quadratic vertex form (Quadratic equations & functions)
blurb: The vertex form of a quadratic function shows the coordinates of the parabola's vertex. For example, the vertex of g(x)=(x-1)²+2 is at (1,2). Learn how to analyze functions given in this form to find their zeros, their vertex, and their graph.

name: Solving quadratics by factoring (Quadratic equations & functions)
blurb: In this tutorial, you'll learn some pretty elaborate ways of solving quadratic equations, by harnessing the mighty strength of algebra.

name: Completing the square (Quadratic equations & functions)
blurb: You're already familiar with factoring quadratics, but have begun to realize that it only is useful in certain cases.  Well, this tutorial will introduce you to something far more powerful and general.  Even better, it is the bridge to understanding and proving the famous quadratic formula.

name: The quadratic formula (Quadratic equations & functions)
blurb: Learn how to solve any quadratic equation with the most general tool of all, the quadratic formula!

name: Quadratic standard form (Quadratic equations & functions)
blurb: In this tutorial, we will learn how to graph quadratic functions given in different forms.

name: Features & forms of quadratic functions (Quadratic equations & functions)
blurb: Learn about the features of quadratic functions, and how to find them given the formula of the function. Also learn about the different forms of quadratic functions: standard, vertex, and factored.

name: Transforming parabolas (Quadratic equations & functions)
blurb: Learn how function transformations affect the graphs of quadratic functions.

name: Systems of quadratic equations (Quadratic equations & functions)
blurb: Learn how to solve systems of two equations in two variables, where at least one of the equations is quadratic.

name: Quadratic inequalities (Quadratic equations & functions)
blurb: Learn how to solve inequalities that contain quadratic expressions. For instance, solve x^2+3x+2>0.

name: Intro to polynomials (Polynomial expressions, equations, & functions)
blurb: Learn about polynomial expressions: What are they? How are they constructed? What can we do with them?

name: Adding & subtracting polynomials (Polynomial expressions, equations, & functions)
blurb: Learn how to add and subtract polynomial expressions with one variable.

name: Adding & subtracting polynomials: two variables (Polynomial expressions, equations, & functions)
blurb: Learn how to add and subtract polynomial that involve two variables. For example, x^3 + xy + 3y - (x^3 + 6xy + 2y^2).

name: Multiplying monomials (Polynomial expressions, equations, & functions)
blurb: As an intro to more elaborate polynomial multiplication, learn how to multiply monomials (which are polynomials with a single term). For example, multiply 2x³ and 5x⁷.

name: Multiplying monomials by polynomials (Polynomial expressions, equations, & functions)
blurb: Learn how to multiply a polynomial expression by a monomial expression. Monomials are just polynomials with a single term!

name: Multiplying binomials (Polynomial expressions, equations, & functions)
blurb: Learn how to multiply two binomials together. For example, (3x - 7) * (10x + 2).

name: Special products of binomials (Polynomial expressions, equations, & functions)
blurb: Learn about the special types of products of binomials: perfect squares and the difference of two squares. These will be very helpful once you tackle more advanced expressions in Algebra.

name: Multiplying binomials by polynomials (Polynomial expressions, equations, & functions)
blurb: Learn how to multiply a polynomial expression by a binomial expression.

name: Polynomials word problems (Polynomial expressions, equations, & functions)
blurb: See a few examples of how we can represent real-world situations with polynomials.

name: Introduction to factorization (Polynomial expressions, equations, & functions)
blurb: Learn what factorization is all about, and warm-up by factoring some monomials.

name: Factoring monomials (Polynomial expressions, equations, & functions)
blurb: Learn how to write a monomial as a factor of two other monomials. For example, write 12x^3 as (4x)(3x^2).

name: Factoring polynomials by taking common factors (Polynomial expressions, equations, & functions)
blurb: Learn how to take a common monomial factor out of a polynomial expression. For example, write 2x^3+6x^2+8x as (2x)(x^2+3x+4).

name: Evaluating expressions with unknown variables (Polynomial expressions, equations, & functions)
blurb: Learn how to evaluate expressions with variables whose values are unknown, by using another information about those variables. For example, given that a+b=3, evaluate 4a+4b.

name: Factoring quadratics 1 (Polynomial expressions, equations, & functions)
blurb: Learn how to factor quadratic expressions with a leading coefficient of 1. For example, factor x²+3x+2 as (x+1)(x+2).

name: Factoring quadratics by grouping (Polynomial expressions, equations, & functions)
blurb: Learn how to factor quadratic expressions with a leading coefficient other than 1. For example, factor 2x²+7x+3 as (2x+1)(x+3).

name: Factoring polynomials with quadratic forms (Polynomial expressions, equations, & functions)
blurb: Learn how to factor quadratic polynomials of the form ax^2+bx+c as the product of two linear binomials. For example, write x^2+3x-10 as (x+5)(x-2). Learn how to identify these forms in more elaborate polynomials that aren't necessarily quadratic. For example, write x^4-4x^2-12 as (x^2+2)(x^2-6).

name: Factoring quadratics: Difference of squares (Polynomial expressions, equations, & functions)
blurb: Learn how to factor quadratics that have the "difference of squares" form. For example, write x²-16 as (x+4)(x-4). Learn how to identify this form in more elaborate expressions. For example, write 4x²-49 as (2x+7)(2x-7).

name: Factoring quadratics: Perfect squares (Polynomial expressions, equations, & functions)
blurb: Learn how to factor quadratics that have the "perfect square" form. For example, write x²+6x+9 as (x+3)². Learn how to identify these forms in more elaborate expressions. For example, write 4x²+28x+49 as (2x+7)².

name: Strategy in factoring quadratics (Polynomial expressions, equations, & functions)
blurb: There are a lot of methods to factor quadratics, which apply on different occasions and conditions. Now that we know all of them, let's think strategically about which of them is useful for a given quadratic expression we want to factor.

name: Factoring polynomials with special product forms (Polynomial expressions, equations, & functions)
blurb: Factor polynomials of various degrees using factorization methods that are based on the special product forms "difference of squares" and "perfect squares." For example, factor 25x⁴-30x²+9 as (5x²-3)².

name: Long division of polynomials (Polynomial expressions, equations, & functions)
blurb: Learn how to divide two polynomials using long division.

name: Synthetic division of polynomials (Polynomial expressions, equations, & functions)
blurb: Learn how to divide polynomials using long division.
