name: Practice dividing polynomials with remainders (Polynomial expressions, equations, & functions)
blurb: After learning about the different methods in which we can find the quotient and the remainder of two polynomials, gain some practice with actually performing polynomial division yourself.

name: Polynomial Remainder Theorem (Polynomial expressions, equations, & functions)
blurb: The polynomial remainder theorem allows us to easily determine whether a linear expression is a factor of a given polynomial. Learn exactly what the theorem means, practice using it, and learn about its proof.

name: Binomial theorem (Polynomial expressions, equations, & functions)
blurb: Learn how to expand powers of binomial expressions (which are polynomial expressions with exactly two terms). This is done using the binomial theorem!

name: Understanding the binomial theorem (Polynomial expressions, equations, & functions)
blurb: Now that you know how to use the binomial theorem in order to expand powers of binomial expressions, let's gain further insight into why this actually works!

name: Advanced polynomial factorization methods (Polynomial expressions, equations, & functions)
blurb: Learn more ways to factor polynomials with degree higher than 2.

name: Proving polynomial identities (Polynomial expressions, equations, & functions)
blurb: Practice proving polynomial identities, using all the factorization and expansion methods you know.

name: Polynomial identities with complex numbers (Polynomial expressions, equations, & functions)
blurb: Prove more polynomial identities, this time including complex numbers!

name: Quadratic equations with complex numbers (Polynomial expressions, equations, & functions)
blurb: Remember all these quadratic equations with "no real solution"? Well, it turns out those equations do have a solution, it's just a complex number! Solve a bunch of those here.

name: Fundamental Theorem of Algebra (Polynomial expressions, equations, & functions)
blurb: You may already have noticed that quadratic equations always have a solution when including complex number solutions. It turns out this is true for any polynomial equation, of any degree! Learn about this and more, right here.

name: Finding zeros of polynomials (Polynomial expressions, equations, & functions)
blurb: Use all the knowledge you have about polynomials to find their zeros (which are the input values that make the polynomial equal to zero).

name: Zeros of polynomials and their graphs (Polynomial expressions, equations, & functions)
blurb: Learn how to use the zeros of polynomials to draw a pretty good sketch of their graphs.

name: End behavior of polynomial functions (Polynomial expressions, equations, & functions)
blurb: Learn about the end behavior of polynomial functions. End behavior is the way the function behaves as the input values grow infinitely positive or infinitely negative.

name: Graphs of polynomials (Polynomial expressions, equations, & functions)
blurb: Combine your knowledge about the zeros and the end behavior of a polynomial in order to sketch its graph.

name: Introduction to symmetry of functions (Polynomial expressions, equations, & functions)
blurb: You may already be familiar with types of symmetries of geometrical shapes. Learn how functions can be symmetrical too!

name: Symmetry of polynomial functions (Polynomial expressions, equations, & functions)
blurb: Learn how to determine the symmetry of a polynomial function.

name: Exponent properties review (Exponential & logarithmic functions)
blurb: Practice using the exponent properties to rewrite powers, where the exponent is an integer that can either be positive or negative.

name: Radicals (Exponential & logarithmic functions)
blurb: Radicals (also known as roots) are a generalization of square roots. They are the inverse operation of any power. For example, the 5th root of 32 is 2, because 2⁵=32.

name: Rational exponents intro (Exponential & logarithmic functions)
blurb: Learn the definition for raising a number by a fractional exponent, like 8^⅔.

name: Properties of exponents (rational exponents) (Exponential & logarithmic functions)
blurb: In this tutorial you will rewrite variable expressions with rational exponents using the properties of exponents.

name: Advanced exponent & radical evaluation (Exponential & logarithmic functions)
blurb: Evaluate elaborate expressions that contain radicals and fractional exponents.

name: Simplifying square roots (Exponential & logarithmic functions)
blurb: We know how to evaluate square roots of perfect squares. For example, √16=4. What about the other square roots? It's harder to give an exact number, but we can simplify them so we have a better understanding of their value. For example, √32=4⋅√2. Learn more about it in this tutorial.

name: Simplifying radicals (higher-index roots) (Exponential & logarithmic functions)
blurb: Just like we can simplify square roots, we can simplify other radicals. This tutorial covers the simplification of higher-index roots. For example, ∜48=2⋅∜3.

name: Radicals (miscellaneous videos) (Exponential & logarithmic functions)
blurb: Various videos we have that cover advanced/special skills related to radical expressions.

name: Exponential vs. linear growth (Exponential & logarithmic functions)
blurb: Learn about exponential growth and decay, and specifically how it always grows (or diminishes) by equal factors.

name: Exponential expressions (Exponential & logarithmic functions)
blurb: Learn how to construct exponential functions to model real-world situations.

name: Graphs of exponential growth (Exponential & logarithmic functions)
blurb: Learn how an exponential function behaves as the value of its input increases to positive infinity or decreases to negative infinity. Learn how to graph basic exponential functions.

name: Exponential vs. linear growth over time (Exponential & logarithmic functions)
blurb: Learn how to  distinguish between linear and exponential growth, and learn the differences between the end behavior of polynomial and exponential functions.

name: Exponential decay (Exponential & logarithmic functions)
blurb: Learn how to construct exponential functions and then analyze them to model and solve real-world problems.

name: Exponential functions from tables & graphs (Exponential & logarithmic functions)
blurb: Learn how to analyze the formulas of basic exponential functions in order to find their common ratio, initial value, and other parameters.

name: Equivalent forms of exponential expressions (Exponential & logarithmic functions)
blurb: Learn how to manipulate exponential expressions in different ways. For example, rewrite 8^x as 2^(3x).

name: Solving exponential equations using properties of exponents (Exponential & logarithmic functions)
blurb: Learn how to solve advanced exponential equations by manipulating the expressions in the equations using the properties of exponents. For example, solve 2^(x+1)=8^x by rewriting 8^x as 2^(3x) and then equating x+1=3x.

name: Introduction to rate of exponential growth and decay (Exponential & logarithmic functions)
blurb: Learn about different ways of describing the rate of change of exponential functions.

name: Interpreting the rate of change of exponential models (Exponential & logarithmic functions)
blurb: Learn how to analyze exponential modeling functions in order to find their rate of change.

name: Constructing exponential models according to rate of change (Exponential & logarithmic functions)
blurb: Learn how to find the modeling function of an exponential real world context, according to the description of its rate of change.

name: Advanced interpretation of exponential models (Exponential & logarithmic functions)
blurb: Learn how to interpret an exponential modeling function by first manipulating it according to your needs. For example, rewrite 5^(2x+1) as 5*25^x to find that the unit growth factor is 25.

name: Distinguishing between linear and exponential growth (Exponential & logarithmic functions)
blurb: Learn how to analyze real-world quantitative relationships given as tables of values to determine whether they represent linear growth or exponential growth.

name: Introduction to logarithms (Exponential & logarithmic functions)
blurb: Learn how we define logarithms and use this definition in order to evaluate various logarithms. For example, evaluate log_2(8) as 3 by realizing that 2^3=8.

name: The constant e and the natural logarithm (Exponential & logarithmic functions)
blurb: Learn about a very special constant in math that has a pivotal role in the world of exponential and logarithmic function, the constant e.

name: Properties of logarithms (Exponential & logarithmic functions)
blurb: Learn about special properties of logarithms that help us rewrite logarithmic expressions in different equivalent (much like we use properties of exponents to rewrite exponential expressions!).

name: The change of base formula for logarithms (Exponential & logarithmic functions)
blurb: Learn how to rewrite any logarithmic expression in a different base. For example, rewrite log_2(3) as ln(3)/ln(2). This is very helpful for evaluating logarithms with a calculator, which only evaluates base-10 and base-e logarithms.

name: Logarithmic equations (Exponential & logarithmic functions)
blurb: Learn how to solve equations that contain logarithmic expressions. For example, solve log(x)+log(3)=log(7).

name: Solving exponential equations with logarithms (Exponential & logarithmic functions)
blurb: Learn how to solve any exponential equation by using logarithms. For example, solve 2^x=3 by calculating log_2(3).

name: Solving exponential models (Exponential & logarithmic functions)
blurb: Learn how to solve word problems that require exponential equations.

name: Graphs of exponential functions (Exponential & logarithmic functions)
blurb: Learn about the graphs of advanced exponential functions of the form y=a*b^(x+c)+d.

name: Graphs of logarithmic functions (Exponential & logarithmic functions)
blurb: Learn about the graphs of logarithmic functions, and how they relate to graphs of exponential functions.

name: Logarithmic scale (Exponential & logarithmic functions)
blurb: Enrich your knowledge with some videos about logarithmic scales and how useful they are.

name: Solving square-root equations (Radical equations & functions)
blurb: Learn how to solve equations with square-root expressions in them. For example, solve √(2x-5)=√(7-3x).

name: Extraneous solutions of radical equations (Radical equations & functions)
blurb: Learn about the conditions for obtaining extraneous solutions while solving radical equations.

name: Solving cube-root equations (Radical equations & functions)
blurb: Learn how to solve equations with cube-root expressions in them. For example, solve ∛(2-6x)=x+3.

name: Domain of radical functions (Radical equations & functions)
blurb: Learn how the domain of radical functions is determined.

name: Graphs of radical functions (Radical equations & functions)
blurb: Learn how the graphs of radical functions look, and how we can reason about them using function transformations (i.e. shifts, stretches, etc.).

name: Intro to rational expressions (Rational expressions, equations, & functions)
blurb: Learn what rational expressions are and about the values for which they are undefined.

name: Simplifying rational expressions (Rational expressions, equations, & functions)
blurb: Learn how to simplify rational expressions by canceling factors that are shared by the numerator and the denominator. Sometimes this calls for factoring the numerator and the denominator in various ways.

name: Multiplying & dividing rational expressions (Rational expressions, equations, & functions)
blurb: Learn how to multiply and divide rational expressions. You will be surprised to see how similar it is to multiplying and dividing fractions!

name: Adding & subtracting rational expressions (Rational expressions, equations, & functions)
blurb: Learn how to add and subtract rational expressions. Like multiplication and division, this skill has a remarkable affinity to adding and subtracting fractions!

name: Nested fractions (Rational expressions, equations, & functions)
blurb: Learn how to simplify rational expressions that contain further rational expressions within their numerators or denominators.

name: Solving rational equations (Rational expressions, equations, & functions)
blurb: Learn how to solve equations that have a rational expression, or a few of those.

name: Direct and inverse variation (Rational expressions, equations, & functions)
blurb: Learn about direct and inverse variation, which are two types of relationships between two quantities. Direct variation is simply a proportional relationship, but inverse variation is more complicated and interesting. Gain some experience with it before we dive deeper into the world of rational functions.

name: End behavior of rational functions (Rational expressions, equations, & functions)
blurb: Learn about the ways in which rational functions behave as x approaches positive or negative infinity. This gets interesting Learn how to determine this behavior for any kind of rational function.

name: Discontinuities of rational functions (Rational expressions, equations, & functions)
blurb: Learn about the ways in which rational functions behave when their denominator is equal to zero. This gets interesting when vertical asymptotes are involved! Learn how to determine this behavior for any kind of rational function.

name: Graphs of rational functions (Rational expressions, equations, & functions)
blurb: Combine your knowledge of intercepts, horizontal asymptotes, vertical asymptotes, and removable discontinuities, in order to analyze entire graphs of rational functions!

name: Modeling with rational functions (Rational expressions, equations, & functions)
blurb: See some examples of how rational functions and equations can come in handy when solving real-world word problems.

name: Rational inequalities (Rational expressions, equations, & functions)
blurb: Learn how to solve inequalities that contain rational expressions. For instance, solve (x-3)/(x+4)≥2.

name: Partial fraction expansion (Rational expressions, equations, & functions)
blurb: Partial fraction expansion is a method that allows us to re-write a relatively complex rational expression as the sum of simpler rational expressions. For example, it allows us to rewrite (3x-8)/(x²-4x-5) as 7/(6x-30)+11/(6x+6).

name: Introduction to radians (Trigonometric functions)
blurb: Learn about radians, which are the official unit of measurement for angles in algebra (in contrast to degrees, which are used in geometry).

name: The unit circle definition of sine, cosine, & tangent (Trigonometric functions)
blurb: Learn how the trigonometric ratios are extended to all real numbers using algebra. Start solving simple problems that involve this new definition of the trigonometric functions.

name: The graphs of sine, cosine, & tangent (Trigonometric functions)
blurb: Learn how the graphs of y=sin(θ), y=cos(θ), and y=tan(θ) look, using the unit circle definition of the functions.

name: Basic trigonometric identities (Trigonometric functions)
blurb: Learn about very useful trigonometric identities that arise by considering different properties of the unit circle definition.

name: Trigonometric values of special angles (Trigonometric functions)
blurb: Learn how to find the trigonometric values of some special angles without the use of a calculator.

name: Pythagorean identity (Trigonometric functions)
blurb: Prove the Pythagorean trigonometric identity for all real numbers and use it in order to solve problems.

name: Introduction to amplitude, midline, & extrema of sinusoidal functions (Trigonometric functions)
blurb: Learn about very important features of sinusoidal functions: the amplitude and the midline. Learn how they relate to the extremum points of the function.

name: Finding amplitude & midline of sinusoidal functions from their formulas (Trigonometric functions)
blurb: Learn how to find the amplitude and the midline of the graph of a sinusoidal function from its formula. For example, find the amplitude and the midline of f(x)=3*sin(2x-1)+5.

name: Period of sinusoidal functions (Trigonometric functions)
blurb: Learn about the period of sinusoidal functions: how it relates to extremum points and the midline, and how to find it from the formula of the function. For example, find the period of f(x)=3*sin(2x-1)+5.

name: Graphing sinusoidal functions (Trigonometric functions)
blurb: Learn how to draw the graph of sinusoidal functions. For example, draw the graph of f(x)=-2*cos(πx)-7.

name: Constructing sinusoidal functions (Trigonometric functions)
blurb: Learn how to find the formula of a sinusoidal function from its graph or a few selected features. Model real-world situations with sinusoidal functions.

name: The inverse trigonometric functions (Trigonometric functions)
blurb: Learn about the inverse functions of sine, cosine, and tangent, and how they are defined even though the functions are not really invertible. These functions will be very helpful when you will solve trigonometric equations.

name: Solving basic sinusoidal equations (Trigonometric functions)
blurb: Learn how to solve equations of the form sin(x)=d or cos(x)=d where d is any number. For example, solve sin(x)=0.6.

name: Solving advanced sinusoidal equations (Trigonometric functions)
blurb: Learn how to solve equations of the form a*sin(bx+c)=d or a*cos(bx+c)=d where a, b, c, and d are any number. For example, solve 5*sin(2x-1)=3.

name: Solving sinusoidal models (Trigonometric functions)
blurb: Solve word problems that involve sinusoidal modeling functions.

name: Introduction to the trigonometric angle addition identities (Trigonometric functions)
blurb: Learn about the trigonometric angle addition identities, which help us discuss the trig values of sums of angles in terms of the trig values of the individual angles. For example, we can express sin(x+y) in terms of sin(x), sin(y), cos(x), and cos(y).

name: Using trigonometric identities to solve problems (Trigonometric functions)
blurb: Learn about different ways in which trigonometric identities, such as the Pythagorean identity and the angle addition identities, can be used to solve problems.

name: Parametric equations (Trigonometric functions)
blurb: Here we will explore representing our x's and y's in terms of a third variable or parameter (often 't').  Not only can we describe new things, but it can be super useful for describing things like particle motion in physics.

name: Rate conversion (Algebraic modeling)
blurb: Practice solving word problems that involve the conversion between different units for the same quantity. For example, a rate problem where some rates are in km/h and some are in m/s.

name: Appropriate units (Algebraic modeling)
blurb: Learn how to work with units that are arithmetic combinations of more simple units. For example, velocity units are quotients of distance units over time units, which corresponds to the formula v=d/t.

name: Word problems with multiple units (Algebraic modeling)
blurb: Practice solving word problems that involve a variety of units.

name: Modeling with one-variable equations & inequalities (Algebraic modeling)
blurb: Learn how to determine the appropriate *type* of modeling equation (or inequality) according to the description of a real-world context.

name: Manipulating formulas (Algebraic modeling)
blurb: Learn how to solve problems that involve multi-variable formulas.

name: What are the imaginary numbers? (Complex numbers)
blurb: Learn about the imaginary unit i (which is the square root of -1) and about imaginary numbers like 3i (which is the square root of -9).

name: What are the complex numbers? (Complex numbers)
blurb: Learn about complex numbers (spoiler: they are numbers that consist of both real and imaginary parts).

name: The complex plane (Complex numbers)
blurb: Learn how we can visualize complex numbers in a plane. This can be seen as an expansion of the 1-dimensional real number line into a 2-dimensional plane!

name: Adding & subtracting complex numbers (Complex numbers)
blurb: Learn how to add or subtract complex numbers. For example, write (2+3i)-(1+2i) as (1+i).

name: Multiplying complex numbers (Complex numbers)
blurb: Learn how to multiply complex numbers using the fact that i^2=-1 and the distributive property. For example, multiply (1+i) by (2+3i).

name: Complex conjugates & dividing complex numbers (Complex numbers)
blurb: Learn how to divide complex numbers using the conjugate of the divisor. For example, divide (2+3i) by (-1+4i) by multiplying both the dividend and the divisor by (-1-4i).

name: Absolute value & angle of complex numbers (Complex numbers)
blurb: Learn about very important graphical features of complex numbers: their absolute value and their angle.

name: Distance & midpoint of complex numbers (Complex numbers)
blurb: Learn how we define the distance of two complex numbers, and how we define their midpoint.

name: Polar form of complex numbers (Complex numbers)
blurb: Learn how to represent complex numbers in a different way. Unlike rectangular form, which emphasizes the real and imaginary parts, polar form emphasizes the absolute value ("modulus") and the angle ("argument").

name: Multiplying & dividing complex numbers in polar form (Complex numbers)
blurb: Learn how complex multiplication and division work when the numbers are given in polar form. Amazingly enough, this is much easier than multiplication and division in rectangular form.

name: Challenging complex number problems (Complex numbers)
blurb: This tutorial goes through a fancy problem from the IIT JEE exam in India (competitive exam for getting into their top engineering schools).  Whether or not you live in India, this is a good example to test whether you are a complex number rock star.

name: Introduction to conic sections (Conic sections)
blurb: Conic sections are formed when you intersect a plane with a cone. In this tutorial, you will learn more about what makes conic sections special.

name: The features of a circle (Conic sections)
blurb: Learn about the graphs of circles, and how their center and radius are represented algebraically.

name: Standard equation of a circle (Conic sections)
blurb: Learn about the standard form to represent a circle with an equation. For example, the equation (x-1)^2+(y+2)^2=9 is a circle whose center is (1,-2) and radius is 3.

name: Expanded equation of a circle (Conic sections)
blurb: Learn how to analyze an equation of a circle that is not given in the standard form. For example, find the center of the circle whose equation is x^2+y^2+4x-5=0.

name: Center and radii of an ellipse (Conic sections)
blurb: Learn about the basic features of ellipses: their center and the two radii that pass through it, the major radius and the minor radius.

name: Foci of an ellipse (Conic sections)
blurb: Learn about the foci of an ellipse, which are two points for which the sum of the distances from any point on the ellipse is constant.

name: Focus and directrix of a parabola (Conic sections)
blurb: A parabola is the set of all points equidistant from a point (called the focus) and a line (called the directrix). In this tutorial you will learn about the focus and the directrix, and how to find the equation of a parabola given its focus and directrix.

name: Introduction to hyperbolas (Conic sections)
blurb: A hyperbola is the set of all points whose distances from two specific points (called the foci) have the same difference. Learn more about it here.

name: Foci of a hyperbola (Conic sections)
blurb: Learn about the foci of the hyperbola: How to find them from the hyperbola's equation and how to find the equation when given the foci.

name: Hyperbolas not centered at the origin (Conic sections)
blurb: Generalize what you learned about hyperbolas to study hyperbolas whose center can be any point.

name: Identifying conic sections from their expanded equations (Conic sections)
blurb: Learn how to analyze expanded equations in order to determine which kind of conic section they represent.

name: Challenging conic section problems (IIT JEE) (Conic sections)
blurb: See Sal solve two (very) advanced problems from the IIT JEE exam, a highly challenging exam administered in India.

name: Basic sigma notation (Series & induction)
blurb: Learn how to use and interpret sigma notation. Hint: It means take the sum!

name: Arithmetic series (Series & induction)
blurb: Learn how to evaluate and work with finite arithmetic series.

name: Geometric sequences (Series & induction)
blurb: Review geometric sequences before you dive into geometric series.

name: Finite geometric series (Series & induction)
blurb: Whether you are computing mortgage payments or calculating how many users your website will have after a few years,  geometric  series show up in life far more than you imagine.  This tutorial will review all the important concepts and more!

name: Finite geometric series applications (Series & induction)
blurb: Apply what you've learned about geometric series to model situations in some fun word problems.

name: Advanced sigma notation (Series & induction)
blurb: Now that you know basic sigma notation and series, we can put the two together to write series using sigma notation and evaluate more challenging expressions.

name: Infinite geometric series (Series & induction)
blurb: You're already familiar with finite geometric series, but you don't want the summation to stop!!  What happens if you keep adding?  The terms are getting small fast!  Can it be that the sum of an infinite number of rapidly shrinking terms can be finite!  Yes, often times it can!  Mind-blowing!  Stupendous!

name: Infinite geometric series applications (Series & induction)
blurb: Apply what you've learned about infinite geometric series to model situations in some fun word problems.

name: Deductive and inductive reasoning (Series & induction)
blurb: You will hear the words "deductive reasoning" and "inductive reasoning" throughout your life.  This very optional tutorial will give you context for what these mean.

name: Induction (Series & induction)
blurb: Proof by induction is a core tool.  This tutorial walks you through the general idea that if 1) something is true for a base case (say when n=1) and 2) if it is true for n, then it is also true for n+1, then it must be true for all n!  Amazing!

name: Sum of n squares (Series & induction)
blurb: (No description)

name: Vector basics (Vectors)
blurb: Learn the basics of vectors, like that a vector has both magnitude and direction.

name: Magnitude of vectors (Vectors)
blurb: Find the magnitude of a vector given in component form.

name: Scalar multiplication (Vectors)
blurb: Multiply a vector by a scalar to get a new vector.

name: Vector addition & subtraction (Vectors)
blurb: Combine two vectors by adding or subtracting them to get a new vector.

name: Combined vector operations (Vectors)
blurb: Use both scalar multiplication and vector addition or subtraction in the same problem!

name: Unit vectors (Vectors)
blurb: Learn about special vectors called unit vectors that have a magnitude of 1.

name: Magnitude & direction form of vectors (Vectors)
blurb: Think about how we can represent vectors using their magnitude and direction instead of their components.

name: Component form of vectors (Vectors)
blurb: Convert vectors from magnitude and direction form to component form.

name: Adding vectors in magnitude & direction form (Vectors)
blurb: Learn how to add two vectors together that are in magnitude and direction form. We can always use our old friend component form!

name: Applications of vectors (Vectors)
blurb: Apply what you've learned about vectors so far to solve some fun word problems.

name: Introduction to matrices (Matrices)
blurb: Learn what matrices are and about their parts (coordinates and dimensions).

name: Representing linear systems of equations with augmented matrices (Matrices)
blurb: Learn how systems of linear equations with multiple variables are represented with matrices.

name: Elementary matrix row operations (Matrices)
blurb: Learn about the three basic operations we can perform on a matrix without changing the solution set of the linear system it represents.

name: Row-echelon form & Gaussian elimination (Matrices)
blurb: Learn how to use the matrix row operations in order to easily solve large systems of linear equations.

name: Adding & subtracting matrices (Matrices)
blurb: Learn how to add and subtract two matrices to obtain a new matrix (just like numbers!).

name: Multiplying matrices by scalars (Matrices)
blurb: Learn how to multiply matrices by scalars (in the world of matrices, scalars are simply regular numbers). For example, multiply a 2X2 matrix by 3.

name: Properties of matrix addition & scalar multiplication (Matrices)
blurb: Learn about zero matrices and about how matrix addition, subtraction, and scalar multiplication are related to their corresponding operations with real numbers.

name: Multiplying matrices by matrices (Matrices)
blurb: Learn how to find the result of a multiplication of two matrices.

name: Properties of matrix multiplication (Matrices)
blurb: Learn about identity matrices and about how matrix multiplication relates to real number multiplication (spoiler: the distributive property applies but the commutative property does not!).

name: Matrices as transformations (Matrices)
blurb: Learn how matrices can be used as transformations of vectors or transformations of the plane.

name: Determinant of a 2x2 matrix (Matrices)
blurb: Learn what the determinant of a matrix is and how to find it for 2x2 matrices.

name: Introduction to matrix inverses (Matrices)
blurb: Learn what the inverse of a matrix is, and how to determine whether two matrices are inverses or whether a matrix is invertible.

name: Finding the inverse of a matrix using its determinant (Matrices)
blurb: Learn about a way to find the inverse of a matrix using its determinant and adjugates.

name: Practice finding the inverses of 2x2 matrices (Matrices)
blurb: After you've learned how to find the inverse of a 2x2 matrix, gain some practice with it.

name: Determinants & inverses of large matrices (Matrices)
blurb: Learn how to find the determinants and the inverses of matrices with dimensions 3x3 or larger.

name: Solving equations with inverse matrices (Matrices)
blurb: Learn how to solve systems of linear equations using inverse matrices, and how to solve matrix equations using inverse matrices.

name: Model real-world situations with matrices (Matrices)
blurb: Learn how matrices can be used to describe real-world situations.

name: Lines, line segments and rays (Lines)
blurb: Let's draw points, lines, line segments, and rays.  We'll also think about perpendicular and parallel lines and identify these in two-dimensional figures.  Common Core Standard: 4.G.A.1

name: Measuring segments (Lines)
blurb: Using a number line, let's learn how we measure segments.

name: Parallel and perpendicular (Lines)
blurb: Learn the definitions of "parallel" and "perpendicular".

name: Points lines & planes (Lines)
blurb: Extending thinking from points and lines (1 and 2 dimensions) to planes (3 dimensions).

name: Geometric definitions (Lines)
blurb: Consider how precise definitions of geometry terms are like angle, circle, parallel lines, and a few others.

name: The golden ratio (Lines)
blurb: Explore a very famous and useful ratio.

name: Angle introduction (Angles)
blurb: What is an angle and how do we label, measure and construct them? Great question. Luckily we have all your answers! To begin our journey towards understanding angles, we'll learn terms like vertex, acute, obtuse, circle arc, circumference, and protractor. These basic angle concepts will get you on the road to angle domination!

name: Measuring angles (Angles)
blurb: Learn how to measure angles using a protractor.

name: Constructing angles (Angles)
blurb: Learn how to draw angles using a protractor.

name: Angles in circles (Angles)
blurb: Learn how to measure angles using a circle protractor and solve word problems about angles as part of a circle.

name: Angle types (Angles)
blurb: Now that we know what angles are, let's dig a bit deeper and classify them and understand their properties better. Acute, obtuse, right, adjacent--all are angles that we will be become familiar with.

name: Vertical, complementary, and supplementary angles (Angles)
blurb: Learn three types of angle pairs: vertical angles, complementary angles, and supplementary angles.

name: Angles between intersecting lines (Angles)
blurb: This tutorial introduces us to angles.  It includes how we measure them, how angles relate to each other and properties of angles created from various types of intersecting lines.  Mr. Angle is actually far more fun than you might initially presume him to be.

name: Sal's old angle videos (Angles)
blurb: These are some of the classic, original angle video that Sal had done way back when (like 2007).  Other tutorials are more polished than this one, but this one has charm.  Also not bad if you're looking for more examples of angles between intersected lines, transversals and parallel lines.

name: Properties of shapes (Shape)
blurb: Learn how different shapes have different numbers of corners, different side lengths, and so on. Use these properties to help you recognize shapes.

name: Classifying shapes (Shape)
blurb: Practice classifying geometric shapes.

name: Curves and polygons (Shape)
blurb: Learn how we define a curve, what are common properties of curves, and what's the relationship between curves and polygons.

name: Angles with polygons (Shape)
blurb: Explore properties of angles in and arou polygons.

name: Geometric solids (Shape)
blurb: Identify 3-dimensional figures and their parts (faces, edges, vertices).

name: Triangle types (Triangles)
blurb: Triangles can be classified in different ways. In this tutorial, we'll learn about scalene, isosceles, equilateral, acute, right, and obtuse triangles.

name: Triangle angles (Triangles)
blurb:
Do the angles in a triangle always add up to the same thing?  Would I ask it if they didn't?  What do we know about the angles of a triangle if two of the sides are congruent (an isosceles triangle) or all three are congruent (an equilateral)?  This tutorial is the place to find out.

Common Core Standard: 8.G.A.5

name: Triangle inequality theorem (Triangles)
blurb:
The triangle inequality theorem is, on some level, kind of simple.  But, as you'll see as you go into high level mathematics, it is often used in fancy proofs.

This tutorial introduces you to what it is and gives you some practice understanding the constraints on the dimensions of a triangle.

name: Perpendicular bisectors (Triangles)
blurb:
In this tutorial, we study lines that are perpendicular to the sides of a triangle and divide them in two (perpendicular bisectors).  As we'll prove, they intersect at a unique point called the cicumcenter (which, quite amazingly, is equidistant to the vertices).  We can then create a circle (circumcircle) centered at this point that goes through all the vertices. 

This tutorial is the extension of the core narrative of the Geometry "course".  After this, you might want to look at the tutorial on angle bisectors.

name: Angle bisectors (Triangles)
blurb: This tutorial experiments with lines that divide the angles of a triangle in two (angle bisectors).  As we'll prove, all three angle bisectors actually intersect at one point called the incenter (amazing!).  We'll also prove that this incenter is equidistant from the sides of the triangle (even more amazing!).  This allows us to create a circle centered at the incenter that is tangent to the sides of the triangle (not surprisingly called the "incircle").

name: Medians and centroids (Triangles)
blurb: You've explored perpendicular bisectors and angle bisectors, but you're craving to study lines that intersect the vertices of a a triangle AND bisect the opposite sides.  Well, you're in luck because that (medians) is what we are going to study in this tutorial.  We'll prove here that the medians intersect at a unique point (amazing!) called the centroid and divide the triangle into six mini triangles of equal area (even more amazing!).  The centroid also always happens to divide all the medians in segments with lengths at a 1:2 ration (stupendous!).

name: Altitudes (Triangles)
blurb: Ok.  You knew triangles where cool, but you never imagined they were this cool!  Well, this tutorial will take things even further.  After perpendicular bisectors, angle bisector and medians, the only other thing (that I can think of) is a line that intersects a vertex and the opposite side (called an altitude).  As we'll see, these are just as cool as the rest and, as you may have guessed, intersect at a unique point called the orthocenter (unbelievable!).

name: Bringing it all together (Triangles)
blurb: This tutorial brings together all of the major ideas in this topic.  First, it starts off with a light-weight review of the various ideas in the topic.  It then goes into a heavy-weight proof of a truly, truly, truly amazing idea.  It was amazing enough that orthocenters, circumcenters, and centroids exist , but we'll see in the videos on Euler lines that they sit on the same line themselves (incenters must be feeling lonely)!!!!!!!

name: Quadrilateral types (Quadrilaterals)
blurb: Not all things with four sides and 90 degree angles are squares or rectangles! Sometimes the angles in these 4-sided shapes are less than (or greater than) 90 degrees, causing them to have a slightly odd shape. These are called quadrilaterals and come in a few different varieties. In this tutorial, you'll learn about them.

name: Quadrilateral proofs & angles (Quadrilaterals)
blurb: Not all things with four sides have to be squares or rectangles!  We will now broaden our understanding of quadrilaterals.

name: Coordinate plane: quadrant 1 (Coordinate plane)
blurb: How can we communicate exactly where something is in two dimensions?  In this tutorial, we cover the basics of the coordinate plane and graphing points.

name: Coordinate plane: 4 quadrants (Coordinate plane)
blurb: We first explored the coordinate plane in the 5th grade, but that was only dealing with positive coordinates.  Now we know all about negative numbers so why not have negative coordinates as well? Let's get cozy with the x and y axis, plotting ordered pairs, quadrants, and reflection points. We got it covered. Sit back, relax, and get ready to groove with us.  Common Core Standards: 6.NS.C.6, 6.NS.C.6b, 6.NS.C.6c, 6.NS.C.8

name: Quadrants (Coordinate plane)
blurb: Learn the 4 quadrants of a coordinate plane.

name: Reflecting points on coordinate plane (Coordinate plane)
blurb: Learn to reflect points on a coordinate plane across both axes and the origin.

name: Quadrilaterals on the coordinate plane (Coordinate plane)
blurb: Math problems that test your understanding of Quadrilateral and points on the coordinate plane

name: Drawing polygons in the coordinate plane (Coordinate plane)
blurb: Practice drawing shapes on the coordinate plane.

name: Count unit squares to find area (Area and perimeter)
blurb: Find area of shapes by counting unit squares.  Some shapes will require combining partial square units to find area.  Create rectangles with a given area by covering unit squares.

name: Area of rectangles (Area and perimeter)
blurb: Transition from counting unit squares to multiplying side length to find area.  Measure side lengths with a ruler to find area.  Find area of rectangles by multiplying side lengths.  Find a missing side length of a rectangle when given the other side length and area.

name: Perimeter (Area and perimeter)
blurb: Have you ever wondered how much fencing you need to surround a plot of land? No? Well, you should still go through this tutorial just in case. You'll learn what perimeter is and how to calculate it.

name: Area of parallelograms (Area and perimeter)
blurb: Understand the formula for the area of a parallelogram.

name: Area of triangles (Area and perimeter)
blurb: Understand the formula for the area of a triangle.

name: Area of shapes on grids (Area and perimeter)
blurb: Area problems involving triangles and quadrilaterals on grids

name: Area of trapezoids and composite figures (Area and perimeter)
blurb: Finding the area of more complex shapes like trapezoids and composite figures (shapes built from other shapes)

name: Area and circumference of circles (Area and perimeter)
blurb: A circle is at the foundation of geometry, and at the foundation of a circle is a special number called Pi. This number allows us to relate the radius, diameter, and circumference of a circle.

name: Advanced area with triangles (Area and perimeter)
blurb: Learn about, prove, and apply area properties of specific types of triangles.

name: Volume of rectangular prisms (Volume and surface area)
blurb: Welcome to the 3rd dimension! [cue spooky music] This tutorial explains how to find volume.

name: Volume with fractions (Volume and surface area)
blurb: Finding the volume of rectangular prisms that have fractional side lengths

name: Surface area (Volume and surface area)
blurb: Learn how to find the total area of the surfaces of 3D shapes. To do this, we wrap 3D shapes in 2D nets.

name: Volume of cones, cylinders, and spheres (Volume and surface area)
blurb: Let's see how to find the volumes of cylinders, spheres and other three dimensional shapes.

name: Solid geometry (Volume and surface area)
blurb: Tired of perimeter and area and now want to measure 3-D space-take-upness.  Well you've found the right tutorial.  Enjoy!

name: Surface and volume density (Volume and surface area)
blurb: Use your knowledge of surface area and volume to solve problems involving density.

name: Cross sections of 3D objects (Volume and surface area)
blurb: It's pretty difficult to work, mentally, with 3D objects. One way of overcoming that difficulty is in thinking about cross sections of such objects. These are 2D slices of 3D objects, and so we're back with the familiar 2D world.

name: Koch snowflake fractal (Volume and surface area)
blurb: Named after Helge von Koch, the Koch snowflake is one of the first fractals to be discovered. It is created by adding smaller and smaller equilateral bumps to an existing equilateral triangle.  Quite amazingly, it produces a figure of infinite perimeter and finite area!

name: Heron's formula (Volume and surface area)
blurb: Named after Heron of Alexandria, Heron's formula is a power (but often overlooked) method for finding the area of ANY triangle.  In this tutorial we will explain how to use it and then prove it!

name: Pythagorean theorem (Pythagorean theorem)
blurb:
Named after the Greek philosopher who lived nearly 2600 years ago, the Pythagorean theorem is as good as math theorems get (Pythagoras also started a religious movement).  It's simple.  It's beautiful.  It's powerful.

Common Core Standards: 8.G.B.7, 8.G.B.8

name: Pythagorean theorem application (Pythagorean theorem)
blurb: Apply the Pythagorean theorem to area and perimeter, 3D figures, and real world problems.

name: Pythagorean theorem and distance between points (Pythagorean theorem)
blurb: Use the Pythagorean theorem to find the distance between points on a coordinate plane and the length of diagonal lines on a coordinate plane.

name: Pythagorean Theorem Proofs (Pythagorean theorem)
blurb:
The Pythagorean theorem is one of the most famous ideas in all of mathematics.  This tutorial proves it.  Then proves it again... and again... and again.  More than just satisfying any skepticism of whether the Pythagorean theorem is really true (only one proof would be sufficient for that), it will hopefully open your mind to new and beautiful ways to prove something very powerful.

Common Core Standard: 8.G.B.6

name: Introduction to rigid transformations (Transformations)
blurb: The three rigid transformations are translations, rotations, and reflections. Get to know them and gain some experience in performing them on different figures.

name: Translations (Transformations)
blurb: Learn how to find the translation that maps a given figure to another, and how to manually draw the image of a translation.

name: Rotations (Transformations)
blurb: Learn how to find the rotation that maps a given figure to another, and how to manually draw the image of a rotation.

name: Reflections (Transformations)
blurb: Learn how to find the reflection that maps a given figure to another, and how to manually draw the image of a reflection.

name: Rigid transformations overview (Transformations)
blurb: After studying each rigid transformation in separate, it's time to take a broader look at those transformations: which properties are preserved under which kind of transformation, and how do we map shapes using sequences of rigid transformations?

name: Dilations (Transformations)
blurb:
In addition to the three rigid transformation, there are the dilations, which expand or shrink figures while keeping the same proportions. These are extremely important in the subject of Similarity!

Gain experience by performing dilation, learn how to find the dilation that maps a given figure to another, and learn how to manually draw the image of a dilation.

name: Properties and definitions of transformations (Transformations)
blurb: Let's continue our deep voyage through the world of transformations! Use your knowledge about the precise descriptions of the rigid transformations and their properties in various situations.

name: Symmetry (Transformations)
blurb: Learn about different kinds of symmetries of two-dimensional shapes, and analyze various shapes according to their symmetries.

name: Old transformations videos (Transformations)
blurb: These are some oldies that we keep here for anyone who's interested.

name: Transformations and congruence (Congruence)
blurb: Two figures are congruent if you can go from one to another through some combination of translations, reflections and rotations.  In this tutorial, we'll really internalize this by working through the actual transformations.

name: Triangle congruence (Congruence)
blurb: Learn how the definition of congruence using rigid transformations can be simplified to simple criteria when studying congruent triangles.

name: Theorems concerning triangle properties (Congruence)
blurb: Now that we know how to show that two triangles are congruent, let's put that to use by proving some theorems about triangles.

name: Working with triangles (Congruence)
blurb: Learn how to solve different geometric problems using triangle congruence.

name: Theorems concerning parallelogram properties (Congruence)
blurb: Triangle congruence is not only useful when working with triangles, it's also useful with any other kind of polygon! Prove a few theorems about the properties of parallelograms using triangle congruence.

name: Proofs of theorems that use triangle congruence (Congruence)
blurb: Gain even more experience with using triangle congruence in proofs.

name: Definitions of similarity (Similarity)
blurb: In this tutorial, you will learn how we determine whether two figures are similar.

name: Triangle similarity (Similarity)
blurb: In this tutorial, we will use what we learned about similarity of polygons in the specific case of triangles. We will come up with specific conditions for triangles to be similar, and use them to determine whether two triangles are similar.

name: Solving similar triangles (Similarity)
blurb: Learn how to find missing measures of triangles using the fact that they are similar to other triangles.

name: Angle bisector theorem (Similarity)
blurb: Learn about the angle bisector theorem, which makes a clever use of triangle similarity in order to find a special proportion that holds for angle bisectors of triangles.

name: Solving problems with similar and congruent triangles (Similarity)
blurb: You already saw how we can use similarity and congruence to find missing measures in triangles. Let's do the same now to solve more kinds of polygons, and more challenging problems!

name: Solving modeling problems with similar and congruent triangles (Similarity)
blurb: Now that you are an expert with solving geometry problems using congruence and similarity, you are ready to solve some real-world problems!

name: Special right triangles  (Trigonometry)
blurb: We hate to pick favorites, but there really are certain right triangles that are more special than others.  In this tutorial, we pick them out, show why they're special, and prove it!  These include 30-60-90 and 45-45-90 triangles (the numbers refer to the measure of the angles in the triangle).

name: Introduction to the trigonometric ratios (Trigonometry)
blurb: Learn what sine, cosine, and tangent are.

name: Solving for a side in a right triangle using the trigonometric ratios (Trigonometry)
blurb: Learn how to find a side length in a right triangle when given one side length and one acute angle.

name: Solving for an angle in a right triangle using the trigonometric ratios (Trigonometry)
blurb: Learn how to find an acute angle in a right triangle when given two side lengths.

name: Modeling with right triangles (Trigonometry)
blurb: Solve real-world problems that can be modeled by right triangles, using trigonometry.

name: Trigonometric ratios and similarity (Trigonometry)
blurb: Learn how the trigonometric ratios are derived from triangle similarity considerations.

name: Sine and cosine of complementary angles (Trigonometry)
blurb: Learn about the relationship between the sine of an angle and the cosine of its complementary angle, which is the angle that completes to 90°.

name: The reciprocal trigonometric ratios (Trigonometry)
blurb: Learn about the remaining three side ratios in a right triangle: the secant, the cosecant, and the cotangent.

name: The law of sines (Trigonometry)
blurb: Learn about the Law of sines and how to use it in order to find missing side lengths and angles in general triangles.

name: Copy of The law of cosines (Trigonometry)
blurb: Learn about the Law of cosines and how to use it in order to find missing side lengths and angles in general triangles.

name: Solving general triangles (Trigonometry)
blurb: Use the power of trigonometry in order to solve various problems that involve triangles.

name: Circles basics (Circles)
blurb: Make sure you're familiar with notation and key terms like radius, diameter, circumference, pi, tangent, secant, and major/minor arcs before you dive into the rest of the circles content.

name: Arc measures (Circles)
blurb: Arc measure is equal to the arc's central angle. We'll explore this fact and solve some problems related to it.

name: Arc length (degrees) (Circles)
blurb: Think about the relationship between central angle and arc length. This tutorial uses degrees not radians.

name: Introduction to radians (Circles)
blurb: Most people know that you can measure angles with degrees, but only exceptionally worldly people know that radians can be an exciting alternative. As you'll see, degrees are somewhat arbitrary.

name: Arc length (radians) (Circles)
blurb: Think about the relationships between arc measures, central angles, and arc length in radians.

name: Sectors (Circles)
blurb: Learn how to find the area of a sector.

name: Inscribed angles (Circles)
blurb: We'll now dig a bit deeper in our understanding of circles by looking at inscribed angles and related properties.

name: Inscribed shapes problem solving (Circles)
blurb: Use properties of inscribed angles to prove properties of inscribed shapes, then apply these properties to some fun problem solving!

name: Properties of tangents (Circles)
blurb: Explore, prove, and apply properties of circles that involve tangents.

name: Area of inscribed triangle (Circles)
blurb: This more advanced (and very optional) tutorial is fun to look at for enrichment.  It builds to figuring out the formula for the area of a triangle inscribed in a circle!

name: Standard equation of a circle (Circles)
blurb: Learn about the standard form to represent a circle with an equation. For example, the equation (x-1)^2+(y+2)^2=9 is a circle whose center is (1,-2) and radius is 3.

name: Expanded equation of a circle (Circles)
blurb: Learn how to analyze an equation of a circle that is not given in the standard form. For example, find the center of the circle whose equation is x^2+y^2+4x-5=0.

name: Distance and midpoints (Analytic geometry)
blurb: Find the distance between two points or the midpoint of two points.

name: Distances between points (Analytic geometry)
blurb: Think about ratios of lengths of segments between points.

name: Problem solving with distance on the coordinate plane (Analytic geometry)
blurb: Use what you know about distance to solve problems on the coordinate plan like finding the perimeter of a shape or determining if a point is on a circle.

name: Parallel and perpendicular lines on the coordinate plane (Analytic geometry)
blurb: You probably know what parallel and perpendicular lines are. In this tutorial, you will learn how these relationships are expressed on the coordinate plane (spoiler: parallel lines have the same slope, and the product of the slopes of perpendicular lines is always -1).

name: Equations of parallel and perpendicular lines (Analytic geometry)
blurb: Learn all about equations of parallel and perpendicular

name: Challenge: Distance between a point and a line (Analytic geometry)
blurb: An optional tutorial where you'll figure out the minimum distance from a point to a given line.

name: Constructing bisectors of lines and angles (Geometric constructions)
blurb: With just a compass and a straightedge  (or virtual versions of them), you'll be amazed by how many geometric shapes you can construct perfectly.  This tutorial gets you started with the building block of how to bisect angle and lines (and how to construct perpendicular bisectors of lines).

name: Constructing regular polygons (Geometric constructions)
blurb: Have you ever wondered how people would draw a square, equilateral triangle or even hexagon before there were computers?  Well, now you're going to do just that (ironically, with a computer).  Using our virtual compass and straightedge, you'll construct several regular shapes (by inscribing them inside circles).

name: Constructing circumcircles and incircles (Geometric constructions)
blurb: In our study of triangles, we spent a decent amount of time think about incenters (the intersections of the angle bisectors) and circumcenters (the intersections of the perpendicular bisectors).  We'll now leverage this knowledge to actually construct circle inscribed and circumscribed about a triangle using only a compass and straightedge (actually virtual versions of them).

name: Constructing a line tangent to a circle (Geometric constructions)
blurb: Learn how to construct tangents to circles with certain conditions using compass and straightedge. For example, draw the tangent to a given circle that passes through a given point.

name: Worked examples: geometry (Miscellaneous)
blurb: Sal does the 80 problems from the released questions from the California Standards Test for Geometry.  Basic understanding of Algebra I necessary.

name: Limits introduction (Limits and continuity)
blurb: A limit is the value that a function or sequence "approaches" as the input or index approaches some value. In this tutorial, we supply an intuitive understanding of limits.

name: Limits from tables (Limits and continuity)
blurb: Find limits by creating a table of values and analyzing the trend.

name: Limits from graphs (Limits and continuity)
blurb: Find limits by analyzing graphs.

name: One-sided limits (Limits and continuity)
blurb: Learn what one-sided limits are and analyze them via graphs.

name: Formal definition of limits (epsilon-delta) (Limits and continuity)
blurb: Now that you have an intuitive understanding of limits, let's do what mathematicians do best and define them rigorously! This definition may be hard to grasp at first, but its beauty will get you in the end.

name: Review: Limits basics (Limits and continuity)
blurb: Review your understanding of the basics of limits with some challenge problems.

name: Continuity at a point (Limits and continuity)
blurb: A function is continuous at a point if its limit at that point exists and is equal to the actual function's value at that point.

name: Limits of combined and composite functions (Limits and continuity)
blurb: Practice your basic understanding of limits and continuity with more complex cases.

name: Continuous functions (Limits and continuity)
blurb: Continuous functions are continuous at all of the points in their domains. In essence, these are functions whose graphs can be drawn with a single brush stroke.

name: Intermediate value theorem (Limits and continuity)
blurb: The intermediate value theorem states that if a continuous function, f, with an interval, [a, b], as its domain, takes values f(a) and f(b) at each end of the interval, then it also takes any value between f(a) and f(b) at some point within the interval. This is a basic but important property of all continuous functions.

name: Review: Continuity (Limits and continuity)
blurb: Review your understanding of continuity with some challenge problems.

name: Limits from equations (direct substitution) (Limits and continuity)
blurb: Take your first steps in finding limits algebraically. For example, find the limit of x²+5x at x=2, or determine whether the limit of 2x/(x+1) at x=-1 exists.

name: Limits from equations (factoring & rationalizing) (Limits and continuity)
blurb: There are some limits that want us to work a little before we find them. Learn about two main methods of dealing with such limits: factorization and rationalization. For example, find the limit of (x²-1)/(x-1) at x=1.

name: Squeeze theorem (Limits and continuity)
blurb: The Squeeze theorem (or Sandwich theorem) states that for any three functions f, g, and h, if f(x)≤g(x)≤h(x) for all x-values on an interval except for a single value x=a, and the limits of f and h at x=a are equal to L, then the limit of g at x=a must be equal to L as well. This may seem simple but it's pure genius. Learn how it helps us find tricky limits like sin(x)/x at x=0.

name: Limits of trigonometric functions (Limits and continuity)
blurb: Find limits of trigonometric functions by manipulating the functions (using trigonometric identities) into expressions that are nicer to handle. For example, find the limit of sin(x)/sin(2x) at x=0.

name: Limits of piecewise functions (Limits and continuity)
blurb: Remember one-sided limits? Well, these are very useful when dealing with piecewise functions. For example, analyze the limit at x=2 of the function that gives (x-2)² for values lower than 2 and 2-x² for values lager than 2.

name: Removable discontinuities (Limits and continuity)
blurb: Removable discontinuities are points where a function isn't continuous but can become continuous with a small adjustment. Analyze such points and determine what adjustments should be made to "remove" them.

name: Review: Limits from equations (Limits and continuity)
blurb: Review your limit-evaluation skills with some challenge problems.

name: Unbounded limits (vertical asymptotes) (Limits and continuity)
blurb: Some limits don't approach a specific value, but instead become boundlessly large as they approach the limiting value. For example, the limit of 1/x as we approach x=0 from the right. Learn about this type of limits and how it relates to vertical asymptotes.

name: Limits at infinity (horizontal asymptotes) (Limits and continuity)
blurb: For some expressions, as we increase x infinitely, approach a finite value. For example, 1/x approaches 0 as x becomes infinitely large. Learn about these types of limits, and how they relate to horizontal asymptotes.

name: Review: Infinite limits (Limits and continuity)
blurb: Review your understanding of infinite limits with some challenge problems.

name: Introduction to differential calculus (Taking derivatives)
blurb: What's differential calculus all about? An answer to this question lies just right here.

name: Derivative as slope of tangent line (Taking derivatives)
blurb: One way of thinking about the derivative (of a function at a point) is as the slope of the tangent line (to the function's graph at that point). Get comfortable with this approach here.

name: Derivative as instantaneous rate of change (Taking derivatives)
blurb: One way of thinking about the derivative is as instantaneous rate of change. This is quite incredible because rate of change is usually found over a period of time, and not at an instant. Get comfortable with this approach here.

name: Secant lines (Taking derivatives)
blurb: Gain some experience working with secant lines. This will help us on our journey to find a formal definition for the derivative.

name: Derivative as a limit (Taking derivatives)
blurb: The derivative is actually a special kind of limit! This is yet another important stop on our continuing journey towards a formal definition of the derivative.

name: Formal definition of derivative (Taking derivatives)
blurb: There are two ways to define the derivative of function f at point x=a. The formal definition is the limit of [f(a+h)-f(x)]/h as h approaches 0, and the alternative definition is the limit of [f(x)-f(a)]/(x-a) as x approaches a. Make introduction with these two definitions.

name: Using the formal definition of derivative (Taking derivatives)
blurb: Learn how we can use their formal definition in order to find the derivatives of specific functions. For example, we find the derivative of f(x)=x² at x=3, or for any x-value.

name: Differentiability (Taking derivatives)
blurb: The derivative of a function isn't necessarily defined at every point. Learn about the conditions for the derivative to exist, and specifically about how continuity fits with this story (spoiler: for a function to be differentiable at a point it must be continuous at that point, but the other way isn't necessary).

name: Derivative as a function (Taking derivatives)
blurb: This may blow your mind, but the derivative of a function is a function in itself! Get comfortable in thinking about the derivative as a function that is separate from, but tightly related to, its original function.

name: Review: Derivative basics (Taking derivatives)
blurb: Review your conceptual understanding of derivatives with some challenge problems.

name: Basic differentiation rules (Taking derivatives)
blurb: If you ever tried to find derivatives using their formal definition, you probably know how tedious that may be. Fortunately, we have ways for finding derivatives much quicker, using differentiation rules! Make your first steps in this fascinating world by working with the more basic rules. For example, the derivative of [f(x)+g(x)] is f'(x)+g'(x), and the derivative of k⋅f(x) is k⋅f'(x).

name: Power rule (Taking derivatives)
blurb: The power rule says that the derivative of xⁿ is n⋅xⁿ⁻¹. It allows us to quickly find the derivative of any polynomial, and it doesn't even stop there! Make introduction with this simple but powerful rule.

name: Polynomial functions differentiation (Taking derivatives)
blurb: Put the power rule to use by differentiating various polynomials.

name: Rational functions differentiation (intro) (Taking derivatives)
blurb: Learn how the power rule can be used to differentiate some basic rational functions.

name: Radical functions differentiation (intro) (Taking derivatives)
blurb: Learn how the power rule can be used to differentiate some basic radical functions.

name: Sine & cosine derivatives (Taking derivatives)
blurb: The derivative of sin(x) is cos(x) and the derivative of cos(x) is -sin(x). How convenient! Practice differentiating functions that include sine and cosine.

name: eˣ and ln(x) derivatives (Taking derivatives)
blurb: The derivative of eˣ is eˣ. That's pretty amazing. The derivative of ln(x) is 1/x, which is just as surprising.

name: Review: Basic differentiation (Taking derivatives)
blurb: Review your understanding of basic differentiation rules and your knowledge of the derivatives of common functions with some challenge problems.

name: Product rule (Taking derivatives)
blurb: The product rule says that the derivative of the product f(x)g(x) is f'(x)g(x)+f(x)g'(x). This helps us find the derivative of a function which is a product of two other, more basic, functions.

name: Chain rule (Taking derivatives)
blurb: The chain rule says that the derivative of the composite function f(g(x)) is f'(g(x))⋅g'(x). This helps us find the derivative of a composite function. It may be slightly hard to grasp, but its importance cannot be overstated!

name: Chain rule proof (Taking derivatives)
blurb: Go "behind the scenes" with Sal and learn how the chain rule is proved.

name: Quotient rule (Taking derivatives)
blurb: The quotient rule says that the derivative of the quotient f(x)/g(x) is [f'(x)g(x)-f(x)g'(x)]/g²(x). This helps us find the derivative of a function which is a quotient of two other, more basic, functions.

name: Review: Product, quotient, & chain rule (Taking derivatives)
blurb: Review your understanding of the product, quotient, and chain rules with some challenge problems.

name: Rational functions differentiation (Taking derivatives)
blurb: Solve problems involving the derivatives of rational functions. For example, find f'(1) of f(x)=(x+2)/(x-3).

name: Radical functions differentiation (Taking derivatives)
blurb: Solve problems involving the derivatives of radical functions. For example, find g'(5) of g(x)=∛(x²+5x-3).

name: Trigonometric functions differentiation (Taking derivatives)
blurb: Solve problems involving the derivatives of trigonometric functions. For example, find h'(π) of h(x)=sin(x²-4x+1).

name: Exponential functions differentiation (Taking derivatives)
blurb: Solve problems involving the derivatives of exponential functions. For example, find f'(1) of f(x)=2^(x²+x+5).

name: Logarithmic functions differentiation (Taking derivatives)
blurb: Solve problems involving the derivatives of logarithmic functions. For example, find g'(4) of g(x)=log(x²-1).

name: Derivatives capstone (Taking derivatives)
blurb: Review your function differentiation skills with some challenge problems.

name: Implicit differentiation introduction (Taking derivatives)
blurb: Some two-variable relationships cannot be turned into a function, like the circle equation x²+y²=4. Implicit differentiation allows us to find the derivative of y with respect to x, even in such equations.

name: Implicit differentiation (advanced examples) (Taking derivatives)
blurb: Tackle some more advanced problems of implicit differentiation. For example, find dy/dx for e^(xy²)=x-y.

name: Inverse trig functions differentiation (Taking derivatives)
blurb: Implicit differentiation allows us to find the derivatives of arcsin(x), arccos(x), and arctan(x).

name: Derivatives of inverse functions (Taking derivatives)
blurb: Implicit differentiation provides us with the relationship between the derivatives of inverse functions: if f and g are inverse functions, then f’(x)=1/(g’(f(x)). Get comfortable working with this relationship.

name: Disguised derivatives (Taking derivatives)
blurb: Equipped with knowledge about the derivatives of all common functions, evaluate some limits that represent various derivatives.

name: Proofs for the derivatives of eˣ and ln(x) (Taking derivatives)
blurb: The derivatives of eˣ and ln(x) may be simple, but proving them is a different story. Learn all about it here.

name: Logarithmic differentiation (Taking derivatives)
blurb: In logarithmic differentiation, we find the derivative of the natural log of a function instead of the derivative of the function itself. It may surprise you, but this can sometimes actually be easier than regular differentiation, if not the only available option. For example, finding the derivative of xˣ.

name: Parametric & vector-valued function differentiation (Taking derivatives)
blurb: Parametric and vector-valued functions basically take one input and return two outputs. How do we differentiate such functions? Find out here.

name: Review: Advanced differentiation (Taking derivatives)
blurb: Review your knowledge of the advanced differentiation topics with some challenge problems.

name: Higher-order derivatives (Taking derivatives)
blurb: The derivative is a function, and as such it has its own derivative! The same goes for the derivative of the derivative, and so forth. These are all called higher-order derivatives.

name: Higher-order derivatives (parametric & vector-valued functions) (Taking derivatives)
blurb: Learn how to find the second derivatives (and any higher-order derivative) of parametric and vector-valued functions.

name: Polar curve differentiation (Taking derivatives)
blurb: Find tangents to polar curves.

name: Critical points (Derivative applications)
blurb: Critical points are points where a function may obtain their minimum or maximum value. They play a critical role (pun intended) in analyzing the increasing and decreasing intervals of functions, and in finding their minimum and maximum points.

name: Increasing & decreasing intervals (Derivative applications)
blurb: Analyze functions to find the intervals in which they are increasing or decreasing.

name: Relative minima & maxima (Derivative applications)
blurb: Analyze functions to find their relative extrema (i.e. their relative minimum and maximum points).

name: Absolute minima & maxima (Derivative applications)
blurb: Analyze functions to find their absolute extrema (i.e. their absolute minimum and maximum points).

name: Review: Increasing/decreasing intervals & extrema (Derivative applications)
blurb: Review your understanding of increasing and decreasing intervals, and extremum points, with some challenge problems.

name: Concavity (Derivative applications)
blurb: Concavity describes the shape of a graph as it increases or decreases: a graph that's concave up is shaped like a cup, U, and a graph that's concave down is shaped like a cap, ∩. Learn more about concavity and how it relates to a function's second derivative.

name: Points of inflection (Derivative applications)
blurb: Points of inflection are points where the function changes concavity. Learn how to find and analyze them.

name: Sketching graphs using calculus (Derivative applications)
blurb: Combine the tools provided by differential calculus with other algebraic tools in order to obtain detailed sketches of various functions.

name: Review: Concavity & points of inflection (Derivative applications)
blurb: Review your understanding of concavity and points of inflections with some challenge problems.

name: Linear approximation (Derivative applications)
blurb: The method of linear approximation (also called local linearization) allows us to approximate a function at hairy x-values using the line tangent to the function's graph at strategic points.

name: Rectilinear motion (diff calc) (Derivative applications)
blurb: Solve problems about motion along a line using the power of differential calculus. For example, given the position of a particle as a function of time s(t), find the particle's maximum velocity.

name: Planar motion (diff calc) (Derivative applications)
blurb: Solve problems about motion on a 2-dimensional plane using the power of differential calculus. For example, given the (x,y) position of a particle as a function of time (x(t),y(t)), find the particle's position when its acceleration is 0.

name: Related rates (Derivative applications)
blurb: Solve geometrical and real-world problems that concern multiple quantities that change at different, but related, rates. For example, given the rate of change of a circle's radius, find the rate of change of the circle's area.

name: Optimization (Derivative applications)
blurb: Solve geometrical and real-world problems that involve finding the maximum (or minimum) possible value of a quantity. For example, find the maximum area of a rectangle whose perimeter is given.

name: Applied rates of change (Derivative applications)
blurb: Solve various rate of change problems where a real-world situation is modeled by an algebraic function.

name: Mean value theorem (Derivative applications)
blurb: The mean value theorem states that if a function f is continuous on the closed interval [a,b] and differentiable on the open interval (a,b), then there exists a point c in (a,b) such that f'(c) is equal to the function's average rate of change over [a,b].

name: L'Hôpital's rule (Derivative applications)
blurb: L'Hôpital's rule provides us with an easy, almost magical way of finding indeterminate limits of quotients of functions using the functions' derivatives. In short, the rule says that if the limits of functions f and g at x=a are 0 (or ထ) and the limit of f'(x)/g'(x) at x=a is equal to L, then the limit of f(x)/g(x) at x=a is also equal to L.

name: Review: Derivative applications (Derivative applications)
blurb: Review your understanding of the various applications of differential calculus with some challenge problems.

name: Antiderivatives (Integration)
blurb: If f' is the derivative of f, then f is the antiderivative of f'. To find the antiderivative of a function we need to perform some kind of reverse differentiation. Learn about it here.

name: Indefinite integrals intro (Integration)
blurb: Indefinite integrals are the way integral calculus deals with antiderivatives. Gain some practice in finding various indefinite integrals.

name: Indefinite integrals of common functions (Integration)
blurb: Indefinite integrals (or antiderivatives) are really just backward differentiation. Therefore, the indefinite integral of eˣ is eˣ+c, the indefinite integral of 1/x is ln(x)+c, the indefinite integral of sin(x) is -cos(x)+c, and the indefinite integral of cos(x) is sin(x)+c.

name: Review: Indefinite integrals & antiderivatives (Integration)
blurb: Review your understanding of indefinite integrals and antiderivatives with some challenge problems.

name: Definite integral as area (Integration)
blurb: Introducing the definite integral. It's basically a way to represent the area under a given curve with left-hand and right-hand bounds.

name: Definite integral properties (Integration)
blurb: Definite integrals behave in specific ways with shared properties. For example, the sum of the definite integrals of a function f from a to b and from b to c is equal to the definite integral of f from a to c. Learn about these properties and use them in order to evaluate integrals.

name: Review: Definite integral basics (Integration)
blurb: Review your understanding of the basics of definite integrals with some challenge problems.

name: Riemann sums (Integration)
blurb: Riemann sums is the name of a family of methods we can use to approximate the area under a curve. Learn about the different ways and how they are constructed.

name: Riemann sums with sigma notation (Integration)
blurb: The larger the number of terms in a Riemann sum, the more accurate it is. But as the number of terms increases, we need better ways to write them down. This is where sigma notation comes in very handy.

name: Trapezoidal rule (Integration)
blurb: The trapezoidal rule is yet another way to approximate the area under a curve. Learn about they way it's constructed and how accurate it is comparing the rectangular Riemann sums.

name: Definite integral as the limit of a Riemann sum (Integration)
blurb: The definite integral of a function is the limit of a sequence of Riemann sums where the intervals become infinitely small. Learn more about this formal definition.

name: Review: Riemann sums (Integration)
blurb: Review your understanding of Riemann sums with some challenge problems.

name: Functions defined by integrals (Integration)
blurb: Get comfortable with functions that for any input x, return the area under a curve between a given bound and x. This is an important stop on our journey to relating differential and integral calculus.

name: Fundamental theorem of calculus (Integration)
blurb: The fundamental theorem of calculus is definitely one of the most important theorems of all time! It relates differential calculus and the concept of the derivative with integral calculus and the concept of the integral. Learn all about it here!

name: Fundamental theorem of calculus: chain rule (Integration)
blurb: Get better acquainted with the fundamental theorem of calculus, and apply it for a class of seemingly hairy problems.

name: Definite integral evaluation (Integration)
blurb: The fundamental theorem tells us how we can evaluate definite integrals. Now let us  put this to use and evaluate some!

name: Definite integrals of piecewise functions (Integration)
blurb: Evaluate definite integrals of piecewise functions. This is where the definite integral properties come into good use.

name: Improper integrals (Integration)
blurb: Improper integrals are like definite integrals, only unbounded from the left and/or right. And yes, some of them have finite values. An unbounded area with a finite size? That's calculus to you!

name: Integration by parts (Integration techniques)
blurb: Learn how to use the product rule in order to find the integral of a product of functions (sadly this is more complicated than using the product rule the regular way).

name: u-substitution (Integration techniques)
blurb: u-substitution is an extremely useful technique. Harnessing the power of the chain rule, it allows us to define a new variable (common denoted by the letter u) as a function of x, and obtain a new expression which is (hopefully) easier to integrate.

name: Reverse chain rule (Integration techniques)
blurb: Reverse chain rule is another, faster way to think about u-substitution.

name: Partial fraction expansion (Integration techniques)
blurb: Learn a useful algebraic tool to find the integrals of some rational functions.

name: Integration using trigonometric identities (Integration techniques)
blurb: Some integrals that contain trig functions demand that we manipulate those functions using trig identities in order to find the integral.

name: Trigonometric substitution (Integration techniques)
blurb: Another super useful technique for computing integrals involves replacing variables with trigonometric functions. This can make things seem a little more complicated at first, but with the help of trigonometric identities, this technique makes certain integrals solvable.

name: Area between curves (Integration applications)
blurb: By integrating the difference of two functions, you can find the area between them.

name: Area defined by polar graphs (Integration applications)
blurb: We're used to finding the area under curves in the Cartesian plane, but integration can be used to find area defined by polar curves too.

name: Arc length (Integration applications)
blurb: Integral calculus isn't only useful for finding area. For example, it can also be used to find lengths of one-dimensional curves. Learn all about it here.

name: Arc length of polar graphs (Integration applications)
