blurb: You may already be familiar with finding arc length of graphs that are defined in terms of rectangular coordinates. We'll now extend our knowledge of arc length to include polar graphs.

name: Average value of a function (Integration applications)
blurb: We usually calculate the average of N terms by summing them up and dividing by N. How do you find the average of infinitely many terms? For example, the average of a function f(x) for all x-values between 0 and 1? Integral calculus to the rescue!

name: Area & net change (Integration applications)
blurb: The area under a rate function gives the net change. This result of the fundamental theorem of calculus is being put here to use with some real-world problems.

name: Rectilinear motion (integral calc) (Integration applications)
blurb: Solve problems about motion along a line using the power of integral calculus. For example, given the velocity of a particle as a function of time v(t), find how much the particle has traveled over a given time period.

name: Solids with known cross sections (Integration applications)
blurb: Let's leverage the definite integral to find volumes of figures where we know what their cross sections look like. It is surprisingly fun.

name: Disc method (Integration applications)
blurb: You know how to use definite integrals to find areas under curves. We now take that idea for "spin" by thinking about the volumes of things created when you rotate functions around various lines.

name: Washer method (Integration applications)
blurb: Washer method is an extension of the disc method for finding the volumes of more elaborate solids of revolution.

name: Shell method (Integration applications)
blurb: Shell method offers us another way of calculating the volume of solids of revolution. Some solids are more easily found with the shell method.

name: Sequences (Series)
blurb: In this tutorial, we'll review what sequences are, their associated notation, and formulas of sequences.

name: Sequence convergence and divergence (Series)
blurb: Now that we understand what a sequence is, we're going to think about what happens to the terms of a sequence at infinity (do they approach 0, a finite value, or +- infinity?).

name: Series review (Series)
blurb: You're familiar with sequences and have been eager to sum them up.  Well wait no longer!  In this tutorial, we'll see that series are just sums of sequences and familiarize ourselves with the notation.

name: Finite geometric series (Series)
blurb: A finite geometric series is the sum of the first few terms of a geometric sequence. It turns out there's a quick way of finding such a sum, without having to really sum all the terms one-by-one.

name: Partial sums (Series)
blurb: Partial sums are another way to think of finite series. Why partial? Because they are a part of an infinite series! Thinking of the partial sums of an infinite series helps us analyze the infinite series itself.

name: Geometric series (Series)
blurb: This might seem unbelievable at first, but for a certain class of geometric sequences, we can take the sum of all the infinite terms in the sequence and end up with a finite number! This sum is called an infinite geometric series. Learn when and how it can be found.

name: Series basics challenge (Series)
blurb: Learn how to find the value of some special classes of series. This material is relatively advanced and isn't included in the AP Calculus course.

name: Basic convergence tests (Series)
blurb: How can we tell whether a series converges or diverges? There is an impressive repository of tools that can help us with this question. In this tutorial, we will cover the basic tests: n-th term test, integral test, and p-series test. These tests can help us later on with the more elaborate convergence tests.

name: Comparison tests (Series)
blurb: If the sum of a series must be smaller than the sum of another series that converges, then that series must converge as well. Makes sense, no? This notion, and similar ones, are at the basis of the comparison convergence tests.

name: Ratio & alternating series tests (Series)
blurb: The ratio test is one of the most useful tests for series convergence. Alternating series are a special class of series that have their own, very useful test for convergence.

name: Estimating infinite series (Series)
blurb: We've spent a lot of time thinking about whether a series converges or diverges.  But, even if we can determine that a series converges, how can we figure out what it converges to?  This tutorial will show techniques of estimating what a series converges to, and for determining how good our estimates are.  This is super useful because most series can't be precisely evaluated (like we were able to do with infinite geometric series).

name: Power series intro (Series)
blurb: Power series is a sum of terms of the general form aₙ(x-a)ⁿ. As you can see, it's actually a function whose sum depends on the x-value. It is a generalization of geometric series, and an extremely useful class of series. Learn more about it in this tutorial.

name: Taylor & Maclaurin polynomials intro (Series)
blurb: Taylor polynomials are a very clever way of approximating any function with a polynomial. Maclaurin polynomials are a special class of Taylor polynomials. Learn how these polynomials work in this tutorial.

name: Maclaurin series of sin(x), cos(x), and eˣ (Series)
blurb: A Maclaurin series is essentially a Maclaurin polynomial with infinite terms. It turns out that the Maclaurin series of sin(x), cos(x), and eˣ return the exact same values as the functions themselves, for any x-value. Wow! Introduce yourselves to these special series and discover one of the most fascinating areas of all of mathematics!

name: Power series function representation using algebra (Series)
blurb: We already saw how Taylor and Maclaurin series can be used to represent a variety of functions. In this tutorial, we will expand the scope of functions that we can represent with power series, by enriching our toolkit!

name: Challenge series exercises (Series)
blurb: Review you knowledge about series with some challenging exercises.

name: AP Calculus AB questions (AP Calculus practice questions)
blurb: Many of you are planning on taking the Calculus AB advanced placement exam.  These are example problems taken directly from previous years' exams. Even if you aren't taking the exam, these are very useful problem for making sure you understand your calculus (as always, best to pause the videos and try them yourself before Sal does).

name: AP Calculus BC questions (AP Calculus practice questions)
blurb: The Calculus BC AP exam is a super set of the AB exam.  It covers everything in AB as well as some of the more advanced topics in integration, sequences and function approximation.  This tutorial is great practice for anyone looking to test their calculus mettle!

name: Limits introduction (Limits basics)
blurb: A limit is the value that a function or sequence "approaches" as the input or index approaches some value. In this tutorial, we supply an intuitive understanding of limits.

name: One-sided limits (Limits basics)
blurb: Learn one-sided and two-sided limits. Investigate the relationship between a two-sided limit at a point and the one-sided limits at that point (spoiler: the two-sided limits exists if and only if the one-sided limits exist and are equal).

name: Formal definition of limits (epsilon-delta) (Limits basics)
blurb: Now that you have an intuitive understanding of limits, let's do what mathematicians do best and define them rigorously! This definition may be hard to grasp at first, but its beauty will get you in the end.

name: Review: Limits basics (Limits basics)
blurb: Review your understanding of the basics of limits with some challenge problems.

name: Continuity at a point (Continuity)
blurb: A function is continuous at a point if its limit at that point exists and is equal to the actual function's value at that point.

name: Limits of combined & composite functions (Continuity)
blurb: Practice your basic understanding of limits and continuity with more complex cases.

name: Continuous functions (Continuity)
blurb: Continuous functions are continuous at all of the points in their domains. In essence, these are functions whose graphs can be drawn with a single brush stroke.

name: Intermediate value theorem (Continuity)
blurb: The intermediate value theorem states that if a continuous function, f, with an interval, [a, b], as its domain, takes values f(a) and f(b) at each end of the interval, then it also takes any value between f(a) and f(b) at some point within the interval. This is a basic but important property of all continuous functions.

name: Review: Continuity (Continuity)
blurb: Review your understanding of continuity with some challenge problems.

name: Limits from equations (direct substitution) (Limits from equations)
blurb: Take your first steps in finding limits algebraically. For example, find the limit of x²+5x at x=2, or determine whether the limit of 2x/(x+1) at x=-1 exists.

name: Limits from equations (factoring & rationalizing) (Limits from equations)
blurb: There are some limits that want us to work a little before we find them. Learn about two main methods of dealing with such limits: factorization and rationalization. For example, find the limit of (x²-1)/(x-1) at x=1.

name: Squeeze theorem (Limits from equations)
blurb: The Squeeze theorem (or Sandwich theorem) states that for any three functions f, g, and h, if f(x)≤g(x)≤h(x) for all x-values on an interval except for a single value x=a, and the limits of f and h at x=a are equal to L, then the limit of g at x=a must be equal to L as well. This may seem simple but it's pure genius. Learn how it helps us find tricky limits like sin(x)/x at x=0.

name: Limits of trigonometric functions (Limits from equations)
blurb: Find limits of trigonometric functions by manipulating the functions (using trigonometric identities) into expressions that are nicer to handle. For example, find the limit of sin(x)/sin(2x) at x=0.

name: Limits of piecewise functions (Limits from equations)
blurb: Remember one-sided limits? Well, these are very useful when dealing with piecewise functions. For example, analyze the limit at x=2 of the function that gives (x-2)² for values lower than 2 and 2-x² for values lager than 2.

name: Removable discontinuities (Limits from equations)
blurb: Removable discontinuities are points where a function isn't continuous but can become continuous with a small adjustment. Analyze such points and determine what adjustments should be made to "remove" them.

name: Review: Limits from equations (Limits from equations)
blurb: Review your limit-evaluation skills with some challenge problems.

name: Unbounded limits (vertical asymptotes) (Infinite limits)
blurb: Some limits don't approach a specific value, but instead become boundlessly large as they approach the limiting value. For example, the limit of 1/x as we approach x=0 from the right. Learn about this type of limits and how it relates to vertical asymptotes.

name: Limits at infinity (horizontal asymptotes) (Infinite limits)
blurb: For some expressions, as we increase x infinitely, approach a finite value. For example, 1/x approaches 0 as x becomes infinitely large. Learn about these types of limits, and how they relate to horizontal asymptotes.

name: Review: Infinite limits (Infinite limits)
blurb: Review your understanding of infinite limits with some challenge problems.

name: Introduction to differential calculus (Derivative introduction)
blurb: What's differential calculus all about? An answer to this question lies just right here.

name: Derivative as slope of tangent line (Derivative introduction)
blurb: One way of thinking about the derivative (of a function at a point) is as the slope of the tangent line (to the function's graph at that point). Get comfortable with this approach here.

name: Derivative as instantaneous rate of change (Derivative introduction)
blurb: One way of thinking about the derivative is as instantaneous rate of change. This is quite incredible because rate of change is usually found over a period of time, and not at an instant. Get comfortable with this approach here.

name: Secant lines (Derivative introduction)
blurb: Gain some experience working with secant lines. This will help us on our journey to find a formal definition for the derivative.

name: Derivative as a limit (Derivative introduction)
blurb: The derivative is actually a special kind of limit! This is yet another important stop on our continuing journey towards a formal definition of the derivative.

name: Formal definition of derivative (Derivative introduction)
blurb: There are two ways to define the derivative of function f at point x=a. The formal definition is the limit of [f(a+h)-f(x)]/h as h approaches 0, and the alternative definition is the limit of [f(x)-f(a)]/(x-a) as x approaches a. Make introduction with these two definitions.

name: Using the formal definition of derivative (Derivative introduction)
blurb: Learn how we can use their formal definition in order to find the derivatives of specific functions. For example, we find the derivative of f(x)=x² at x=3, or for any x-value.

name: Differentiability (Derivative introduction)
blurb: The derivative of a function isn't necessarily defined at every point. Learn about the conditions for the derivative to exist, and specifically about how continuity fits with this story (spoiler: for a function to be differentiable at a point it must be continuous at that point, but the other way isn't necessary).

name: Derivative as a function (Derivative introduction)
blurb: This may blow your mind, but the derivative of a function is a function in itself! Get comfortable in thinking about the derivative as a function that is separate from, but tightly related to, its original function.

name: Review: Derivative basics (Derivative introduction)
blurb: Review your conceptual understanding of derivatives with some challenge problems.

name: Basic differentiation rules (Basic differentiation)
blurb: If you ever tried to find derivatives using their formal definition, you probably know how tedious that may be. Fortunately, we have ways for finding derivatives much quicker, using differentiation rules! Make your first steps in this fascinating world by working with the more basic rules. For example, the derivative of [f(x)+g(x)] is f'(x)+g'(x), and the derivative of k⋅f(x) is k⋅f'(x).

name: Power rule (Basic differentiation)
blurb: The power rule says that the derivative of xⁿ is n⋅xⁿ⁻¹. It allows us to quickly find the derivative of any polynomial, and it doesn't even stop there! Make introduction with this simple but powerful rule.

name: Polynomial functions differentiation (Basic differentiation)
blurb: Put the power rule to use by differentiating various polynomials.

name: Rational functions differentiation (intro) (Basic differentiation)
blurb: Learn how the power rule can be used to differentiate some basic rational functions.

name: Radical functions differentiation (intro) (Basic differentiation)
blurb: Learn how the power rule can be used to differentiate some basic radical functions.

name: Sine & cosine derivatives (Basic differentiation)
blurb: The derivative of sin(x) is cos(x) and the derivative of cos(x) is -sin(x). How convenient! Practice differentiating functions that include sine and cosine.

name: eˣ and ln(x) derivatives (Basic differentiation)
blurb: The derivative of eˣ is eˣ. That's pretty amazing. The derivative of ln(x) is 1/x, which is just as surprising.

name: Review: Basic differentiation (Basic differentiation)
blurb: Review your understanding of basic differentiation rules and your knowledge of the derivatives of common functions with some challenge problems.

name: Product rule (Product, quotient, & chain rules)
blurb: The product rule says that the derivative of the product f(x)g(x) is f'(x)g(x)+f(x)g'(x). This helps us find the derivative of a function which is a product of two other, more basic, functions.

name: Chain rule (Product, quotient, & chain rules)
blurb: The chain rule says that the derivative of the composite function f(g(x)) is f'(g(x))⋅g'(x). This helps us find the derivative of a composite function. It may be slightly hard to grasp, but its importance cannot be overstated!

name: Chain rule proof (Product, quotient, & chain rules)
blurb: Go "behind the scenes" with Sal and learn how the chain rule is proved.

name: Quotient rule (Product, quotient, & chain rules)
blurb: The quotient rule says that the derivative of the quotient f(x)/g(x) is [f'(x)g(x)-f(x)g'(x)]/g²(x). This helps us find the derivative of a function which is a quotient of two other, more basic, functions.

name: Review: Product, quotient, & chain rule (Product, quotient, & chain rules)
blurb: Review your understanding of the product, quotient, and chain rules with some challenge problems.

name: Rational functions differentiation (Differentiating common functions)
blurb: Solve problems involving the derivatives of rational functions. For example, find f'(1) of f(x)=(x+2)/(x-3).

name: Radical functions differentiation (Differentiating common functions)
blurb: Solve problems involving the derivatives of radical functions. For example, find g'(5) of g(x)=∛(x²+5x-3).

name: Trigonometric functions differentiation (Differentiating common functions)
blurb: Solve problems involving the derivatives of trigonometric functions. For example, find h'(π) of h(x)=sin(x²-4x+1).

name: Exponential functions differentiation (Differentiating common functions)
blurb: Solve problems involving the derivatives of exponential functions. For example, find f'(1) of f(x)=2^(x²+x+5).

name: Logarithmic functions differentiation (Differentiating common functions)
blurb: Solve problems involving the derivatives of logarithmic functions. For example, find g'(4) of g(x)=log(x²-1).

name: Derivatives capstone (Differentiating common functions)
blurb: Review your function differentiation skills with some challenge problems.

name: Implicit differentiation introduction (Advanced differentiation)
blurb: Some two-variable relationships cannot be turned into a function, like the circle equation x²+y²=4. Implicit differentiation allows us to find the derivative of y with respect to x, even in such equations.

name: Implicit differentiation (advanced examples) (Advanced differentiation)
blurb: Tackle some more advanced problems of implicit differentiation. For example, find dy/dx for e^(xy²)=x-y.

name: Inverse trig functions differentiation (Advanced differentiation)
blurb: Implicit differentiation allows us to find the derivatives of arcsin(x), arccos(x), and arctan(x).

name: Derivatives of inverse functions (Advanced differentiation)
blurb: Implicit differentiation provides us with the relationship between the derivatives of inverse functions: if f and g are inverse functions, then f’(x)=1/(g’(f(x)). Get comfortable working with this relationship.

name: Disguised derivatives (Advanced differentiation)
blurb: Equipped with knowledge about the derivatives of all common functions, evaluate some limits that represent various derivatives.

name: Proofs for the derivatives of eˣ and ln(x) (Advanced differentiation)
blurb: The derivatives of eˣ and ln(x) may be simple, but proving them is a different story. Learn all about it here.

name: Logarithmic differentiation (Advanced differentiation)
blurb: In logarithmic differentiation, we find the derivative of the natural log of a function instead of the derivative of the function itself. It may surprise you, but this can sometimes actually be easier than regular differentiation, if not the only available option. For example, finding the derivative of xˣ.

name: Parametric & vector-valued function differentiation (Advanced differentiation)
blurb: Parametric and vector-valued functions basically take one input and return two outputs. How do we differentiate such functions? Find out here.

name: Review: Advanced differentiation (Advanced differentiation)
blurb: Review your knowledge of the advanced differentiation topics with some challenge problems.

name: Higher-order derivatives (Advanced differentiation)
blurb: The derivative is a function, and as such it has its own derivative! The same goes for the derivative of the derivative, and so forth. These are all called higher-order derivatives.

name: Higher-order derivatives (parametric & vector-valued functions) (Advanced differentiation)
blurb: Learn how to find the second derivatives (and any higher-order derivative) of parametric and vector-valued functions.

name: Critical points (Analyzing functions with calculus)
blurb: Critical points are points where a function may obtain their minimum or maximum value. They play a critical role (pun intended) in analyzing the increasing and decreasing intervals of functions, and in finding their minimum and maximum points.

name: Increasing & decreasing intervals (Analyzing functions with calculus)
blurb: Analyze functions to find the intervals in which they are increasing or decreasing.

name: Relative minima & maxima (Analyzing functions with calculus)
blurb: Analyze functions to find their relative extrema (i.e. their relative minimum and maximum points).

name: Absolute minima & maxima (Analyzing functions with calculus)
blurb: Analyze functions to find their absolute extrema (i.e. their absolute minimum and maximum points).

name: Review: Increasing/decreasing intervals & extrema (Analyzing functions with calculus)
blurb: Review your understanding of increasing and decreasing intervals, and extremum points, with some challenge problems.

name: Concavity (Analyzing functions with calculus)
blurb: Concavity describes the shape of a graph as it increases or decreases: a graph that's concave up is shaped like a cup, U, and a graph that's concave down is shaped like a cap, ∩. Learn more about concavity and how it relates to a function's second derivative.

name: Points of inflection (Analyzing functions with calculus)
blurb: Points of inflection are points where the function changes concavity. Learn how to find and analyze them.

name: Sketching graphs using calculus (Analyzing functions with calculus)
blurb: Combine the tools provided by differential calculus with other algebraic tools in order to obtain detailed sketches of various functions.

name: Review: Concavity & points of inflection (Analyzing functions with calculus)
blurb: Review your understanding of concavity and points of inflections with some challenge problems.

name: Linear approximation (Derivative applications)
blurb: The method of linear approximation (also called local linearization) allows us to approximate a function at hairy x-values using the line tangent to the function's graph at strategic points.

name: Rectilinear motion (diff calc) (Derivative applications)
blurb: Solve problems about motion along a line using the power of differential calculus. For example, given the position of a particle as a function of time s(t), find the particle's maximum velocity.

name: Planar motion (diff calc) (Derivative applications)
blurb: Solve problems about motion on a 2-dimensional plane using the power of differential calculus. For example, given the (x,y) position of a particle as a function of time (x(t),y(t)), find the particle's position when its acceleration is 0.

name: Related rates (Derivative applications)
blurb: Solve geometrical and real-world problems that concern multiple quantities that change at different, but related, rates. For example, given the rate of change of a circle's radius, find the rate of change of the circle's area.

name: Optimization (Derivative applications)
blurb: Solve geometrical and real-world problems that involve finding the maximum (or minimum) possible value of a quantity. For example, find the maximum area of a rectangle whose perimeter is given.

name: Applied rates of change (Derivative applications)
blurb: Solve various rate of change problems where a real-world situation is modeled by an algebraic function.

name: Mean value theorem (Derivative applications)
blurb: The mean value theorem states that if a function f is continuous on the closed interval [a,b] and differentiable on the open interval (a,b), then there exists a point c in (a,b) such that f'(c) is equal to the function's average rate of change over [a,b].

name: L'Hôpital's rule (Derivative applications)
blurb: L'Hôpital's rule provides us with an easy, almost magical way of finding indeterminate limits of quotients of functions using the functions' derivatives. In short, the rule says that if the limits of functions f and g at x=a are 0 (or ထ) and the limit of f'(x)/g'(x) at x=a is equal to L, then the limit of f(x)/g(x) at x=a is also equal to L.

name: Review: Derivative applications (Derivative applications)
blurb: Review your understanding of the various applications of differential calculus with some challenge problems.

name: Definite integral as area (Definite integrals introduction)
blurb: Introducing the definite integral. It's basically a way to represent the area under a given curve with left-hand and right-hand bounds.

name: Definite integral properties (Definite integrals introduction)
blurb: Definite integrals behave is specific ways with shared properties. For example, the sum of the definite integrals of a function f from a to b and from b to c is equal to the definite integral of f from a to c. Learn about these properties and use them in order to evaluate integrals.

name: Review: Definite integral basics (Definite integrals introduction)
blurb: Review your understanding of the basics of definite integrals with some challenge problems.

name: Riemann sums (Riemann sums)
blurb: Riemann sums is the name of a family of methods we can use to approximate the area under a curve. Learn about the different ways and how they are constructed.

name: Riemann sums with sigma notation (Riemann sums)
blurb: The larger the number of terms in a Riemann sum, the more accurate it is. But as the number of terms increases, we need better ways to write them down. This is where sigma notation comes in very handy.

name: Trapezoidal rule (Riemann sums)
blurb: The trapezoidal rule is yet another way to approximate the area under a curve. Learn about they way it's constructed and how accurate it is comparing the rectangular Riemann sums.

name: Definite integral as the limit of a Riemann sum (Riemann sums)
blurb: The definite integral of a function is the limit of a sequence of Riemann sums where the intervals become infinitely small. Learn more about this formal definition.

name: Review: Riemann sums (Riemann sums)
blurb: Review your understanding of Riemann sums with some challenge problems.

name: Functions defined by integrals (Fundamental theorem of calculus)
blurb: Get comfortable with functions that for any input x, return the area under a curve between a given bound and x. This is an important stop on our journey to relating differential and integral calculus.

name: Fundamental theorem of calculus (Fundamental theorem of calculus)
blurb: The fundamental theorem of calculus is definitely one of the most important theorems of all time! It relates differential calculus and the concept of the derivative with integral calculus and the concept of the integral. Learn all about it here!

name: Fundamental theorem of calculus: chain rule (Fundamental theorem of calculus)
blurb: Get better acquainted with the fundamental theorem of calculus, and apply it for a class of seemingly hairy problems.

name: Antiderivatives (Indefinite integrals)
blurb: If f' is the derivative of f, then f is the antiderivative of f'. To find the antiderivative of a function we need to perform some kind of reverse differentiation. Learn about it here.

name: Indefinite integrals intro (Indefinite integrals)
blurb: Indefinite integrals are the way integral calculus deals with antiderivatives. Gain some practice in finding various indefinite integrals.

name: Indefinite integrals of common functions (Indefinite integrals)
blurb: Indefinite integrals (or antiderivatives) are really just backward differentiation. Therefore, the indefinite integral of eˣ is eˣ+c, the indefinite integral of 1/x is ln(x)+c, the indefinite integral of sin(x) is -cos(x)+c, and the indefinite integral of cos(x) is sin(x)+c.

name: Review: Indefinite integrals & antiderivatives (Indefinite integrals)
blurb: Review your understanding of indefinite integrals and antiderivatives with some challenge problems.

name: Definite integral evaluation (Definite integral evaluation)
blurb: The fundamental theorem tells us how we can evaluate definite integrals. Now let us  put this to use and evaluate some!

name: Definite integrals of piecewise functions (Definite integral evaluation)
blurb: Evaluate definite integrals of piecewise functions. This is where the definite integral properties come into good use.

name: Improper integrals (Definite integral evaluation)
blurb: Improper integrals are like definite integrals, only unbounded from the left and/or right. And yes, some of them have finite values. An unbounded area with a finite size? That's calculus to you!

name: Integration by parts (Integration techniques)
blurb: Learn how to use the product rule in order to find the integral of a product of functions (sadly this is more complicated than using the product rule the regular way).

name: u-substitution (Integration techniques)
blurb: u-substitution is an extremely useful technique. Harnessing the power of the chain rule, it allows us to define a new variable (common denoted by the letter u) as a function of x, and obtain a new expression which is (hopefully) easier to integrate.

name: Reverse chain rule (Integration techniques)
blurb: Reverse chain rule is another, faster way to think about u-substitution.

name: Partial fraction expansion (Integration techniques)
blurb: Learn a useful algebraic tool to find the integrals of some rational functions.

name: Integration using trigonometric identities (Integration techniques)
blurb: Some integrals that contain trig functions demand that we manipulate those functions using trig identities in order to find the integral.

name: Trigonometric substitution (Integration techniques)
blurb: Another super useful technique for computing integrals involves replacing variables with trigonometric functions. This can make things seem a little more complicated at first, but with the help of trigonometric identities, this technique makes certain integrals solvable.

name: Area between curves (Area & arc length using calculus)
blurb: By integrating the difference of two functions, you can find the area between them.

name: Arc length (Area & arc length using calculus)
blurb: Integral calculus isn't only useful for finding area. For example, it can also be used to find lengths of one-dimensional curves. Learn all about it here.

name: Area defined by polar graphs (Area & arc length using calculus)
blurb: We're used to finding the area under curves in the Cartesian plane, but integration can be used to find area defined by polar curves too.

name: Arc length of polar graphs (Area & arc length using calculus)
blurb: You may already be familiar with finding arc length of graphs that are defined in terms of rectangular coordinates. We'll now extend our knowledge of arc length to include polar graphs.

name: Area & net change (Integration applications)
blurb: The area under a rate function gives the net change. This result of the fundamental theorem of calculus is being put here to use with some real-world problems.

name: Rectilinear motion (integral calc) (Integration applications)
blurb: Solve problems about motion along a line using the power of integral calculus. For example, given the velocity of a particle as a function of time v(t), find how much the particle has traveled over a given time period.

name: Average value of a function (Integration applications)
blurb: We usually calculate the average of N terms by summing them up and dividing by N. How do you find the average of infinitely many terms? For example, the average of a function f(x) for all x-values between 0 and 1? Integral calculus to the rescue!

name: Solids with known cross sections (Volume using calculus)
blurb: Let's leverage the definite integral to find volumes of figures where we know what their cross sections look like. It is surprisingly fun.

name: Disc method (Volume using calculus)
blurb: You know how to use definite integrals to find areas under curves. We now take that idea for "spin" by thinking about the volumes of things created when you rotate functions around various lines.

name: Washer method (Volume using calculus)
blurb: Washer method is an extension of the disc method for finding the volumes of more elaborate solids of revolution.

name: Shell method (Volume using calculus)
blurb: Shell method offers us another way of calculating the volume of solids of revolution. Some solids are more easily found with the shell method.

name: Sequences review (Series intro)
blurb: In this tutorial, we'll review what sequences are, their associated notation, and formulas of sequences.

name: Infinite sequences (Series intro)
blurb: Now that we understand what a sequence is, we're going to think about what happens to the terms of a sequence at infinity (do they approach 0, a finite value, or +- infinity?).

name: Series review (Series intro)
blurb: You're familiar with sequences and have been eager to sum them up.  Well wait no longer!  In this tutorial, we'll see that series are just sums of sequences and familiarize ourselves with the notation.

name: Finite geometric series (Series intro)
blurb: A finite geometric series is the sum of the first few terms of a geometric sequence. It turns out there's a quick way of finding such a sum, without having to really sum all the terms one-by-one.

name: Partial sums (Series intro)
blurb: Partial sums are another way to think of finite series. Why partial? Because they are a part of an infinite series! Thinking of the partial sums of an infinite series helps us analyze the infinite series itself.

name: Infinite geometric series (Series intro)
blurb: This might seem unbelievable at first, but for a certain class of geometric sequences, we can take the sum of all the infinite terms in the sequence and end up with a finite number! This sum is called an infinite geometric series. Learn when and how it can be found.

name: Series basics challenge (Series intro)
blurb: Learn how to find the value of some special classes of series. This material is relatively advanced and isn't included in the AP Calculus course.

name: Basic convergence tests (Series convergence & estimation)
blurb: How can we tell whether a series converges or diverges? There is an impressive repository of tools that can help us with this question. In this tutorial, we will cover the basic tests: n-th term test, integral test, and p-series test. These tests can help us later on with the more elaborate convergence tests.

name: Comparison tests (Series convergence & estimation)
blurb: If the sum of a series must be smaller than the sum of another series that converges, then that series must converge as well. Makes sense, no? This notion, and similar ones, are at the basis of the comparison convergence tests.

name: Ratio & alternating series tests (Series convergence & estimation)
blurb: The ratio test is one of the most useful tests for series convergence. Alternating series are a special class of series that have their own, very useful test for convergence.

name: Estimating infinite series (Series convergence & estimation)
blurb: We've spent a lot of time thinking about whether a series converges or diverges.  But, even if we can determine that a series converges, how can we figure out what it converges to?  This tutorial will show techniques of estimating what a series converges to, and for determining how good our estimates are.  This is super useful because most series can't be precisely evaluated (like we were able to do with infinite geometric series).

name: Power series intro (Power series)
blurb: Power series is a sum of terms of the general form aₙ(x-a)ⁿ. As you can see, it's actually a function whose sum depends on the x-value. It is a generalization of geometric series, and an extremely useful class of series. Learn more about it in this tutorial.

name: Taylor & Maclaurin polynomials intro (Power series)
blurb: Taylor polynomials are a very clever way of approximating any function with a polynomial. Maclaurin polynomials are a special class of Taylor polynomials. Learn how these polynomials work in this tutorial.

name: Maclaurin series of sin(x), cos(x), and eˣ (Power series)
blurb: A Maclaurin series is essentially a Maclaurin polynomial with infinite terms. It turns out that the Maclaurin series of sin(x), cos(x), and eˣ return the exact same values as the functions themselves, for any x-value. Wow! Introduce yourselves to these special series and discover one of the most fascinating areas of all of mathematics!

name: Power series function representation (Power series)
blurb: We already saw how Taylor and Maclaurin series can be used to represent a variety of functions. In this tutorial, we will expand the scope of functions that we can represent with power series, by enriching our toolkit!

name: Challenge series exercises (Power series)
blurb: Review you knowledge about series with some challenging exercises.

name: About the course (Limits and continuity)
blurb: Watch testimonials about learning calculus with Khan Academy and read about the required knowledge in order to start learning AP Calculus.

name: Analyzing limits graphically (Limits and continuity)
blurb: Graph are the best way to start reasoning about limits, because they show how the function behaves in a very immediate way. Learn how to estimate limits off of graphs and how to find points on the graph where the limit doesn't exist.

name: Analyzing limits numerically (Limits and continuity)
blurb: We can estimate a certain limit by looking at the values of the function in points that are very close to the limit. Learn how to pick the right values for estimating limits, and how to read limits given from tables of values.

name: One-sided limits (Limits and continuity)
blurb: A limit only exists if the function approaches the same value from the left and from the right. Sometimes we want to reason about what the function approaches from the left only, or from the right only. These are one-sided limits.

name: Continuity (Limits and continuity)
blurb: Intuitively, a function is continuous if we can draw its graph without lifting the pencil. For centuries mathematicians tried to find a formal definition for continuity, and this was finally achieved with limits. Learn how we define continuity and how we determine whether a function is continuous.

name: Limit rules for sums, differences, products, quotients, & composites (Limits and continuity)
blurb: If we know the limit of two basic functions, we can determine the limit of a more elaborate function that uses the two basic functions. For example, if we know the limit at x=c of functions ƒ and 𝑔, we can tell the limit at x=c of ƒ+𝑔, ƒ⋅𝑔, or ƒ/𝑔.

name: Determining limits using direct substitution (Limits and continuity)
blurb: We are about to learn how to calculate the limit of a function whose equation is given. The first step in this journey is to simply evaluate the function at the limit. Let's see how this is done.

name: Determining limits by factoring & rationalizing (Limits and continuity)
blurb: When direct substitution of a limit ends with the indeterminate form 0/0, we need to look for ways to rewrite the function. Two common ways are factoring and rationalizing.

name: Trigonometric limits & squeeze theorem (Limits and continuity)
blurb: Just like other continuous functions, limits of trigonometric functions can be found using direct substitution. In some cases where we end up with the indeterminate form 0/0, we will need to use other tools like trigonometric identities or the squeeze theorem.

name: Infinite limits intro (Limits and continuity)
blurb: There are two kinds of infinite limits: limits at infinity (i.e. the value the function approaches as x approaches infinity) and unbounded limits (which correspond to a vertical asymptote in the graph of the function).

name: Analyzing limits at infinity (Limits and continuity)
blurb: After we've learned how to identify limits at infinity in the graphs of functions, we will learn here how to analyze a function's limits at infinity from the function's equation.

name: Analyzing functions for discontinuities (Limits and continuity)
blurb: It's possible to classify points of discontinuity according to three main types: removable discontinuities, jump discontinuities, and infinite discontinuities. Learn how to classify and analyze points of discontinuity given the function's graph or the function's equation.

name: Strategy in finding limits (Limits and continuity)
blurb: Throughout this unit we've learned many different ways to find limits. Each way, or method, applies under certain conditions. Now it's time to take a broader look and come up with a complete workflow for finding limits.

name: Optional videos | Limits & continuity | AP Calculus AB | Khan Academy (Limits and continuity)
blurb: Some things are not explicitly required by the AP Calculus AB course, but many teachers cover them and we also find them useful. We've gathered those optional videos here for your convenience.

name: The derivative: An intuitive introduction (Derivatives introduction)
blurb: The derivative of a function describes the function's instantaneous rate of change at a certain point. Another common interpretation is that the derivative gives us the slope of the line tangent to the function's graph at that point.

name: Estimating derivatives with secant lines and average rate of change (Derivatives introduction)
blurb: The slope of the line tangent to a function's graph can be estimated using secant lines that are close to the point of tangency. Similarly, a function's instantaneous rate of change can be estimated using the function's average rate of change over intervals that are close to the point in question.

name: Secant lines & average rate of change with arbitrary points (Derivatives introduction)
blurb: As a preparation for formally defining the derivative, gain some experience in describing a function's average rate of change (or slope of secant line) over an interval where one of the endpoints is arbitrarily defined. For example, find the average rate of change of f(x)=x² over the interval [1,t].

name: Formal definition of the derivative as a limit (Derivatives introduction)
blurb: The derivative is formally defined as the limit of the slopes of secant lines where the intersection points approach the point of tangency. Similarly, it's the function's average rate of change over an interval where the interval's endpoints both approach the point in question.

name: Differentiability (Derivatives introduction)
blurb: Learn about the conditions for differentiability, which is the existence of a derivative to a function at a certain point. It turns out that differentiability has a close link with continuity.

name: Tangent lines and local linearity (Derivatives introduction)
blurb: As we zoom-in on a differentiable function at a certain point, the function resembles a line, which means we can use the line tangent to that point to approximate the function at values close to that point.

name: Optional videos | Derivatives introduction | AP Calculus AB | Khan Academy (Derivatives introduction)
blurb: Some things are not explicitly required by the AP Calculus AB course, but many teachers cover them and we also find them useful. We've gathered those optional videos here for your convenience.

name: Basic differentiation rules (Derivative rules)
blurb: If you ever tried to find derivatives using their formal definition, you probably know how time consuming that may be. Fortunately, we have ways for finding derivatives much quicker, using differentiation rules! Make your first steps in this fascinating world by working with the more basic rules. For example, the derivative of [f(x)+g(x)] is f'(x)+g'(x), and the derivative of k⋅f'(x).

name: Power rule (Derivative rules)
blurb: The power rule says that the derivative of the function xⁿ is n⋅xⁿ⁻¹. This is very useful for differentiating polynomials and other types of functions.

name: Polynomial functions differentiation (Derivative rules)
blurb: Put the power rule to use by differentiating various polynomials.

name: Derivatives of negative and fractional powers with power rule (Derivative rules)
blurb: The power rule tells us how to differentiate functions like 1/x or √x, because they can be written in the form xⁿ.

name: Derivatives of sin(x) and cos(x) (Derivative rules)
blurb: The derivative of sin(x) is cos(x) and the derivative of cos(x) is -sin(x). Practice differentiating functions with sine and cosine expressions.

name: Product rule (Derivative rules)
blurb: The product rule tells us how to differentiate functions that are products of other, more basic, functions. Unlike what you might guess, the derivative of f(x)⋅g(x) isn't f'(x)⋅g'(x). It's actually f(x)⋅g'(x)+f'(x)⋅g(x). Learn all about it here.

name: Quotient rule (Derivative rules)
blurb: The quotient rule tells us how to differentiate functions that are quotients of other, more basic, functions. Unlike what you might guess, the derivative of f(x)/g(x) isn't f'(x)/g'(x). It's actually [f(x)⋅g'(x)-f'(x)⋅g(x)]/[g(x)]². Learn all about it here.

name: Rational functions differentiation (Derivative rules)
blurb: Solve problems involving the derivatives of rational functions. For example, find f'(1) of f(x)=(x+2)/(x-3).

name: Chain rule (Derivative rules)
blurb: The chain rule tells us how to differentiate composite functions: the derivative of f(g(x)) is f'(g(x))⋅g'(x). Brush up on your function composition skills and dive right into differentiating composite functions using the chain rule.

name: Radical functions differentiation (Derivative rules)
blurb: Solve problems involving the derivatives of radical functions. For example, find g'(5) of g(x)=∛(x²+5x-3).

name: Trigonometric functions differentiation (Derivative rules)
blurb: The quotient rule tells us how to find the derivatives of tan(x), cot(x), sec(x), and csc(x) using the derivatives of sin(x) and cos(x). The chain rule tells us how to find the derivatives of trigonometric functions whose argument is more elaborate than x, like sin(x²+1).

name: Strategy in differentiating functions (Derivative rules)
blurb: Differentiation has so many different rules and there are so many different ways to apply them! Let's take a broader look at differentiation and come up with a workflow that will allow us to find the derivative of any function, efficiently and without mistakes.

name: Optional videos | Derivative rules | AP Calculus AB | Khan Academy (Derivative rules)
blurb: Some things are not explicitly required by the AP Calculus AB course, but many teachers cover them and we also find them useful. We've gathered those optional videos here for your convenience.

name: Differentiating using multiple rules (Advanced derivatives )
blurb: Practice differentiating elaborate functions that require the use of the product, quotient, or chain rule, multiple times. For example, find the derivative of [x²⋅sin(x)]³.

name: Second derivatives (Advanced derivatives )
blurb: The derivative is a function, and as such it has its own derivative! The derivative of the derivative of a function is called the second derivative. Later, we will see how the second derivative gives us information about the behavior of the function. For now, we will focus on finding second derivatives.

name: Implicit differentiation (Advanced derivatives )
blurb: Some two-variable relationships cannot be turned into a function, like the circle equation x²+y²=4. Implicit differentiation allows us to find the derivative of y with respect to x, even in such equations.

name: Derivatives of inverse functions (Advanced derivatives )
blurb: Implicit differentiation provides us with the relationship between the derivatives of inverse functions: if f and g are inverse functions, then f’(x)=1/(g’(f(x)). Get comfortable working with this relationship.

name: Derivatives of inverse trigonometric functions (Advanced derivatives )
blurb: Implicit differentiation allows us to find the derivatives of the inverse trigonometric functions: arcsin(x), arccos(x), and arctan(x).

name: Derivatives of exponential functions (Advanced derivatives )
blurb: You might have heard about the mathematical constant 𝑒 that's approximately equal to 2.71828. If not, you will learn about it now. One of the most interesting things about 𝑒 is the fact that the derivative of 𝑒ˣ is... well... 𝑒ˣ. This allows us to find the derivative of any other exponential function.

name: Derivatives of logarithmic functions (Advanced derivatives )
blurb: ln(x) is the natural logarithm, which is the logarithm whose base is 𝑒. It turns out that the derivative of ln(x) is simply 1/x. This allows us to find the derivative of any logarithmic function.

name: Optional videos | Advanced derivatives | AP Calculus AB | Khan Academy (Advanced derivatives )
blurb: Some things are not explicitly required by the AP Calculus AB course, but many teachers cover them and we also find them useful. We've gathered those optional videos here for your convenience.

name: Intermediate and extreme value theorems (Existence theorems)
blurb: The intermediate value theorem and the extreme value theorem describe properties of continuous functions. Learn how to establish whether they apply for a certain function on a certain interval, and use the intermediate value theorem to solve problems.

name: Mean value theorem (Existence theorems)
blurb: The mean value theorem describes a property of differentiable functions. Learn how to establish whether it applies for a certain function on a certain interval, and use it to solve problems.

name: L'Hôpital's rule (Using derivatives to analyze functions)
blurb: L'Hôpital's rule uses derivatives to helps us find limits where direct substitution ends with the indeterminate forms 0/0 or  ∞/∞.

name: Justifying properties of functions using the first derivative (Using derivatives to analyze functions)
blurb: Let's take a close look at how the behavior of a function is related to the behavior of its derivative. This type of reasoning is called "calculus-based reasoning." Learn how to apply it appropriately.

name: Critical points & intervals of increase or decrease (Using derivatives to analyze functions)
blurb: A function is increasing/decreasing whenever its derivative is positive/negative (correspondingly). Learn how we use this fact to find where functions are increasing/decreasing and about the main role critical points have in this process.

name: Finding relative extrema (first derivative test) (Using derivatives to analyze functions)
blurb: After we've learned about critical points, let's dive into the process of finding extremum (i.e. minimum and maximum) points. This process is often called the first derivative test.

name: Finding absolute extrema (Using derivatives to analyze functions)
blurb: While a function may have many relative maximum points, it has only one absolute maximum. Learn how we can use the first derivative, along with the extreme value theorem, to find the absolute maximum or minimum of functions.

name: Concavity & inflection points intro (Using derivatives to analyze functions)
blurb: A function is concave up/down whenever its derivative is increasing/decreasing (correspondingly). Graphically, a graph that's concave up is shaped like a cup, U, and a graph that's concave down is shaped like a cap, ∩. Inflection points are where the function changes concavity (from up to down and vice versa).

name: Justifying properties of functions using the second derivative (Using derivatives to analyze functions)
blurb: Let's take a closer look at how we use the second derivative of a function to justify the properties of that function.

name: Finding inflection points & analyzing concavity (Using derivatives to analyze functions)
blurb: Use the second derivative of a function to find the intervals where the function is concave up or down, and to find inflection points.

name: Connecting ƒ, ƒ’, and ƒ’’ (Using derivatives to analyze functions)
blurb: To conclude this unit, let's look at functions along with both their first derivative and their second derivative.

name: Optional videos | Using derivatives to analyze functions | AP Calculus AB | Khan Academy (Using derivatives to analyze functions)
blurb: Some things are not explicitly required by the AP Calculus AB course, but many teachers cover them and we also find them useful. We've gathered those optional videos here for your convenience.

name: Rates of change in applied contexts (Applications of derivatives)
blurb: Differential calculus is all about instantaneous rate of change. Let's see how this can be used to solve real-world word problems.

name: Related rates intro (Applications of derivatives)
blurb: Related rates problems are word problems where we reason about the rate of change of a quantity by using information we have about the rate of change of another quantity that's related to it. Let's take our first venture into this world, see what defines a related rates problem and how to approach it.

name: Related rates problems (Applications of derivatives)
blurb: In the previous lesson we've learned what related rates problems are and how we approach their solution. In this lesson we will tackle a variety of related rates problems and solve, solve, solve!

name: Optimization (Applications of derivatives)
blurb: In optimization problems we are looking for a certain value within a possible range that yields the best results. For example, an optimization problem might ask us to find the dimensions of a rectangle that yield the most area for a given perimeter.

name: Motion problems (Applications of derivatives)
blurb: The rate of change of a moving object is its velocity, and the rate of change of the velocity is acceleration. This relationship, and the fact that derivatives give us the rate of change of a quantity, is commonly applied in motion word problems.

name: Definite integrals intro (Accumulation and Riemann sums)
blurb: The definite integral represents the area under the curve of a function between two vertical lines. Find definite integrals of simple functions.

name: Left & right Riemann sums (Accumulation and Riemann sums)
blurb: Definite integrals can be estimated with rectangles. Such estimations are called Riemann sums. Learn how we can use them to approximate the area under a curve.

name: Midpoint & trapezoidal sums (Accumulation and Riemann sums)
blurb: Midpoint sums and trapezoidal sums offer other ways to approximate definite integrals besides left and right Riemann sums. Midpoint and trapezoidal sums usually approximate better for the same number of shapes, but calculating them is slightly more involved.

name: Summation notation (Accumulation and Riemann sums)
blurb: Mathematicians have invented a special notation to describe sums with multiple terms, using the sigma operator, Σ. Review how it's done before we use this notation to describe Riemann sums.

name: Riemann sums in summation notation (Accumulation and Riemann sums)
blurb: Are you familiar with left and right Riemann sums? Great. Do you know how to use summation notation? Even better. Now let's write the approximation of Riemann sums using summation notation.

name: Definite integral as the limit of a Riemann sum (Accumulation and Riemann sums)
blurb: Riemann sums help us approximate definite integrals, but they also help us formally define definite integrals. In short, the definite integral is the limit of Riemann sum approximations as the number of rectangles becomes infinitely large and the width of each rectangle becomes infinitely small.

name: Definite integrals properties (Accumulation and Riemann sums)
blurb: Let's take a look at some basic properties of definite integrals and how they can be used to calculate elaborate definite integrals.

name: Functions defined by integrals (Accumulation and Riemann sums)
blurb: Given a continuous function ƒ, we can define a new function 𝑔 that for every input 𝘹 returns the definite integral of ƒ between a constant 𝘢 and 𝘹. For now, we only want to get some practice with such functions. In a few lessons we are going to learn something pretty cool about them.

name: Antiderivatives and indefinite integrals intro (Antiderivatives and the fundamental theorem of calculus)
blurb: The antiderivative of a function ƒ is a function whose derivative is ƒ. Antiderivatives are also called indefinite integrals.

name: Fundamental theorem of calculus (Antiderivatives and the fundamental theorem of calculus)
blurb: The fundamental theorem of calculus connects differential and integral calculus. It tells us that the definite integral of function ƒ over the interval [𝘢,𝘣] is 𝘍(𝘣)-𝘍(𝘢), where 𝘍 is any antiderivative of ƒ. Another version of the theorem says that if we define 𝘍(𝘹) to be the definite integral of ƒ over the interval [𝘢,𝘹], then 𝘍 is an antiderivative of ƒ.

name: Indefinite integrals: reverse power rule (Antiderivatives and the fundamental theorem of calculus)
blurb: To find antiderivatives we must apply the derivative rules we already know, only in reverse. The reverse power helps us find the indefinite integral of an function of the form 𝘹ⁿ where 𝘯≠-1.

name: Indefinite integrals of sin(x), cos(x), eˣ, and 1/x (Antiderivatives and the fundamental theorem of calculus)
blurb: To find antiderivatives we must apply the derivative rules we already know, only in reverse. We can find the antiderivatives of sin(x), cos(x), eˣ, and 1/x by asking which function has them as a derivative.

name: Finding definite integrals (Antiderivatives and the fundamental theorem of calculus)
blurb: Let's combine our knowledge of indefinite integrals with the fundamental theorem of calculus in order to find definite integrals!

name: 𝘶-substitution (Antiderivatives and the fundamental theorem of calculus)
blurb: 𝘶-substitution essentially reverses the chain rule for derivatives. In other words, it helps us integrate composite functions.

name: Average value of a function (Antiderivatives and the fundamental theorem of calculus)
blurb: We're used to finding the average of a finite set of values, but what about the average of infinitely many values? Definite integrals can help us with that.

name: Interpreting behavior of 𝑔 from graph of 𝑔'=ƒ (Antiderivatives and the fundamental theorem of calculus)
blurb: In differential calculus we reasoned about the properties of a function ƒ based on information given about its derivative ƒ'. In integral calculus, instead of talking about functions and their derivatives, we will talk about functions and their antiderivatives.

name: Optional videos | Antiderivatives and the fundamental theorem of calculus | AP Calculus AB | Khan Academy (Antiderivatives and the fundamental theorem of calculus)
blurb: Some things are not explicitly required by the AP Calculus AB course, but many teachers cover them and we also find them useful. We've gathered those optional videos here for your convenience.

name: Differential equations intro (Differential equations)
blurb: Differential equations are equations that include both a function and its derivative. Unlike regular equations, the solutions of differential equations are functions. Learn how to check whether a function is a solution of a differential equation, and write differential equations that model a specific function behavior.

name: Separable differential equations (Differential equations)
blurb: One of the most common methods for solving differential equations is separation of variables. Learn how to use it and how to identify when an equation can be solved using separation of variables (we call such equations "separable equations").

name: Differential equations: specific solutions (Differential equations)
blurb: Usually, a differential equation has infinitely many possible solutions. If we're given some initial conditions, we can find a specific solution of the equation that also has these conditions.

name: Slope fields (Differential equations)
blurb: Slope fields are a clever way for approximating the solutions to a differential equation.

name: Exponential models (Differential equations)
blurb: 𝘥𝘺/𝘥𝘹=𝘬⋅𝘺 is a differential equation that models the case where the rate of change of a quantity is proportional to the size of the quantity. The solution of such an equation is an exponential function.

name: Word problems involving definite integrals (Applications of definite integrals)
blurb: Definite integrals are all about the accumulation of quantities. Let's see how they are applied in order to solve real-world word problems.

name: Motion problems (with integrals) (Applications of definite integrals)
blurb: In differential calculus we solved motion problems by differentiating the position function to find the velocity function. Now we go the opposite way. We also learn about the difference between speed and velocity, and between distance and displacement.

name: Area: vertical areas between curves (Applications of definite integrals)
blurb: Let's apply definite integrals to find the area below, above, and between curves.

name: Area: horizontal areas between curves (Applications of definite integrals)
blurb: With a slight manipulation, definite integrals can be used to find the area between a curve and the 𝘺-axis. In other words, we find the horizontal area to the right or to the left of the curve.

name: Volumes with known cross sections (Applications of definite integrals)
blurb: You know how to use definite integrals to find areas under curves. We now take that idea for a spin by thinking about the volumes of figures that are created when you rotate functions around various lines.

name: Volume: disc method (Applications of definite integrals)
blurb: The disc method is a method for calculating the volume of a solid of revolution by modeling the resulting three-dimensional shape as a stack of an infinite number of discs whose thickness is infinitely small.

name: Volume: washer method (Applications of definite integrals)
blurb: The washer method is an extension of the disc method for finding the volumes of more elaborate solids of revolution.

name: Volume: shell method (optional) (Applications of definite integrals)
blurb: Shell method offers us another way of calculating the volume of solids of revolution. Some solids are more easily found with the shell method. This method isn't required by the AP Calculus AB course, but many teachers cover it and we also find it useful.

name: AP Calculus AB 2017 free response (AP Calculus AB solved free response questions from past exams)
blurb: Solved examples from AP Calculus AB 2017.

name: AP Calculus AB 2015 free response (AP Calculus AB solved free response questions from past exams)
blurb: Solved examples from AP Calculus AB 2015.

name: AP Calculus AB 2011 free response (AP Calculus AB solved free response questions from past exams)
blurb: Solved examples from AP Calculus AB 2011.

name: About the course (Limits and continuity)
blurb: Watch testimonials about learning calculus with Khan Academy and read about the required knowledge in order to start learning AP Calculus.

name: Analyzing limits graphically (Limits and continuity)
blurb: Graph are the best way to start reasoning about limits, because they show how the function behaves in a very immediate way. Learn how to estimate limits off of graphs and how to find points on the graph where the limit doesn't exist.

name: Analyzing limits numerically (Limits and continuity)
blurb: We can estimate a certain limit by looking at the values of the function in points that are very close to the limit. Learn how to pick the right values for estimating limits, and how to read limits given from tables of values.

name: One-sided limits (Limits and continuity)
blurb: A limit only exists if the function approaches the same value from the left and from the right. Sometimes we want to reason about what the function approaches from the left only, or from the right only. These are one-sided limits.

name: Continuity (Limits and continuity)
blurb: Intuitively, a function is continuous if we can draw its graph without lifting the pencil. For centuries mathematicians tried to find a formal definition for continuity, and this was finally achieved with limits. Learn how we define continuity and how we determine whether a function is continuous.

name: Limit rules for sums, differences, products, quotients, & composites (Limits and continuity)
blurb: If we know the limit of two basic functions, we can determine the limit of a more elaborate function that uses the two basic functions. For example, if we know the limit at x=c of functions ƒ and 𝑔, we can tell the limit at x=c of ƒ+𝑔, ƒ⋅𝑔, or ƒ/𝑔.

name: Determining limits using direct substitution (Limits and continuity)
blurb: We are about to learn how to calculate the limit of a function whose equation is given. The first step in this journey is to simply evaluate the function at the limit. Let's see how this is done.

name: Determining limits by factoring & rationalizing (Limits and continuity)
blurb: When direct substitution of a limit ends with the indeterminate form 0/0, we need to look for ways to rewrite the function. Two common ways are factoring and rationalizing.

name: Trigonometric limits & squeeze theorem (Limits and continuity)
blurb: Just like other continuous functions, limits of trigonometric functions can be found using direct substitution. In some cases where we end up with the indeterminate form 0/0, we will need to use other tools like trigonometric identities or the squeeze theorem.

name: Infinite limits intro (Limits and continuity)
blurb: There are two kinds of infinite limits: limits at infinity (i.e. the value the function approaches as x approaches infinity) and unbounded limits (which correspond to a vertical asymptote in the graph of the function).

name: Analyzing limits at infinity (Limits and continuity)
blurb: After we've learned how to identify limits at infinity in the graphs of functions, we will learn here how to analyze a function's limits at infinity from the function's equation.

name: Analyzing functions for discontinuities (Limits and continuity)
blurb: It's possible to classify points of discontinuity according to three main types: removable discontinuities, jump discontinuities, and infinite discontinuities. Learn how to classify and analyze points of discontinuity given the function's graph or the function's equation.

name: Strategy in finding limits (Limits and continuity)
blurb: Throughout this unit we've learned many different ways to find limits. Each way, or method, applies under certain conditions. Now it's time to take a broader look and come up with a complete workflow for finding limits.

name: Optional videos | Limits & continuity | AP Calculus BC | Khan Academy (Limits and continuity)
blurb: Some things are not explicitly required by the AP Calculus BC course, but many teachers cover them and we also find them useful. We've gathered those optional videos here for your convenience.

name: The derivative: An intuitive introduction (Derivatives introduction)
blurb: The derivative of a function describes the function's instantaneous rate of change at a certain point. Another common interpretation is that the derivative gives us the slope of the line tangent to the function's graph at that point.

name: Estimating derivatives with secant lines and average rate of change (Derivatives introduction)
blurb: The slope of the line tangent to a function's graph can be estimated using secant lines that are close to the point of tangency. Similarly, a function's instantaneous rate of change can be estimated using the function's average rate of change over intervals that are close to the point in question.

name: Secant lines & average rate of change with arbitrary points (Derivatives introduction)
blurb: As a preparation for formally defining the derivative, gain some experience in describing a function's average rate of change (or slope of secant line) over an interval where one of the endpoints is arbitrarily defined. For example, find the average rate of change of f(x)=x² over the interval [1,t].

name: Formal definition of the derivative as a limit (Derivatives introduction)
blurb: The derivative is formally defined as the limit of the slopes of secant lines where the intersection points approach the point of tangency. Similarly, it's the function's average rate of change over an interval where the interval's endpoints both approach the point in question.

name: Differentiability (Derivatives introduction)
blurb: Learn about the conditions for differentiability, which is the existence of a derivative to a function at a certain point. It turns out that differentiability has a close link with continuity.

name: Tangent lines and local linearity (Derivatives introduction)
blurb: As we zoom-in on a differentiable function at a certain point, the function resembles a line, which means we can use the line tangent to that point to approximate the function at values close to that point.

name: Optional videos | Derivatives introduction | AP Calculus BC | Khan Academy (Derivatives introduction)
blurb: Some things are not explicitly required by the AP Calculus BC course, but many teachers cover them and we also find them useful. We've gathered those optional videos here for your convenience.

name: Basic differentiation rules (Derivative rules)
blurb: If you ever tried to find derivatives using their formal definition, you probably know how time consuming that may be. Fortunately, we have ways for finding derivatives much quicker, using differentiation rules! Make your first steps in this fascinating world by working with the more basic rules. For example, the derivative of [f(x)+g(x)] is f'(x)+g'(x), and the derivative of k⋅f'(x).

name: Power rule (Derivative rules)
blurb: The power rule says that the derivative of the function xⁿ is n⋅xⁿ⁻¹. This is very useful for differentiating polynomials and other types of functions.

name: Polynomial functions differentiation (Derivative rules)
blurb: Put the power rule to use by differentiating various polynomials.

name: Derivatives of negative and fractional powers with power rule (Derivative rules)
blurb: The power rule tells us how to differentiate functions like 1/x or √x, because they can be written in the form xⁿ.

name: Derivatives of sin(x) and cos(x) (Derivative rules)
blurb: The derivative of sin(x) is cos(x) and the derivative of cos(x) is -sin(x). Practice differentiating functions with sine and cosine expressions.

name: Product rule (Derivative rules)
blurb: The product rule tells us how to differentiate functions that are products of other, more basic, functions. Unlike what you might guess, the derivative of f(x)⋅g(x) isn't f'(x)⋅g'(x). It's actually f(x)⋅g'(x)+f'(x)⋅g(x). Learn all about it here.

name: Quotient rule (Derivative rules)
blurb: The quotient rule tells us how to differentiate functions that are quotients of other, more basic, functions. Unlike what you might guess, the derivative of f(x)/g(x) isn't f'(x)/g'(x). It's actually [f(x)⋅g'(x)-f'(x)⋅g(x)]/[g(x)]². Learn all about it here.

name: Rational functions differentiation (Derivative rules)
blurb: Solve problems involving the derivatives of rational functions. For example, find f'(1) of f(x)=(x+2)/(x-3).

name: Chain rule (Derivative rules)
blurb: The chain rule tells us how to differentiate composite functions: the derivative of f(g(x)) is f'(g(x))⋅g'(x). Brush up on your function composition skills and dive right into differentiating composite functions using the chain rule.

name: Radical functions differentiation (Derivative rules)
blurb: Solve problems involving the derivatives of radical functions. For example, find g'(5) of g(x)=∛(x²+5x-3).

name: Trigonometric functions differentiation (Derivative rules)
blurb: The quotient rule tells us how to find the derivatives of tan(x), cot(x), sec(x), and csc(x) using the derivatives of sin(x) and cos(x). The chain rule tells us how to find the derivatives of trigonometric functions whose argument is more elaborate than x, like sin(x²+1).

name: Strategy in differentiating functions (Derivative rules)
blurb: Differentiation has so many different rules and there are so many different ways to apply them! Let's take a broader look at differentiation and come up with a workflow that will allow us to find the derivative of any function, efficiently and without mistakes.

name: Optional videos | Derivative rules | AP Calculus BC | Khan Academy (Derivative rules)
blurb: Some things are not explicitly required by the AP Calculus BC course, but many teachers cover them and we also find them useful. We've gathered those optional videos here for your convenience.

name: Differentiating using multiple rules (Advanced derivatives)
blurb: Practice differentiating elaborate functions that require the use of the product, quotient, or chain rule, multiple times. For example, find the derivative of [x²⋅sin(x)]³.

name: Second derivatives (Advanced derivatives)
blurb: The derivative is a function, and as such it has its own derivative! The derivative of the derivative of a function is called the second derivative. Later, we will see how the second derivative gives us information about the behavior of the function. For now, we will focus on finding second derivatives.

name: Implicit differentiation (Advanced derivatives)
blurb: Some two-variable relationships cannot be turned into a function, like the circle equation x²+y²=4. Implicit differentiation allows us to find the derivative of y with respect to x, even in such equations.

name: Derivatives of inverse functions (Advanced derivatives)
blurb: Implicit differentiation provides us with the relationship between the derivatives of inverse functions: if f and g are inverse functions, then f’(x)=1/(g’(f(x)). Get comfortable working with this relationship.

name: Derivatives of inverse trigonometric functions (Advanced derivatives)
blurb: Implicit differentiation allows us to find the derivatives of the inverse trigonometric functions: arcsin(x), arccos(x), and arctan(x).

name: Derivatives of exponential functions (Advanced derivatives)
blurb: You might have heard about the mathematical constant 𝑒 that's approximately equal to 2.71828. If not, you will learn about it now. One of the most interesting things about 𝑒 is the fact that the derivative of 𝑒ˣ is... well... 𝑒ˣ. This allows us to find the derivative of any other exponential function.

name: Derivatives of logarithmic functions (Advanced derivatives)
blurb: ln(x) is the natural logarithm, which is the logarithm whose base is 𝑒. It turns out that the derivative of ln(x) is simply 1/x. This allows us to find the derivative of any logarithmic function.

name: Parametric & vector-valued function differentiation (Advanced derivatives)
blurb: Parametric and vector-valued functions basically take one input and return two outputs. How do we differentiate such functions? Find out here. (This content belongs in AP Calc BC only, and not in AP Calc AB.)

name: Polar functions differentiation (Advanced derivatives)
blurb: A polar curve is defined by a function 𝑟(θ), where 𝑟 (the distance from the origin) is given as a function of θ (the angle relative to the 𝘹-axis).  Learn how to find the rate of change of the curve with respect to the 𝘹-coordinate, the 𝘺-coordinate, or simply find the slope of the line tangent to the curve. (This content belongs in AP Calc BC only, and not in AP Calc AB.)

name: Optional videos | Advanced derivatives | AP Calculus BC | Khan Academy (Advanced derivatives)
blurb: Some things are not explicitly required by the AP Calculus BC course, but many teachers cover them and we also find them useful. We've gathered those optional videos here for your convenience.

name: Intermediate and extreme value theorems (Existence theorems)
blurb: The intermediate value theorem and the extreme value theorem describe properties of continuous functions. Learn how to establish whether they apply for a certain function on a certain interval, and use the intermediate value theorem to solve problems.

name: Mean value theorem (Existence theorems)
blurb: The mean value theorem describes a property of differentiable functions. Learn how to establish whether it applies for a certain function on a certain interval, and use it to solve problems.

name: L'Hôpital's rule (Using derivatives to analyze functions)
blurb: L'Hôpital's rule uses derivatives to helps us find limits where direct substitution ends with the indeterminate forms 0/0 or  ∞/∞.

name: Justifying properties of functions using the first derivative (Using derivatives to analyze functions)
blurb: Let's take a close look at how the behavior of a function is related to the behavior of its derivative. This type of reasoning is called "calculus-based reasoning." Learn how to apply it appropriately.

name: Critical points & intervals of increase or decrease (Using derivatives to analyze functions)
blurb: A function is increasing/decreasing whenever its derivative is positive/negative (correspondingly). Learn how we use this fact to find where functions are increasing/decreasing and about the main role critical points have in this process.

name: Finding relative extrema (first derivative test) (Using derivatives to analyze functions)
blurb: After we've learned about critical points, let's dive into the process of finding extremum (i.e. minimum and maximum) points. This process is often called the first derivative test.

name: Finding absolute extrema (Using derivatives to analyze functions)
blurb: While a function may have many relative maximum points, it has only one absolute maximum. Learn how we can use the first derivative, along with the extreme value theorem, to find the absolute maximum or minimum of functions.

name: Concavity & inflection points intro (Using derivatives to analyze functions)
blurb: A function is concave up/down whenever its derivative is increasing/decreasing (correspondingly). Graphically, a graph that's concave up is shaped like a cup, U, and a graph that's concave down is shaped like a cap, ∩. Inflection points are where the function changes concavity (from up to down and vice versa).

name: Justifying properties of functions using the second derivative (Using derivatives to analyze functions)
blurb: Let's take a closer look at how we use the second derivative of a function to justify the properties of that function.

name: Finding inflection points & analyzing concavity (Using derivatives to analyze functions)
blurb: Use the second derivative of a function to find the intervals where the function is concave up or down, and to find inflection points.

name: Connecting ƒ, ƒ’, and ƒ’’ (Using derivatives to analyze functions)
blurb: To conclude this unit, let's look at functions along with both their first derivative and their second derivative.

name: Optional videos | Using derivatives to analyze functions | AP Calculus BC | Khan Academy (Using derivatives to analyze functions)
