blurb: Some things are not explicitly required by the AP Calculus BC course, but many teachers cover them and we also find them useful. We've gathered those optional videos here for your convenience.

blurb: Differential calculus is all about instantaneous rate of change. Let's see how this can be used to solve real-world word problems.

name: Related rates intro (Applications of derivatives)
blurb: Related rates problems are word problems where we reason about the rate of change of a quantity by using information we have about the rate of change of another quantity that's related to it. Let's take our first venture into this world, see what defines a related rates problem and how to approach it.

name: Related rates problems (Applications of derivatives)
blurb: In the previous lesson we've learned what related rates problems are and how we approach their solution. In this lesson we will tackle a variety of related rates problems and solve, solve, solve!

name: Optimization (Applications of derivatives)
blurb: In optimization problems we are looking for a certain value within a possible range that yields the best results. For example, an optimization problem might ask us to find the dimensions of a rectangle that yield the most area for a given perimeter.

name: Motion problems (Applications of derivatives)
blurb: The rate of change of a moving object is its velocity, and the rate of change of the velocity is acceleration. This relationship, and the fact that derivatives give us the rate of change of a quantity, is commonly applied in motion word problems.

name: Planar motion (Applications of derivatives)
blurb: Solve problems about motion on a 2-dimensional plane using the power of differential calculus. For example, given the (x,y) position of a particle as a function of time (x(t),y(t)), find the particle's position when its acceleration is 0. (This content belongs in AP Calc BC only, and not in AP Calc AB.)

name: Riemann sums in summation notation (Accumulation and Riemann sums)
blurb: Are you familiar with left and right Riemann sums? Great. Do you know how to use summation notation? Even better. Now let's write the approximation of Riemann sums using summation notation.

blurb: The antiderivative of a function ƒ is a function whose derivative is ƒ. Antiderivatives are also called indefinite integrals.

name: Fundamental theorem of calculus (Antiderivatives and the fundamental theorem of calculus)
blurb: The fundamental theorem of calculus connects differential and integral calculus. It tells us that the definite integral of function ƒ over the interval [𝘢,𝘣] is 𝘍(𝘣)-𝘍(𝘢), where 𝘍 is any antiderivative of ƒ. blurb: To find antiderivatives we must apply the derivative rules we already know, only in reverse. We can find the antiderivatives of sin(x), cos(x), eˣ, and 1/x by asking which function has them as a derivative.

name: Finding definite integrals (Antiderivatives and the fundamental theorem of calculus)
blurb: Let's combine our knowledge of indefinite integrals with the fundamental theorem of calculus in order to find definite integrals!

name: Improper integrals (Antiderivatives and the fundamental theorem of calculus)
blurb: Improper integrals are like definite integrals, only unbounded from the left and/or right. And yes, some of them have finite values. An unbounded area with a finite size? That's calculus to you! (This content belongs in AP Calc BC only, and not in AP Calc AB.)

name: 𝘶-substitution (Antiderivatives and the fundamental theorem of calculus)
blurb: 𝘶-substitution essentially reverses the chain rule for derivatives. In other words, it helps us integrate composite functions.

name: Integration by parts (Antiderivatives and the fundamental theorem of calculus)
blurb: Integration by parts is the method of applying the product rule in reverse in order to find the integral of a product of functions. (This content belongs in AP Calc BC only, and not in AP Calc AB.)

name: Partial fraction expansion (Antiderivatives and the fundamental theorem of calculus)
blurb: Partial fractions are a useful algebraic tool to find the integrals of some rational functions. (This content belongs in AP Calc BC only, and not in AP Calc AB.)

name: Average value of a function (Antiderivatives and the fundamental theorem of calculus)
blurb: We're used to finding the average of a finite set of values, but what about the average of infinitely many values? Definite integrals can help us with that.

name: Interpreting behavior of 𝑔 from graph of 𝑔'=ƒ (Antiderivatives and the fundamental theorem of calculus)
blurb: In differential calculus we reasoned about the properties of a function ƒ based on information given about its derivative ƒ'. In integral calculus, instead of talking about functions and their derivatives, we will talk about functions and their antiderivatives.

name: Optional videos | Antiderivatives and the fundamental theorem of calculus | AP Calculus BC | Khan Academy (Antiderivatives and the fundamental theorem of calculus)
blurb: Some things are not explicitly required by the AP Calculus BC course, but many teachers cover them and we also find them useful. We've gathered those optional videos here for your convenience.

name: Differential equations intro (Differential equations)
blurb: Differential equations are equations that include both a function and its derivative. Unlike regular equations, the solutions of differential equations are functions. Learn how to check whether a function is a solution of a differential equation, and write differential equations that model a specific function behavior.

name: Separable differential equations (Differential equations)
blurb: One of the most common methods for solving differential equations is separation of variables. Learn how to use it and how to identify when an equation can be solved using separation of variables (we call such equations "separable equations").

name: Differential equations: specific solutions (Differential equations)
blurb: Usually, a differential equation has infinitely many possible solutions. If we're given some initial conditions, we can find a specific solution of the equation that also has these conditions.

name: Slope fields (Differential equations)
blurb: Slope fields are a clever way for approximating the solutions to a differential equation.

name: Euler's Method (Differential equations)
blurb: Euler's method is a relatively simple numerical tool for approximating values for solutions of differential equations. It is based on the understanding that a function behaves similar to its tangent around the point where the tangent touches the function. (This content belongs in AP Calc BC only, and not in AP Calc AB.)

name: Exponential models (Differential equations)
blurb: 𝘥𝘺/𝘥𝘹=𝘬⋅𝘺 is a differential equation that models the case where the rate of change of a quantity is proportional to the size of the quantity. The solution of such an equation is an exponential function.

name: Logistic models (Differential equations)
blurb: Can population grow exponentially forever? Malthus would say "no". Well, how do you model that mathematically? The logistic differential equation and logistic function are there to rescue us! (This content belongs in AP Calc BC only, and not in AP Calc AB.)

name: Word problems involving definite integrals (Applications of definite integrals)
blurb: Definite integrals are all about the accumulation of quantities. Let's see how they are applied in order to solve real-world word problems.

name: Motion problems (with integrals) (Applications of definite integrals)
blurb: In differential calculus we solved motion problems by differentiating the position function to find the velocity function. Now we go the opposite way. We also learn about the difference between speed and velocity, and between distance and displacement.

name: Area: vertical areas between curves (Applications of definite integrals)
blurb: Let's apply definite integrals to find the area below, above, and between curves.

name: Area: horizontal areas between curves (Applications of definite integrals)
blurb: With a slight manipulation, definite integrals can be used to find the area between a curve and the 𝘺-axis. In other words, we find the horizontal area to the right or to the left of the curve.

name: Area: polar curves (Applications of definite integrals)
blurb: We're used to finding the area under curves in the Cartesian plane, but integration can be used to find area defined by polar curves too. (This content belongs in AP Calc BC only, and not in AP Calc AB.)

name: Arc length (Applications of definite integrals)
blurb: Definite integrals can be used to find the length of a curve (this is often called "arc length"). Learn all about it here. (This content belongs in AP Calc BC only, and not in AP Calc AB.)

name: Volumes with known cross sections (Applications of definite integrals)
blurb: You know how to use definite integrals to find areas under curves. We now take that idea for a spin by thinking about the volumes of figures that are created when you rotate functions around various lines.

name: Volume: disc method (Applications of definite integrals)
blurb: The disc method is a method for calculating the volume of a solid of revolution by modeling the resulting three-dimensional shape as a stack of an infinite number of discs whose thickness is infinitely small.

name: Volume: washer method (Applications of definite integrals)
blurb: The washer method is an extension of the disc method for finding the volumes of more elaborate solids of revolution.

name: Volume: shell method (optional) (Applications of definite integrals)
blurb: Shell method offers us another way of calculating the volume of solids of revolution. Some solids are more easily found with the shell method. This method isn't required by the AP Calculus AB course, but many teachers cover it and we also find it useful.

name: Infinite sequences (Series)
blurb: When a sequence follows a certain rule (like "multiply by 1/2"), we can extend it indefinitely so it essentially has an infinite number of terms. In some cases, those terms approach a certain value, not unlike they way limits at infinity work! For example, if we start with 1 and keep multiplying by 1/2, the sequence will converge to 0. Learn about determining whether a sequence converges and to what value.

name: Finite geometric series (Series)
blurb: A finite geometric series is the sum of the first few terms of a geometric sequence. It turns out there's a quick way of finding such a sum, without having to really sum all the terms one by one.

name: Partial sums (Series)
blurb: Partial sums are another way to think of finite series. Why partial? Because they are a part of an infinite series! Thinking of the partial sums of an infinite series helps us analyze the infinite series itself.

name: Infinite geometric series (Series)
blurb: This might seem unbelievable at first, but for a certain class of geometric sequences, we can take the sum of all the infinite terms in the sequence and end up with a finite number! This sum is called an infinite geometric series. Learn when and how it can be found.

name: Basic convergence tests (Series)
blurb: How can we tell whether a series converges or diverges? There is an impressive repository of tools that can help us with this question. In this tutorial, we will cover the basic tests: n-th term test, integral test, and p-series test. These tests can help us later on with the more elaborate convergence tests.

name: Comparison tests (Series)
blurb: If the sum of a series must be smaller than the sum of another series that converges, then that series must converge as well. Makes sense, no? This notion, and similar ones, are at the basis of the comparison convergence tests.

name: Ratio & alternating series tests (Series)
blurb: The ratio test is one of the most useful tests for series convergence. Alternating series are a special class of series that have their own, very useful test for convergence.

name: Estimating infinite series (Series)
blurb: Finding the value a convergent infinite series converges to can be a very hard task, but we can always have an estimation. Learn how this is done and how we can tell how good our estimates are.

name: Power series intro (Series)
blurb: Power series is a sum of terms of the general form aₙ(x-a)ⁿ. As you can see, it's actually a function whose sum depends on the x-value. It is a generalization of geometric series, and an extremely useful class of series. Learn more about it in this tutorial.

name: Taylor & Maclaurin polynomials intro (Series)
blurb: Taylor polynomials are a very clever way of approximating any function with a polynomial. Maclaurin polynomials are a special class of Taylor polynomials. Learn how these polynomials work in this tutorial.

name: Maclaurin series of sin(x), cos(x), and eˣ (Series)
blurb: A Maclaurin series is essentially a Maclaurin polynomial with infinite terms. It turns out that the Maclaurin series of sin(x), cos(x), and eˣ return the exact same values as the functions themselves, for any x-value. Wow! Introduce yourselves to these special series and discover one of the most fascinating areas of all of mathematics!

name: Power series function representation (Series)
blurb: We already saw how Taylor and Maclaurin series can be used to represent a variety of functions. In this tutorial, we will expand the scope of functions that we can represent with power series, by enriching our toolkit!

name: Optional videos | Series | AP Calculus BC | Khan Academy (Series)
blurb: Some things are not explicitly required by the AP Calculus BC course, but many teachers cover them and we also find them useful. We've gathered those optional videos here for your convenience.

name: AP Calculus BC 2017 (AP Calculus BC solved exams)
blurb: Solved examples from AP Calculus BC 2017.

name: AP Calculus BC 2015 (AP Calculus BC solved exams)
blurb: Solved examples from AP Calculus BC 2015.

name: AP Calculus BC 2011 (AP Calculus BC solved exams)
blurb: Solved examples from AP Calculus BC 2011.

name: AP Calculus BC 2008 (AP Calculus BC solved exams)
blurb: Solved examples from AP Calculus BC 2008.

name: Spirals, Fibonacci and being a plant (Vi Hart)
blurb: You're feeling spirally today, and math class today is taking place in greenhouse #3...

name: Doodling in Math (Vi Hart)
blurb: Let's say you're me and you're in math class…

name: Hexaflexagons (Vi Hart)
blurb: Since it's shaped like a hexagon and flex rhymes with hex, hexaflexagon it is!

name: About pi and tau (Vi Hart)
blurb: When you want to make a circle, how is it done?  Well you probably will start with the radius one.

name: Singing (and noises) (Vi Hart)
blurb: The title says it all...

name: Mobius strips (Vi Hart)
blurb: Playing mathematically with strips!

name: Thanksgiving math (Vi Hart)
blurb: Mathed potatoes, Borromean onion rings, green bean matheroles and Turduckenen-duckenen (yes, you read that right)

name: Infinity . . . (Vi Hart)
blurb: Understanding infinity (all different kinds!). Countable and uncountable infinities. Bigger and smaller infinities.

name: Other cool stuff (Vi Hart)
blurb: Pythagoras, snakes, fractals, snowflakes...

name: Brain teasers (Puzzles)
blurb: Random logic puzzles and brain teasers.  Fun to do and useful for many job interviews!

name: Transformation Puzzles (Puzzles)
blurb: Random puzzles involving rotating, reflecting, and dilating polygons.

name: Lights Puzzles (Puzzles)
blurb: Try to light up all the tiles!

name: 2013 AMC 10 A (AMC 10)
blurb: The AMC 10 is part of the series of contests administered by the MAA American Mathematics Final five questions on the 2013 AMC 10 A. (Three of these problems are shared with the 2013 AMC 12 A.)

name: 2003 AIME (AIME)
blurb: (No description)

name: Probability warmups (Math warmups)
blurb: The 'problem of points' is a classic problem Fermat and Pascal famously debated in the 17th century. Their solution to this problem formed the basis of modern day probability theory. Now it's your turn to relive this challenge!

name: Distribution warmup (Math warmups)
blurb: Introduction to probability distributions, center, spread, and overall shape. In this warmup we will discover the binomial distribution!

name: Arithmetic warmups (Math warmups)
blurb: Arithmetic warmups

name: Introduction to rational numbers (Rational numbers)
blurb: You know what natural or counting numbers are, you know what whole numbers are, you even know what integers are. Do you want to learn what 'rational numbers' are? There is a clue in the name 'ratio'nal itself. Lets' jump in and learn more about this new type of numbers.

name: Solving equations with linear expressions on one side and numbers on the other (Linear equations in one variable)
blurb: We have already studied how to solve equations with variable on one side in class 7th, let's see how much you remember!

name: Some applications (Linear equations in one variable)
blurb: We have already studied how to frame and solve equations with variable on one side in class 7th, let's see how much you remember!

name: Solving linear equations with variables on both sides (Linear equations in one variable)
blurb: Learn how to solve linear equations that have the variable on both sides of the equation. For example, solve 2x+5=6x-3.

name: Reducing equations to simpler form (Linear equations in one variable)
blurb: Here we will study how to reduce complex linear equations to simpler form.

name: Some more applications (Linear equations in one variable)
blurb: Here we are going to deal with the framing of equations that variables on both sides of the equality.

name: Algebraic equations review (Linear equations in one variable)
blurb: Recollect what it means for equations with variables (algebraic equations) to be solved.

name: Polygons (Understanding quadrilaterals)
blurb: Polygons are many-sided figures, with sides that are line segments. Polygons are named according to the number of sides and angles they have. The most familiar polygons are the triangle, the rectangle, and the square. In this topic we will learn about the exterior angle property, interior angle property, and we will also practice with some exercises related to polygons.

name: Sum of the measures of the exterior angles of a polygon (Understanding quadrilaterals)
blurb: In this section we will learn about how to calculate the sum of the measure of the exterior angles of a polygon.

name: Kinds of quadrilaterals (Understanding quadrilaterals)
blurb: A quadrilateral is a four sides polygon with 4 angles. In this topic we will learn about the different kinds of quadrilaterals that can exist!

name: Copy of Quadrilateral proofs & angles (Understanding quadrilaterals)
blurb: Not all things with four sides have to be squares or rectangles!  We will now broaden our understanding of quadrilaterals.

name: Organizing data (Data Handling)
blurb: Usually, data available to us is in an unorganised form called raw data. To draw meaningful inferences, we need to organise the data systematically. We will learn about a couple of ways to do so.

name: Grouping Data (Data Handling)
blurb: In this topic we will learn about depicting and interpreting data on bar graphs, and pictographs.

name: Circle Graphs or Pie Charts (Data Handling)
blurb: In this topic we will learn about reading and depicting data on pie charts (circle graphs).

name: Chance and Probability (Data Handling)
blurb: Probability is the measure of the likeliness that an event will occur. In this topic we will learn about the basics of probability, frequency probability, independent events, compound probability and we will increase our understanding of this topic by looking at several examples and exercises.

name: Squares (Squares and square roots)
blurb: You get the square of a number when you multiply it with itself. Why is this called the Square? Does it have anything to do with the shape that you are already familiar with? Think about these questions as you learn more about squares.

name: Square roots (Squares and square roots)
blurb: The square root of a given number is an integer which yields the given number when multiplied by itself. You will now learn the symbol for a square root and also how to calculate and simplify square roots.

name: Estimating square roots (Squares and square roots)
blurb: In this topic we will learn how to estimate square roots when we cannot find the exact result, using a simple method.

name: Cube Roots (Cubes and cube roots)
blurb: In this topic we will learn about ways to find the cube root of a number and we will solve some exercises to practice this technique.

name: What are expressions? (Algebraic expressions and identities)
blurb: An algebraic expression is a statement built up from constants, variables, and the algebraic operations like addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division.

name: Addition and subtraction of algebraic expressions (Algebraic expressions and identities)
blurb: You have already studied how to add and subtract algebraic expressions in grade 7, let's see how much you remember!

name: Multiplying a monomial by a monomial (Algebraic expressions and identities)
blurb: Here we will learn multiplication of monomials by finding area of rectangle.

name: Multiplying a monomial by a polynomial (Algebraic expressions and identities)
blurb: Here we will learn how to multiply a monomial with a polynomial.

name: Multiplying a polynomial by a polynomial (Algebraic expressions and identities)
blurb: Here we will learn how to multiply a polynomial with a polynomial, a binomial with a binomial, and a binomial with a trinomial.

name: Standard identities (Algebraic expressions and identities)
blurb: An identity is an equality, which is true for all values of the variables in the equality. Here we will learn three standard identities- (a+b)^2=a^2+b^2+2ab, (a-b)^2=a^2+b^2-2ab, (a+b)(a-b)=a^2-b^2.

name: Mapping space around us (Visualising solid shapes)
blurb: A map depicts objects much smaller than they are in real life. A map is a great example of a scale drawing. In this tutorial, we'll take a mathematical look at the nature of scale drawings.

name: Let us recall (Mensuration)
blurb: We have studied about area of squares, rectangles, triangles, circles in previous classes; let's check how much you remember!

name: Area of a trapezium (Mensuration)
blurb: A quadrilateral which has one pair of opposite sides parallel is called trapezium. Here we will learn how to calculate area of trapezium

name: Area of general quadrilaterals (Mensuration)
blurb: Here we will learn how to calculate area of rhombus.

name: Area of polygons (Mensuration)
blurb: A polygon can be decomposed into different parts and the area of individual parts can be added to find the area of polygon.

name: Surface area (Mensuration)
blurb: Learn how to find the total area of the surfaces of 3D shapes. To do this, we wrap 3D shapes in 2D nets.

name: Volume of cube, cuboid, and cylinder (Mensuration)
blurb: In this topic we will learn about three dimensional shapes like Cubes, Cuboids, and Cylinders and we will learn about to calculate their volumes.

name: Powers with negative exponents (Exponents and powers)
blurb: In this topic we will learn about negative exponents, exponent properties involving quotients, zero, non-negative, and fractional exponents. We will also solve some exercises to have a better understanding of this topic.

name: Laws of exponents (Exponents and powers)
blurb: We have already studied laws of exponents in grade 7 but there powers of exponents used to be positive. Here we will study about the laws of exponents with negative powers. The laws which are applicable to positive powers of exponents shall be applicable on negative powers of  exponents as well.

name: Use of Exponents to Express Small Numbers in Standard Form (Exponents and powers)
blurb: Here we will learn how very very very large and very very very small numbers can be expressed easily using the standard form. This form has another fancier name, the scientific notation.

name: Direct and inverse proportions (Direct and inverse proportions)
blurb: Two values are said to be in direct proportion when increase in one results in a proportional increase in the other. Similarly, they are said to be in indirect proportion when the increase in one results in a proportional decrease in the other. Simply because one quantity increases when another one does, it doesn't mean they are in direct proportion. Dive in to learn more about what conditions are required for quantities to be in direct or inverse proportion and also look at a few examples to see why this concept is useful.

name: Introduction to factorization (Factorization)
blurb: Learn what factorization is all about, and warm-up by factoring some monomials.

name: Factoring polynomials by taking common factors (Factorization)
blurb: Learn how to take a common monomial factor out of a polynomial expression. For example, write 2x^3+6x^2+8x as (2x)(x^2+3x+4).

name: Factoring quadratics 1 (Factorization)
blurb: Learn how to factor quadratic expressions with a leading coefficient of 1. For example, factor x²+3x+2 as (x+1)(x+2).

name: Factoring quadratics: Difference of squares (Factorization)
blurb: Learn how to factor quadratics that have the "difference of squares" form. For example, write x²-16 as (x+4)(x-4). Learn how to identify this form in more elaborate expressions. For example, write 4x²-49 as (2x+7)(2x-7).

name: Factoring quadratics: Perfect squares (Factorization)
blurb: Learn how to factor quadratics that have the "perfect square" form. For example, write x²+6x+9 as (x+3)². Learn how to identify these forms in more elaborate expressions. For example, write 4x²+28x+49 as (2x+7)².

name: Factoring quadratics 2 (Factorization)
blurb: Learn how to factor quadratic expressions with a leading coefficient other than 1. For example, factor 2x²+7x+3 as (2x+1)(x+3).

name: Copy of Picture graphs, bar graphs, and histograms (Introduction to graphs)
blurb: Read and interpret picture graphs, bar graphs and histograms.  Also, make some graphs of your own!

name: Linear graphs (Introduction to graphs)
blurb: A series of points, discrete or continuous, forming a curve or surface, each of which represents a value of a variable make up a linear graph. It can also be called a network of lines connecting points. In this topic we will learn how to read a line graph.

name: Intro to the Coordinate plane (Introduction to graphs)
blurb: How can we communicate exactly where something is in two dimensions?  In this tutorial, we cover the basics of the coordinate plane and graphing points.

name: Coordinate plane word problems (Introduction to graphs)
blurb: Represent real world problems by graphing points in the first quadrant of the coordinate plane, and interpret coordinate values of points in the context of the situation.

name: Dependent & independent variables (Introduction to graphs)
blurb: Sometimes one variable depends on another. For example, the amount of money you make might depend on how many hours you work.

name: Some applications (Introduction to graphs)
blurb: In this topic we will learn about visualization of sequence relationships, interpreting & graphing relationships, interpreting relationships betweens patterns on a graph, and we will do some exercises which will help us understand the use of graphs a little better!

name: Numbers in general form (Playing with umbers)
blurb: Writing numbers in the expanded form, as '10a + b' or '100a + 10b + c'.

name: Tests of divisibility (Playing with umbers)
blurb: In grade 6, you learnt how to check divisibility by the following divisors: 10, 5, 2, 3, 6, 4, 8, 9, 11. You would have found the tests easy to do, but you may have wondered at the same time why they work. Now, in this chapter, we shall go into the “why” aspect of the above.

name: Math - Indian curriculum (Math)
blurb: (No description)

name: Learn with Hindi videos (Math)
blurb: (No description)

name: Learn math with Hindi videos (Math)
blurb: To help students who prefer to learn by watching Hindi videos, we've created courses where the videos are in Hindi but the practice exercises and review articles are in English. Click on any class below to get started.

name: Reflection of light (Light – reflection & refraction)
blurb: We see light bouncing all around us. It makes us see most of the things. In this lesson, we will explore the rule that this 'bouncing' of light obeys and talk about plane mirrors.

name: Concave & convex mirrors (Light – reflection & refraction)
blurb: We have experience and intuition for flat mirrors. But if we slightly curve these mirrors, a whole new world opens up. In this lesson we will explore the concave and convex mirrors and their applications.

name: Spherical mirrors (Light – reflection & refraction)
blurb: In this lesson, we will explore the shape of the concave and convex mirrors. We will also introduce some common terms that we will use a lot later on.

name: Spherical mirrors image formation (Light – reflection & refraction)
blurb: Let's learn how to construct images, when an object is kept in front of curved mirrors, using ray diagrams.

name: Sign conventions(10.2.3)[MVP]: (Light – reflection & refraction)
blurb: It's possible to address whether a mirror is concave or convex, whether an object is in front or behind the mirror, whether an image is real or virtual, with just positive and negative signs. Let's explore how in this lesson

name: Mirror formula derivation (Bonus) (Light – reflection & refraction)
blurb: let's see if we can figure out where an image would be, given where an object is kept in front of a curved mirror. In effect, we will end up deriving the famous mirror formula.

name: Mirror formula & magnification (Light – reflection & refraction)
blurb: Let's explore how to use the mirror formula to locate image positions when objects are kept in front of convex and concave mirrors.

name: Refraction of light (Light – reflection & refraction)
blurb: You may have seen that a straw, immersed in a glass of water, appears bent. It's actually the light, coming from the straw, that's bent. Light bends when it changes medium. It's a big deal because if it didn't, our eyes wouldn't work. So let's explore this bending of light in this lesson.

name: Absolute & relative refractive index (Light – reflection & refraction)
blurb: In this lesson, we will clarify the difference between absolute & relative refractive index. We will also see how to connect them.

name: Refraction of light through glass slab  (Light – reflection & refraction)
blurb: Let's explore what happens to a ray of light as it enters and exits a medium whose sides are parallel to each other.

name: Image formation by spherical lenses  (Light – reflection & refraction)
blurb: Let's explore how to construct images, when objects are kept in front of a lens, by drawing ray diagrams.

name: Lens formula derivation (Bonus) (Light – reflection & refraction)
blurb: Given the object location and focal length of a lens, let's figure out exactly where the image would be. We will be deriving the lens formula & magnification formula for lenses.

name: Lens formula & magnification (Light – reflection & refraction)
blurb: Let's explore how to use the lens formula to figure out where images are and how big they get when some objects are kept in front of lenses.

name: Dioptres & power of a lens (Light – reflection & refraction)
blurb: You may have heard about power related to your eye after a typical eye exam. Let's explore what this 'power' is and why define them that way.

name: The human eye  (The human eye and the colourful world)
blurb: Our eyes help us explore the beauty of nature with all her intricate details and colours. But what's our eye made of? How do we see things? In this lesson let's look at the structure of our eye and see what each part does.

name: Power of accommodation (The human eye and the colourful world)
blurb: Regardless of how far an object is, from us, our eyes can 'adjust' itself to focus on it. This 'adjusting' is called the 'Accommodation'. In this lesson, we will learn the details of this Accommodation. This will also help us explore why we can't focus on things which are too close.

name: Defects of vision and correction (The human eye and the colourful world)
blurb: We see people wearing glasses all the time. Without these glasses, some people cannot see far away objects (Myopia), some cannot see nearby objects (hypermetropia). Some cannot see nearby and far away objects (Presbyopia). Let's explore what causes these defects, and how these glasses correct them.

name: Defects of vision and correction numerical  (The human eye and the colourful world)
blurb: In this lesson, we will solve numerical problems to identify and correct the defects in human eyes.

name: Dispersion of light  (The human eye and the colourful world)
blurb: Rainbows are beautiful and have been a mystery for quite a long time in the past. In this lesson, let's explore what causes them by studying the dispersion of light by prisms.

name: Dispersion of light in prism (The human eye and the colourful world)
blurb: Why does dispersion happen in prism but not in window panes? How did we realize that the prism only separates white light into its constituent colors but not creates those color? In this lesson, we will explore these questions.

name: Atmospheric refraction (The human eye and the colourful world)
blurb: Twinkle twinkle little star, how I wonder what you are. Have you wondered what causes the twinkling of stars? Why don't planets twinkle? Also, why does the sun look squashed at the horizon? In this lesson, we will explore how our atmosphere is responsible for all of this.

name: Scattering of light and Tyndall effect (The human eye and the colourful world)
blurb: Sometimes you can see a beam of light from car headlights, sometimes you don't, sometimes the sun is yellow, sometimes it's red, the sky is blue but the clouds are white. In this lesson, we will explore one single reason for these seemly disparate things.

name: Coming soon (Electricity)
blurb: We are actively working on this chapter. It will be published soon.

name: Coming soon (Magnetic effects of electric current)
blurb: (No description)

name: Physics and its laws (Physical world)
blurb: Get a big picture overview of what physics is, and get recommendations for prerequisite knowledge.

name: Physical quantities and their measurement (Units and measurement)
blurb: (No description)

name: Scientific notation (Units and measurement)
blurb: (No description)

name: Significant figures (Units and measurement)
blurb: (No description)

name: Copy of Introduction to logarithms (Fundamental math concepts for physics (Prerequisite))
blurb: Learn how we define logarithms and use this definition in order to evaluate various logarithms. For example, evaluate log_2(8) as 3 by realizing that 2^3=8.

name: The constant e and the natural logarithm (Fundamental math concepts for physics (Prerequisite))
blurb: Learn about a very special constant in math that has a pivotal role in the world of exponential and logarithmic function, the constant e.

name: Slope (Fundamental math concepts for physics (Prerequisite))
blurb: Learn about slope (the steepness of a line) and how to find it.

name: Basics of trigonometry (Fundamental math concepts for physics (Prerequisite))
blurb: (No description)

name: The unit circle definition of sine, cosine, and tangent (Fundamental math concepts for physics (Prerequisite))
blurb: Learn how the trigonometric ratios are extended to all real numbers using algebra. Start solving simple problems that involve this new definition of the trigonometric functions.

name: The graphs of sine, cosine, and tangent (Fundamental math concepts for physics (Prerequisite))
blurb: Learn how the graphs of y=sin(θ), y=cos(θ), and y=tan(θ) look, using the unit circle definition of the functions.

name: Basic trigonometric identities (Fundamental math concepts for physics (Prerequisite))
blurb: Learn about very useful trigonometric identities that arise by considering different properties of the unit circle definition.

name: Evaluating functions (Fundamental math concepts for physics (Prerequisite))
blurb: Learn how to find the value of a function for a given input value.

name: Inputs and outputs of a function (Fundamental math concepts for physics (Prerequisite))
blurb: Extend your understanding of the relationship between the inputs of a function and the outputs of that function.

name: Maximum and minimum points (Fundamental math concepts for physics (Prerequisite))
blurb: Learn about maximum and minimum points of functions.

name: Intervals where a function is positive, negative, increasing, or decreasing (Fundamental math concepts for physics (Prerequisite))
blurb: Learn about features of functions that have distinct graphical representations: intervals where the function is always positive or always negative, and intervals where the function is always increasing or always decreasing.

name: Interpreting features of graphs (Fundamental math concepts for physics (Prerequisite))
blurb: Interpret the graphs of functions in terms of the contexts that are modeled by the functions.

name: Slope (Differentiation for physics (Prerequisite))
blurb: Learn about slope (the steepness of a line) and how to find it.

name: Introduction to differential calculus (Differentiation for physics (Prerequisite))
blurb: What's differential calculus all about? An answer to this question lies just right here.

name: Secant lines (Differentiation for physics (Prerequisite))
blurb: Gain some experience working with secant lines. This will help us on our journey to find a formal definition for the derivative.

name: Limit basics (Differentiation for physics (Prerequisite))
blurb: A limit is the value that a function or sequence "approaches" as the input or index approaches some value. In this tutorial, we supply an intuitive understanding of limits.

name: Derivative as a limit (Differentiation for physics (Prerequisite))
blurb: There are two ways to define the derivative of function f at point x=a. The formal definition is the limit of [f(a+h)-f(x)]/h as h approaches 0, and the alternative definition is the limit of [f(x)-f(a)]/(x-a) as x approaches a. Make introduction with these two definitions.

name: Using the formal definition of derivative (Differentiation for physics (Prerequisite))
blurb: Learn how we can use their formal definition in order to find the derivatives of specific functions. For example, we find the derivative of f(x)=x² at x=3, or for any x-value.

name: Derivative as a function (Differentiation for physics (Prerequisite))
blurb: This may blow your mind, but the derivative of a function is a function in itself! Get comfortable in thinking about the derivative as a function that is separate from, but tightly related to, its original function.

name: Basic differentiation rules (Differentiation for physics (Prerequisite))
blurb: If you ever tried to find derivatives using their formal definition, you probably know how tedious that may be. Fortunately, we have ways for finding derivatives much quicker, using differentiation rules! Make your first steps in this fascinating world by working with the more basic rules. For example, the derivative of [f(x)+g(x)] is f'(x)+g'(x), and the derivative of k⋅f(x) is k⋅f'(x).

name: Power rule (Differentiation for physics (Prerequisite))
blurb: The power rule says that the derivative of xⁿ is n⋅xⁿ⁻¹. It allows us to quickly find the derivative of any polynomial, and it doesn't even stop there! Make introduction with this simple but powerful rule.

name: Polynomial functions differentiation (Differentiation for physics (Prerequisite))
blurb: Put the power rule to use by differentiating various polynomials.

name: Sine & cosine derivatives (Differentiation for physics (Prerequisite))
blurb: The derivative of sin(x) is cos(x) and the derivative of cos(x) is -sin(x). How convenient! Practice differentiating functions that include sine and cosine.

name: Product rule (Differentiation for physics (Prerequisite))
blurb: The product rule says that the derivative of the product f(x)g(x) is f'(x)g(x)+f(x)g'(x). This helps us find the derivative of a function which is a product of two other, more basic, functions.

name: Chain rule (Differentiation for physics (Prerequisite))
blurb: The chain rule says that the derivative of the composite function f(g(x)) is f'(g(x))⋅g'(x). This helps us find the derivative of a composite function. It may be slightly hard to grasp, but its importance cannot be overstated!

name: Copy of Antiderivatives (Integration for physics (Prerequisite))
blurb: If f' is the derivative of f, then f is the antiderivative of f'. To find the antiderivative of a function we need to perform some kind of reverse differentiation. Learn about it here.

name: Indefinite integrals of common functions (Integration for physics (Prerequisite))
blurb: Indefinite integrals (or antiderivatives) are really just backward differentiation. Therefore, the indefinite integral of eˣ is eˣ+c, the indefinite integral of 1/x is ln(x)+c, the indefinite integral of sin(x) is -cos(x)+c, and the indefinite integral of cos(x) is sin(x)+c.

name: Definite integral as area (Integration for physics (Prerequisite))
blurb: Introducing the definite integral. It's basically a way to represent the area under a given curve with left-hand and right-hand bounds.

name: Riemann sums (Integration for physics (Prerequisite))
blurb: Riemann sums is the name of a family of methods we can use to approximate the area under a curve. Learn about the different ways and how they are constructed.

name: Definite integral evaluation (Integration for physics (Prerequisite))
blurb: The fundamental theorem tells us how we can evaluate definite integrals. Now let us  put this to use and evaluate some!

name: u-substitution (Integration for physics (Prerequisite))
blurb: u-substitution is an extremely useful technique. Harnessing the power of the chain rule, it allows us to define a new variable (common denoted by the letter u) as a function of x, and obtain a new expression which is (hopefully) easier to integrate.

name: Area & net change (Integration for physics (Prerequisite))
blurb: The area under a rate function gives the net change. This result of the fundamental theorem of calculus is being put here to use with some real-world problems.

name: Distance, displacement, and coordinate systems (Motion in a straight line)
blurb: We'll review the concepts of distance and displacement and use different ways to visualize motion such as graphs and number lines. So strap your seatbelts (actually this might not be necessary since we don't plan on decelerating in this tutorial) and prepare for a gentle ride of foundational physics knowledge.

name: Average velocity and average speed (Motion in a straight line)
blurb: This tutorial is the backbone of your understanding of kinematics (i.e., the motion of objects).  You might already know that distance = rate x time.  This tutorial essentially reviews that idea with a vector lens (we introduce you to vectors here as well).  So strap your belts (actually this might not be necessary since we don't plan on decelerating in this tutorial) and prepare for a gentle ride of foundational physics knowledge.

name: Velocity and speed from graphs (Motion in a straight line)
blurb: We'll review the concepts of instantaneous velocity and speed and use velocity-time and position-time graphs to analyze motion.

name: Acceleration (Motion in a straight line)
blurb: In a world full of unbalanced forces (which you learn more about when you study Newton's laws), you will have acceleration (which is the rate in change of velocity).  Whether you're thinking about how fast a Porsche can get to 60mph or how long it takes for a passenger plane to get to the necessary speed for flight, this tutorial will help.

name: Kinematic formulas (Motion in a straight line)
blurb: We don't believe in memorizing formulas and neither should you (unless you want to live your life as a shadow of your true potential).  This tutorial builds on what we know about displacement, velocity and acceleration to solve problems in kinematics (including projectile motion problems).  Along the way, we derive (and re-derive) some of the classic formulas that you might see in your physics book.

name: Objects in freefall (Motion in a straight line)
blurb: We don't believe in memorizing formulas and neither should you (unless you want to live your life as a shadow of your true potential).  This tutorial builds on what we know about displacement, velocity and acceleration to solve problems in kinematics (including projectile motion problems).  Along the way, we derive (and re-derive) some of the classic formulas that you might see in your physics book.

name: Rectilinear motion (integral calc) (Motion in a straight line)
blurb: Solve problems about motion along a line using the power of integral calculus. For example, given the velocity of a particle as a function of time v(t), find how much the particle has traveled over a given time period.

name: Relative velocity in 1D (Motion in a straight line)
blurb: Let's understand and learn how to solve problems involving relative motion and frames of reference when the motion happens on a straight line.

name: Vector basics (Vectors (Prerequisite))
blurb: Learn the basics of vectors, like that a vector has both magnitude and direction.

name: Magnitude of vectors (Vectors (Prerequisite))
blurb: Find the magnitude of a vector given in component form.

name: Scalar multiplication (Vectors (Prerequisite))
blurb: Multiply a vector by a scalar to get a new vector.

name: Vector addition and subtraction (Vectors (Prerequisite))
blurb: Combine two vectors by adding or subtracting them to get a new vector.

name: Combined vector operations (Vectors (Prerequisite))
blurb: Use both scalar multiplication and vector addition or subtraction in the same problem!

name: Unit vectors (Vectors (Prerequisite))
blurb: Learn about special vectors called unit vectors that have a magnitude of 1.

name: Vectors in magnitude and direction form (Vectors (Prerequisite))
blurb: Think about how we can represent vectors using their magnitude and direction instead of their components.

name: Component form of vectors (Vectors (Prerequisite))
blurb: Convert vectors from magnitude and direction form to component form.

name: Adding vectors in magnitude and direction form (Vectors (Prerequisite))
blurb: Learn how to add two vectors together that are in magnitude and direction form. We can always use our old friend component form!

name: Applications of vectors (Vectors (Prerequisite))
blurb: Apply what you've learned about vectors so far to solve some fun word problems.

name: Introduction to vectors and two-dimensional motion (Motion in a plane)
blurb: We'll review how to add, subtract, and break down vectors graphically. These skills will be helpful for analyzing motion in two-dimensions.

name: Analyzing vectors using trigonometry (Motion in a plane)
blurb: We'll review how to analyze vectors using trigonometry. You might find it helpful to brush up on sine and cosine functions.

name: Review: Unit vectors (Motion in a plane)
blurb: (No description)

name: Graphs of projectile motion (Motion in a plane)
blurb: We'll use graphs to analyze projectile motion in the horizontal and vertical directions.

name: Horizontally launched projectiles (Motion in a plane)
blurb: This lesson builds on one and two-dimensional kinematics to answer questions about horizontally launched objects, such as how long and far something can travel.

name: Projectiles launched at an angle (Motion in a plane)
blurb: This lesson tackles a fundamental question, how do we launch things as far as possible? We'll build our intuition for finding optimal launch angles with a little bit of trig.

name: Projectiles launched from/to a height (Motion in a plane)
blurb: Let's escape from the binds of one-dimension (where we were forced to launch things straight up) and start launching at angles.  With a little bit of trig (might want to review sin and cos) we'll be figuring out just how long and far something can travel.

name: Relative motion in 2D (Motion in a plane)
blurb: Let's learn how to solve problems involving relative velocity and frames of reference when the motion happens on a plane.

name: Copy of Introduction to uniform circular motion (Motion in a plane)
blurb: In this lesson, we will learn how to describe the motion of objects moving in a circle using angular motion variables such as angular velocity and angular displacement.

name: Centripetal acceleration (Motion in a plane)
blurb: Is something moving in a circle at a constant speed accelerating?  If so, in what direction? In this lesson, we'll consider centripetal acceleration in more detail.

name: Introduction to forces and free body diagrams (Laws of motion)
blurb: This lesson reviews different types of forces and how to draw free body diagrams to represent the forces on an object.

name: Newton's first law: Mass and inertia (Laws of motion)
blurb: Newton's first law, also called the law of inertia, says that there must be a net external force on an object for there to be any change in velocity.

name: Newton's second law (Laws of motion)
blurb: Newton's second law tells us how much an object will accelerate for a given net force.

name: Newton's third law (Laws of motion)
blurb: Newton's third law says that forces always occur in pairs. For example, if the Earth is pulling down on you, you are also pulling up on the Earth with a force of equal magnitude and opposite direction.

name: Normal force and contact force (Laws of motion)
blurb: A dog is balancing on one arm on my head.  Is my head applying a force to the dog's hand?  If it weren't, wouldn't there be nothing to offset the pull of gravity causing the acrobatic dog to fall?  What would we call this force?  Can we have a general term for the component of a contact force that acts perpendicular to the plane of contact?  These are absolutely normal questions to ask.

name: Balanced and unbalanced forces (Laws of motion)
blurb: You will often hear physics professors be careful to say "net force" or "unbalanced force" rather than just "force".  Why?  This tutorial explains why and might give you more intuition about Newton's laws in the process.

name: Slow sock on Lubricon VI (Laws of motion)
blurb: This short tutorial will have you dealing with orbiting frozen socks in order to understand whether you understand Newton's Laws.  We also quiz you a bit during the videos just to make sure that you aren't daydreaming about what you would do with a frozen sock.

name: Inclined planes (Laws of motion)
blurb: What forces are acting on you when you slide down a frictionless ramp? In this lesson we'll learn how to analyze the motion of an object on an inclined plane.

name: Friction (Laws of motion)
blurb: We've all slid down slides/snow-or-mud-covered-hills/railings at some point in our life (if not, you haven't really lived) and noticed that the smoother the surface the more we would accelerate (try to slide down a non-snow-or-mud-covered hill).  This tutorial looks into this in some depth.  We'll look at masses on inclined planes and think about static and kinetic friction.

name: Tension (Laws of motion)
blurb:
Bad commute? Baby crying?  Bills to pay?  Looking to take a bath with some Calgon (do a search on YouTube for context) to ease your tension?  This tutorial has nothing (actually little, not nothing) to do with that.

So far, most of the forces we've been dealing with are forces of "pushing"--contact forces at the macro level because of atoms not wanting to get to close at the micro level.  Now we'll deal with "pulling" force or tension (at a micro level this is the force of attraction between bonded atoms).

name: Treating systems (Laws of motion)
blurb: When two or more objects must move with the same magnitude of acceleration (like masses on strings, or boxes pushed into each other), we can treat the entire system as a single object when finding the acceleration.

name: Centripetal forces (Laws of motion)
blurb: Learn how to identify centripetal forces and how they relate to speed, tension, normal force, and radius.

name: Centripetal force problem solving (Laws of motion)
blurb: Learn how to deal with centripetal forces and how to relate it to speed, tension, normal force, and radius.

name: Introduction to linear momentum and impulse (Laws of motion)
blurb: In this lesson, we'll learn about momentum and how it is transferred.  Whether you're playing pool (or "billiards") or deciding whether you want to get tackled by the 150 kg person, these concepts are of key importance.

name: Conservation of linear momentum and elastic collision (Laws of motion)
blurb: Depending on your view of things, this may be the most violent of our tutorials.  Things will crash and collide.  We'll learn about momentum and how it is transferred.  Whether you're playing pool (or "billiards") or deciding whether you want to get tackled by the 300lb. guy, this tutorial is of key importance.

name: Collision in 2D (Laws of motion)
blurb: (No description)

name: Introduction to work (Work, energy and power)
blurb: You're doing a lot more work than you realize (most of which goes unpaid).  This lesson will introduce the definition of work we use in physics, which will give us another way to think about forces and movement.

name: Kinetic energy (Work, energy and power)
blurb: Kinetic energy is the energy an object has because of its motion. We'll talk about how to calculate kinetic energy, and how kinetic energy is related to work.

name: Work-energy theorem (Work, energy and power)
blurb: (No description)

name: Conservative forces and gravitational potential energy (Work, energy and power)
blurb: Learn about what gravitational energy means and how it is related to conservative forces such as gravity.

name: Spring potential energy and Hooke's law (Work, energy and power)
blurb: Weighing machines of all sorts employ springs that take a certain amount of force to keep compressed or stretched to a certain point.  Hooke's law will give us all the tools to weigh in on the subject ourselves and spring into action (pun intended)!

name: Conservation of energy (Work, energy and power)
blurb: Learn about the law of conservation of energy, and how it can be useful for solving physics problems.

name: Work and energy problems involving friction (Work, energy and power)
blurb: (No description)

name: Power (Work, energy and power)
blurb: Learn what power means and how we use it in physics to describe the rate of energy transfer.

name: Elastic and inelastic collisions (Work, energy and power)
blurb: Categorizing the different types of collisions can be useful. Here, you'll learn what it means for a collision to be elastic or inelastic and what that implies mathematically.

name: Centre of mass (System of particles and rotational motion)
blurb: Learn what center of mass means, why it's useful, and how to calculate it.

name: Introduction to angular motion (System of particles and rotational motion)
blurb: Learn what angular displacement, angular velocity, and angular acceleration mean, as well as how they relate to their linear counterparts.

name: Angular kinematics (System of particles and rotational motion)
blurb: Learn the relationships between angular displacement, angular velocity, and angular acceleration using the rotational kinematic formulas.

name: Torque and equilibrium (System of particles and rotational motion)
blurb: Anyone who has ever opened a door has an intuitive understanding of torque. In this lesson, we'll explore why and how objects rotate using the concepts of torque and rotational equilibrium.

name: Cross product and torque (System of particles and rotational motion)
blurb: (No description)

name: Rotational inertia and angular second law (System of particles and rotational motion)
blurb: In this lesson, we'll learn how the distribution of mass can impact how easily the angular velocity can be changed around an axis. This property is called rotational inertia.

name: Rotational kinetic energy (System of particles and rotational motion)
blurb: Does a baseball have more kinetic energy if it is spinning? In this lesson, we'll learn how to determine the rotational kinetic energy of an object so we can figure out how much more energy the baseball has.

name: Angular momentum and angular impulse (System of particles and rotational motion)
blurb: In this lesson, we'll learn about angular momentum and angular impulse, and how these quantities are related to translational (or linear) momentum.

name: Conservation of angular momentum (System of particles and rotational motion)
blurb: Angular momentum is constant where there is no net torque, just like how linear momentum is constant when there is no net force. In this lesson, we'll learn about the conservation of angular momentum and how to apply the new conservation law to solve problems.

name: Newton's law of gravitation (Gravitation)
blurb:
Why are you sticking to your chair (ignoring the spilled glue)?  Why does the earth orbit the sun (or does it)? How high could I throw my dog on the moon?

Gravitation defines our everyday life and the structure of the universe.  This tutorial will introduce it to you in the Newtonian sense.

name: Gravitational potential energy (Gravitation)
blurb: Until this lesson, we have always assumed the gravitational field is uniform and potential energy is equal to mgh. Now we'll learn how to find the gravitational potential energy at large distances when these assumptions no longer hold.

name: Stress strain and modulus of elasticity (Mechanical properties of solids)
blurb: The best way to quantify elastic property of any material is to talk about 'stress' and 'strain'. Although we often use these words in our day to day life, they have a very concrete definition and meaning in physics. In this lesson, we will learn exactly what they are.

name: Shear and bulk stress (Mechanical properties of solids)
blurb: Sometimes forces acting on a body could twist the body or even squeeze it. In these cases, materials respond differently. So, in this lesson, we will introduce these new terms called shear and bulk and see how to take care of them.

name: Application of elastic properties (Bonus)  (Mechanical properties of solids)
blurb: Understanding the elastic behaviour of materials have great engineering applications. Let's look at some of them which may be familiar to you.

name: Density and pressure (Mechanical properties of fluid)
blurb: In these videos and articles you'll learn the definitions of density and specific gravity. You'll also learn the definition of pressure, how it relates to force and area, and how to determine the pressure within a fluid. The difference between absolute and gauge pressure will also be discussed.

name: Buoyant force and Archimedes' principle (Mechanical properties of fluid)
blurb: In these videos and articles you'll learn how pressure variations cause a buoyant force on a submerged object and how to calculate the value of the buoyant force. You'll also learn the meaning of Archimedes' principle.

name: Fluid dynamics (Mechanical properties of fluid)
blurb: Flowing fluids behave different from static fluids. In these videos and articles you'll learn about volume flow rate and the equation of continuity. You'll also learn how Bernoulli's principle and Bernoulli's equation relate the pressure and speed of a flowing fluid. The effects of turbulence and viscosity will also be discussed.

name: Viscosity (Mechanical properties of fluid)
blurb: (No description)

name: Surface tension (Mechanical properties of fluid)
blurb: (No description)

name: Temperature, kinetic theory, and the ideal gas law (Thermal properties of matter)
blurb: In these videos and articles you'll learn about the Celsius and Kelvin temperature scales. The definition of a mole of a substance will be given. You'll also learn how the ideal gas law relates the pressure, volume, and temperature of a gas. Lastly, you'll learn how the Maxwell-Boltzmann distribution gives the probability of finding a gas molecule moving at a specific speed.

name: Specific heat and heat transfer (Thermal properties of matter)
blurb: In these videos and articles you'll learn the definition of specific heat and latent heat and how to use them in problem solving. You'll also learn the 3 modes of heat transfer; conduction, convection, and radiation. Lastly, we will look in more depth at how the rate of thermal conduction through a material depends on the material's thickness, conductivity constant, area, and difference in temperature.

name: Thermal expansion in solids (Thermal properties of matter)
blurb: (No description)

name: Thermal expansion in fluids (Thermal properties of matter)
blurb: (No description)

name: Thermal stress (Thermal properties of matter)
blurb: (No description)

name: Zeroth and first law of thermodynamics (Thermodynamics)
blurb: (No description)

name: Work from PV graph and internal energy (Thermodynamics)
blurb: (No description)

name: Thermodynamic processes and Carnot cycle (Thermodynamics)
blurb: (No description)

name: Ideal gas equation (Kinetic theory)
blurb: In this tutorial, Sal shows you how to use the ideal gas equation in calculations.

name: Kinetic molecular theory of gases (Kinetic theory)
blurb: 4A: Though we may not be able to always visualize them, gases are comprised of atoms and molecules. We’ll explore the molecular behavior that determines the pressure and temperature of a gas. In addition, we will discuss the first law of thermodynamics and heat capacity.

name: Introduction to simple harmonic motion (Oscillations)
blurb: In this lesson, we'll develop some intuition for what a simple harmonic oscillator is, why they oscillate, and how to analyze and model the motion of spring-mass systems and simple pendulums.

name: Spring-mass systems (Oscillations)
blurb: In this lesson, we'll learn more about how simple harmonic motion describes the motion of a mass on a spring.

name: Simple pendulums (Oscillations)
blurb: In this lesson, we'll learn more about how simple harmonic motion describes the motion of a simple pendulum.

name: Energy in a simple harmonic oscillator (Oscillations)
blurb: In this lesson, we'll learn about how the total energy, potential energy, and kinetic energy of a simple harmonic oscillator change over time.

name: Simple harmonic motion (with calculus) (Oscillations)
blurb: In these videos Sal explores how to deal with simple harmonic motion when using calculus.

name: Introduction to waves (Waves)
blurb: In this lesson, you'll learn the definition of a wave and the difference between transverse and longitudinal waves.

name: Wave characteristics (Waves)
blurb: In this lesson, you'll learn the definition of the basic terms used to characterize waves such as amplitude, period, frequency, and wavelength.

name: Wave interference (Waves)
blurb: In this lesson, we'll discuss how waves can overlap to produce constructive or destructive interference.

name: Standing waves (Waves)
blurb: In this lesson, we'll discuss how and why standing waves occur, and well as how to determine the wavelength and frequency for a standing wave.

name: Sound (Waves)
blurb: In these videos and articles you'll see visualizations of the propagation of sound waves, along with a visual definition of a sound wave's amplitude, period, frequency, and wavelength. You'll also learn how the speed of sound depends on the different characteristics of the medium. It will be shown how Mach numbers characterize faster than sound travel and their relationship to sonic booms. Also, you'll learn about the decibel scale, why sounds get softer, and how ultrasound medical imaging works.

name: Beats and interference of sound waves (Waves)
blurb: In this lesson, we'll discuss what happens when sound waves with different frequencies overlap.

name: The Doppler effect (Waves)
blurb: In these videos and articles you'll learn how the Doppler effect causes a change in the measured frequency of a moving source of sound or moving sound detector. You'll also learn how to calculate the observed frequency using the formula for the Doppler effect when dealing with either a moving source of sound or a moving sound detector.

name: Electric charge (Electric charges and field)
blurb: In this lesson, we'll review protons and electrons and start discussing the properties of electric charge, including how charge is quantized.

name: Conservation of charge (Electric charges and field)
blurb: In this lesson, we'll learn about the law of conservation of charge, insulators and conductors, and how charge is transferred.

name: Coulomb's law and electric force (Electric charges and field)
blurb: In this lesson, we'll learn how Coulomb's law relates the electric force to charge and separation distance. We'll also compare the electric force and gravitational force.

name: Electric field (Electric charges and field)
blurb: In these videos and articles you'll learn what an electric field is and how to calculate the value of the electric field for a point charge and an infinite sheet.

name: Electric potential energy, electric potential, and voltage (Electrostatic potential and capacitance)
blurb: In these videos and articles you'll learn the difference between electric potential, electric potential energy, and voltage. You'll also learn how to calculate the electric potential at a point in space, electric potential energy between two charges, and voltage between two points in space.

name: Circuits with capacitors (Electrostatic potential and capacitance)
blurb: In these videos and articles you'll learn how capacitors store charge and energy. You'll also learn the relationships between capacitance, charge stored, energy stored, and voltage across a capacitor. Techniques for finding the equivalent capacitance for capacitors in series and parallel will be discussed. Lastly, you'll learn how a dielectric can change the amount of charge, voltage, and capacitance of a capacitor.

name: Electric current and voltage (Current electricity)
blurb: (No description)

name: Resistivity, and Ohm's law (Current electricity)
blurb: In this lesson, you'll learn how Ohm's law relates the voltage across a resistor, the current through a resistor, and the resistance of the resistor. We'll also start talking about circuits and the resistivity of materials.

name: Electric power and DC circuits (Current electricity)
blurb: In this lesson, we'll learn about power used by a resistor and how to interpret circuit diagrams.

name: Kirchhoff's junction rule (Current electricity)
blurb: Learn how to analyze the current flow in a DC circuit using Kirchhoff junction rule (or current law).

name: Kirchhoff's loop rule (Current electricity)
blurb: Learn how to analyze the voltage in a DC circuit using Kirchhoff loop rule (or voltage law).

name: Series and parallel resistors (Current electricity)
blurb: In these videos and articles you'll learn how Ohm's law relates the voltage across a resistor, the current through a resistor, and the resistance of the resistor. You'll also learn how resistors in series and parallel combine to form an equivalent resistance. The resistivity of materials, power used by a resistor, and how to use voltmeters and ammeters will also be discussed.

name: DC Circuit analysis (Current electricity)
blurb: Learn how to analyze a more complicated DC circuit using the strategies we've learned so far, including Kirchhoff's laws and Ohm's law.

name: Cross product (Prerequisite) (Moving charges and magnetism)
blurb: (No description)

name: Magnets and Magnetic Force (Moving charges and magnetism)
blurb: In these videos and articles you'll learn how the magnitude of the magnetic force depends on the charge, velocity, and magnetic field. You'll also learn how to use the right hand rule to determine the direction of the magnetic force. Lastly, it will be explained how to determine the magnetic force on a current carrying wire.

name: Magnetic field created by a current (Moving charges and magnetism)
blurb: In these videos and articles you'll learn how the magnetic field created by a long straight wire depends on the current and distance from the wire. You'll also learn how to use the right hand rule to determine the direction of the magnetic field. The magnetic force between two current carrying wires will be discussed as well as the induced current in a wire moving through a magnetic field.

name: Electric motors (Moving charges and magnetism)
blurb: In these videos and articles you'll learn how electric motors rely on a magnetic force that can cause a torque which rotates a loop of wire. You'll also learn how commutators allow the direction the the current to switch, which causes the motor to continue turning.

name: Magnetic flux and Faraday's law (Electromagnetic induction)
blurb: In these videos and articles you'll learn how magnetic flux depends on magnetic field strength, area, and angle. You'll also learn how Faraday's law states that a changing magnetic flux can cause an induced current. It will be shown how Lenz's law can allow you to find the direction of the induced current. Example problems will also be solved to show how to apply Faraday's law and Lenz's law.

name: Introduction to light waves (Electromagnetic waves)
blurb: In these videos and articles you'll learn about the different categories of the electromagnetic spectrum; radio waves, microwaves, infrared, visible, ultraviolet, x-ray, and gamma ray. You'll also learn what it means for light to be polarized, and how polarized light can allow for the creation of 3D movies.

name: Reflection and refraction (Ray optics and optical instruments)
blurb: In these videos and articles, you'll learn how to determine the angle of reflected light and the definition of specular and diffuse reflection.

name: Mirrors (Ray optics and optical instruments)
blurb: In these videos and articles, you'll learn how curved spherical mirrors create images. The definitions of real and virtual images will be discussed. You'll also learn how to use the mirror equation to determine the image distance, magnification, image height, and object height when dealing with curved mirrors. The sign convention for positive and negative image distance, object distance, and focal length will be discussed.

name: Refraction at plane surfaces (Ray optics and optical instruments)
blurb: You may have seen a straw dipped in a glass of water appears bent.  It's not the straw that's bending, it's the light.  In this lesson we will explore this bending or 'refraction' of light. We will see when it happens, why it happens and the rule called 'Snell's law' that governs it.

name: Refraction in prisms (Ray optics and optical instruments)
blurb: Why does a prism split white light into 7 colours? In this section, we will answer this question and also explore prisms in detail.

name: Refraction at curved surfaces (Ray optics and optical instruments)
blurb: From the moons of Jupiter to the viruses that attack the bacteria, today we can see it all. And it's all possible due to refraction of light through curved pieces of glass. So in this section, we will explore this refraction through curved surfaces.

name: Refraction in thin lenses (Ray optics and optical instruments)
blurb: In this section, we will learn how to use ray tracings and the thin lens equation to find the location and size of images created by a curved lens.

name: Optic instruments: human eye and defects (Ray optics and optical instruments)
blurb: Why do things close to us look blurred while focussing on far ones? How do spectacles help some people see clearly? In this lesson, we will answer these questions by using ray diagrams and the thin lens formulae. Let us also learn about the defects in the human eye such as myopia and hypermetropia.

name: Optic instruments: telescopes and microscopes (Ray optics and optical instruments)
blurb: Microscopes and telescopes seem to work like magic. But it isn't magic, it's just that they use the properties of light. In this section, we will build telescopes and compound microscopes intuitively. We will also explore how an everyday magnifying glass really works.

name: Introduction to light waves (Wave optics)
blurb: In these videos and articles you'll learn about the different categories of the electromagnetic spectrum; radio waves, microwaves, infrared, visible, ultraviolet, x-ray, and gamma ray. You'll also learn what it means for light to be polarized, and how polarized light can allow for the creation of 3D movies.

name: Interference of light waves (Wave optics)
blurb: In these videos and articles you'll learn how overlapping light waves can cause constructive and destructive interference. Some examples of light interference that will be discussed include Young's double slit interference, single slit interference, and thin film interference.

name: Photons (Dual nature of radiation and matter)
blurb: Light can have wave-like or particle-like properties depending on the experiment being done. These "particles" of light are called photons. In this tutorial you'll learn about photon energy and momentum.

name: History of atomic structure (Atoms)
blurb: (No description)

name: Atoms and electrons (Atoms)
blurb: Sometimes people draw atoms like little solar systems, but they're way stranger than that. In this section you'll learn how electrons can have wavelengths, jump orbitals, and emit photons while in an atom.

name: Nuclear physics (Nuclei)
blurb: (No description)

name: Half life and decay rate (Nuclei)
blurb: In this tutorial, we will learn about radioactive decay, nuclear stability, and what is happening on a subatomic level during a nuclear reaction.

name: Band theory of solids (Semiconductors)
blurb:
Why do some things conduct electricity readily while others don't? 
Turns out we need to learn a new theory of solids called 'band theory' to answer this question.
In this section we will explore why we need this new theory, what is this band theory, and how we can use it to explain the conducting properties of solids.

name: Basics of semiconductors (Semiconductors)
blurb:
We love semiconductors because we can alter its properties.  
In this section we will exlore, how we alter these properties.

name: The PN junction (Semiconductors)
blurb:
An N-type or a P-type semiconductor alone isn't very useful for us. But a PN junction is. 
In this section, we will explore this PN junction and its properties.

name: PN junction biasing (Semiconductors)
blurb:
Building a one-way valve. 
The key to making a computing device is to be able to build a one-way valve (something that only allows a flow of charges in 1 direction) with no moving parts. In this section, we will explore how the PN junction act's as a one-way valve.

name: Rectifiers (Semiconductors)
blurb:
AC to DC. 
A rectifier is something that converts AC to DC. This is useful in many electronic appliances, for example in your phones. 
In this, we will explore how a PN junction diode can be used to build rectifiers.

name: Zener diode (Semiconductors)
blurb:
We usually don't like a diode to undergo reverse breakdown in any circuit. But a special diode called 'Zener diode' is used exclusively in its reverse breakdown region. 
In this section, we will explore what's special about these so-called 'Zener diodes' and look at its application.

name: Transistors working (Semiconductors)
blurb:
The semiconductor transistor was the key to building pocket radios and other communication devices. 
In this section, we will explore what these transistors are, and what they do.

name: Transistor characteristics (Semiconductors)
blurb:
In this section, we will explore the full behaviour of the transistor. 
We will see that they only amplify signals under certain conditions. We will also look at how they behave when those conditions are not met.

name: Transistor as a device (Semiconductors)
blurb: Let's explore how a transistor can be used as a voltage amplifier and a switch.

name: Distance, displacement, and coordinate systems (Hindi) (Motion in a straight line (Hindi))
blurb: We'll review the concepts of distance and displacement and use different ways to visualize motion such as graphs and number lines. So strap your seatbelts (actually this might not be necessary since we don't plan on decelerating in this tutorial) and prepare for a gentle ride of foundational physics knowledge.

name: Average velocity and average speed (Hindi) (Motion in a straight line (Hindi))
blurb: This tutorial is the backbone of your understanding of kinematics (i.e., the motion of objects).  You might already know that distance = rate x time.  This tutorial essentially reviews that idea with a vector lens (we introduce you to vectors here as well).  So strap your belts (actually this might not be necessary since we don't plan on decelerating in this tutorial) and prepare for a gentle ride of foundational physics knowledge.

name: Velocity and speed from graphs (Hindi) (Motion in a straight line (Hindi))
blurb: We'll review the concepts of instantaneous velocity and speed and use velocity-time and position-time graphs to analyze motion.

name: Acceleration (Hindi) (Motion in a straight line (Hindi))
blurb: In a world full of unbalanced forces (which you learn more about when you study Newton's laws), you will have acceleration (which is the rate in change of velocity).  Whether you're thinking about how fast a Porsche can get to 60mph or how long it takes for a passenger plane to get to the necessary speed for flight, this tutorial will help.

name: Kinematic formulas (Hindi) (Motion in a straight line (Hindi))
blurb: We don't believe in memorizing formulas and neither should you (unless you want to live your life as a shadow of your true potential).  This tutorial builds on what we know about displacement, velocity and acceleration to solve problems in kinematics (including projectile motion problems).  Along the way, we derive (and re-derive) some of the classic formulas that you might see in your physics book.

name: Objects in freefall (Hindi) (Motion in a straight line (Hindi))
blurb: We don't believe in memorizing formulas and neither should you (unless you want to live your life as a shadow of your true potential).  This tutorial builds on what we know about displacement, velocity and acceleration to solve problems in kinematics (including projectile motion problems).  Along the way, we derive (and re-derive) some of the classic formulas that you might see in your physics book.

name: Rectilinear motion (integral calc) (Hindi) (Motion in a straight line (Hindi))
blurb: Solve problems about motion along a line using the power of integral calculus. For example, given the velocity of a particle as a function of time v(t), find how much the particle has traveled over a given time period.

name: Relative velocity in 1D (Hindi) (Motion in a straight line (Hindi))
blurb: Let's understand and learn how to solve problems involving relative motion and frames of reference when the motion happens on a straight line.

name: Introduction to vectors and two-dimensional motion (Hindi) (Motion in a plane (Hindi))
blurb: We'll review how to add, subtract, and break down vectors graphically. These skills will be helpful for analyzing motion in two-dimensions.
