name: Analyzing vectors using trigonometry (Hindi) (Motion in a plane (Hindi))
blurb: We'll review how to analyze vectors using trigonometry. You might find it helpful to brush up on sine and cosine functions.

name: Graphs of projectile motion (Hindi) (Motion in a plane (Hindi))
blurb: We'll use graphs to analyze projectile motion in the horizontal and vertical directions.

name: Horizontally launched projectiles (Hindi) (Motion in a plane (Hindi))
blurb: This lesson builds on one and two-dimensional kinematics to answer questions about horizontally launched objects, such as how long and far something can travel.

name: Projectiles launched at an angle (Hindi) (Motion in a plane (Hindi))
blurb: This lesson tackles a fundamental question, how do we launch things as far as possible? We'll build our intuition for finding optimal launch angles with a little bit of trig.

name: Projectiles launched from/to a height (Hindi) (Motion in a plane (Hindi))
blurb: Let's escape from the binds of one-dimension (where we were forced to launch things straight up) and start launching at angles.  With a little bit of trig (might want to review sin and cos) we'll be figuring out just how long and far something can travel.

name: Projectile on an incline (Hindi) (Motion in a plane (Hindi))
blurb: Till now we have been throwing projectile on a horizontal surface, let's throw it on an incline now.

name: Relative motion in 2D (Hindi) (Motion in a plane (Hindi))
blurb: Let's learn how to solve problems involving relative velocity and frames of reference when the motion happens on a plane.

name: Uniform circular motion introduction (Hindi) (Motion in a plane (Hindi))
blurb: In this lesson, we will learn how to describe the motion of objects moving in a circle using angular motion variables such as angular velocity and angular displacement.

name: Centripetal acceleration (Hindi) (Motion in a plane (Hindi))
blurb: Is something moving in a circle at a constant speed accelerating?  If so, in what direction? In this lesson, we'll consider centripetal acceleration in more detail.

name: Introduction to forces and free body diagrams (Hindi) (Laws of motion (Hindi))
blurb: This lesson reviews different types of forces and how to draw free body diagrams to represent the forces on an object.

name: Newton's first law: Mass and inertia (Hindi) (Laws of motion (Hindi))
blurb: Newton's first law, also called the law of inertia, says that there must be a net external force on an object for there to be any change in velocity.

name: Newton's second law (Hindi) (Laws of motion (Hindi))
blurb: Newton's second law tells us how much an object will accelerate for a given net force.

name: Newton's third law (Hindi) (Laws of motion (Hindi))
blurb: Newton's third law says that forces always occur in pairs. For example, if the Earth is pulling down on you, you are also pulling up on the Earth with a force of equal magnitude and opposite direction.

name: Normal force and contact force (Hindi) (Laws of motion (Hindi))
blurb: A dog is balancing on one arm on my head.  Is my head applying a force to the dog's hand?  If it weren't, wouldn't there be nothing to offset the pull of gravity causing the acrobatic dog to fall?  What would we call this force?  Can we have a general term for the component of a contact force that acts perpendicular to the plane of contact?  These are absolutely normal questions to ask.

name: Balanced and unbalanced forces (Hindi) (Laws of motion (Hindi))
blurb: You will often hear physics professors be careful to say "net force" or "unbalanced force" rather than just "force".  Why?  This tutorial explains why and might give you more intuition about Newton's laws in the process.

name: Slow sock on Lubricon VI (Hindi) (Laws of motion (Hindi))
blurb: This short tutorial will have you dealing with orbiting frozen socks in order to understand whether you understand Newton's Laws.  We also quiz you a bit during the videos just to make sure that you aren't daydreaming about what you would do with a frozen sock.

name: Inclined planes (Hindi) (Laws of motion (Hindi))
blurb: What forces are acting on you when you slide down a frictionless ramp? In this lesson we'll learn how to analyze the motion of an object on an inclined plane.

name: Friction (Hindi) (Laws of motion (Hindi))
blurb: We've all slid down slides/snow-or-mud-covered-hills/railings at some point in our life (if not, you haven't really lived) and noticed that the smoother the surface the more we would accelerate (try to slide down a non-snow-or-mud-covered hill).  This tutorial looks into this in some depth.  We'll look at masses on inclined planes and think about static and kinetic friction.

name: Tension (Hindi) (Laws of motion (Hindi))
blurb:
Bad commute? Baby crying?  Bills to pay?  Looking to take a bath with some Calgon (do a search on YouTube for context) to ease your tension?  This tutorial has nothing (actually little, not nothing) to do with that.

So far, most of the forces we've been dealing with are forces of "pushing"--contact forces at the macro level because of atoms not wanting to get to close at the micro level.  Now we'll deal with "pulling" force or tension (at a micro level this is the force of attraction between bonded atoms).

name: Treating systems (Hindi) (Laws of motion (Hindi))
blurb: When two or more objects must move with the same magnitude of acceleration (like masses on strings, or boxes pushed into each other), we can treat the entire system as a single object when finding the acceleration.

name: Centripetal forces (Hindi) (Laws of motion (Hindi))
blurb: Learn how to identify centripetal forces and how they relate to speed, tension, normal force, and radius.

name: Centripetal force problem solving (Hindi) (Laws of motion (Hindi))
blurb: Learn how to deal with centripetal forces and how to relate it to speed, tension, normal force, and radius.

name: Introduction to linear momentum and impulse (Hindi) (Laws of motion (Hindi))
blurb: In this lesson, we'll learn about momentum and how it is transferred.  Whether you're playing pool (or "billiards") or deciding whether you want to get tackled by the 150 kg person, these concepts are of key importance.

name: Conservation of linear momentum and elastic collision (Hindi) (Laws of motion (Hindi))
blurb: Depending on your view of things, this may be the most violent of our tutorials.  Things will crash and collide.  We'll learn about momentum and how it is transferred.  Whether you're playing pool (or "billiards") or deciding whether you want to get tackled by the 300lb. guy, this tutorial is of key importance.

name: Collision in 2D (Hindi) (Laws of motion (Hindi))
blurb: (No description)

name: Introduction to work (Hindi) (Work, energy and power (Hindi))
blurb: You're doing a lot more work than you realize (most of which goes unpaid).  This lesson will introduce the definition of work we use in physics, which will give us another way to think about forces and movement.

name: Kinetic energy (Hindi) (Work, energy and power (Hindi))
blurb: Kinetic energy is the energy an object has because of its motion. We'll talk about how to calculate kinetic energy, and how kinetic energy is related to work.

name: Work-energy theorem (Hindi) (Work, energy and power (Hindi))
blurb: (No description)

name: Gravitational potential energy and conservative forces (Hindi) (Work, energy and power (Hindi))
blurb: Learn about what gravitational energy means and how it is related to conservative forces such as gravity.

name: Spring potential energy and Hooke's law (Hindi) (Work, energy and power (Hindi))
blurb: Weighing machines of all sorts employ springs that take a certain amount of force to keep compressed or stretched to a certain point.  Hooke's law will give us all the tools to weigh in on the subject ourselves and spring into action (pun intended)!

name: Conservation of energy (Hindi) (Work, energy and power (Hindi))
blurb: Learn about the law of conservation of energy, and how it can be useful for solving physics problems.

name: Work and energy problems involving friction (Hindi) (Work, energy and power (Hindi))
blurb: (No description)

name: Power (Hindi) (Work, energy and power (Hindi))
blurb: Learn what power means and how we use it in physics to describe the rate of energy transfer.

name: Elastic and inelastic collisions (Hindi) (Work, energy and power (Hindi))
blurb: Categorizing the different types of collisions can be useful. Here, you'll learn what it means for a collision to be elastic or inelastic and what that implies mathematically.

name: Centre of mass (Hindi) (System of particles and rotational motion (Hindi))
blurb: Learn what center of mass means, why it's useful, and how to calculate it.

name: Introduction to rotational motion (Hindi) (System of particles and rotational motion (Hindi))
blurb: Learn what angular displacement, angular velocity, and angular acceleration mean, as well as how they relate to their linear counterparts.

name: Angular kinematics (Hindi) (System of particles and rotational motion (Hindi))
blurb: Learn the relationships between angular displacement, angular velocity, and angular acceleration using the rotational kinematic formulas.

name: Torque and equilibrium (Hindi) (System of particles and rotational motion (Hindi))
blurb: Anyone who has ever opened a door has an intuitive understanding of torque. In this lesson, we'll explore why and how objects rotate using the concepts of torque and rotational equilibrium.

name: Cross product and torque (Hindi) (System of particles and rotational motion (Hindi))
blurb: (No description)

name: Rotational inertia and angular second law (Hindi) (System of particles and rotational motion (Hindi))
blurb: In this lesson, we'll learn how the distribution of mass can impact how easily the angular velocity can be changed around an axis. This property is called rotational inertia.

name: Rotational kinetic energy (Hindi) (System of particles and rotational motion (Hindi))
blurb: Does a baseball have more kinetic energy if it is spinning? In this lesson, we'll learn how to determine the rotational kinetic energy of an object so we can figure out how much more energy the baseball has.

name: Angular momentum and angular impulse (Hindi) (System of particles and rotational motion (Hindi))
blurb: In this lesson, we'll learn about angular momentum and angular impulse, and how these quantities are related to translational (or linear) momentum.

name: Conservation of angular momentum (Hindi) (System of particles and rotational motion (Hindi))
blurb: Angular momentum is constant where there is no net torque, just like how linear momentum is constant when there is no net force. In this lesson, we'll learn about the conservation of angular momentum and how to apply the new conservation law to solve problems.

name: Newton's law of gravitation (Hindi) (Gravitation (Hindi))
blurb:
Why are you sticking to your chair (ignoring the spilled glue)?  Why does the earth orbit the sun (or does it)? How high could I throw my dog on the moon?

Gravitation defines our everyday life and the structure of the universe.  This tutorial will introduce it to you in the Newtonian sense.

name: Gravitational potential energy at large distances (Hindi) (Gravitation (Hindi))
blurb: Until this lesson, we have always assumed the gravitational field is uniform and potential energy is equal to mgh. Now we'll learn how to find the gravitational potential energy at large distances when these assumptions no longer hold.

name: Stress, strain, and modulus of elasticity (Hindi) (Mechanical properties of solids (Hindi))
blurb: The best way to quantify elastic property of any material is to talk about 'stress' and 'strain'. Although we often use these words in our day to day life, they have a very concrete definition and meaning in physics. In this lesson, we will learn exactly what they are.

name: Density and pressure (Hindi) (Mechanical properties of fluid (Hindi))
blurb: In these videos and articles you'll learn the definitions of density and specific gravity. You'll also learn the definition of pressure, how it relates to force and area, and how to determine the pressure within a fluid. The difference between absolute and gauge pressure will also be discussed.

name: Buoyant force and Archimedes' principle (Hindi) (Mechanical properties of fluid (Hindi))
blurb: In these videos and articles you'll learn how pressure variations cause a buoyant force on a submerged object and how to calculate the value of the buoyant force. You'll also learn the meaning of Archimedes' principle.

name: Fluid dynamics (Hindi) (Mechanical properties of fluid (Hindi))
blurb: Flowing fluids behave different from static fluids. In these videos and articles you'll learn about volume flow rate and the equation of continuity. You'll also learn how Bernoulli's principle and Bernoulli's equation relate the pressure and speed of a flowing fluid. The effects of turbulence and viscosity will also be discussed.

name: Viscosity (Hindi) (Mechanical properties of fluid (Hindi))
blurb: (No description)

name: Surface tension (Hindi) (Mechanical properties of fluid (Hindi))
blurb: (No description)

name: Thermal expansion in solids (Hindi) (Thermal properties of matter (Hindi))
blurb: (No description)

name: Thermal expansion in fluids (Hindi) (Thermal properties of matter (Hindi))
blurb: (No description)

name: Thermal stress (Hindi) (Thermal properties of matter (Hindi))
blurb: (No description)

name: Introduction to simple harmonic motion (Hindi) (Oscillations (Hindi))
blurb: In this lesson, we'll develop some intuition for what a simple harmonic oscillator is, why they oscillate, and how to analyze and model the motion of spring-mass systems and simple pendulums.

name: Simple harmonic motion in spring-mass systems (Hindi) (Oscillations (Hindi))
blurb: In this lesson, we'll learn more about how simple harmonic motion describes the motion of a mass on a spring.

name: Simple pendulums (Hindi) (Oscillations (Hindi))
blurb: In this lesson, we'll learn more about how simple harmonic motion describes the motion of a simple pendulum.

name: Energy in simple harmonic oscillators (Hindi) (Oscillations (Hindi))
blurb: In this lesson, we'll learn about how the total energy, potential energy, and kinetic energy of a simple harmonic oscillator change over time.

name: Simple harmonic motion (with calculus) (Hindi) (Oscillations (Hindi))
blurb: In these videos Ram explores how to deal with simple harmonic motion when using calculus.

name: Introduction to waves (Hindi) (Waves (Hindi))
blurb: In this lesson, you'll learn the definition of a wave and the difference between transverse and longitudinal waves.

name: Wave characteristics (Hindi) (Waves (Hindi))
blurb: In this lesson, you'll learn the definition of the basic terms used to characterize waves such as amplitude, period, frequency, and wavelength.

name: Wave interference (Hindi) (Waves (Hindi))
blurb: In this lesson, we'll discuss how waves can overlap to produce constructive or destructive interference.

name: Standing waves (Hindi) (Waves (Hindi))
blurb: In this lesson, we'll discuss how and why standing waves occur, and well as how to determine the wavelength and frequency for a standing wave.

name: Sound (Hindi) (Waves (Hindi))
blurb: In these videos and articles you'll see visualizations of the propagation of sound waves, along with a visual definition of a sound wave's amplitude, period, frequency, and wavelength. You'll also learn how the speed of sound depends on the different characteristics of the medium. It will be shown how Mach numbers characterize faster than sound travel and their relationship to sonic booms. Also, you'll learn about the decibel scale, why sounds get softer, and how ultrasound medical imaging works.

name: Beats and interference of sound waves (Hindi) (Waves (Hindi))
blurb: In this lesson, we'll discuss what happens when sound waves with different frequencies overlap.

name: The Doppler effect (Hindi) (Waves (Hindi))
blurb: In these videos and articles you'll learn how the Doppler effect causes a change in the measured frequency of a moving source of sound or moving sound detector. You'll also learn how to calculate the observed frequency using the formula for the Doppler effect when dealing with either a moving source of sound or a moving sound detector.

blurb: Get a big picture overview of what physics is, and get recommendations for prerequisite knowledge.

name: Optimal angle for a projectile (Two-dimensional motion)
blurb: This tutorial tackles a fundamental question when trying to launch things as far as possible (key if you're looking to capture a fort with anything from water balloons to arrows).  With a bit of calculus, we'll get to a fairly intuitive answer.

name: Newton's laws of motion (Forces and Newton's Laws of Motion)
blurb: This tutorial will expose you to the foundation of classical mechanics--Newton's laws.  On one level they are intuitive, on another lever they are completely counter-intuitive.  Challenge your take on reality and watch this tutorial.  The world will look very different after you're done.

name: Centripetal acceleration (Centripetal force and gravitation)
blurb: Why do things move in circles? Seriously.  Why does *anything* ever move in a circle (straight lines seem much more natural)?  Is something moving in a circle at a constant speed accelerating?  If so, in what direction?  This tutorial will help you get your mind around this super-fun topic.

name: Centripetal forces (Centripetal force and gravitation)
blurb: Learn how to deal with centripetal forces and how to relate it to speed, tension, normal force, and radius.

name: Newton's law of gravitation (Centripetal force and gravitation)
blurb:
Why are you sticking to your chair (ignoring the spilled glue)?  Why does the earth orbit the sun (or does it)? How high could I throw my dog on the moon?

name: Work and energy (Work and energy)
blurb: You're doing a lot more work than you realize (most of which goes unpaid).  This tutorial will have you seeing the world in terms of potentials and energy and work (which is more fun than you can possibly imagine).

name: Springs and Hooke's Law (Work and energy)
blurb: Weighing machines of all sorts employ springs that take a certain amount of force to keep compressed or stretched to a certain point.  Hooke's law will give us all the tools to weigh in on the subject ourselves and spring into action (yes, the puns are annoying us too)!

name: Mechanical advantage (Work and energy)
blurb: If you have ever used a tool of any kind (including the bones in your body), you have employed mechanical advantage.  Whether you used an incline plane to drag something off of a pick-up truck, or the back of a hammer to remove a nail, the world of mechanical advantage surrounds us.

name: Momentum (Impacts and linear momentum)
blurb: Depending on your view of things, this may be the most violent of our tutorials.  Things will crash and collide.  We'll learn about momentum and how it is transferred.  Whether you're playing pool (or "billiards") or deciding whether you want to get tackled by the 300lb. guy, this tutorial is of key importance.

name: Elastic and inelastic collisions (Impacts and linear momentum)
blurb: Categorizing the different types of collisions can be useful. Here, you'll learn what it means for a collision to be elastic or inelastic and what that implies mathematically.

name: Center of mass (Impacts and linear momentum)
blurb: Learn what center of mass means, why it's useful, and how to calculate it.

name: Rotational kinematics (Moments, torque, and angular momentum)
blurb: Learn what angular displacement, angular velocity, and angular acceleration mean, as well as the relationship between them.

name: Torque, moments, and angular momentum (Moments, torque, and angular momentum)
blurb: Until this tutorial, we have been completely ignoring that things rotate.  In this tutorial, we'll explore why they rotate and how they do it.  It will leave your head spinning (no, it won't, but seemed like a fun thing to say given the subject matter).

name: Harmonic motion (Mechanical waves and sound)
blurb: Ever watch a slinky gyrate back and forth.  This is harmonic motion (a special class of oscillatory motion).  In this tutorial we'll see how we can model and deal with this type of phenomena.

name: Simple harmonic motion (with calculus) (Mechanical waves and sound)
blurb: In these videos Sal explores how to deal with simple harmonic motion when using calculus.

name: Mechanical waves (Mechanical waves and sound)
blurb: In these videos and articles you'll learn the definition of a wave and the difference between transverse and longitudinal waves. You'll also learn the definition of the basic terms used to characterize waves; amplitude, period, frequency, and wavelength.

name: Sound (Mechanical waves and sound)
blurb: In these videos and articles you'll see visualizations of the propagation of sound waves, along with a visual definition of a sound wave's amplitude, period, frequency, and wavelength. You'll also learn how the speed of sound depends on the different characteristics of the medium. It will be shown how Mach numbers characterize faster than sound travel and their relationship to sonic booms. Also, you'll learn about the decibel scale, why sounds get softer, and how ultrasound medical imaging works.

name: The Doppler effect (Mechanical waves and sound)
blurb: In these videos and articles you'll learn how the Doppler effect causes a change in the measured frequency of a moving source of sound or moving sound detector. You'll also learn how to calculate the observed frequency using the formula for the Doppler effect when dealing with either a moving source of sound or a moving sound detector.

name: Standing waves (Mechanical waves and sound)
blurb: In these videos and articles you'll learn how standing waves are produced and how to determine the wavelength and frequency of the different harmonics of standing waves produced in an open open tube or an open closed tube.

name: Density and Pressure (Fluids)
blurb: In these videos and articles you'll learn the definitions of density and specific gravity. You'll also learn the definition of pressure, how it relates to force and area, and how to determine the pressure within a fluid. The difference between absolute and gauge pressure will also be discussed.

name: Buoyant Force and Archimedes' Principle (Fluids)
blurb: In these videos and articles you'll learn how pressure variations cause a buoyant force on a submerged object and how to calculate the value of the buoyant force. You'll also learn the meaning of Archimedes' principle.

name: Fluid Dynamics (Fluids)
blurb: Flowing fluids behave different from static fluids. In these videos and articles you'll learn about volume flow rate and the equation of continuity. You'll also learn how Bernoulli's principle and Bernoulli's equation relate the pressure and speed of a flowing fluid. The effects of turbulence and viscosity will also be discussed.

name: Temperature, kinetic theory, and the ideal gas law (Thermodynamics)
blurb: In these videos and articles you'll learn about the Celsius and Kelvin temperature scales. The definition of a mole of a substance will be given. You'll also learn how the ideal gas law relates the pressure, volume, and temperature of a gas. Lastly, you'll learn how the Maxwell-Boltzmann distribution gives the probability of finding a gas molecule moving at a specific speed.

name: Specific heat and heat transfer (Thermodynamics)
blurb: In these videos and articles you'll learn the definition of specific heat and latent heat and how to use them in problem solving. You'll also learn the 3 modes of heat transfer; conduction, convection, and radiation. Lastly, we will look in more depth at how the rate of thermal conduction through a material depends on the material's thickness, conductivity constant, area, and difference in temperature.

name: Laws of thermodynamics (Thermodynamics)
blurb: In these videos and articles you'll learn how the first law of thermodynamics relates the change in internal energy of a gas, heat that enters the gas, and work done on the gas. PV diagrams will be discussed, as well as the four common thermal processes: isobaric, isochoric/isovolumetric, isothermal, and adiabatic. You'll also learn about how the second law of thermodynamics relates the entropy change to the multiplicity of microstates and the heat that enters a macroscopic system. The efficiency of a heat engine will also be explained.

name: Charge and electric force (Coulomb's law) (Electric charge, electric force, and voltage)
blurb: In these videos and articles the definition of electric charge will be given as well as a discussion of the law of conservation of charge. You'll learn how Coulomb's law relates the electric force to charge and separation distance. The difference between an electrically conducting vs. electrically insulating material will also be discussed.

name: Electric field (Electric charge, electric force, and voltage)
blurb: In these videos and articles you'll learn what an electric field is and how to calculate the value of the electric field for a point charge and an infinite sheet.

name: Electric potential energy, electric potential, and voltage (Electric charge, electric force, and voltage)
blurb: In these videos and articles you'll learn the difference between electric potential, electric potential energy, and voltage. You'll also learn how to calculate the electric potential at a point in space, electric potential energy between two charges, and voltage between two points in space.

name: Ohm's law and circuits with resistors (Circuits)
blurb: In these videos and articles you'll learn how Ohm's law relates the voltage across a resistor, the current through a resistor, and the resistance of the resistor. You'll also learn how resistors in series and parallel combine to form an equivalent resistance. The resistivity of materials, power used by a resistor, and how to use voltmeters and ammeters will also be discussed.

name: Circuits with capacitors (Circuits)
blurb: In these videos and articles you'll learn how capacitors store charge and energy. You'll also learn the relationships between capacitance, charge stored, energy stored, and voltage across a capacitor. Techniques for finding the equivalent capacitance for capacitors in series and parallel will be discussed. Lastly, you'll learn how a dielectric can change the amount of charge, voltage, and capacitance of a capacitor.

name: Magnets and Magnetic Force (Magnetic forces, magnetic fields, and Faraday's Law)
blurb: In these videos and articles you'll learn how the magnitude of the magnetic force depends on the charge, velocity, and magnetic field. You'll also learn how to use the right hand rule to determine the direction of the magnetic force. Lastly, it will be explained how to determine the magnetic force on a current carrying wire.

name: Magnetic field created by a current (Magnetic forces, magnetic fields, and Faraday's Law)
blurb: In these videos and articles you'll learn how the magnetic field created by a long straight wire depends on the current and distance from the wire. You'll also learn how to use the right hand rule to determine the direction of the magnetic field. The magnetic force between two current carrying wires will be discussed as well as the induced current in a wire moving through a magnetic field.

name: Electric motors (Magnetic forces, magnetic fields, and Faraday's Law)
blurb: In these videos and articles you'll learn how electric motors rely on a magnetic force that can cause a torque which rotates a loop of wire. You'll also learn how commutators allow the direction the the current to switch, which causes the motor to continue turning.

name: Magnetic flux and Faraday's law (Magnetic forces, magnetic fields, and Faraday's Law)
blurb: In these videos and articles you'll learn how magnetic flux depends on magnetic field strength, area, and angle. You'll also learn how Faraday's law states that a changing magnetic flux can cause an induced current. It will be shown how Lenz's law can allow you to find the direction of the induced current. Example problems will also be solved to show how to apply Faraday's law and Lenz's law.

name: Introduction to light waves (Light waves)
blurb: In these videos and articles you'll learn about the different categories of the electromagnetic spectrum; radio waves, microwaves, infrared, visible, ultraviolet, x-ray, and gamma ray. You'll also learn what it means for light to be polarized, and how polarized light can allow for the creation of 3D movies.

name: Interference of light waves (Light waves)
blurb: In these videos and articles you'll learn how overlapping light waves can cause constructive and destructive interference. Some examples of light interference that will be discussed include Young's double slit interference, single slit interference, and thin film interference.

name: Reflection and refraction (Geometric optics)
blurb: In these videos and articles you'll learn how to determine the angle of reflected light and the definition of specular and diffuse reflection. You'll also learn how to use Snell's law to determine the angle of a refracted light ray. Example problems dealing with the refraction of light rays will be solved. The topics of total internal reflection, critical angle, and dispersion will also be discussed.

name: Mirrors (Geometric optics)
blurb: In these videos and articles you'll learn how flat and curved/parabolic mirrors create images. The definitions of real and virtual images will be discussed. You'll also learn how to use the mirror equation to determine the image distance, magnification, image height, and object height when dealing with curved mirrors. The sign convention for positive and negative image distance, object distance, and focal length will be discussed.

name: Lenses (Geometric optics)
blurb: Curved lenses help people see better. In this section you'll learn how to use ray tracings and the thin lens equation to find the location and size of images created by a curved lenses.

name: Historical background (Special relativity)
blurb: The Michelson and Morley experiment was a momentous event in the lead up to special relativity. In this section, we'll explain Michelson and Morley's search for experimental evidence of a luminiferous ether. (Spoiler...they didn't find it. And that blew people's minds.)

name: Minkowski spacetime (Special relativity)
blurb: In a Newtonian world we assume that the passage of time or lengths in space are absolute--that regardless of one's inertial frame of reference, everyone would agree that the same time passed in every frame of reference and that something of a certain length in one frame would be the same length in other frames.  This leads to the speed of light needing to be relative depending on the frame of reference which contradicts observation.  We reconcile observations by loosening our assumptions about absolute space and time.  We explore this through Minkowski spacetime diagrams.

name: Lorentz transformation (Special relativity)
blurb: We'll now put some algebraic meat on our special relativity bone by introducing ourselves to the Lorentz transformation.  Interestingly, Lorentz came up with them before Einstein introduced Special Relativity as a nice way to reconcile some observations, but special relativity gave them real conceptual meat.  The Lorentz transformation is going to allow us to calculate the spacetime coordinates in different frames of reference!

name: Einstein velocity addition (Special relativity)
blurb: You're traveling toward me at half the speed of light.  My friend is traveling away from me at half the speed of light.  From either of your points-of-view, how quickly are you approaching each other?  Things are going to get even more fun now.  We're going to think about relative velocities in different frames of reference.

name: Photons (Quantum physics)
blurb: Light can have wave-like or particle-like properties depending on the experiment being done. These "particles" of light are called photons. In this tutorial you'll learn about photon energy and momentum.

name: Atoms and electrons (Quantum physics)
blurb: Sometimes people draw atoms like little solar systems, but they're way stranger than that. In this section you'll learn how electrons can have wavelengths, jump orbitals, and emit photons while in an atom.

name: Quantum numbers and orbitals (Quantum physics)
blurb: In this tutorial, we will see how the quantum numbers predict the orbitals available in different energy levels.

name: Nuclei (Quantum physics)
blurb: In this tutorial, we will learn about radioactive decay, nuclear stability, and what is happening on a subatomic level during a nuclear reaction.

name: Discovery of Magnetism (Discoveries and projects)
blurb: The discovery of magnetism. What can we do with this invisible force?

name: Discovery of magnetic fields (Discoveries and projects)
blurb: Let's find out more about this invisible force which guides the compass. How strong is it? What shape is it?

name: Measuring magnetic fields (Discoveries and projects)
blurb: How can we quantify the strength of magnetic fields? How strong is the Earth's field?

name: Batteries (Discoveries and projects)
blurb: Basic observations leading to homemade batteries

name: Electromagnet (Discoveries and projects)
blurb: Discoveries leading to the Right Hand rule

name: resistance (Discoveries and projects)
blurb: Exploring materials which cause a decrease in deflection when added in series with our meter.

name: Electric Motor (Discoveries and projects)
blurb: How can we turn electric current into rotary motion?

name: electrostatics (Discoveries and projects)
blurb: Discovering static electricity & electrostatic force. What is it? How can it be created, detected, and measured?

name: Projectile Launcher (Discoveries and projects)
blurb: (No description)

name: Thermodynamics (Discoveries and projects)
blurb: (No description)

name: Simple Machines Explorations (Discoveries and projects)
blurb: (No description)

name: AP Physics 1 concept review (Review for AP Physics 1 exam)
blurb: These videos quickly explain each concept within a chapter from the AP Physics 1 exam and solve a sample problem for each concept.

name: AP Physics 1 free response questions 2015 (Review for AP Physics 1 exam)
blurb: Want to know what the problems on the AP Physics 1 exam are like? In these videos we show how to solve the free response questions on the 2015 AP Physics 1 exam.

name: AP Physics foundations (One-dimensional motion)
blurb: An introduction to Physics, including an overview of the subject, information about prerequisite knowledge, and an interview with one of Khan Academy's content creators.

name: Distance, displacement, and coordinate systems (One-dimensional motion)
blurb: We'll review the concepts of distance and displacement and use different ways to visualize motion such as graphs and number lines. So strap your seatbelts (actually this might not be necessary since we don't plan on decelerating in this tutorial) and prepare for a gentle ride of foundational physics knowledge.

name: Average velocity and average speed (One-dimensional motion)
blurb: We'll review the concepts of average velocity and average speed and practice calculating both quantities in word problems.

name: Velocity and speed from graphs (One-dimensional motion)
blurb: We'll review the concepts of instantaneous velocity and speed and use velocity-time and position-time graphs to analyze motion.

name: Average and instantaneous acceleration (One-dimensional motion)
blurb: Acceleration is the rate of change in velocity.  Whether you're thinking about how fast a Porsche can get to 60 mph or how long it takes for a passenger plane to get to the necessary speed for takeoff, this lesson will help.

name: Motion with constant acceleration (One-dimensional motion)
blurb: This lesson builds on what we know about displacement, velocity, and acceleration to solve problems in one-dimensional kinematics where acceleration is constant.

name: Objects in freefall (One-dimensional motion)
blurb: Freefall is a special case of motion with constant acceleration because acceleration due to gravity is always constant and downward.  This lesson builds on the kinematic formulas to analyze the motion of projectiles and objects in freefall.

name: Introduction to vectors and two-dimensional motion (Two-dimensional motion)
blurb: We'll review how to add, subtract, and break down vectors graphically. These skills will be helpful for analyzing motion in two-dimensions.

name: Analyzing vectors using trigonometry (Two-dimensional motion)
blurb: We'll review how to analyze vectors using trigonometry. You might find it helpful to brush up on sine and cosine functions.

name: Graphs of projectile motion (Two-dimensional motion)
blurb: We'll use graphs to analyze projectile motion in the horizontal and vertical directions.

name: Horizontally launched projectiles (Two-dimensional motion)
blurb: This lesson builds on one and two-dimensional kinematics to answer questions about horizontally launched objects, such as how long and far something can travel.

name: Projectiles launched at an angle (Two-dimensional motion)
blurb: This lesson tackles a fundamental question, how do we launch things as far as possible? We'll build our intuition for finding optimal launch angles with a little bit of trig.

name: Introduction to forces and free body diagrams (Forces and Newton's laws of motion)
blurb: This lesson reviews different types of forces and how to draw free body diagrams to represent the forces on an object.

name: Newton's first law: Mass and inertia (Forces and Newton's laws of motion)
blurb: Newton's first law, also called the law of inertia, says that there must be a net external force on an object for there to be any change in velocity.

name: Newton's second law (Forces and Newton's laws of motion)
blurb: Newton's second law tells us how much an object will accelerate for a given net force.

name: Newton's third law (Forces and Newton's laws of motion)
blurb: Newton's third law says that forces always occur in pairs. For example, if the Earth is pulling down on you, you are also pulling up on the Earth with a force of equal magnitude and opposite direction.

name: Angled forces (Forces and Newton's laws of motion)
blurb: Sometimes forces are applied at an angle. We can use trigonometry to separately analyze the force components along the coordinate axes.

name: Inclined planes (Forces and Newton's laws of motion)
blurb: What forces are acting on you when you slide down a frictionless ramp? In this lesson we'll learn how to analyze the motion of an object on an inclined plane.

name: Friction (Forces and Newton's laws of motion)
blurb: What keeps a parked car from sliding down a slope? This lesson looks at what happens when we include static and kinetic friction forces between two objects.

name: Introduction to uniform circular motion (Uniform circular motion and gravitation)
blurb: In this lesson, we will learn how to describe the motion of objects moving in a circle using angular motion variables such as angular velocity and angular displacement.

name: Centripetal acceleration (Uniform circular motion and gravitation)
blurb: Is something moving in a circle at a constant speed accelerating?  If so, in what direction? In this lesson, we'll consider centripetal acceleration in more detail.

name: Centripetal forces (Uniform circular motion and gravitation)
blurb: Learn how to identify centripetal forces and how they relate to speed, tension, normal force, and radius.

name: Newton's law of gravitation (Uniform circular motion and gravitation)
blurb: Why does the earth orbit the sun (or does it)? Gravitation defines our everyday life and the structure of the universe.  This tutorial will introduce gravity in the Newtonian sense.

name: Introduction to work (Work and energy)
blurb: You're doing a lot more work than you realize (most of which goes unpaid).  This lesson will introduce the definition of work we use in physics, which will give us another way to think about forces and movement.

name: Kinetic energy (Work and energy)
blurb: Kinetic energy is the energy an object has because of its motion. We'll talk about how to calculate kinetic energy, and how kinetic energy is related to work.

name: Work-energy theorem (Work and energy)
blurb: (No description)

name: Conservative forces and gravitational potential energy (Work and energy)
blurb: Learn about what gravitational energy means and how it is related to conservative forces such as gravity.

name: Spring potential energy and Hooke's law (Work and energy)
blurb: Weighing machines of all sorts employ springs that take a certain amount of force to keep compressed or stretched to a certain point.  Hooke's law will give us all the tools to weigh in on the subject ourselves and spring into action (pun intended)!

name: Conservation of energy (Work and energy)
blurb: Learn about the law of conservation of energy, and how it can be useful for solving physics problems.

name: Power (Work and energy)
blurb: Learn what power means and how we use it in physics to describe the rate of energy transfer.

name: Introduction to linear momentum and impulse (Linear momentum and collisions)
blurb: In this lesson, we'll learn about momentum and how it is transferred.  Whether you're playing pool (or "billiards") or deciding whether you want to get tackled by the 150 kg person, these concepts are of key importance.

name: Conservation of momentum in collisions (Linear momentum and collisions)
blurb: Categorizing the different types of collisions can be useful. In this lesson, we'll learn what it means for a collision to be elastic and what that tells us about the momentum and kinetic energy during the collision.

name: Inelastic collisions (Linear momentum and collisions)
blurb: Collisions can be elastic or inelastic. In this lesson, we'll learn what quantities are conserved and not conserved during inelastic collisions.

name: Center of mass (Linear momentum and collisions)
blurb: Learn about the center of mass and how to analyze momentum for collisions in two-dimensions.

name: Introduction to angular motion (Rotational motion and torque)
blurb: Learn what angular displacement, angular velocity, and angular acceleration mean, as well as how they relate to their linear counterparts.

name: Angular kinematics (Rotational motion and torque)
blurb: Learn the relationships between angular displacement, angular velocity, and angular acceleration using the rotational kinematic formulas.

name: Torque and equilibrium (Rotational motion and torque)
blurb: Anyone who has ever opened a door has an intuitive understanding of torque. In this lesson, we'll explore why and how objects rotate using the concepts of torque and rotational equilibrium.

name: Rotational inertia and angular second law (Rotational motion and torque)
blurb: In this lesson, we'll learn how the distribution of mass can impact how easily the angular velocity can be changed around an axis. This property is called rotational inertia.

name: Rotational kinetic energy (Rotational motion and torque)
blurb: Does a baseball have more kinetic energy if it is spinning? In this lesson, we'll learn how to determine the rotational kinetic energy of an object so we can figure out how much more energy the baseball has.

name: Angular momentum and angular impulse (Rotational motion and torque)
blurb: In this lesson, we'll learn about angular momentum and angular impulse, and how these quantities are related to translational (or linear) momentum.

name: Conservation of angular momentum (Rotational motion and torque)
blurb: Angular momentum is constant where there is no net torque, just like how linear momentum is constant when there is no net force. In this lesson, we'll learn about the conservation of angular momentum and how to apply the new conservation law to solve problems.

name: Gravitational potential energy (Rotational motion and torque)
blurb: Until this lesson, we have always assumed the gravitational field is uniform and potential energy is equal to mgh. Now we'll learn how to find the gravitational potential energy at large distances when these assumptions no longer hold.

name: Introduction to simple harmonic motion (Simple harmonic motion)
blurb: In this lesson, we'll develop some intuition for what a simple harmonic oscillator is, why they oscillate, and how to analyze and model the motion of spring-mass systems and simple pendulums.

name: Spring-mass systems (Simple harmonic motion)
blurb: In this lesson, we'll learn more about how simple harmonic motion describes the motion of a mass on a spring.

name: Simple pendulums (Simple harmonic motion)
blurb: In this lesson, we'll learn more about how simple harmonic motion describes the motion of a simple pendulum.

name: Energy in a simple harmonic oscillator (Simple harmonic motion)
blurb: In this lesson, we'll learn about how the total energy, potential energy, and kinetic energy of a simple harmonic oscillator change over time.

name: Introduction to waves (Waves)
blurb: In this lesson, you'll learn the definition of a wave and the difference between transverse and longitudinal waves.

name: Wave characteristics (Waves)
blurb: In this lesson, you'll learn the definition of the basic terms used to characterize waves such as amplitude, period, frequency, and wavelength.

name: Wave interference (Waves)
blurb: In this lesson, we'll discuss how waves can overlap to produce constructive or destructive interference.

name: Standing waves (Waves)
blurb: In this lesson, we'll discuss how and why standing waves occur, and well as how to determine the wavelength and frequency for a standing wave.

name: Introduction to sound (Waves)
blurb: In this lesson, you'll see visualizations of sound waves, along with a visual definition of a sound wave's amplitude, period, frequency, and wavelength.

name: Beats and interference of sound waves (Waves)
blurb: In this lesson, we'll discuss what happens when sound waves with different frequencies overlap.

name: Doppler effect (Waves)
blurb: (No description)

name: Electric charge (Electric charge and electric force)
blurb: In this lesson, we'll review protons and electrons and start discussing the properties of electric charge, including how charge is quantized.

name: Conservation of charge (Electric charge and electric force)
blurb: In this lesson, we'll learn about the law of conservation of charge, insulators and conductors, and how charge is transferred.

name: Coulomb's law and electric force (Electric charge and electric force)
blurb: In this lesson, we'll learn how Coulomb's law relates the electric force to charge and separation distance. We'll also compare the electric force and gravitational force.

name: Electric current, resistivity, and Ohm's law (DC Circuits)
blurb: In this lesson, you'll learn how Ohm's law relates the voltage across a resistor, the current through a resistor, and the resistance of the resistor. We'll also start talking about circuits and the resistivity of materials.

name: Electric power and DC circuits (DC Circuits)
blurb: In this lesson, we'll learn about power used by a resistor and how to interpret circuit diagrams.

name: Kirchhoff's junction rule (DC Circuits)
blurb: Learn how to analyze the current flow in a DC circuit using Kirchhoff junction rule (or current law).

name: Kirchhoff's loop rule (DC Circuits)
blurb: Learn how to analyze the voltage in a DC circuit using Kirchhoff loop rule (or voltage law).

name: Series circuits (DC Circuits)
blurb: Learn how to simplify a circuit diagram with resistors in series or in parallel.

name: DC Ammeters and voltmeters (DC Circuits)
blurb: Learn how to use voltmeters and ammeters to measure the potential difference and current in a DC circuit.

name: DC Circuit analysis (DC Circuits)
blurb: Learn how to analyze a more complicated DC circuit using the strategies we've learned so far, including Kirchhoff's laws and Ohm's law.

name: Prepare for the 2019 AP Physics 1 exam (Prepare for the 2019 AP Physics 1 Exam)
blurb: (No description)

name: AP Physics 1 concept review (Prepare for the 2019 AP Physics 1 Exam)
blurb: These videos quickly explain each concept within a chapter from the AP Physics 1 exam and solve a sample problem for each concept.

name: AP Physics 1 free response questions  (Prepare for the 2019 AP Physics 1 Exam)
blurb: Want to know what the problems on the AP Physics 1 exam are like? In these videos we show how to solve the free response questions on the 2015 AP Physics 1 exam.

name: AP Physics 1 : Advanced practice (Prepare for the 2019 AP Physics 1 Exam)
blurb: Practice exercises to help you prepare for more advanced problems that cover multiple physics topics

The sign convention for positive and negative image distance, object distance, and focal length will be discussed.

name: Lenses (Geometric optics)
blurb: Curved lenses help people see better. In this section you'll learn how to use ray tracings and the thin lens equation to find the location and size of images created by a curved lenses.

name: Photons (Quantum physics)
blurb: Light can have wave-like or particle-like properties depending on the experiment being done. These "particles" of light are called photons. In this tutorial you'll learn about photon energy and momentum.

name: Atoms and electrons (Quantum physics)
blurb: Sometimes people draw atoms like little solar systems, but they're way stranger than that. In this section you'll learn how electrons can have wavelengths, jump orbitals, and emit photons while in an atom.

name: Quantum numbers and orbitals (Quantum physics)
blurb: In this tutorial, we will see how the quantum numbers predict the orbitals available in different energy levels.

name: Nuclear physics (Quantum physics)
blurb: In this tutorial, we will learn about radioactive decay, nuclear stability, and what is happening on a subatomic level during a nuclear reaction.

name: Introduction to the atom (Atoms, molecules, and ions)
blurb: In chemistry, we will often be thinking about the world on a much smaller scale than you can see with the naked eye. Here we will learn about atoms and elements, tiny particles that make up the world around us. What are atoms, and what kind of properties do they have? How do we weigh and count atoms? We will answer those questions in this section!

name: Ions and compounds (Atoms, molecules, and ions)
blurb: Atoms can lose or gain electrons to form ions, or combine in specific ratios to form compounds. In this tutorial we will learn about how ions and compounds are formed, visualized, and measured.

name: Names and formulas of ionic compounds (Atoms, molecules, and ions)
blurb: Anions and cations can combine to form ionic compounds such as sodium chloride (table salt) and and sodium bicarbonate (baking soda). In this tutorial, we will be learning how to name ions and ionic compounds from the formula, and how to find the formula from the compound name.

name: Mass spectrometry (Atoms, molecules, and ions)
blurb: Learn how mass spectrometry can be used to detect isotopes, atoms of the same element with different numbers of neutrons.

name: Balancing chemical equations (Chemical reactions and stoichiometry)
blurb: We are now going to look at chemical reactions.  But as we do, we need to make sure that atoms aren't magically appearing or disappearing.  Put another way, we need to sure that we have the same number of each constituent atom in the product of the reaction as we do in the reactants (the molecules that react)!

name: Stoichiometry (Chemical reactions and stoichiometry)
blurb: Now we are going to draw the connections between balancing equations and what happens in the lab (where you actually have a certain mass of a compound).

name: Limiting reagent stoichiometry (Chemical reactions and stoichiometry)
blurb: In a reaction, you often have extra of one molecule (or too little of the other) so all the reactant doesn't react.  We'll explore how to identify which reactant is limiting which is helpful in a whole series of scenarios.

name: Molecular composition (Chemical reactions and stoichiometry)
blurb: We'll now explore two different ways of representing what elements are in a molecule: molecular and empirical formulas.  Molecular formulas actually represent the number of atoms in  a molecule while empirical formulas show us the ratio of the constituents based on experiments.  In order to help us connect these ideas, we'll also explore a quantity called the "mole".  Just as a "dozen" represents 12 of something, a "mole" represents  roughly 602,200,000,000,000,000,000,000 of something.  This will help us think about mass composition of molecules.

name: Types of chemical reactions (Chemical reactions and stoichiometry)
blurb: In a chemical reaction, atoms get rearranged, combined and separated to form new substances. We will be learning about the different ways reactions can be classified, and the properties of different reaction types.

name: History of atomic structure (Electronic structure of atoms)
blurb: How did scientists figure out the structure of the atom, and how did they discover subatomic particles? The answer is X-ray vision (just kidding!). In this section, we will discuss some of the awesome experiments in science history that led to our modern understanding of atomic structure.

name: Bohr's model of the hydrogen atom (Electronic structure of atoms)
blurb: Atomic theory is not Bohr-ing!  While it doesn't work for atoms with more than one electron, the Bohr model successfully predicts the emission spectrum of hydrogen.

name: Quantum numbers and orbitals (Electronic structure of atoms)
blurb: In this tutorial, we will see how the quantum numbers predict the orbitals available in different energy levels.

name: Electron configurations (Electronic structure of atoms)
blurb: In this tutorial, Sal and Jay show how to write electron configurations.

name: Introduction to the periodic table (Periodic table)
blurb: How are the elements organized in the periodic table? This tutorial will cover the classification of elements including groups, transition metals, and valence electrons.

name: Periodic table trends  (Periodic table)
blurb: Have you ever wondered why it is called the "periodic" table? The elements are organized based on their electronic structure, which results in some interesting trends in atomic properties as you move down a group or across a period. This tutorial will try to explain some of those trends!

name: Types of chemical bonds (Chemical bonds)
blurb: In this tutorial, we will learn about electronegativity and the different types of chemical bonds.

name: Dot structures (Chemical bonds)
blurb: We can’t always see molecules, but we can always simplify and draw depictions of them with pen and paper. It is the language of chemistry that we want you to get acquainted with. You will learn to draw Lewis dot structures and resonance structures, assign formal charges, and analyze the geometry of molecules and ions using VSEPR theory.

name: Hybridization and hybrid orbitals (Chemical bonds)
blurb: In this tutorial, we will learn about sp3, sp2, and sp hybridization.

name: Ideal gas equation (Gases and kinetic molecular theory)
blurb: In this tutorial, Sal shows you how to use the ideal gas equation in calculations.

name: Non-ideal gas behavior (Gases and kinetic molecular theory)
blurb: The ideal gas law works well for gases at standard temperature and pressure. In this tutorial, we will discuss the assumptions made when using the ideal gas equation, and what happens when gases are not at standard temperature and pressure.

name: States of matter (States of matter and intermolecular forces)
blurb: Matter can be in the liquid, solid, gas, or plasma state. We will be learning about properties of each state of matter, as well analyzing phase changes using heating curves and phase diagrams.

name: Introduction to intermolecular forces (States of matter and intermolecular forces)
blurb: Intermolecular forces act between neighboring atoms, molecules, or ions, and they can be used to explain pretty much every macroscopic property of matter! We'll be learning about the different kinds of intermolecular forces and how they affect properties such as surface tension.

name: Mixtures and solutions (States of matter and intermolecular forces)
blurb: The air you are (hopefully) breathing is a mixture of nitrogen and oxygen gases. We could also think of it as a solution of oxygen gas in nitrogen gas. In this section we will be learning about different types of mixtures, how to calculate concentration, and colligative properties.

name: Equilibrium constant (Chemical equilibrium)
blurb: In this tutorial, we will examine the equilibrium state and learn how to write the expression for the equilibrium constant.

name: Factors that affect chemical equilibrium (Chemical equilibrium)
blurb: In this tutorial, we will learn about the different factors that affect a reaction mixture at equilibrium.

name: Acids and bases (Acids and bases)
blurb: What makes a compound acidic or basic? We will learn about the different definitions for acids and bases, and how we measure how acidic or basic a substance is. We will be putting our chemical equilibrium knowledge to good use when we look at the reactivity of weak acids and bases.

name: Acid-base equilibria (Acids and bases)
blurb: In this tutorial, we will learn how the strength of an acid or base is related to the equilibrium reaction that is happening in our solution. We will also see what happens when we mix solutions of acids and bases in neutralization reactions.

name: Buffer solutions (Acid-base equilibria and solubility equilibria)
blurb: Buffer solutions play an important role in many chemical and biological processes.  In this tutorial we will learn how buffers resist changes in pH, and how to calculate the pH of a buffer solution.

name: Titrations (Acid-base equilibria and solubility equilibria)
blurb: Chemists use titrations to determine the concentration of an acid, base, or other substance in solution. We will cover the different types (strong acid/strong base, strong acid/weak base, weak acid/strong base, and redox), calculating the pH at different points of the titration, and choosing indicators.

name: Solubility equilibria (Acid-base equilibria and solubility equilibria)
blurb: In this tutorial we will learn how to think about the solubility and precipitation of ionic compounds in the context of chemical equilibrium. We will also look at different factors that can affect the solubility such as pH and the formation of complex ions.

name: Internal energy (Thermodynamics)
blurb: An introduction to the first law of thermodynamics, internal energy, heat, work, and PV diagrams

name: Enthalpy (Thermodynamics)
blurb: An introduction to enthalpy and Hess's law

name: Entropy (Thermodynamics)
blurb: An introduction to the Carnot cycle and entropy

name: Gibbs free energy (Thermodynamics)
blurb: An introduction to Gibbs free energy and how free energy relates to spontaneity and the equilibrium constant

name: Redox reactions (Redox reactions and electrochemistry)
blurb: Oxidation and reduction are powerful ideas for thinking about how charge is transferred within a reaction.  As we'll see, it is something of a hypothetical, but it is, nonetheless, very useful.

name: Galvanic cells (Redox reactions and electrochemistry)
blurb: Batteries power much of our lives (literally).  In this tutorial, we'll use our knowledge of oxidation and reduction to understand how Galvanic/Voltaic cells actually work.

name: Cell potentials (Redox reactions and electrochemistry)
blurb: An introduction to calculating cell potentials at standard state.

name: Electrochemistry, thermodynamics, and equilibrium (Redox reactions and electrochemistry)
blurb: Relating the cell potential to the equilibrium constant K and Gibbs free energy.

name: Cell potentials under nonstandard conditions (Redox reactions and electrochemistry)
blurb: Calculating the cell potential when operating at nonstandard conditions.

name: Electrolytic cells and electrolysis (Redox reactions and electrochemistry)
blurb: An introduction to electrolytic cells and electrolysis

name: Reaction rates and rate laws (Kinetics)
blurb: In this tutorial, we will examine the rates of chemical reactions and learn how to write rate laws.

name: Relationship between reaction concentrations and time (Kinetics)
blurb: In this tutorial, we will convert rate laws into equations that allow us to determine the concentrations of reactants at any time during the course of a reaction.

name: Arrhenius equation and reaction mechanisms (Kinetics)
blurb: In this tutorial, we will learn about reaction mechanisms and how temperature and the activation energy affect the rate of a reaction.

name: Spectrophotometry (Kinetics)
blurb: In the lab, it is useful to know how much of something you have or the concentration of a solute.  In this tutorial, we'll light to do that!

name: Radioactive decay (Nuclear chemistry)
blurb: In this tutorial, we will learn about radioactive decay, nuclear stability, and what is happening on a subatomic level during a nuclear reaction.

name: 2015 AP Chemistry free response questions (Studying for the AP Chemistry exam?)
blurb: In these videos, Sal explains how to solve the free response questions from the 2015 AP Chemistry exam.

name: Meet the chemistry professional (Meet a chemistry professional)
blurb: We've invited professionals from all kinds of careers to share their stories. What do all these people have in common? They all studied chemistry! Find out how chemistry can be used in everything from engineering to making TV shows.

name: Introduction to the atom (Atoms, compounds, and ions)
blurb: In chemistry, we will often be thinking about the world on a much smaller scale than you can see with the naked eye. Here we will learn about atoms and elements, tiny particles that make up the world around us. What are atoms, and what kind of properties do they have? How do we weigh and count atoms? We will answer those questions in this section!

name: Compounds and ions (Atoms, compounds, and ions)
blurb: There are 118 elements on the periodic table, and often you will see them combine in specific ratios to form compounds. In this tutorial we will learn about the different ways that chemists represent, count, and categorize compounds.

name: Mass Spectrometry (Atoms, compounds, and ions)
blurb: Learn how mass spectrometry can be used to detect isotopes, atoms of the same element with different numbers of neutrons.

blurb: (No description)

name: Enthalpy (Thermodynamics)

name: Entropy (Thermodynamics)

name: Gibbs free energy (Thermodynamics)

name: Equilibrium constant (Chemical equilibrium)
blurb: In this tutorial, we will examine the equilibrium state and learn how to write the expression for the equilibrium constant.

name: Factors that affect chemical equilibrium (Chemical equilibrium)
blurb: In this tutorial, we will learn about the different factors that affect a reaction mixture at equilibrium.

name: Acids, bases and pH (Acids and bases)
blurb: What makes a compound acidic or basic? We will learn about the different definitions for acids and bases, and how we measure how acidic or basic a substance is. We will be putting our chemical equilibrium knowledge to good use when we look at the reactivity of weak acids and bases.

name: Acid-base equilibria (Acids and bases)
blurb: In this tutorial, we will learn how the strength of an acid or base is related to the equilibrium reaction that is happening in our solution. We will also see what happens when we mix solutions of acids and bases in neutralization reactions.

name: Buffer solutions (Buffers, titrations, and solubility equilibria)
blurb: Buffer solutions play an important role in many chemical and biological processes.  In this tutorial we will learn how buffers resist changes in pH, and how to calculate the pH of a buffer solution.

name: Titrations (Buffers, titrations, and solubility equilibria)
blurb: Chemists use titrations to determine the concentration of an acid, base, or other substance in solution. We will cover the different types (strong acid/strong base, strong acid/weak base, weak acid/strong base, and redox), calculating the pH at different points of the titration, and choosing indicators.

name: Solubility equilibria (Buffers, titrations, and solubility equilibria)
blurb: In this tutorial we will learn how to think about the solubility and precipitation of ionic compounds in the context of chemical equilibrium. We will also look at different factors that can affect the solubility such as pH and the formation of complex ions.

name: Redox reactions (Redox reactions and electrochemistry)
blurb: Oxidation and reduction are powerful ideas for thinking about how charge is transferred within a reaction.  As we'll see, it is something of a hypothetical, but it is, nonetheless, very useful.

name: Galvanic cells (Redox reactions and electrochemistry)
blurb: Batteries power much of our lives (literally).  In this tutorial, we'll use our knowledge of oxidation and reduction to understand how Galvanic/Voltaic cells actually work.

name: Standard cell potentials (Redox reactions and electrochemistry)
blurb: An introduction to calculating cell potentials at standard state.

name: Electrochemistry, thermodynamics, and equilibrium (Redox reactions and electrochemistry)
blurb: Relating the cell potential to the equilibrium constant K and Gibbs free energy.

name: Cell potentials under nonstandard conditions (Redox reactions and electrochemistry)
blurb: Calculating the cell potential when operating at nonstandard conditions.

name: Electrolytic cells and electrolysis (Redox reactions and electrochemistry)
blurb: An introduction to electrolytic cells and electrolysis

name: 2015 AP Chemistry free response questions (Studying for the AP Chemistry exam?)
blurb: In these videos, Sal explains how to solve the free response questions from the 2015 AP Chemistry exam.

name: Dot structures (Structure and bonding)
blurb: Going dotty trying to review?  Don't worry about a single thing - or multiples for that matter!  Get some points on simple organic dot structures in this tutorial.

name: Hybridization (Structure and bonding)
blurb: How closely bonded are you to your idea of orbitals?   In this tutorial, we will learn about hybridized orbitals, the ligers of organic chemistry.

name: Bond-line structures (Structure and bonding)
blurb: Call them Bonds. Covalent Bonds. Smart chemists need time to stir (and shake) their solutions. In this tutorial, we will explain how chemists use bond-line structures as a form of organic shorthand to skip time-consuming carbon and hydrogen atoms labeling. Watch this tutorial so you too can be in the Dr. Know.

name: Electronegativity (Structure and bonding)
blurb: What is the most attractive concept in undergraduate organic chemistry?  Currently most are polarized on the topic, but the pull of electronegativity is hard to resist.  Within this tutorial, we will learn about electronegativity and see how it applies to polarity, intermolecular forces, and physical properties.

name: Counting electrons (Resonance and acid-base chemistry)
blurb: Aspiring chemists need to be able to count electrons.  Without this ability, your days as a chemist would be numbered.   In this tutorial, you will learn how to count electrons to assign formal charges and oxidation states.  Both forms of "electron bookkeeping" are important concepts to understand for organic reactions.

name: Resonance structures (Resonance and acid-base chemistry)
blurb: Are bond-line drawings not resonating with you?  Sometimes one drawing is not enough to accurately describe the distribution of electron density.   In this tutorial, we will learn how two or more resonance structures are merged to give us a single representation (a resonance hybrid).

name: Organic acid-base chemistry (Resonance and acid-base chemistry)
blurb: Do you remember the basics of acid-base chemistry?  If your answer is neutral, then you might want to watch this tutorial and review these important concepts from general chemistry.

name: Naming alkanes (Alkanes and cycloalkanes)
blurb: Methane, ethane, propane, butane .  .  .   by the time you get to five carbons you might have some pent up frustration.  By six carbons you might even believe that you are hexed!  Don’t worry though, you’ll feel sane again once Sal shows you how to name alkanes in this tutorial.

name: Naming alkanes, cycloalkanes, and bicyclic compounds (Alkanes and cycloalkanes)
blurb: Do you speak the language of organic chemistry?  Nomenclature running rings around you?  Feel like the victim of a vicious cycle?  In this tutorial, we will learn how to be fluent in naming alkanes, cycloalkanes, and bicyclic compounds.

name: Conformations of alkanes and cycloalkanes (Alkanes and cycloalkanes)
blurb: Feeling unsure about conformations?  If you need a little more perspective on alkanes, try looking at them from Newman’s point of view.  The result might leave you feeling more stable.

name: Conformations (Alkanes and cycloalkanes)
blurb: Do conformations float your boat?  If so, pull up a chair and learn about the different conformations of cyclohexane.

name: Functional groups (Alkanes and cycloalkanes)
blurb: The chemistry of every organic compound is determined by the functional groups it contains.  In this tutorial, we put the fun back into identifying functional groups!

name: Chirality  (Stereochemistry)
blurb: Are you right handed or sinister-handed?  Have you ever thought that you might not be as attractive as you look in the mirror?  Welcome to the world of chirality!

name: Enantiomers (Stereochemistry)
blurb: In this tutorial, we will explore enantiomers, compounds that have the same composition and bonding but are fundamentally different because they are mirror images of each other (kind of like Tomax and Xamot--the Crimson Guard Commanders from GI Joe).

name: Stereoisomeric relationships (Stereochemistry)
blurb: Mirror, mirror on the wall . . . who is the fairest stereoisomer of all?  In this tutorial, we will examine the relationships between different stereoisomers.

name: Free radical reaction (Substitution and elimination reactions)
blurb: In this tutorial, Sal introduces free radical reactions by showing the reaction of methane with chlorine.

name: Nucleophilicity and basicity (Substitution and elimination reactions)
blurb: In this tutorial, Sal discusses the difference between nucleophilicity and basicity.

name: Elimination reactions (Substitution and elimination reactions)
blurb: In this tutorial, Sal explains the difference between an E1 and an E2 elimination reaction.

name: SN1/SN2/E1/E2 (Substitution and elimination reactions)
blurb: In this tutorial, Sal compares the differences between SN1, SN2, E1, and E2 reactions.

name: SN1 and SN2 (Substitution and elimination reactions)
blurb: In this tutorial, Jay covers the definitions of nucleophile/electrophile, The Schwartz Rules (may the Schwartz be with you!), and the differences between SN1 and SN2 reactions.

name: E1 and E2 reactions (Substitution and elimination reactions)
blurb: In this tutorial, Jay covers the E1 elimination mechanism, carbocation rearrangements, and the details of the E2 elimination reaction.

name: SN1/SN2/E1/E2 (Substitution and elimination reactions)
blurb: In this tutorial, Jay discusses the strength of a nucleophile and the differences between SN1, SN2, E1, and E2 reactions.

name: Naming alkenes (Alkenes and alkynes)
blurb: In this tutorial, Sal names alkenes and discusses the E-Z system.

name: Alkene reactions (Alkenes and alkynes)
blurb: In this tutorial, Sal shows several reactions of alkenes.

name: Alkene nomenclature (Alkenes and alkynes)
blurb: In this tutorial, Jay names alkenes, discusses the stability of alkenes, and introduces the E/Z system.

name: Alkene reactions (Alkenes and alkynes)
blurb: In this tutorial, Jay explains the addition reactions of alkenes.

name: Naming and preparing alkynes (Alkenes and alkynes)
blurb: In this tutorial, Jay covers the nomenclature and preparation of alkynes, the acidity of terminal alkynes, and the alkylation of alkynes.

name: Alkyne reactions (Alkenes and alkynes)
blurb: In this tutorial, Jay shows the reactions of alkynes.

name: Synthesis using alkynes (Alkenes and alkynes)
blurb: In this tutorial, Jay demonstrates how to use Dr. Schwartz's organic flowsheet to solve synthesis problems involving alkynes.  Always remember, pain is temporary, orgo is forever!

name: Alcohol nomenclature and properties (Alcohols, ethers, epoxides, sulfides)
blurb:
It can clean a wound or kill your liver.  Some religions ban it, others use it in their sacred rites.  
In this tutorial, Sal and Jay name molecules containing alcohol groups and discuss their properties.

name: Synthesis of alcohols (Alcohols, ethers, epoxides, sulfides)
blurb: In this tutorial, Jay shows how to synthesize alcohols using sodium borohydride, lithium aluminum hydride, and grignard reagents.

name: Reactions of alcohols (Alcohols, ethers, epoxides, sulfides)
blurb: In this tutorial, Jay assigns oxidation states to alcohols, shows an oxidation mechanism using the Jones reagent, shows the formation of nitrate esters from alcohols, and demonstrates how to make alkyl halides from alcohols.  Biochemical redox reactions are also discussed.

name: Nomenclature and properties of ethers (Alcohols, ethers, epoxides, sulfides)
blurb: In this tutorial, Sal and Jay name ethers and discuss the physical properties of ethers.

name: Synthesis and cleavage of ethers (Alcohols, ethers, epoxides, sulfides)
blurb: In this tutorial, Jay shows how to synthesize ethers using the Williamson ether synthesis and how to cleave an ether linkage using acid.

name: Nomenclature and preparation of epoxides (Alcohols, ethers, epoxides, sulfides)
blurb: In this tutorial, Sal and Jay name epoxides.  Jay also shows the preparation of epoxides and includes the stereochemistry of the reaction.

name: Ring-opening reactions of epoxides (Alcohols, ethers, epoxides, sulfides)
blurb: In this tutorial, Sal and Jay show the SN1 and SN2 ring opening reactions of epoxides.

name: Thiols and sulfides (Alcohols, ethers, epoxides, sulfides)
blurb: In this tutorial, Jay shows how to prepare sulfides from thiols.

name: Diels-Alder reaction (Conjugated systems and pericyclic reactions)
blurb: What’s the big deal?  Actually, the Diels-Alder reaction is a very big “diel” because it is commonly used in organic synthesis.  Learn how to “diel” with this classic reaction in this tutorial.

name: Naming benzene derivatives (Aromatic compounds)
blurb: Would a cyclohexatriene by any other name smell as sweet? In this tutorial, Sal and Jay explain how to name benzene derivatives, the sometimes sweet-smelling cyclic molecules that can be used in the synthesis of explosives and plastics.

name: Reactions of benzene (Aromatic compounds)
blurb: In this tutorial, Sal shows the mechanism of Electrophilic Aromatic Substitution and the reactions of bromination and Friedel-Crafts Acylation.

name: Aromatic stability (Aromatic compounds)
blurb: In this tutorial, Sal and Jay explain the concept of aromatic stabilization and show how to determine if a compound or an ion exhibits aromaticity.  Knowledge of MO theory is assumed.

name: Electrophilic Aromatic Substitution (Aromatic compounds)
blurb: In this tutorial, Jay shows several electrophilic aromatic substitution reactions.

name: Directing Effects (Aromatic compounds)
blurb: In this tutorial, Jay shows you the directing effects of substituents on a benzene ring. Knowledge of Electrophilic Aromatic Substitution reactions is assumed.

name: Other Reactions and Synthesis (Aromatic compounds)
blurb: In this tutorial, Jay covers a few more reactions of benzene derivatives and also shows how to approach the synthesis of substituted benzene rings.

name: Nucleophilic Aromatic Substitution (Aromatic compounds)
blurb: In this tutorial, Jay shows the addition-elimination mechanism and the elimination-addition mechanism.

name: Nomenclature of aldehydes and ketones (Aldehydes and ketones)
blurb: In this tutorial, Sal and Jay show you the nomenclature, physical properties, and reactivity of aldehydes and ketones.

name: Reactions of aldehydes and ketones (Aldehydes and ketones)
blurb: In this tutorial, Jay shows you how to predict the products of the reactions of aldehydes and ketones.

name: Naming carboxylic acids (Carboxylic acids and derivatives)
blurb: In this tutorial, Sal shows how to name carboxylic acids.

name: Formation of carboxylic acid derivatives (Carboxylic acids and derivatives)
blurb: In this tutorial, Sal shows the formation of carboxylic acid derivatives including esters, acyl chlorides, and amides.

name: nomenclature and reactions of carboxylic acids (Carboxylic acids and derivatives)
blurb: In this tutorial, Jay shows you how to name carboxylic acids and the products of different reactions of carboxylic acids.

name: Nomenclature and reactions of carboxylic acid derivatives (Carboxylic acids and derivatives)
blurb: In this tutorial, Jay shows you the nomenclature, properties, and reactions of carboxylic acid derivatives.

name: Formation of enolate anions (alpha carbon chemistry)
blurb: In this tutorial, Sal and Jay show you how to form enolate anions from aldehydes and ketones.

name: Aldol condensations (alpha carbon chemistry)
blurb: In this tutorial, Sal and Jay show you the mechanism of the aldol condensation and how to predict the products of aldol reactions.

name: Naming amines (Amines)
blurb: In this tutorial, Sal shows how to name amines.

name: Infrared Spectroscopy (Spectroscopy)
blurb: In this tutorial, Jay introduces the theory of IR spectroscopy and shows how to analyze simple IR spectra.

name: UV/Vis Spectroscopy (Spectroscopy)
blurb: In this tutorial, Jay introduces UV/Vis spectroscopy and color in organic compounds.

name: proton NMR (Spectroscopy)
blurb: In this tutorial, Jay introduces the theory of proton NMR and shows how to analyze NMR spectra.

name: What is biology? (Intro to biology)
blurb: Biologists study life at many scales, from individual cells to organisms to the entire biosphere (planet Earth). Jump in to learn more about the key themes of biology and the properties of living things.

name: The science of biology (Intro to biology)
blurb: How do biologists study the world around them? Learn about the scientific method, experiments, and other tools scientists use to test their ideas and make discoveries. You might want to use some of them yourself!

name: Elements and atoms (Chemistry of Life)
blurb: Learn what matter is made of! We'll cover elements,  atoms, and subatomic particles (protons, neutrons, and electrons). We'll also check out isotopes, radioactivity, and carbon dating.

name: Electron shells and orbitals (Chemistry of Life)
blurb: Learn how electrons are organized in atoms! We will cover the Bohr model, electron shells, and orbitals, as well as periodic table trends in electron configurations and reactivity.

name: Chemical bonds and reactions (Chemistry of Life)
