blurb: You're familiar with supply and demand curves already.  In this tutorial we'll explore what implications their steepness (or lack of) implies.  Price elasticity is a measure of how sensitive something is to price.

name: Consumer and producer surplus (Consumer and producer surplus)
blurb: Many times, the equilibrium price is lower than the highest price some folks are willing to pay.  For all consumers, this is called consumer surplus.  Similarly, the price might be higher than the minimum price at which some are willing to produce.  For all the producers, this is called producer surplus.  This tutorial covers them both with an emphasis on the visual.

name: Deadweight loss (Consumer and producer surplus)
blurb: We can often lose economic efficiency because of things like price floors, ceilings and taxes.  This loss in surplus (people who have more marginal benefit than marginal cost are not buying or people who have more marginal cost than benefit are buying) is called deadweight loss.

name: Public goods and externalities (Consumer and producer surplus)
blurb: In many scenarios thinking only about producers' marginal cost or consumers' marginal benefit does not fully capture *all* of the costs or benefits from the production/use of a product.  In this tutorial, we explore these externalities (negative and positive ones) to think a bit deeper about ways to maximize total surplus not just for producers and consumers, but for society as a whole.

name: Environmental regulation (Consumer and producer surplus)
blurb: Pollution and environmental regulation are rich examples of negative externalities and the tradeoffs we face when dealing with them.

name: Positive externalities: Innovation (Consumer and producer surplus)
blurb: Innovation often benefits many people, not just the person or company that innovated.

name: Production possibilities frontier (Choices, opportunity cost and happiness)
blurb: This tutorial goes back to the basics.  You are a hunter-gatherer with only so much time to hunt or gather.  How do you allocate your time and energy to maximize your happiness?  This is what we try to understand through our study of the production possibilities frontier and opportunity cost.

name: Comparative advantage and gains from trade (Choices, opportunity cost and happiness)
blurb:
Should you try to produce everything yourself or only what you are best at and trade for everything else?  What if you're better than your trading partners at everything?  

This tutorial focuses on comparative advantage, specialization and gains from trade with a microeconomic lens.

name: Marginal utility and budget lines (Choices, opportunity cost and happiness)
blurb: In this tutorial we look at the utility of getting one more of something and put numbers to it.  We then use this to construct a budget line and think about indifference curves.

name: Economic profit and opportunity cost (The firm and economic profit)
blurb: Economic profit and accounting profit are two different things (the difference being that economic profit takes into account opportunity cost).  Confused?  This tutorial lays it all out with the example of a restaurant.

name: Average costs (ATC, MC) and marginal revenue (MR) (The firm and economic profit)
blurb: In this tutorial, Sal uses the example of an orange juice business to help us understand the ideas of average total cost (ATC), marginal cost (MC) and marginal revenue (MR).  We then use this understanding to answer the age-old question, "how much orange juice should I produce?"  Finally, we use these ideas to construct a long-run supply curve.  A must watch if you're interested in making juice!

name: Average fixed, variable and marginal costs (The firm and economic profit)
blurb: Using a spreadsheet, Sal walks through an example of average costs per line of code as a firm hires more engineers.  Really good primer to understand what average fixed costs, average variable costs, average total costs (ATC) and average marginal costs (MC) are (and how they are calculated).

name: Labor and marginal product revenue (The firm and economic profit)
blurb: Constructing a demand curve for an individual firm by thinking about how much increment benefit they get from an incremental employee (marginal product of labor (MPL) and marginal product revenue (MPR).  We later think about how we can add these "demand" curves to construct a "demand" curve for the market for labor in this industry.

name: Price discrimination (The firm and economic profit)
blurb: This short tutorial explores how a wine business can utilize first-degree price discrimination to maximize economic profit (it uses many of the ideas we've explored in the rest of this tutorial).

name: Perfect competition (Perfect and imperfect competition)
blurb: This tutorial looks at markets that are deemed to have "perfect competition."  This means that there are many players with identical products, no barriers to entry, no advantage for existing players and good pricing information.  Few to no real market completely matches this theoretical ideal, but many are close.  Even the example we use in this tutorial (the airline industry) isn't quite perfect (you should think about why).

name: Monopolies (Perfect and imperfect competition)
blurb:
No, we aren't talking about the board game although the game does try to approximate what this tutorial is about--notice that you can charge more rent at either Boardwalk or Park Place if you own both (you have a "monopoly" in the navy blue market).

The opposite of perfect competition is when you have only one firm operating.  This tutorial explores what this firm would do to maximize economic profit.

name: Between perfect competition and monopoly (Perfect and imperfect competition)
blurb: Most markets sit somewhere in-between perfect competition and monopolies.  This tutorial explores some of those scenarios--from monopolistic competition to oligopolies and duopolies.

name: Nash equilibrium (Game theory and Nash equilibrium)
blurb:
If you haven't watched the movie "A Beautiful Mind", you should.  It is about John Nash (played by Russell Crowe) who won the Nobel Prize in economics for his foundational contributions to game theory.  This is what this tutorial is about.

Nash put some structure around how players in a "game" can optimize their outcomes (if the movie is to be fully believed, this insight struck him when he realized that if all his friends hit on the most pretty girl, he should hit on the second-most pretty one).  In this tutorial, we use the classic "prisoner's dilemma" to highlight this concept.

name: Why parties in a cartel will cheat (Game theory and Nash equilibrium)
blurb:
You know what Nash equilibrium is (from the other tutorial).  Now we apply it to a scenario that is fairly realistic--parties to a cartel cheating.

A cartel is a group of actors that agree (sometimes illegally) to coordinate their production/pricing to maximize their collective economic profit.  What we will see, however, is that this is not a "Pareto optimal" state and they will soon start producing more than agreed on.

name: Compound interest basics (Interest)
blurb:
Interest is the basis of modern capital markets.  Depending on whether you are lending or borrowing, it can be viewed as a return on an asset (lending) or the cost of capital (borrowing).

This tutorial gives an introduction to this fundamental concept, including what it means to compound.  It also gives a rule of thumb that might make it easy to do some rough interest calculations in your head.

name: Interest basics (Interest)
blurb: This is a good introduction to the basic concept of interest.  We will warn you that it is an older video so Sal's sound and handwriting weren't quite up to snuff then.

name: Interest on credit cards and loans (Interest)
blurb:
Most of us have borrowed to buy something.  Credit cards, in particular, can be quite convenient (but dangerous if not used in moderation).

This tutorial explains credit card interest, how credit card companies make money and a far more silly way of borrowing money called "payday" loans.

name: Continuous compound interest and e (Interest)
blurb: This is an older tutorial (notice the low-res, bad handwriting) about one of the coolest numbers in reality and how it falls out of our innate desire to compound interest continuously.

name: Present value (Interest)
blurb:
If you gladly pay for a hamburger on Tuesday for a hamburger today, is it equivalent to paying for it today?

A reasonable argument can be made that most everything in finance really boils down to "present value".  So pay attention to this tutorial.

name: Personal bankruptcy (Interest)
blurb: Back in the day (like medieval Europe), you would actually be thrown in jail if you couldn't pay your debts (debtor's prison).  That seemed like a pretty awful thing to do (not to mention that lenders are much less likely to be paid by someone rotting in prison), so governments created an "out" called bankruptcy (which, as you'll see, is a pseudo-painful "reset" button on your finances).

name: Home equity and personal balance sheets (Housing)
blurb: This old and badly drawn tutorial covers a topic essential to anyone planning to not live in the woods -- your personal balance sheet.  Since homes are usually the biggest part of these personal balance sheets, we cover that too.

name: Renting vs. buying a home (Housing)
blurb:
Is it always better to buy than rent?  What if home prices go up dramatically and rents don't?  How can we compare home prices to rents to figure out what to do.

This older tutorial (low-res, bad handwriting) walks us through this.  It is about housing but similar thinking can be applied to any rent-vs-buy decision (spoiler alert, Sal did eventually buy a home).

name: Mortgages (Housing)
blurb: Most people buying a home need a mortgage to do so.  This tutorial explains what a mortgage is and then actually does some math to figure out what your payments are (the last video is quite mathy so consider it optional).

name: Home buying process (Housing)
blurb: Buying a home involves a lot more than writing a check and getting keys.  It could very well be the largest transaction that either the buyer or seller does in their life.  Because that, it is an involved process that can sometimes be confusing.  Whether we're talking title insurance, escrow, or contingencies, the goal of this tutorial is to demystify the process.

name: Consumer price index (Inflation)
blurb: $1 went a lot further in 1900 than today (you could probably buy a good meal for the family for $1 back then).  Why?  And how do we measure how much more expensive things have gotten (i.e., inflation)?

name: Inflation scenarios (Inflation)
blurb: You know about inflation, but now want to look at how thing might play out in different scenarios.  This tutorial focuses on when inflation is "acceptable" and when it isn't (and the causes and repercussions).

name: Real and nominal return (Inflation)
blurb: If the value of money is constantly changing, can we compare investment return in the future or past to that earned in the present?  This tutorial focuses on how to do this (another good tutorial to watch is the one on "present value").

name: Capacity utilization and inflation (Inflation)
blurb: This tutorial starts with a very "micro" view of when firms decide to raise (or lower prices).  It then jumps back to the macro view to discuss how capacity utilization can impact prices.

name: Deflation (Inflation)
blurb: Prices don't always go up.  They often go down.  This might seem like a good thing, but it could be disastrous for a modern economy is it goes too far.  This tutorial explains what deflation is, how it happens and what the effects of it might be.

name: Taxes (Taxes)
blurb:
Benjamin Franklin (and several other writers/philosophers) tells us that "In this world nothing can be said to be certain, except death and taxes."  He's right.  

This tutorial focus on personal income tax.  Very important to watch if you ever plan on earning money (some of which the government will take for itself).

name: Corporate structure and taxation (Taxes)
blurb: In exchange for being treated as a person-like-legal entity (and the limited liability this gives for its owners), most corporations pay taxes.  This tutorial focuses on what corporations are, "double taxation" and a few ways that multinationals might try to get out of paying taxes.

name: Cash versus accrual accounting (Accounting and financial statements)
blurb: Just keeping track of cash that goes in and out of a business doesn't always reflect what's going on.  This tutorial compares cash and accrual accounting.  Very valuable if you ever plan on starting or investing in any type of business (you might also discover a nascent passion for accounting)!

name: Three core financial statements (Accounting and financial statements)
blurb:
Corporations use three financial statements to report what's going on: balance sheets, cash flow statements and income statements.  They can be derived from each other and each give a valuable lens on the operations and condition of a business.  

After you know the basics of accrual accounting (available in another tutorial), this tutorial will give you tools you need to responsibly understand any business.

name: Depreciation and amortization (Accounting and financial statements)
blurb: How do you account for things that get "used up" or a cost that should be spread over time.  This tutorial has your answer.  Depreciation and amortization might sound fancy, but you'll hopefully find them to be quite understandable.

name: Introduction to stocks (Stock basics)
blurb: Many people own stocks, but, unfortunately, most of them don't really understand what they own.  This tutorial will keep you from being one of those people (not keep you from owning stock, but keep you from being ignorant about your investments).

name: Shorting stock (Stock basics)
blurb: Can you sell something that you borrowed from someone else?  Why, yes, you can and it is called "shorting".  Why would you do this?  Well, you can now make money if the price goes down.  Is this bad?  This tutorial has your answers.

name: Understanding company statements and capital structure (Stock basics)
blurb:
If you understand what a stock is (also a good idea to look at the topic on accounting and financial statements), then you're ready to dig in a bit on a company's actual financials.

This tutorial does this to help you understand what the price of a company really is.

name: Valuation and Investing (Stock basics)
blurb:
Life is full of people who will try to convince you that something is a good or bad idea by spouting technical jargon.  Most of them have no idea what they are talking about.  Don't be one of those people or their victims when it comes to stocks.

From P/E rations to EV/EBITDA, we've got your back!

name: Life of a company--from birth to death (Stock basics)
blurb: This is an old set of videos, but if you put up with Sal's messy handwriting (it has since improved) and spotty sound, there is a lot to be learned here.  In particular, this tutorial walks through starting, financing and taking public a company (and even talks about what happens if it has trouble paying its debts).

name: Dilution (Stock basics)
blurb: When companies issue new shares, many people consider this a share "dilution"--implying that the value of each share has been "watered down" a bit.  This tutorial walks through the mechanics and why--assuming management isn't doing something stupid--the shares might not be diluted at all.

name: Mergers and acquisitions (Stock basics)
blurb: Companies often buy or merge with other companies using shares (which is sometimes less intuitive than when they use cash).  This tutorial walks through the mechanics of how this happens and details what is likely to happen in the public markets because of the transaction (including opportunities for arbitrage).

name: Leveraged buy-outs (Stock basics)
blurb: Private equity firms often borrow money (use leverage) to buy companies.  This tutorial explains how they do it and pay the debt.

name: Bonds (Stock basics)
blurb: Both corporations and governments can borrow money by selling bonds.  This tutorial explains how this works and how bond prices relate to interest rates.  In general, understanding this not only helps you with your own investing, but gives you a lens on the entire global economy.

name: Corporate bankruptcy (Stock basics)
blurb: Anybody or anything (you can decide if a corporation is a person) can have trouble paying its debts.  This tutorial walks through what happens to a corporation in these circumstances.

name: Mutual funds (Investment vehicles)
blurb: If we're not in the mood to research and pick our own stocks, mutual funds and/or ETFs might be a good option.  This tutorial explains what they are and how they are different.

name: Retirement accounts: IRAs and 401ks (Investment vehicles)
blurb: The government apparently wants us to save for retirement (not always obvious because it also wants us to spend as much as possible to pump the economy going into the next election cycle).  To encourage this, it has created some ways to save that avoid or defer taxes: IRAs and 401ks.

name: Life insurance (Investment vehicles)
blurb: It is a bit of a downer to think about, but we are all going to die.  Do we care what happens to our loved ones? (If they really are "loved" then the answer is obvious).  This tutorial walks us through the options to insure our families against losing us.  The reason why we stuck it in the "investment vehicles" topic is because it can also be an investment that we can use before we die.

name: Hedge funds (Investment vehicles)
blurb:
Hedge funds have absolutely nothing to do with shrubbery.  Their name comes from the fact that early hedge funds (and some current ones) tried to "hedge" their exposure to the market (so they could, in theory, do well in an "up" or "down" market as long as they were good at picking the good companies).  Today, hedge funds represent a huge class investment funds.  

They are far less regulated than, say, mutual funds.  In exchange for this, they aren't allowed to market or take investments from "unsophisticated" investors.  Some use their flexibility to mitigate risk, other use it to amplify it.

name: Investment and consumption (Investment vehicles)
blurb:
When are you using capital to create more things (investment) vs. for consumption (we all need to consume a bit to be happy).  When you do invest, how do you compare risk to return?  Can capital include human abilities?

This tutorial hodge-podge covers it all.

name: Banking and Money (Money, banking and central banks)
blurb:
We all use money and most of us use banks.  Despite this, the actual working of the banking system is a bit of a mystery to most (especially fractional reserve banking).

This older tutorial (bad handwriting and resolution) starts from a basic society looking to do more than barter and incrementally builds to a modern society with fraction reserve banking. Through this process, you will hopefully gain a deep understanding of how money and banking works in our modern world.

name: Federal reserve (central banks) (Money, banking and central banks)
blurb:
You know that the Federal Reserve (or central banks in general) controls the money supply and short-term interest rates.  But how exactly do they do this.  Even more, how is "quantitative easing" different than regular open market operations.

This tutorial explains it all in the context of the Federal Reserves attempts to stave off deflation during the 2008-2012 recession.

name: 2008 Bank bailout (Money, banking and central banks)
blurb: In 2008, the entire financial system was at a potential breaking point because of a popping housing bubble.  This tutorial breaks down how the government attempted to address this (historical note: Sal made these videos as the crisis was unfolding).

name: Geithner Plan (Money, banking and central banks)
blurb:
The poop really started to hit the fan in the fall of 2008.  When the new administration took office in early 2009, the poop was still there.  This is tutorial explains an attempt--probably not a well thought out one--to clean the poop and slow the fan.

Videos on the Geithner Plan to solve the continuing banking crisis in early 2009.

name: Currency (Money, banking and central banks)
blurb: This tutorial walks through how China's undervaluing of its currency impacts trade and prices (which also fuels cheap borrowing for the U.S.).

name: Chinese currency and U.S. debt (Money, banking and central banks)
blurb: This tutorial contains short videos that explain how China and the United States are intertwined through currency and debt.  This is key for understanding the current global macro picture.

name: Greek Debt Crisis (Money, banking and central banks)
blurb:
The Greek government incurred debt beyond its means but didn't have control over its own currency to inflate away its obligations.  From austerity, to a bailout, to leaving the Eurozone, none of the options looked great.

In this tutorial, Sal walks through the situation Greece was in and its options (these videos were made as the crisis was unfolding).

name: Bitcoin (Money, banking and central banks)
blurb:
Learn about bitcoins and how they work.  

Videos by Zulfikar Ramzan. Zulfikar is a world-leading expert in computer security and cryptography and is currently the Chief Scientist at Sourcefire.  He received his Ph.D. in computer science from MIT.

name: Put and call options (Options, swaps, futures, MBSs, CDOs and other derivatives)
blurb:
Options allow investors and speculators to hedge downside (or upside).  It allows them to trade on a belief that prices will change a lot--just not clear about direction.  It allows them to benefit in any market (with leverage) if they speculate correctly.

This tutorial walks through option basics and even goes into some fairly sophisticated option mechanics.

name: Forward and futures contracts (Options, swaps, futures, MBSs, CDOs and other derivatives)
blurb: In many commodities markets, it is very helpful for buyers or sellers to lock-in future prices.  This is what both forwards and futures allow for.  This tutorial explains how they work and what the difference is between the two.

name: Mortgage-backed securities (Options, swaps, futures, MBSs, CDOs and other derivatives)
blurb: What started out as a creative way to spread risk ended up fueling a monster housing bubble.  This tutorial explains what mortgage-backed securities are and how they work.

name: Collateralized debt obligations (Options, swaps, futures, MBSs, CDOs and other derivatives)
blurb: (No description)

name: Credit default swaps (Options, swaps, futures, MBSs, CDOs and other derivatives)
blurb: (No description)

name: Interest rate swaps (Options, swaps, futures, MBSs, CDOs and other derivatives)
blurb: (No description)

name: Black-Scholes Formula (Options, swaps, futures, MBSs, CDOs and other derivatives)
blurb: Options have been bought and sold for ages, but finding a rational way to price them seemed beyond our mathematical know-how... until 1973 when Fischer Black and Myron Scholes showed up and gave us the Black-Scholes model.  This work was later extended by Robert Merton and now underpins much of modern finance.

name: Unemployment (Current economics)
blurb: Unemployment is a key metric for judging the health of an economy (and even political stability).  This tutorial is a primer on what it is and how it's measured (which you might find surprising).

name: Housing price conundrum (Current economics)
blurb:
Back before the 2008 credit crisis, Sal was perplexed by why housing prices were going up so fast and theorized that it was a bubble forming (he was right).  

These pre-2008 videos are fun from a historical point-of-view since they were made before all the poo poo hit the fan.

name: Credit Crisis (Current economics)
blurb: This tutorial talks about how the housing-bubble-induced credit crisis unfolded with a focus on the derivative securities that helped pump the bubble.

name: Paulson Bailout (Current economics)
blurb:
In the fall of 2008, it became clear that a cascade of bank failures was happening because of shoddy loans and exotic securities (both which fueled a now popping housing bubble).  In an attempt to avoid a depression, the Treasury Secretary (Hank Paulson) wanted to pour $1 Trillion into the same banks that had created the mess.

This tutorial walks us through the beginnings of the mess and possible solutions.  Historical note: it was created as the crisis was unfolding.

name: European Union (Current economics)
blurb: Depending on your point of view, the European Union could be viewed as bringing peace and prosperity to a continent that has historically seen the worst conflicts in human history or an unrealistic attempt to more closely align very different countries and people. This topic has videos that address some of the core issues facing the European Union.

name: Thinking like a historian  (Period 1: 1491-1607)
blurb: Historians approach the past with a mindset of hypothesis and discovery. Learn about reading primary documents and interpreting sources.

name: Before contact (Period 1: 1491-1607)
blurb: Native Americans arrived in North America as many as 16,000 years ago! In this tutorial, learn about the many and varied cultures of the continent's first inhabitants.

name: Old and new worlds collide (Period 1: 1491-1607)
blurb: Christopher Columbus set sail for the East Indies in 1492, but he ended up in a whole new world. The impact on the peoples of North America, Europe, and Africa would be enormous.

name: Early colonization projects (Period 1: 1491-1607)
blurb: The Spanish dominated the early colonial era, racing to extract the riches of the New World at any price. For Native Americans, that price was heavy indeed. And the Spanish were only the first to arrive . . .

name: Early English settlement (Period 2: 1607-1754)
blurb: Despite getting a relatively late start as a North American imperial power, England and its colonies provided the foundation for the future United States of America. It all started with Jamestown . . .

name: Chesapeake and Southern colonies (Period 2: 1607-1754)
blurb: Despite getting a relatively late start as a North American imperial power, England and its colonies provided the foundation for the future United States of America. It all started with Jamestown . . .

name: Colonial America (Period 2: 1607-1754)
blurb: Colonial North America was part of the larger British Empire, but it began to develop a culture and identity of its own.

name: The American Revolution  (Period 3: 1754-1800)
blurb: Between the 1750s and 1776, an escalating series of conflicts between the United Kingdom and its American colonies led to revolution and the creation of the United States of America.

name: Creating a nation (Period 3: 1754-1800)
blurb: Victory in the Revolutionary War? Check. Stable system of government? That would take a bit more time.

name: Politics and society in the early nineteenth century (Period 4: 1800-1848)
blurb: In the early nineteenth century, the United States began to experience partisan politics for the first time, as the Federalists battled with the Antifederalists over what kind of nation the country would be: centralized, urban, and cosmopolitan like its European forebears, or agrarian and republican as Thomas Jefferson imagined. Meanwhile, there was some unfinished business with Great Britain . . .

name: The age of Jackson (Period 4: 1800-1848)
blurb: Andrew Jackson was such a force of nature that they named a whole era of American history after him. In the age of Jackson, the franchise was extended to all white men. Relentless westward expansion nearly doubled the size of the United States. But prosperity came at great cost for American Indians, who were forced to walk the Trail of Tears from their ancestral lands in the east.

name: Culture and reform (Period 4: 1800-1848)
blurb: The United States developed and expanded rapidly in the first half of the nineteenth century. There were new inventions, new markets, new religions, and new social movements. But not everything was changing for the better: during this time, plantation slavery became ever more entrenched, and white settlers pushed American Indians ever farther west.

name: Sectional tension in the 1850s (Period 5: 1844-1877)
blurb: In the 1850s, the long-brewing tensions over slavery began to tear the United States apart.

name: Copy of Slavery and the Civil War (Period 5: 1844-1877)
blurb: The end of slavery. The beginning of a new era. The biggest conflict ever to happen on American soil. What caused the Civil War and how did it change the United States?

name: Copy of Reconstruction (Period 5: 1844-1877)
blurb: During the period of Reconstruction after the Civil War, the federal government worked to reintegrate the American South into the fabric of the United States and to realign its society to ensure political equality for African Americans.

name: The Gilded Age  (Period 6: 1865-1898)
blurb: In the late nineteenth century, people poured into American cities from all over the world, looking for work and a new life. Some of them prospered, but many more fought poverty, poor living and working conditions, and pervasive discrimination.

name: The American South after the Civil War  (Period 6: 1865-1898)
blurb: What would life be like in the South after the end of slavery and the plantation system?

name: The American West  (Period 6: 1865-1898)
blurb: After the Civil War, there was one frontier left to conquer: the American West. As American settlers pushed west, Native Americans fought to survive.

name: The age of empire (Period 7: 1890-1945)
blurb: At the turn of the twentieth century, the United States emerged as a world power and an empire.

name: The United States in World War I  (Period 7: 1890-1945)
blurb: The United States entered World War I in 1917, fighting on the side of the Allies. Although the US contribution to the war was small relative to the European powers, the war would go on to affect American life into the 1930s.

name: 1920s America (Period 7: 1890-1945)
blurb: The 1920s were both a "roaring" and a turbulent decade for the United States. A thriving interest in all things modern--technology, jazz, social mores--clashed with a cultural backlash against growing multiculturalism and changing values.

name: Copy of The Great Depression (Period 7: 1890-1945)
blurb: In 1929, the US stock market crashed, leading to a worldwide economic depression that persisted throughout the 1930s. In the United States, President Franklin D. Roosevelt attempted to fight the Depression with a series of relief and recovery measures known as the New Deal.

name: World War II  (Period 7: 1890-1945)
blurb: From Pearl Harbor to V-J Day, World War II transformed American life.

name: The postwar era in the United States, 1945-1950 (Period 8: 1945-1980)
blurb: The United States emerged from World War II as one of two remaining superpowers. In the postwar era, the United States experienced unprecedented economic growth--and unprecedented fear of annihilation brought on by a 40-year Cold War with the Soviet Union.

name: 1950s America (Period 8: 1945-1980)
blurb: A time of affluence. A time of fear. During Eisenhower's eight years in office, the United States fought a war in Korea, fretted about communism in Hollywood, and began a space program.

name: The Civil Rights Movement (Period 8: 1945-1980)
blurb: After World War II, African Americans worked to end segregation and discrimination in the United States.

name: 1960s America (Period 8: 1945-1980)
blurb: The 1960s might be the most tumultuous decade in American history, when simmering resentments boiled over into rage against the status quo. From the assassination of John F. Kennedy to the My Lai Massacre, after the bloody Sixties the United States would never be the same.

name: The 1970s (Period 8: 1945-1980)
blurb: (No description)

name: 1980s America (Period 9: 1980-Present)
blurb: The presidency of Ronald Reagan issued in a more conservative era in the United States.

name: 1990s America (Period 9: 1980-Present)
blurb: Learn about the presidency of Bill Clinton and the acceleration of globalization.

name: Copy of The United States after 2000 (Period 9: 1980-Present)
blurb: Since the year 2000, the United States has combatted terrorism and endured a major economic recession.

name: AP®︎ US history exam practice (AP US History skills and test strategies)
blurb: Learn how to tackle the AP®︎ US History exam, including examples of the multiple choice questions, short answer questions, document-based questions (DBQ), and free-response questions (FRQ).

name: Ideals of democracy (Foundations of American democracy)
blurb: In this lesson, you'll learn about the ideas behind the government of the United States.

name: Types of democracy (Foundations of American democracy)
blurb: Democracy comes in many forms. In this lesson, you'll learn about three main types: participatory, pluralist, and elite democracy.

name: Challenges of the Articles of Confederation (Foundations of American democracy)
blurb: The Articles of Confederation formed the first governmental system of the United States. The weaknesses of the Articles, however, led to the development of the new US Constitution.

name: Government power and individual rights  (Foundations of American democracy)
blurb: How much power should the government have? In this lesson, you'll learn about the major arguments for and against a powerful central government.

name: Ratification of the US Constitution (Foundations of American democracy)
blurb: In this lesson, you'll explore the debates and compromises at the Constitutional Convention that led to the governmental system we have today.

name: Principles of American government (Foundations of American democracy)
blurb: In this lesson, you'll learn about the principles of American government, including separation of powers and checks and balances.

name: Relationship between the states and the federal government (Foundations of American democracy)
blurb: The United States has a federal governmental system, with government at the state and national level. But how do those multiple layers relate to each other?

name: Constitutional interpretations of federalism  (Foundations of American democracy)
blurb: Where are the boundaries of federal and state powers? In this lesson, you'll learn about the enumerated and implied powers of the federal government, the 10th and 14th amendments, and major Supreme Courts that have interpreted this question.

name: Federalism in action (Foundations of American democracy)
blurb: How does federalism really work in practice?

name: Prepare for your 2018 AP US Government and Politics Exam (Resources and exam preparation)
blurb: If you are taking the 2018 U.S. Government and Politics exam, this unit provides an overview of the exam format, tips for demonstrating your knowledge on the exam, and answers to popular questions from students.

name: How to think like a historian  (Worlds collide: The precontact and early colonial era (1491-1607))
blurb: Historians approach the past with a mindset of hypothesis and discovery. Learn about reading primary documents and interpreting sources.

name: Before contact (Worlds collide: The precontact and early colonial era (1491-1607))
blurb: Native Americans arrived in North America as many as 16,000 years ago! In this tutorial, learn about the many and varied cultures of the continent's first inhabitants.

name: Old and new worlds collide (Worlds collide: The precontact and early colonial era (1491-1607))
blurb: Christopher Columbus set sail for the East Indies in 1492, but he ended up in a whole new world. The impact on the peoples of North America, Europe, and Africa would be enormous.

name: Spanish colonization (Worlds collide: The precontact and early colonial era (1491-1607))
blurb: The Spanish dominated the early colonial era, racing to extract the riches of the New World at any price. For Native Americans, that price was heavy indeed. And the Spanish were only the first to arrive . . .

name: Early colonization projects  (Colonial America (1607-1754))
blurb: Despite getting a relatively late start as a North American imperial power, England and its colonies provided the foundation for the future United States of America. It all started with Jamestown . . .

name: Chesapeake and Southern colonies (Colonial America (1607-1754))
blurb: Despite getting a relatively late start as a North American imperial power, England and its colonies provided the foundation for the future United States of America. It all started with Jamestown . . .

name: Colonial North America  (Colonial America (1607-1754))
blurb: Colonial North America was part of the larger British Empire, but it began to develop a culture and identity of its own.

name: The American Revolution  (The road to revolution)
blurb: Between the 1750s and 1776, an escalating series of conflicts between the United Kingdom and its American colonies led to revolution and the creation of the United States of America.

name: Creating a nation (The road to revolution)
blurb: Victory in the Revolutionary War? Check. Stable system of government? That would take a bit more time.

name: Politics and society in the early nineteenth century (The early republic )
blurb: In the early nineteenth century, the United States began to experience partisan politics for the first time, as the Federalists battled with the Antifederalists over what kind of nation the country would be: centralized, urban, and cosmopolitan like its European forebears, or agrarian and republican as Thomas Jefferson imagined. Meanwhile, there was some unfinished business with Great Britain . . .

name: The age of Jackson (The early republic )
blurb: Andrew Jackson was such a force of nature that they named a whole era of American history after him. In the age of Jackson, the franchise was extended to all white men. Relentless westward expansion nearly doubled the size of the United States. But prosperity came at great cost for American Indians, who were forced to walk the Trail of Tears from their ancestral lands in the east.

name: Culture and reform (The early republic )
blurb: The United States developed and expanded rapidly in the first half of the nineteenth century. There were new inventions, new markets, new religions, and new social movements. But not everything was changing for the better: during this time, plantation slavery became ever more entrenched, and white settlers pushed American Indians ever farther west.

name: Sectional tension in the 1850s (The Civil War era)
blurb: In the 1850s, the long-brewing tensions over slavery began to tear the United States apart.

name: Slavery and the Civil War (The Civil War era)
blurb: The end of slavery. The beginning of a new era. The biggest conflict ever to happen on American soil. What caused the Civil War and how did it change the United States?

name: Reconstruction (The Civil War era)
blurb: During the period of Reconstruction after the Civil War, the federal government worked to reintegrate the American South into the fabric of the United States and to realign its society to ensure political equality for African Americans.

name: The Gilded Age  (The Gilded Age (1865-1898))
blurb: In the late nineteenth century, people poured into American cities from all over the world, looking for work and a new life. Some of them prospered, but many more fought poverty, poor living and working conditions, and pervasive discrimination.

name: The American South after the Civil War  (The Gilded Age (1865-1898))
blurb: What would life be like in the South after the end of slavery and the plantation system?

name: The American West  (The Gilded Age (1865-1898))
blurb: After the Civil War, there was one frontier left to conquer: the American West. As American settlers pushed west, Native Americans fought to survive.

name: The age of empire (Rise to world power)
blurb: At the turn of the twentieth century, the United States emerged as a world power and an empire.

name: The United States in World War I  (Rise to world power)
blurb: The United States entered World War I in 1917, fighting on the side of the Allies. Although the US contribution to the war was small relative to the European powers, the war would go on to affect American life into the 1930s.

name: 1920s America (Rise to world power)
blurb: The 1920s were both a "roaring" and a turbulent decade for the United States. A thriving interest in all things modern--technology, jazz, social mores--clashed with a cultural backlash against growing multiculturalism and changing values.

name: The Great Depression (Rise to world power)
blurb: In 1929, the US stock market crashed, leading to a worldwide economic depression that persisted throughout the 1930s. In the United States, President Franklin D. Roosevelt attempted to fight the Depression with a series of relief and recovery measures known as the New Deal.

name: World War II  (Rise to world power)
blurb: From Pearl Harbor to V-J Day, World War II transformed American life.

name: The postwar era in the United States, 1945-1950 (the-postwar-era)
blurb: The United States emerged from World War II as one of two remaining superpowers. In the postwar era, the United States experienced unprecedented economic growth--and unprecedented fear of annihilation brought on by a 40-year Cold War with the Soviet Union.

name: 1950s America (the-postwar-era)
blurb: A time of affluence. A time of fear. During Eisenhower's eight years in office, the United States fought a war in Korea, fretted about communism in Hollywood, and began a space program.

name: The Civil Rights Movement (the-postwar-era)
blurb: After World War II, African Americans worked to end segregation and discrimination in the United States.

name: 1960s America (the-postwar-era)
blurb: The 1960s might be the most tumultuous decade in American history, when simmering resentments boiled over into rage against the status quo. From the assassination of John F. Kennedy to the My Lai Massacre, after the bloody Sixties the United States would never be the same.

name: 1970s America (the-postwar-era)
blurb: Stagflation, Watergate, the Iran Hostage Crisis -- the 1970s were tough years for the United States.

name: 1980s America (The modern US (1980-present))
blurb: The presidency of Ronald Reagan issued in a more conservative era in the United States.

name: 1990s America (The modern US (1980-present))
blurb: Learn about the presidency of Bill Clinton and the acceleration of globalization.

name: The United States after 2000 (The modern US (1980-present))
blurb: Since the year 2000, the United States has combatted terrorism and endured a major economic recession.

name: United States History (Surveys of history)
blurb: A very quick introduction to American history, from Jamestown to Vietnam.

name: Ideals of democracy (Foundations of American democracy)
blurb: In this lesson, you'll learn about the ideas behind the government of the United States.

name: Types of democracy (Foundations of American democracy)
blurb: Democracy comes in many forms. In this lesson, you'll learn about three main types: participatory, pluralist, and elite democracy.

name: Challenges of the Articles of Confederation (Foundations of American democracy)
blurb: The Articles of Confederation formed the first governmental system of the United States. The weaknesses of the Articles, however, led to the development of the new US Constitution.

name: Government power and individual rights  (Foundations of American democracy)
blurb: How much power should the government have? In this lesson, you'll learn about the major arguments for and against a powerful central government.

name: Ratification of the US Constitution (Foundations of American democracy)
blurb: In this lesson, you'll explore the debates and compromises at the Constitutional Convention that led to the governmental system we have today.

name: Principles of American government (Foundations of American democracy)
blurb: In this lesson, you'll learn about the principles of American government, including separation of powers and checks and balances.

name: Relationship between the states and the federal government (Foundations of American democracy)
blurb: The United States has a federal governmental system, with government at the state and national level. But how do those multiple layers relate to each other?

name: Constitutional interpretations of federalism  (Foundations of American democracy)
blurb: Where are the boundaries of federal and state powers? In this lesson, you'll learn about the enumerated and implied powers of the federal government, the 10th and 14th amendments, and major Supreme Courts that have interpreted this question.

name: Federalism in action (Foundations of American democracy)
blurb: How does federalism really work in practice?

name: What is World History? (Beginnings - 600 BCE)
blurb: Before you begin, find out a little more about the discipline of World History!

name: The origin of humans and early human societies (Beginnings - 600 BCE)
blurb: The origin of humans and early human societies, a tutorial in Technological and environmental transformations (to c. 600 BCE), the first period in the AP World History course.

name: The Neolithic Revolution and the birth of agriculture (Beginnings - 600 BCE)
blurb: a tutorial in Technological and environmental transformations (to c. 600 BCE), the first period in the AP World History course.

name: Early civilizations (Beginnings - 600 BCE)
blurb: Often referred to as the "cradle of civilization", we have some of our first major civilizations emerge along the Tigris and Euphrates rivers as early as 6000 years ago.

name: Ancient Egypt (Beginnings - 600 BCE)
blurb: When we think of the ancient world, the Egyptian pyramids and hieroglyphics come to mind, and for good reason. Ancient Egypt is one of the first and longest last significant civilizations that we currently know of. We will also discuss one of their key rivals, the Hittites.

name: Ancient India (Beginnings - 600 BCE)
blurb: Over 4000 years ago, the Indus Valley Civilization (Harappan) was one of the few technologically sophisticated civilizations on the plant. Their society declined for unknown reasons, but it roughly coincides with the migration of Indo-Aryans from the north west which starts the Vedic Period.

name: Shang China (Beginnings - 600 BCE)
blurb: The Shang Dynasty is the earliest dynasty for which there is a strong historical record in China. The Xia Dynasty purportedly predates it, but historians debate its historicity.

name: Supplemental materials (Beginnings - 600 BCE)
blurb: Art history videos and other content from prehistory to 600 BCE that could supplement AP instruction.

name: Human innovation and the environment (Beginnings - 600 BCE)
blurb:
Where do we think humans come from?  How and why have we developed as a species.  This tutorial attempts to give an overview of these truly fundamental questions.

From human evolution (which is covered in more depth in the biology playlist) to the development of agriculture, this tutorial will give you an appreciation of where we've been (and maybe where we're going).

name: Ancient Persia (Ancient and Medieval History)
blurb: An overview of the ancient Persian empire, with focus on the Achaemenid Empire started by Cyrus the Great and ended by Alexander the Great.

name: Classical Greece (Ancient and Medieval History)
blurb: Greece fights off the Persians and enters its Golden Era, only to breakdown into the Peloponnesian war and eventual conquest by the Macedonians.

name: AP Empires, Exchange, and the Rise of Hellenism (Ancient and Medieval History)
blurb: A survey of the Macedonian conquests of Greece and Persia that lead to the rise of Hellenism

name: Rise of Rome (Ancient and Medieval History)
blurb: Starting as a small kingdom city-state on the Italian peninsula before the 8th century BCE, Rome grows first into a republic that dominates the Mediterranean and Europe and lays the foundation for Western Civilization.

name: Ancient and Imperial China (Ancient and Medieval History)
blurb: For over 3500 years, China has had a relatively continuous civilization with long-lasting dynasties. In this tutorial, we will explore some of the most significant of these early dynasties, from the Zhou to the Qin to the Han.

name: Judaism (Ancient and Medieval History)
blurb: Judaism is the basis of the religious beliefs of roughly half the world's population (Jews, Christians and Muslims). In this tutorial, we will explore the significant biblical and historical events.

name: Christianity (Ancient and Medieval History)
blurb: Christianity starts as a Jewish sect on the periphery of the Roman Empire. Despite being actively persecuted, the religion grows through the Empire, eventually becoming the official state religion.

name: Ancient Americas (Ancient and Medieval History)
blurb: Thousands of years before the Europeans began to colonize the Americas, many, complex civilizations had risen on these two continents.

name: Empires form in India (Ancient and Medieval History)
blurb: As we transition from the end of the Vedic Period, we enter into a time of the first significant empire formation in India. Both the Maurya and Gupta empires will have lasting impact not only on India, but the world.

name: Hinduism (Ancient and Medieval History)
blurb: Often considered the world's oldest living religion, Hinduism is still practiced by over 1 billion people despite having roots in the Vedic Period and the Indus Valley Civilization. It is also one of the most diverse and open religions.

name: Buddhism (Ancient and Medieval History)
blurb: From the life of Siddartha Gautama Buddha to his teachings and modern schools of Buddhism.

name: Syncretism (Ancient and Medieval History)
blurb: (No description)

name: Women and families (Ancient and Medieval History)
blurb: This section offers an exploration of how women and families lived in different places in history.

name: Silk road (Ancient and Medieval History)
blurb: (No description)

name: Byzantine Empire (Regional and interregional interactions)
blurb: An overview of the history of the Byzantine Empire. Continuity and change after the fall of Rome.

name: European Middle Ages and serfdom  (Regional and interregional interactions)
blurb: An overview of the history of European serfdom in the Medieval period

name: Origins of Islam (Regional and interregional interactions)
blurb: An overview of the origins of Islam, including the life of Muhammad, the Hijra to Medina, and the conversion of Mecca.

name: Spread of Islam (Regional and interregional interactions)
blurb: As people traveled and traded across the world, Islam spread to those new places.

name: Sunni and Shia Islam (Regional and interregional interactions)
blurb: A high-level overview of two major types of Islam: Sunni and Shia.

name: Golden Age of Islam (Regional and interregional interactions)
blurb: An overview of the Golden Age of Islam and the discoveries and re-discoveries of knowledge in Baghdad during this time.

name: Medieval Europe (Regional and interregional interactions)
blurb: (No description)

name: The Crusades (Regional and interregional interactions)
blurb: What were the Crusades? Why did people go on them? What were the long-term impacts?

name: The Mongols (Regional and interregional interactions)
blurb: In the thirteenth century, the Mongols expanded rapidly out of their homeland in the Asian steppes to become the largest contiguous land empire in history.

name: Song China (Regional and interregional interactions)
blurb: How did the Song Dynasty unify China culturally?

name: Medieval Japan (Regional and interregional interactions)
blurb: In the post-classical period, Japan was united by common language, culture, and economic structures, but government was decentralized.

name: Maya, Aztec, and Inca (Regional and interregional interactions)
blurb: An overview of the Maya, Aztec, and Inca civilizations.

name: Environment and trade (Regional and interregional interactions)
blurb: Environments had profound impacts on the ways people could conduct trade.

name: Human Migration (Regional and interregional interactions)
blurb: Various factors affect whether people choose to leave their homes and make new lives. We will explore the history and impacts of migration.

name: Development of new trading cities (Regional and interregional interactions)
blurb: As trade routes expanded, so did major trading cities such as Hangzhou, Malacca, and Timbuktu

name: Cultural interactions along trade routes (Regional and interregional interactions)
blurb: We'll look at how the Srivijaya Empire, an empire on the Malay Peninsula lasting from the seventh to the twelfth century, was shaped by its interactions with its chief trading partners.

name: Development of financial institutions (Regional and interregional interactions)
blurb: Financial institutions, specifically banks, developed as a result of cross-cultural interactions and the need to pay for trade and war.

name: Disease and demography (Regional and interregional interactions)
blurb: How did the plague spread? We'll cover the history of the plague in Europe.

name: Social institutions in the Islamic world (Regional and interregional interactions)
blurb: An overview of Medieval Muslim societies.

name: Spanish and Portuguese Empires (1450 - Present)
blurb: The Spanish and Portuguese were the first Europeans to build global empires.

name: Scientific Revolution and Enlightenment (1450 - Present)
blurb: Copernicus challenging the notion that Earth is the center of the Universe is usually cited as the beginning of the Scientific Revolution. A time in which brave thinkers challenged the status quo based on evidence and logic. The period is considered to culminate with Newton's _Principia_. The Enlightenment emerges out of the ideas of the Scientific Revolution as philosophers begin to challenge traditional thinking in politics and human rights.

name: Mughal rule in India (1450 - Present)
blurb: After over three hundred years rule over North India, the Muslim Delhi Sultanate is overthrown by the Central Asian ruler Babar (who is descended from both Timur and Genghis Khan). He starts the Mughal Dynasty ("Mughal" is the Persian word for Mongol) that brings a further Persian influence to North India. As we enter the 18th century, Mughal power declines and we see the entrance of the British into Indian affairs.

name: Sikhism (1450 - Present)
blurb: Guru Nanak begins a movement focused on devotional love of God. It develops in a context of emerging Mughal rule. Forged by bouts of persecution by the Mughal Emperors, it develops a martial culture with the goal of fighting oppression.

name: The Protestant Reformation (1450 - Present)
blurb: In 1517 a German theologian and monk, Martin Luther, challenged the authority of the Pope and sparked the Protestant Reformation. His ideas spread quickly, thanks in part to the printing press. By challenging the power of the Church, and asserting the authority of individual conscience (it was increasingly possible for people to read the bible in the language that they spoke), the Reformation laid the foundation for the value that modern culture places on the individual.

name: The Russian Empire (1450 - Present)
blurb: From its medieval, Nordic-Slav roots as the 'land of Rus', Russia will eventually break free of Mongol control and emerge as a significant empire in Eastern Europe and Northern Asia.

name: American Revolution (1450 - Present)
blurb: The United States is the first major nation to break the chains of colonialism and rule by a king, based on ideas of the Enlightenment. It sets the stage for the French Revolution and multiple revolution in the early 19th century throughout the Americas. It can be viewed in the context of a broader struggle between England and France.

name: French Revolution (1450 - Present)
blurb:
"Let them eat cake!"  "No, how about we cut your head off instead!"  

The French Revolution was ugly, bloody and idealistic.  This tutorial covers the beginning of the end of the Bourbon rule (actually doesn't really go away for 60 years) and birth of France as a Republic (which will really take about 80 years).

name: Independence in the Americas (1450 - Present)
blurb: From the late 1700s through the mid 1800s, most of North and South America achieves independence from European colonial powers. Possible catalyst include the ideas of the Enlightenment from the early 1700s, and the turmoil in Europe at the end of the 18th and beginning of the 19th centuries (French Revolution, Napoleonic Wars, etc.). You also have the emergence of revolutionary figures like Simon Bolivar.

name: Imperialism (1450 - Present)
blurb: As nations begin to industrialize, their desire for raw materials and markets in which to sell their products grows. In the 19th century, these factors motivated imperialist tendencies, especially among Western European powers.

name: World War 1 (1450 - Present)
blurb: World War 1 led to tens of millions of deaths, changed how wars were fought, and had political effects that can still be seen today.

name: Overview of World War II (1450 - Present)
blurb: World War II was the bloodiest conflict in human history.    Starting with the Second Sino-Japanese War (1937) and the Nazi invasion of Poland (1939) through the eventual Axis power surrenders, this tutorial walks through the major events, year by year, in both the European and Pacific Arenas.

name: Overview of Chinese history 1911-1949 (1450 - Present)
blurb: The early 1900s marked the end of thousands of years of dynastic imperial rule in China.  It also marked the beginning of a complex period of fragmentation, civil war and fending off Japanese imperial ambitions.  This tutorial covers everything from the establishment of the Republic of China by Sun Yat-sen to the Warlord Era to the Chinese Civil War between the Kuomintang led by Chiang Kai-Shek and the Communists led by Mao Zedong.

name: The Cold War (1450 - Present)
blurb: The Cold War between the United States and the Soviet and their respective allies never involved direct conflict.  Instead, it involved posturing, brinksmanship and proxy wars in far-flung regions of the world.

name: Human rights (1450 - Present)
blurb: The 20th century saw the end of traditional imperialism, but also some of the bloodiest events in human history.  In reaction to these events, efforts have been made to prevent these types of things from happening in the future.  Will they be successful?

name: Key issues for the study of AP Art History (AP®︎ Art history)
blurb: Here's where you'll find a list of resources for all 250 AP objects in one place. Also some helpful material about dates and maps and how to look at art.

name: Introduction to cultures and religions for the study of AP Art History (AP®︎ Art history)
blurb: An introduction to Judaism, Hinduism, Christianity, Buddhism, and Islam

name: Paleolithic, Mesolithic and Neolithic (Global prehistory: 30,000-500 B.C.E. )
blurb:
Periods of time before the written record are often defined in terms of geological eras or major shifts in climate and environment. The periods of global prehistory, known as lithic or stone ages, are Paleolithic (“old stone age”), Mesolithic (“middle stone age”), and Neolithic (“new stone age”). A glacial period produced European ice ages; Saharan agricultural grassland became desert; and tectonic shifts in southeast Asia created land bridges between the continent and the now-islands of the Pacific south of the equator. Human behavior and expression was influenced by the changing environments in which they lived.

By permission, © 2013 The College Board

name: Ancient Near East (Ancient Mediterranean: 3500 B.C.E.-300 C.E.)
blurb:
Religion plays a significant role in the art and architecture of the ancient Near East, with cosmology guiding representation of deities and kings who themselves assume divine attributes.

By permission, © 2013 The College Board

name: Ancient Egypt  (Ancient Mediterranean: 3500 B.C.E.-300 C.E.)
blurb:
The art of dynastic Egypt embodies a sense of permanence. It was created for eternity in the service of a culture that focused on preserving a cycle of rebirth.

By permission, © 2013 The College Board

name: Ancient Greece (Ancient Mediterranean: 3500 B.C.E.-300 C.E.)
blurb:
The art of Ancient Greece and Rome is grounded in civic ideals and polytheism. Etruscan and Roman artists and architects accumulated and creatively adapted Greek objects and forms to create buildings and artworks that appealed to their tastes for eclecticism and historicism. Contextual information for ancient Greek and Roman art can be derived from contemporary literary, political, legal, and economic records as well as from archaeological excavations conducted from the mid-18th century onward. Etruscan art, by contrast, is illuminated primarily by modern archaeological record and by descriptions of contemporary external observers.

By permission, © 2013 The College Board

name: Ancient Etruria (Ancient Mediterranean: 3500 B.C.E.-300 C.E.)
blurb: (No description)

name: Ancient Rome (Ancient Mediterranean: 3500 B.C.E.-300 C.E.)
blurb: (No description)

name: Medieval Europe and the Islamic world (3-1 to 3-2) (Early Europe and colonial Americas: 200-1750 C.E.)
blurb:
Medieval artistic traditions include late antique, early Christian, Byzantine, Islamic, migratory, Carolingian*, Romanesque, and Gothic, named for their principal culture, religion, government, and/or artistic style. Continuities and exchanges between coexisting traditions in medieval Europe are evident in shared artistic forms, functions, and techniques. Contextual information comes primarily from literary, theological, and governmental (both secular and religious) records, which vary in quantity according to period and geographical region, and to a lesser extent from archaeological excavations. Elite religious and court cultures throughout the Middle Ages prioritized the study of theology, music, literary and poetic invention, and in the Islamic world, scientific and mathematical theory. Cultural and artistic exchanges were facilitated through trade and conquest.

By permission, © 2013 The College Board

name: Art of the Islamic World  (Early Europe and colonial Americas: 200-1750 C.E.)
blurb: (No description)

name: Renaissance Art in Europe (Early Europe and colonial Americas: 200-1750 C.E.)
blurb: (No description)

name: Protestant reformation and Catholic counter-reformation (3-5) (Early Europe and colonial Americas: 200-1750 C.E.)
blurb:
Production of religious imagery declined in northern Europe, and nonreligious genres, such as landscape, still life, genre, history, mythology, and portraiture, developed and flourished. In the south, there was an increase in the production of political propaganda, religious imagery, and pageantry, with the elaboration of naturalism, dynamic compositions, bold color schemes, and the affective power of images and constructed spaces. Production of religious imagery declined in northern Europe, and nonreligious genres, such as landscape, still life, genre, history, mythology, and portraiture, developed and flourished. In the south, there was an increase in the production of political propaganda, religious imagery, and pageantry, with the elaboration of naturalism, dynamic compositions, bold color schemes, and the affective power of images and constructed spaces.

By permission, © 2013 The College Board

name: colonial-americas (Early Europe and colonial Americas: 200-1750 C.E.)
blurb: (No description)

name: Enlightenment and Revolution (4-1) (Later Europe and Americas: 1750-1980 C.E.)
blurb:
The Enlightenment set the stage for this era. Scientific inquiry and empirical evidence were promoted in order to reveal and understand the physical world. Belief in knowledge and progress led to revolutions and a new emphasis on human rights. Subsequently, Romanticism offered a critique of Enlightenment principles and industrialization. Philosophies of Marx and Darwin impacted worldviews, followed by the work of Freud and Einstein. Later, postmodern theory influenced art making and the study of art. In addition, artists were affected by exposure to diverse cultures, largely as a result of colonialism. The advent of mass production supplied artists with ready images, which they were quick to appropriate.

By permission, © 2013 The College Board

name: Modernism (Later Europe and Americas: 1750-1980 C.E.)
blurb:
Diverse artists with a common dedication to innovation came to be discussed as the avant-garde. Subdivisions include Neoclassicism, Romanticism, Realism, Impressionism, Post-Impressionism, Symbolism, Expressionism, Cubism, Constructivism, Abstraction, Surrealism, Abstract Expressionism, Pop Art, performance art, and earth and environmental art. Many of these categories fall under the general heading of modernism.

© 2013 The College Board

name: Indigenous Americas (AP®︎ Art history)
blurb: Art of the Indigenous Americas is among the world’s oldest artistic traditions. While its roots lie in northern Asia, it developed independently between c. 10,000 B.C.E. and 1492 C.E., which marked the beginning of the European invasions. Regions and cultures are referred to as the Indigenous Americas to signal the priority of First Nations cultural traditions over those of the colonizing and migrant peoples that have progressively taken over the American continents for the last 500 years.

name: Africa: 1100-1980 C.E. (AP®︎ Art history)
blurb: Human life, which is understood to have begun in Africa, developed over millions of years and radiated beyond the continent of Africa. The earliest African art dates to 77,000 years ago. While interpretation of this art is conjectural at best, the clarity and strength of design and expression in the work is obvious.

name: West and central Asia: 500 B.C.E.-1980 C.E. (AP®︎ Art history)
blurb: The arts of West and Central Asia play a key role in the history of world art, giving form to the vast cultural interchanges that have occurred in these lands that link the European and Asian peoples.

name: India (South, East, and Southeast Asia: 300 B.C.E. - 1980 C.E.)
blurb: (No description)

name: China (South, East, and Southeast Asia: 300 B.C.E. - 1980 C.E.)
blurb: (No description)

name: Korea (South, East, and Southeast Asia: 300 B.C.E. - 1980 C.E.)
blurb: (No description)

name: Japan (South, East, and Southeast Asia: 300 B.C.E. - 1980 C.E.)
blurb: (No description)

name: Cambodia (South, East, and Southeast Asia: 300 B.C.E. - 1980 C.E.)
blurb: (No description)

name: Indonesia (South, East, and Southeast Asia: 300 B.C.E. - 1980 C.E.)
blurb: (No description)

name: The Pacific (content area 9) (AP®︎ Art history)
blurb: The arts of the Pacific vary by virtue of ecological situations, social structure, and impact of external influences, such as commerce, colonialism, and missionary activity. Created in a variety of media, Pacific arts are distinguished by the virtuosity with which materials are used and presented.

name: Global contemporary: 1980-present  (AP®︎ Art history)
blurb: Global contemporary art is characterized by a transcendence of traditional conceptions of art and is supported by technological developments and global awareness. Digital technology in particular provides increased access to imagery and contextual information about diverse artists and artworks throughout history and across the globe.

name: The Noun (Parts of speech: the noun)
blurb: Nouns are people, places, things, and ideas – let's dive into what that all means, and how to put nouns to their best use!
